PETITION.PRESENTERS: Calvert, Sen Paul; Cooney, Sen Barney; Ray, Sen Robert
PETITION.TITLE: Repatriation Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the Senate the fact that members of the Royal Australian Navy who served in Malaya between 1955 and 1960 are the only Australians to be deliberately excluded from eligibility for repatriation benefits in the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 (the Act) for honourable `active service'. Australian Archives records show that the only reason for the exclusion was to save money. Members of the Australian Army and Air Force serving in Malaya were not excluded, and the costs associated with the land forces was one of the main reasons for the exclusion of the Navy. An injustice was done which later events have compounded.

There are two forms of benefits for ex‐servicemen, Disability Pensions for war caused disabilities (denied the sailors referred to but introduced in 1972 for `Defence Service' within Australia) and Service Pensions. Allied veterans of 55 nations involved in conflicts with Australian forces until the end of the Vietnam War can have qualifying eligibility for Service Pensions under the Act. Service by 5 countries in Vietnam was recognised after RAN service in Malaya was excluded. The Department of Veterans' Affairs confirms that 686 ex‐members of the South Vietnamese Armed Forces are in receipt of Australian Service Pensions; 571 on married rate and 115 on single rate. In effect, 1,257 Service Pensions, denied to ex‐members of the RAN, are being paid for serving alongside Australians in Vietnam.
It is claimed that:

(a) Naval personnel were engaged on operational duties that applied to all other Australian service personnel serving overseas on `active service'. They bombarded enemy positions in Malaya and secretly intercepted enemy communications;

(b) Naval personnel were subject to similar dangers as all other Australian service personnel serving in Malaya and there were RAN casualties, none of which appear on the Roll of Honour at the Australian War Memorial;

(c) the Royal Australian Navy was `allotted' for operational service from 1st July 1955 and this is documented in Navy Office Minute No. 011448 of 11 November 1955, signed by the Secretary to the Department of the Navy. The RAN was then apparently `unallotted' secretly to enable the excluding legislation to be introduced;

(d) the Department of Veterans' Affairs has said it can find no written reason(s) for the RAN exclusion in the Act. In two independent Federal Court cases (Davis WA G130 of 1989 and Doessel Qld G62 of 1990) the courts found the two ex‐members of the RAN had been `allotted'. Davis had served in Malaya in 1956 and 57. As a result of these cases ex‐members of the RAN who served in Malaya and who had, at that time, claims before the Department of Veterans' Affairs for benefits, had their claims accepted. Eight weeks after the Doessel decision the Act was amended to require allotment to have been by written instrument. In parliament, it was claimed the amendment was necessary to restore the intended purpose of the exclusion, reasons for which can not, allegedly, be found.

(e) Naval personnel were not, as claimed, bound by the `Special Overseas Service' requirements, introduced in the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act 1962. This Act became law some two years after the war in Malaya ended;

(f) as Australian citizens serving with the Royal Australian Navy they complied with three of the four requirements for `active service'. The fourth, for `military occupation of a foreign country' did not apply to Malaya.

Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to remove the discriminatory exclusion in the Act thereby restoring justice and recognition of honourable `active service' with the Royal Australian Navy in direct support of British and Malayan forces during the Malayan Emergency between 1955 and 1960.

PETITION.TITLE: Repatriation Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The Petition of the undersigned shows that only one group have been excluded from eligibility for repatriation benefits in the Veterans Entitlements Act 1986 (the Act) where such group has performed honourable overseas `active service'. That group being members of the Royal Australian Navy who served in Malaya between 1955 and 1960 which were excluded under `Operational Service' at Section 6. (1)(e)(ii) of the Act.

The various claims made in Statements to the House and the Senate and the contents of correspondence from various Ministers to maintain the exclusion are answered as follows, the answers are from documents obtained under FIO and from public record:

(i) `They were never allotted for operational service', (contained in a letter from the Hon. Con Sciacca Minister for Defence Science and Personnel 1995). A letter from the Secretary Department of the Navy to Treasury dated 11 November 1955 stated `the date that the Navy were allotted for operational service was 1 July 1955'.

(ii) `Members of the RAN were only doing the duty for which they had enlisted', (October 1956 The Hon. Dr Cameron representing the Minister for Repatriation in the Senate). This applies to all Service personnel everywhere.

(iii) `They were in no danger', (November 1956 The Hon. Dr Cameron representing the Minister for Repatriation in the Senate). They shared the same danger as all other Australian Service personnel serving in Malaya at the time.

(iv) `They were not on Special Overseas Service', (in a letter from the office of The Hon. Bronwyn Bishop Minister for Defence Industry Science and Personnel to Mrs Williams of Adelaide dated October 1996). Requirement for Special Overseas Service was introduced in 1962 without retrospective conditions, therefore has no relevance to events of 1960.

(v) `They were not on Active Service', (in a letter from the office of The Hon. Bronwyn Bishop Minister for Defence Industry Science and Personnel dated October 1996). It is now, as it was then, that Service Personnel had to comply with one of three requirements for Active Service, this group complied with two, or twice as many as is needed. The one that they did not comply with was, `is in military occupation of a foreign country'.

Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate should remove the discriminatory exclusion in the Act, thereby giving the Australian sailors involved comparative recognition with the Army and RAAF personnel that served at the same time, and all other Australians who have served their Country on active service overseas.

PETITION.TITLE: Sexual Discrimination Bill 1995
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament, Assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully shows that the Sexual Discrimination Bill 1995 will promote homosexuality and attack the institution of marriage. Therefore your petitioners pray that the Senate disallow this Bill.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Labelling
PETITION.PARA: We the undersigned request the Australian Senate implements the following:
A Senate enquiry into the use of genetic engineering in the Australian Food Supply, including the ethics of its use.
That consultations be undertaken with the general public to ask if we want this technology in our food supply and consent to its use.
That consumers be resourced to attend these consultations.
Any food that is genetically engineered or contains components that are genetically engineered are required to be labelled, including the origin of the genes.
That meaningful right to know legislation be enacted to guarantee public access to toxicology data.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I wish to report two matters concerning the committee. In the Senate on 13 February 1997 Senator Short raised issues about the operation of the resolution providing for the declaration of senators' interests: firstly, what does a senator do who holds shares in a company without detailed knowledge of the company; secondly, what is a relevant interest that should be declared during a debate or a division; and, thirdly, should not the fact of a written declaration preclude the need for an oral declaration again during the debates or votes? During debate yesterday Senator Gibson also raised the issue of what is a material interest that should be declared in debate.

SPEECH.PARA: The committee considered the issues raised by Senator Short and wrote to him about them. The committee took the view, firstly, that senators should make reasonable efforts to find out the activities of companies in which they hold shares. Secondly, we considered that what constitutes a relevant or material interest is usually not difficult to determine. At the margin it is a matter for each senator to think carefully about the consequences of too narrow or unreasonable a view of relevance. Thirdly, the rule about oral declarations during debate or before votes should not be changed. This rule enables the Senate and the public to be informed during proceedings of any conflict of interest so that the conflict can be taken into account by all concerned at the relevant time, otherwise potential conflict declared in the register would not appear in the relevant Hansard record.

The committee endorsed the view of its predecessor committee that, although it can give some guidance, decisions on the appropriate interpretation of the resolution must be the responsibility of individual senators. It is for each individual senator to consider their responsibility for declaring or not declaring some personal, financial or other interest that might constitute a conflict of interest in relation to proceedings in which she or he participates in the Senate.

At the end of the day senators must be alive to the potential for conflicts of interest between their private interests and official responsibilities, and act in accordance with the spirit and intention of the Senate resolution. In such matters it may be best to err on the side of caution and make declarations. It is not a contempt of the Senate to have a conflict of interest. It could be a serious contempt to fail to declare one. I seek leave to table the letter and incorporate it in Hansard so that it is available for senators.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows—
18 March 1997
Senator the Hon Jim Short
Senator for Victoria
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
YOUR QUERY IN THE SENATE ABOUT ORAL DECLARATIONS OF INTERESTS

At its meeting on 18 March 1997 the Committee considered the remarks you made in the Senate on 13 February 1997 about aspects of the resolution concerning the declaration of senators' interests. You asked that the President refer the matter to the Committee. However, the Committee itself can respond to particular submissions and it decided it should do so to assist you and other senators.
You raised three specific points. First, what does a senator do who holds shares in a company without any detailed knowledge of its activities?

Secondly, the question of what is a "relevant" interest may be a difficult one: for example, in a debate or division on a company law bill or a superannuation bill does a senator holding shares have a "relevant" interest for the purposes of that debate or division?
Thirdly, in any event, should not a proper written declaration in the Register of Senators' Interests be sufficient for all future occasions where, currently, an oral declaration is required?

Against the background of these issues you invited the President to refer the operation of the resolution to the Committee for examination and report in light of the past three years of experience with the Register.

This broader question of a full review of the operation of the resolution is at this time perhaps more properly one for the Senate to consider. However, on the three specific issues you raise the Committee offers the following advice.

The essential purpose of the Register, and the procedures for oral declarations during Senate and committee proceedings, is to enable the Senate and the public to be aware of private interests that senators and, so far as their interests are known, their spouses and dependent children have which might conflict with their official responsibilities, so that those interests can be properly taken into account by all concerned each time a potential conflict might arise.

In general terms, the Committee considers that where a senator (including a spouse or child) has a financial or other real, personal, interest in a company, body, activity or place, and that interest or that company, body, activity or place could reasonably be advantaged by the outcome of a debate, division or committee inquiry, the senator should declare that interest in debate, prior to the division, or during the committee's proceedings, if the senator participates or votes.

Where a senator holds financial interests in a company it would be expected that a responsible senator would know of, or seek to find out, the activities of that company and be in a position to declare an interest in proceedings that might reasonably affect that company's activities to the senator's advantage.

The Senate's procedures ensure that on each occasion of debate, voting or committee participation senators declare the fact that they have a private interest which might be advantaged by a Senate process in which they take part. That fact can then be taken into account by all concerned.
The interest does not, of course, necessarily preclude the senator from participating—though on some rare occasions it might, in the senator's judgement, require his or her abstention.

In any event, the declaration of the interest in the midst of debate, while not removing the possibility of conflict, protects a senator from any insinuation that they have not been open about the position they are in and from which they enter the debate or the vote. Under the Senate resolution it is a serious contempt to fail to disclose a relevant interest; it is not a contempt simply to have such an interest.

At the time of passing the resolution (17 March 1994) it was clearly the Senate's intention that senators should orally declare relevant interests on every relevant occasion. Most relevant interests can be clearly identified by senators and understood by the community from the terms of the Senate resolution and the Explanatory Notes. On the margins, identification of a relevant interest that should be declared is a matter for the senator concerned. In the past, the committee has stressed the personal responsibility of individual senators in this regard. In its First Report (June 1994) the Committee stated:

". . . the Committee advises that while it may, from time to time, provide guidance on the interpretation of particular matters set out in the resolution, final decisions on the appropriate interpretation of the resolution must be the responsibility of individual Senators."
In the same vein, the Explanatory Note accompanying declaration forms states:
"No form can cover all possible circumstances and senators should consequently bear in mind the purpose and spirit of the return in deciding which matters should be registered."

The Committee takes the view that appropriate oral declarations should continue to be made in the Senate and in committees, as provided by the resolution. The committee also considers that, apart from the plain words of the resolution itself, the Explanatory Notes and any special guidance given in Committee reports, the question of the relevance of an interest is a matter for the senator's individual responsibility. Senators should err on the side of caution and make declarations if they wish to preserve "the purpose and spirit" of the procedure.

At the end of the day, senators must, at all times, be alive to the potential for conflict of interest between their private interests and their official responsibilities. When this potential manifests itself, the Senate and the public are entitled to be reminded of the senator's personal interests when that senator participates in Senate proceedings.
I hope this is helpful to you. The matter you have raised is important and I propose to table in the Senate a copy of this letter for the information of all senators.
Yours sincerely
KAY DENMAN
Chair

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee also considered whether the explanatory notes used by senators in making declarations should be amended in relation to shareholdings. This would clarify the requirements about declaring actual shareholdings held by family and business trusts, partnerships or nominee companies; thus, where a senator alone or with their family can exercise control over the voting rights or disposal of shareholdings, the actual shareholdings should be declared.

SPEECH.PARA: The committee has decided to amend the explanatory notes to remove the possibility of any misunderstandings about this. The House of Representatives has also decided to do this. I seek leave to both table and incorporate in Hansard a brief background paper on this matter.
Leave granted.
The background paper read as follows—
Notification of shareholdings held by family or business trusts, nominee companies or partnerships controlled by a senator and/or their spouse and/or a dependent child, or a majority of these three
Where a senator, spouse or dependent child is a trustee of a family or business trust holding shares he/she has a legal interest in the shares and is (usually) entitled to exercise control over them.
Where a senator, spouse or dependent child is a beneficiary of the trust, he/she has an equitable interest in the shares and is often entitled to exercise control over them.
Similarly, a nominee company or partnership which holds shares is controlled by a senator, spouse or dependent child if one or more of them owns the company or controls the partnership.
Control means power to exercise voting rights attached to the shares or power to dispose of the shares.

Where the senator and/or their spouse and/or their dependent child (or a majority of the three) can exercise such control, the actual shareholdings held by the trust, nominee company or partnership should be declared.

By implication, the Senate resolution of 17 March 1994 currently requires a declaration of such actual shareholdings rather than merely a declaration of the name, activity and beneficiary of the trust, nominee company or partnership.
This obligation is to be made explicit by an amendment to the Explanatory Notes stating what actual shares are to be declared:

Shareholdings in public and private companies etc: This includes shares held by a family or business trust, a nominee company or a partnership where a senator, the senator's spouse or dependent children (or two or more of the senator, the senator's spouse, or a dependent child or dependent children acting together) are able to exercise control over the right to vote or dispose of those shares.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present report No. 349 entitled Review of Auditor‐General's reports 1995-96 and report No. 350 entitled Review of Auditor-General's reports 1996-97: first quarter . I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the reports.
I seek leave to incorporate my tabling speech in Hansard .
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—
These are the first reports arising from the JCPA's new public hearing-based review procedures.

These two reports do not attempt to analyse in detail all of the audit findings and recommendations. Instead they draw attention to the key issues discussed at the hearings and highlight any commitments given by witnesses.

Having said that, may I turn now to Report 349, Review of the Auditor-General's Reports: 1995-96 . Three public hearings were held in order to take evidence on the 14 reports selected by the JCPA for closer scrutiny.

Among the reports listed is Audit Report No. 28, 1995-96, Jindalee Operational Radar Network (JORN) Project , Department of Defence. After considering the evidence taken in relation to Audit Report No. 28, on the JORN Project, the JCPA decided that the issues canvassed in the Audit Report warranted further examinations as part of a full and separate inquiry. The inquiry is currently still under way and will be reported separately, probably in the 1997 autumn sittings.
The terms of reference for the JCPA's JORN inquiry are:

As part of its statutory responsibilities to examine reports from the Auditor-General, the committee shall inquire into and report on Audit Report No. 28, 1995-96 Jindalee Operational Radar Network Project, Department of Defence (June 1996) and any circumstances connected with matters raised in the audit report.
The committee's inquiry will focus on:
(a) the management of the project by the Department of Defence; and
(b) the performance of Telstra Corporation Ltd in its capacity as the prime contractor for the
In regard to the remaining Audit Reports, further examination of the issues involved resulted in the six recommendations contained in Report 349.

I would draw particular attention to Recommendation 1, in which the JCPA seeks amendments to the Cabinet Handbook so that any potential liabilities to which the Commonwealth may be exposed as a result of action being recommended in a Cabinet Submission or discussed in a Cabinet Memorandum are clearly identified and costed.

This recommendation arose from the public hearing into Audit Report No. 14: The Sale of the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories (CSL) , when the committee discovered that the then Minister for Health had been provided with verbal briefings only prior to committing to the arrangements underpinning the sale of CSL Consequently the Commonwealth incurred an uncapped liability in relation to a number of potential claims.

The committee considers that it is totally unsatisfactory for departmental officials to enter into substantial agreements on behalf of the Commonwealth without written ministerial consent or approval. There needs to be an appropriate paper trail so that accountability and probity questions may be answered.

The JCPA is pleased that recently, the Department of Health and Family Services has been successfully investigating commercial insurance arrangements in relation to CSL indemnities. The committee supports such initiatives and considers that greater incentive and flexibility to consider risk retention and risk transfer in relation to the Commonwealth's exposures will result in greater accountability in public agencies.
JORN project.

In its third public hearing session for 1995-96 audit reports, the JCPA focused on the client services programs. Announcements made in the 1996-97 Budget impacted significantly on the programs and methods of service delivery which were the subject of the six audit reports being examined at that public hearing. The committee therefore decided to review the programs in the light of future changes so that the relevant departments and agencies take client service needs and accountability into consideration when implementing the budget changes.
One concern which emerged during this public hearing was the difficulty experienced by ANAO officers in gaining audit access to information from third party providers of client service programs.

Although the Auditor-General Bill 1996 which is currently before the parliament, provides the Auditor-General with unfettered powers to obtain any information required to fulfil audit functions, this power would be enhanced considerably if it were specifically referred to in contracts between the Commonwealth and third party providers.

Recommendation 6 in Report 349 therefore urges the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, when establishing contracts with private sector employment placement agencies, to include contract provisions which make explicit the Auditor-General's statutory authority to obtain information from third party service providers.

Madam President, it is clear that much work needs to be done by DEETYA and DSS (within a relatively short time frame) to ensure that integrated and contractually sound performance measurement and monitoring systems are in place for the introduction of the employment placement market. The committee believes it has played a part in ensuring that both departments are fully aware of the need to incorporate accountability requirements into the management arrangements they are drafting for the new programs.
Madam President, I now turn to the 1996-97 audit reports.

Two reports of the Auditor-General were the focus of the first quarterly public hearing for 1996-97. These were Audit Report No. 5, Accounting for Aid. The Management of funding to Non-Government Organisations and Audit Report No. 6, Commonwealth Guarantees, Indemnities and Letters of Comfort . Report 350 focuses on the main issues raised during the public hearings.

The JCPA notes the audit finding in Audit Report No. 5 that AusAID's regime for the management of funding to NGOs is generally of a high standard and that aspects of the management framework are at the leading edge of international best practice.
The committee is reassured by AusAID's advice that evaluation and audit activities will continue, as a check on the new performance reports to be provided by NGOs.

The JCPA awaits with interest the Simon's review of the overall priorities, objectives and focus of the Australian aid program and, in particular, the findings of the review in relation to the role of NGOs in the delivery of Australian aid.
The Report contains two recommendations for further action in relation to Audit Report No. 6, 1996-97, Commonwealth Guarantees, Indemnities and Letters of Comfort.

The recommendations in Audit Report No. 6 are designed to improve agency awareness and management. In order to encourage agencies to focus on a responsibility that most Chief Executive Officers have been neglecting, the JCPA recommends that the Department of Finance seek statements from agencies on the steps they have taken to address each relevant recommendation in Audit Report No 6.

The JCPA considers that the current state of reporting on liabilities is clearly deficient and recommends that full statements of off-balance sheet liabilities associated with guarantees, indemnities and letters of comfort should be a mandatory inclusion in annual financial statements of departments.

Madam President, I am confident that our new review and reporting procedures will result in more timely and effective parliamentary examination of audit reports and that this will be to the benefit of all parties involved: the Parliament, the ANAO and audited agencies. The JCPA looks forward to receiving the government's response to its reports.

May I conclude, Madam President, by thanking all those people who contributed their time and expertise to the JCPA's round of scrutiny hearings, held between July and October 1996, upon which these two reports are based. The JCPA has been appreciative of the full co-operation it has received from the people involved.
Madam President, I commend the reports to the Senate.
19 March 1997
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present report No. 351 entitled An advisory report on the Charter of Budget Honesty Bill 1996 . I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

I want to advise the Senate of the history of this report. In early 1995 the Joint Committee of Public Accounts decided to do an investi gation on fiscal responsibility legislation. I am proud of the fact that I was the initiator of that move. At the same time I managed to persuade Mr Costello and Mr Howard that the coalition should take on board fiscal responsibility legislation as a coalition policy which we called the charter for budget honesty.

This resulted from the excellent work done by the public accounts committee in 1995. I pay tribute to all members of that committee, particularly the chairman, Les Scott, for agreeing to take that on board. That investigation in 1995 meant that the departments of treasury and finance were able to do all their homework over several months in preparation for this work. When we came to government last year, the government was able to proceed forthwith with the charter of budget honesty. I am delighted to see that it is now progressing through the parliament. I seek leave to incorporate the rest of my speech.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

As honourable senators are aware, the Charter of Budget Honesty Bill was referred to the JCPA on 3 March 1996 for tabling today. As a consequence of this tight deadline, the committee held only one public hearing, taking evidence from the stakeholders in the public sector and from peak representative groups in the private sector. Those groups which were unable to attend managed to make submissions within our tight timetable.

The committee supports the framework outlined in the bill as it implements mechanisms for improving the accountability and transparency of government fiscal policy objectives, strategies and outcomes. The JCPA believes that the Charter of Budget Honesty Bill is another element in the improvement of the overall fiscal accountability framework. Transparency is the essence of such a framework and this bill legislates for the provision of regular published reports so that the public may be better informed.

During its review of the bill, the committee encountered widespread general support and very little criticism. However, there are several important aspects which I wish to draw parliament's attention.

While the committee applauds the requirement for the fiscal reports to be prepared in accordance with recognised external reporting standards, the committee believes firmly that the reasons for any deviations from those standards should be fully explained in the reports.
SCHEDULE 1—CLAUSES 12(4), 16(5) & 24(5)

Although the committee recognises the need to suppress information of a confidential commercial or national security nature, it believes that a statement, providing a general description of the information being suppressed and its aggregate amount should be included in the reports.
SCHEDULE 1- CLAUSES 13,17, 28 & 32

The committee is pleased that the fiscal reports being legislated by this bill provide an approximation of whole-of-government reporting. However, the above-named clauses enables Commonwealth agencies to withhold information. Where this occurs, then a statement, showing the effect of this omission and its aggregate amount should be included in the reports.
SCHEDULE 1- CLAUSE 22

The committee notes that a pre-election economic and fiscal outlook report is to be released within 10 days of the issues of the writ for a general election. Given that a writ can be delayed up to 10 days after the dissolution of parliament, the committee believes that it would be more sensible to have the pre-election reports released within 10 days of the dissolution of parliament.

My final point, Madam President, is to seek the government's agreement to including a review component in the schedule of the bill so that the full reporting process can be assessed after the next election.
I am confident that our report reflects the concerns of the parliament. The JCPA looks forward to receiving the government's response to Report 351.

Madam President, the JCPA has a proud history of co-operation among its members: very few of our inquiries have ever resulted in a dissenting report. I mention this because the l9th committee has excelled itself in completing this report within the tight time frame imposed on the committee. It has held a public hearing, received submissions, deliberated on the issues and produced the report I now table.

All of this was done within 16 days, Madam President:—16 days which included 2 state/territory public holidays and 2 weekends! I therefore wish to record my thanks to my fellow committee members for their willingness to rearrange busy schedules at short notice in order to participate in the review of this bill. Without them the committee could not have conducted the review.

May I conclude, Madam President, by thanking those people who contributed their time and expertise to the JCPA's public hearing, held on 13 March 1997, and those who sent in submissions. The JCPA has been appreciative of the full co-operation it has received from the people involved. In particular, I wish to record the committee's thanks to His Excellency, the New Zealand High Commissioner who very kindly provided the committee with a comprehensive overview of the changes to economic and fiscal reporting in New Zealand after the introduction of its Fiscal Responsibility Act in 1994. Without them the committee could not have conducted the review.

I would also like to thank Hansard who did a marvellous job getting the transcripts back to the committee in record time. Without these the committee's report drafting would have been much more difficult.
Madam President, I commend Report 351 to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TELECOMMUNICATIONS BILL 1996

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering the Telecommunications Bill as a whole and the Greens (WA) amendments 1 to 3. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night when discussing my amendment we found out that each time a question was asked we went in a larger and larger circle, or perhaps a tighter and tighter circle. Then the circle went off in many different directions. Rather than clarifying the situation, we found that the problems had multiplied. There were problems of understanding and definition. There were problems associated with consumers understanding their current situation and future situation—a situation which seems like a nightmare. I think the administrative aspects for networks and governments handling the kinds of issues that are going to come up are going to be a nightmare.

SPEECH.PARA: Basically, what I have asked for in my amendment is that we clarify the situation and take it back to where the network boundary is at the plug then, if it is necessary, over the next couple of years renegotiate that. If there seems to be a commercial necessity, then that is possible. The indications from last night's debate are that certainly there are so many problems, so many issues, associated with the change that we might not be acting responsibly as a Senate if we allowed it to go in that direction without any further clarification of the implications.

There is still not sufficient explanation given as to why consumers—and I think they are the important ones—do not have more availability of competition. I have spoken here on a number of occasions that competition itself does not bring the benefit, but it does have some actual benefits. The benefits have to include being able to understand what is being done, who is responsible and being able to get an answer from somebody or get the lines fixed if something goes wrong. The indication from last night's debate is that the benefits to the consumers may well be far less than the complications and uncertainties that this move to change the status quo will entail.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate committee never dealt at any length with this amendment. There were some major submissions in this area. Certainly, the CEPU I think, as Senator Margetts has said, have some concern about this but it never became a major issue at the Senate committee. At the Senate committee we only dealt with issues about which major submissions were made and debate amongst various players, so to speak, was available. I certainly have always stuck to the view that the committee was dealing with major issues raised by the community and by organisations. I certainly accept that this is now an issue in the debate which has arisen as a result of the Greens amendment. In the discussion we had last night there are now a number of issues that do create some concern for the opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Last night, towards the end of the discussion, you, Minister, made a couple of comments which I hope you might be able to clarify. One is that you said that, in effect, when a line comes into the box in a multiple residential building that is already operating, implying that the legislation that is now before us to change the definition was catching up on the practice. That is the way I would interpret it. If that is the case, does that mean that the existing legislation which is being amended was being ignored or was out of date or did it allow that to occur? If it did, why do we need to change it in the definition?

Secondly, last night we asked questions about changing the definition of a network from the socket inside in a normal house back to the outside of the building. We asked who owned the cable, now laid by Telstra in 99.9 per cent of cases. Was that an asset of Telstra that suddenly, by expropriation, was handed over to somebody else; namely, the con sumer? You replied that, if it were a normal telephony line, Telstra would still own it and they would lease it to the person who wanted to change their carrier.

My view is that if Telstra are to lease it—and that means they are not the carrier providing the actual service—why should there be any need to change the definition of the boundary? If Telstra are leasing it to another carrier under some commercial arrangement for the operation of the service, I cannot see why there should be any change to the definition. The further issue you mentioned was that, with the development of new on-line services, carriers may have to put new cabling in to provide the capacity for the expanded on-line service that the present copper wire pair cannot provide. But that is an additional service; it is not the standard service of telephony. We are obviously changing over the years—and I am one who wants to change and expand the definition of the standard telephone service to include, as we debated yesterday or the day before, digital data capability. But that is an additional service, so if any carrier wants to go in and negotiate to put an extra line in for on-line services that is not the standard guarantee of a telephony service, which is in the existing legislation and in this legislation.

If carriers want to get an agreement to wire the building and put that extra line in, that socket is in the network for the standard telephone service that we are talking about. If Telstra maintains the ownership of the cable, irrespective of who the carrier is, and has to make arrangements for leasing, I still see that as the existing definition of the socket.

I accept these examples are in quicksand, and I accept that there is always going to be difficulty in being absolutely correct in answering every example we are trying to raise. Minister, the issue is not so much that of supporting the Greens amendment but of maintaining the existing definition of the socket, which is on page 10 and 11 of the Telecommunications Act 1991, until we get more practical experience of how this is going to operate in this area in the deregulated model.

BREAK.PARA: It seems to me that you are not deregulating; you are not changing the cable that is already there, which is overwhelmingly Telstra's. You are saying that it looks like they are going to lease it to another carrier to provide the subscription. You are not handing the ownership of that cable over to another carrier and/or to the building or to the consumer, whether it is a single consumer or a number of consumers in a strata title building or tenement and so on.

Subject to your answers, I believe there is a good case for saying that we ought to stick to the present definition and look at it with a review from the ACA in, say, 12 to 18 months to see how this is evolving. I am a bit afraid that we may accidentally throw the baby out with the bathwater and that, in particular, consumers will be left in a more difficult position as to knowing what their rights are and how they can have things dealt with.

In the end, I am not opposed to changing boundary networks—I think one should have an open mind about that to make sure consumers get the best growth of services—but it seems to me that what we are dealing with here is not the provision of on-line services, because that is going to need in most cases new cabling to be put in. What we are dealing with here is who owns the standard cable copper pair that provides the standard telephone service under this new network arrangement. I strongly oppose—I am sure you would—Telstra taking a hit in the neck as a result of saying that the asset they had suddenly disappears or is handed over by accident to either a consumer in ownership or another carrier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason this has not been a contentious issue and was not discussed at any length in the Senate committee hearings is that this has been around for years. You say that we should adjourn it to enable the ACA to have a good look at it, but you have a report from Austel of September 1993 in effect saying that the use of the first telephone socket as the network boundary, network termination point in the residential sector has the effect of restricting competition and disadvantaging some customers.
—Some customers and carriers, or just customers?

—Customers, because they end up paying more than they need to pay. The carriers are not opposed to this. So this idea of expropriating Telstra's assets is a furphy. Firstly, they do not lose their asset. As the situation works at the moment, the only way preselection applies to the point where you would use the existing line is for long distance and international, because you do not have preselection on local calls. To the extent that you wanted to use that existing line and be an Optus subscriber you would preselect, and Optus has an arrangement with Telstra which enables them to use the existing line.

SPEECH.PARA: But for new services, if you wanted Optus local calls then in the overwhelming majority of cases you would get those through Optus installing a new line. Optus would need to then come into the house and build a separate and distinct line. In most instances, again, that would provide you with the whole suite. In other words, it would be pay TV and broadband as well as local. But even if it were just local, they want to break away from having to pay the interconnect fee to Telstra, so they would have their own separate line.

Of course, the Greens are implacably opposed to any concept of competition, but there is no doubt that this would be of particular benefit in the construction of new premises. At the moment, builders are required to use Telstra to install the cabling right up to the wall socket. If they are allowed to have the network boundary at the wall of the premises, then they can tender it out to whoever they like in the same way that with electricity services you just look up an electrician in the pink pages and away you go. There are already cabling contractors out there who will do this. It is simply a means of making it a competitive market.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is competitive on installation.

—Yes, that is on installation—and, indeed, on maintenance in a separate way. The wall socket is currently the network boundary point for single occupier premises—residential homes. For multi‐occupier residences—apartments, flats, housing commissions and the like—it is actually the mainframe distribution point, which I think we said yesterday is usually in the basement. What the Greens would like to do is actually change that, regress to the point where it becomes the wall socket. You would then have an obligation imposed on the carrier to provide that service on a monopoly basis right through to the wall socket. That is fundamentally anti-competitive and would be very disruptive of existing arrangements.

SPEECH.PARA: I heard Senator Margetts mouth something about `if it appears to be more commercially attractive in a few years time', but the fact is that it is more commercially attractive right now. That is why there is such unanimity in the industry and elsewhere—including amongst consumer groups, who have all participated in these discussions over a number of years.

The location of the network boundary has been subject to extensive public consultation, including several times on draft regulations under the current act. While the first socket was a workable interim solution, the telecommunications industry in general has now agreed that the building entry point is the best location, and recent consultation has focused on this definition. Having the boundary at the building entry point will not only increase choice for customers; it will also facilitate greater competition in the provision of cabling services, which will operate to the benefit of the majority of cabling providers, including the majority of CEPU cabling provider members.

I probably do not need to spell it out for most members in the chamber, but the benefit of having greater competition in the provision of cabling services is that you will then have an incentive to provide better service, better quality, lower prices. So that is why there is a very clear benefit to consumers. If you simply have a monopoly regime up to the wall socket, then no-one knows what the true cost of the service is. Telstra is able to effectively disguise it within the monthly rental charge and it can be quite out of line with the true cost of the service.

For example, if it cost you $56 to make that repair call and you were charging a dollar a week, built into your monthly rental call as a carrier, you would be laughing all the way to the bank because in 99 per cent of situations there would never be a need to even have your Telstra tradesperson go out and attend to the call. So for the odd occasion when it might cost you something like $50 you are getting a dollar a month from every consumer in the country who is a subscriber to Telstra. So Telstra is making a very substantial profit on this arrangement.

They are not complaining but they would like it to be more competitive because that enables them to get prices down and it improves the work practices by enabling independent contractors and cabling providers to offer their services. That is why you are seeing a number of cable contractors springing up around the country. No doubt there will be a lot more if we continue down this path.

Regulations may be made so that the boundary in any particular case may be moved in either direction, back towards the core network or further into the customer's building, by agreement between the customer and a carrier or carriage service provider. There are very significant benefits at all levels of installation and maintenance, both for residential consumers and for building contractors. Of course, the prices they have to pay are reflected in the cost they pass on to purchasers and, ultimately, consumers of telecommunications services.

There are, I think, a number of ways in which this benefits the industry, and the very fact, as I say, that it has been quite uncontentious tells you a great deal about the efficacy of these arrangements. Apart from a few marginal interests—they have not been in any way evident in the debate to date, so I am not sure who the Greens are reflecting in this—the fact is that industry, consumer groups, carriers, everyone else in the debate, have canvassed these issues over a number of years and that is why it is no longer a contentious issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —During this debate the minister first of all used the word `unanimity', which in my dictionary means that everyone agrees. Then he said `Apart from a few marginal interests. . . '. You cannot use both words. There is either unanimity or—
—I meant you.

—Oh, I am the `few marginal interests!' Right. Now I would like to know whether the minister has yet received any of the same contacts that our office has received which indicate that, whilst the process of getting a number of groups to the table in relation to the inquiry might have had some good effects for some of the issues involved with telecommunications, there has actually been, from what we can see, a considerable amount of concern about the process by which this set of bills was discussed. I am getting representations—and I don't know why they are not contacting the minister—from a number of people who are very unhappy about the process. People found that they had very little time to prepare their submissions and they felt that their ability to deal with such details was limited. They are now saying that they were not able to say the things they felt during the process which took place.

SPEECH.PARA: The minister is shaking his head but I just wonder, when he refers to unanimity among consumer groups, whether he would like to reconsider that statement to the Senate. Either those people who are concerned are not writing to the minister or he has not come clean and told us whether those concerns have been expressed to his office as well as to ours. Why would they only contact us and not the minister's office?

TALK.START.PARA: —Who are we talking about? What consumer groups have contacted you and expressed concern?

—My question to you, Minister, is: have there been contacts to your office showing concern about the process and indicating that these kinds of issues were very difficult to deal with under the process that was put forward, because of the lack of time and because the groups were told they had to come up with amendments? The groups were told they had to come to the process with proposed amendments. The average consumer group, especially if it is underfunded, does not necessarily have a parliamentary draftsperson, or person with that ability, so people found it very difficult. If you have had no contacts at all, fine. Perhaps it is just our office. I will check with my office and ask them to give a list of the types of people and the groups who are concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I would like you to reconsider that term—`unanimity among consumer groups'. If you are standing by that, fine. Perhaps I will come back later and tell you which groups, apart from a few marginal Greens, are concerned about the process. I don't think we can brush people off. Even if just one group has expressed concern, there is certainly not unanimity. I believe it has been the case during the whole Telstra debate that the people who are quite underresourced as consumer advocates—not necessarily the big commercial players—find it very difficult to participate in the process in the way that suits governments and sometimes in the way that suits major parties. I would like the minister to reconsider whether he is representing the interests of industry only or indeed representing unanimity among consumer groups. Let us include community groups in that category, because they are consumers as well. Are you standing by your term `unanimity'?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me put it this way: there are a number of consumer groups with a particular interest in telecommunications issues. There are a number of other community groups, as you call them, who also keep a close watch on these issues from the consumer perspective. That meant that very many submissions were addressed to the Senate inquiry, which as you know went for a number of days. People had opportunity to put in submissions, and consumer groups did. They addressed a vast range of issues—some of them with a great deal of enthusiasm—and covered all the areas that were of concern to them. My information is that no consumer groups expressed concerns about this issue. For example—

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Margetts interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not, and the department is not aware of that. The note I have got, for example, says that the default boundary has been the subject of extensive consultation by Austel, including with CTN. CTN would probably be more likely to have a view on this issue than perhaps the ACA—I do not know. But the fact remains that I exhibited a mild level of frustration because it seems to me and to the government that this is a non‐contentious issue. That is why I asked you who is expressing those concerns. Apparently you do not know and you will go back and find out. But that is not what has occurred.

BREAK.PARA: I think it is quite unrealistic of you to say that because consumer organisations have unlimited resources they were not able to make a submission on this issue. The fact is they were able to make submissions on every issue in the bill—and they did. They addressed the issues that were of concern to them and they did not comment on this one. That is because this issue has been kicked around over the years, and it has reached the point now where it is the conventional wisdom. We are not representing carriers' interests here. In many respects I think Telstra would have been torn, particularly if it were driven by some of those vested interests who did not have a particular interest in getting the cost structures down. But we have reached the point now where everyone acknowledges the virtues of competition within that cabling process.

You will hopefully get to the point in the electricity industry where you simply call in a tradesman, an electrician, as a matter of course to do the job in the house. You do not call in the electricity company because their functions are quite separate and different. I would be prepared to say, and I am saying it for your benefit as well, that we would be prepared to introduce guidelines that would enable consumer choice. If the people who have been in touch with Senator Margetts would like the wall socket to remain their network boundary point and are not particularly interested in the competitive benefits that might flow from what everyone else in the industry seems to think is a good idea, then we could allow them to have their—

TALK.START.PARA: —And that would be in the—
—That would be in regulations that would be prescribed under—
—It would be in prescribed regulations?
—Yes, it would be done under the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I think what we have heard today is quite a serious flaw on behalf of the minister. After talking about unanimity and after talking about the fact that it might just be someone who has contacted a few marginal interests, meaning me, the minister actually mentioned the Consumer Telecommunications Network. The reason this is serious is that in the meantime my office rang through and said the very first issue in the submission by the Consumer Telecommunications Network is—guess what?—network boundaries!
—I thought you told me they didn't have the time or the resources to address this issue at the Senate inquiry?

—How dare you! Through you, Mr Chair, this chamber deserves an apology. If you are going to stand there and say it was unanimity whilst the very group you mentioned put it as their first issue in their submission, you have misled the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: I would also like to point out that my amendments do allow that choice for consumers, but they provide that certainty for those in the difficult position, having paid all that rent up to now, of finding that they are still responsible for the maintenance of that line which they have paid rent on for a long time. Our amendments try to give that certainty, but they also give that flexibility for those who want to make their own arrangements. I will await your apology to the Senate, Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to add to the list of those who agreed with CTN a couple of other submitters to the inquiry: the Communications, Electrical and Plumbing Union and the ACA. Each of those groups mentioned this issue and their concerns about consumers not receiving any sort of compensatory reduction in installation costs or charges.

—I have been listening to the debate on this matter since the day before yesterday when this particular amendment was put. I take the view that, irrespective of whether a matter has been raised by any group, if the matter is brought forward by an honourable senator it ought to be considered on its merits. I have been trying to do that in listening to the arguments and discussions. I do not want to delay this matter, but I think a valid point has been made by Senator Margetts in relation to her point about a community group or community groups. I think she may have been sidetracked a little bit by the comments of Senator Schacht when he mentioned during the committee consideration of the matter that the matter was not of burning importance. Nevertheless, it is a burning consideration right here and now. I suppose the sooner we get the matter to the vote after final explanations by Senator Alston the better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Harradine is perfectly correct in saying that the merits of the argument ought to be addressed. Certainly, that has been our concern, and that is why this issue has been debated over recent years and why there have been innumerable opportunities for people to express comments and concerns.

SPEECH.PARA: As I understood, Senator Margetts started off by saying that the reason why these people did not put in submissions on the issue was that they did not have time to do it. The fact is that all of the main consumer groups did make submissions to the Senate inquiry and all of them addressed a whole range of issues. As I understand it, the submission from CTN said that it remains unclear exactly how the network boundary will impact on residential consumers. I suppose you can always say that. You can never predict the future precisely, so it does not seem to me that that necessarily raises any particular—

TALK.START.PARA: —You said they didn't raise the issue.

—I did not say that they did not raise the issue at all. You were the one who was saying that it had not been canvassed in the committee because they had not had time to get around to it. But, in any event, can we rise above that. I am simply saying that part of their submission was that they had been unable to obtain an assurance that consumers will have to take on greater expense. Once again, they were not raising anything by way of concrete expressions of concern about particular aspects, but simply making general statements which are obviously part and parcel of the debate but which are pretty general in the scheme of things. What I would suggest is an amendment—if the opposition is interested in pursuing an amendment—that would allow customers to have a consumer choice rather than simply knocking the whole thing off and, in many respects, going backwards, because that is what Senator Margetts wants to do in relation to multi‐occupied premises. The current arrangements are that the—
—It still allows choice for those people who want it.

—No, it does not. You want to move the network boundary for apartments and units and housing commissions back from the mainframe distribution point to the wall socket. You want to go backwards, in effect. I would be prepared to stand the matter down so that we could have some further discussions on what might constitute an effective choice regime, unless you are happy to proceed on the basis that I undertake there will be regulations to that effect—but I am just as happy to explore it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, this morning we have some more precise information from you that, for the opposition, has assuaged some of the concerns we raised in the quicksand of the discussion last night about who owned the cable and those sorts of issues. Those issues have now been clarified. If Telstra has put it in to the socket, it is their property and, if they want to sublease it to someone else, that is their decision. Now that I have got that clear, that is one issue.

SPEECH.PARA: The next issue you have clarified is this. I have had a chance overnight to look at the act. It is very true that, under the existing act, on page 10, in section 6, it says:
6. (1) An end facility is:
(a) a main distribution frame; or
(b) a telephone socket.

So, clearly, Senator Margetts is correct in that, since 1991—you may argue whether that was a correct decision anyway—this act came in for multiple strata title buildings and multiple tenanted buildings where the mainframe somewhere in the basement was the end system. That is what the minister is continuing with in the draft. I do not think it is possible to go back and say that the socket, anywhere in a strata title building of 150 apartments, now goes back to being the end of the network. I think if it has been there since 1991—I have to say, in a Labor government piece of legislation—it would be a bit hypocritical to say that you have got to go back and change the network. But it does come down to the telephone socket, which is clearly, for the individual consumer in Adelaide Torrens title houses, I suppose, where there is concern.

The minister quite rightly has put his finger on the fact that a lot of consumers in Australia are not great devotees of the theory of competition policy as we would argue it here in the parliament. They just want the telephone system to work. They want to know that, if there is a fault, they can get it fixed without a frustrating series of phone calls. I also have to say that, over the last six or seven years, because of the significant improvement in Telstra's service performance, people are now, by and large, much happier. Even though it could be argued that, in competition, the price of the local telephone call could be at 20c rather than 25c, I think ordinary Australian consumers have been delighted that it has not gone up for what is now nearly a decade, because of the price capping and the arrangements and the pressure parliament has put on.

Consumers will also see that obviously, by not increasing the cost, even by inflation, the local telephone call has got cheaper in Australia. That is good for consumers. The argument of the aficionados may be that, with the full infrastructure competition that Optus is supposedly providing with their cable roll out, prices could get down to 18c, 19c or 20c. Maybe. But I think consumers want to balance the convenience of knowing that, if something goes wrong, the process of getting it fixed can be undertaken by just one phone call. I think that really is important and they are balancing that.

Minister, I am more than happy for you to adjourn this discussion. If you want to put in an amendment about consumer choice, I would say that that would, I think—along with the answers you have already given—assuage most of the concerns that we were raising last night. The opposition is happy to have this item adjourned while an appropriate amendment is drafted by the minister's advisers to go into the bill. I think that would be useful. I cannot speak for other parties, but that would be a reasonable compromise. Certainly, on the basis of the opposition's involvement in the process of the committee stage of this bill, I think that would be a useful compromise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to add a few points to Senator Schacht's comments about this issue. I would like to raise two issues. Firstly, the 1991 definition, obviously, as we have heard, did specify that mainframe connection point or point of entry. The new definition tightens it up, but there is no doubt that the old definition excluded that two socket in those large structures.

SPEECH.PARA: There is something else that we also need to consider, and I would ask you, Minister, to make a comment on this. I believe that we are now moving into a totally different context because we are introducing a new deregulatory regime. What impact does that have upon the regulations as they were? For what purpose is it necessary to redefine yet again exactly what that building entry point is? By virtue of the fact that it was in the previous act, in your amendments you are attempting to redefine it yet again. If we are looking at a logical flow and things not changing too dramatically, why is it being redefined? Also, what is different about the deregulatory regime that might be the motivation for redefining that entry point definition?

There is one other thing I would ask you respond to, Minister. Given that we have already established the ownership of that last few feet or metres, or however long it is—I will have to describe a hypothetical situation here—if you have a carrier who provides a cable to a point of entry under your proposed definition and that carrier, to provide the service required by the consumer, also installs additional line from that point of entry to the socket, to get the bandwidth or whatever, under the act, because the network is only limited to that point of entry, does that affect the universal service obligation of the carrier to provide maintenance to that subsequent section of line? How does that definition of point of entry affect the maintenance and upkeep of the line from that point to the socket, both with respect to the USO and generally?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —The first point you raised was: how will the new regime vary from the old? In practice, having moved in 1991 to the mainframe distribution point, that will effectively remain the boundary point for those premises. It will change, however, for new constructions. Where builders are installing cabling inside the building, they will have the opportunity from the network boundary being the building entry point to then, in effect, get competitive bids to see who—
—That's for any sort of building—a single house or multi-occupancy?

—Yes, that is true; it is not just for multi-occupied. I suppose the point really is that where there are big buildings—many units, apartments and the like—there is much more opportunity because there is a lot more cost involved in actually putting the telephone lines into each flat. The builder will then have the opportunity to get competitive tenders rather than having to take the single carrier right up to the wall socket. So it will make quite a difference at that point.

SPEECH.PARA: It will also make a difference to consumers in that they will have the opportunity to choose whether they simply stay with the carrier that they subscribe to, and those carriers would accept responsibility for maintenance either on a bundled or unbundled basis, or they could opt to take responsibility themselves. That is why the idea of allowing them the choice is ultimately the way to go. You might choose to self-insure on the basis that, if the worst came to the worst and you did have to call in a tradesman, it may cost you $50. The chances of that happening are very remote in most residential homes. On the other hand, you might want to take out insurance with your carrier or with a local tradesman.

TALK.START.PARA: —When was the last tradesman you got for $50?
—That is what Telstra was agreeing to do at one stage. They were guaranteeing that if you did not pay the monthly rental fee—
—When was the last private tradesperson you got in for $50?
—Let us put it this way: if Telstra was prepared to do it for $56, no tradesman would be in business unless he could beat that fee.
—After‐hours, weekends, holidays!
—That is a matter of choice. It depends on when you want it done.
—Sure, whether you have a phone on or not.
—You do not want me to tell you my story about Telstra and my telephone, where they refused to come and fix it at weekends.

SPEECH.PARA: I will finish responding to Senator Lundy's other question about whether it would affect the USO—

TALK.START.PARA: —And who would provide the actual maintenance on that line, given that it is technically outside the description of what is the carrier's—

—The USO obligation is to provide the services to the premises—in other words, it guarantees that you get a telephone service. So it would not matter where the network termination point was; there would be an obligation one way or another and that would be cross‐subsidised out of the fund. One way or another, the universal service provider accepts the obligation to ensure that you get a functioning telephone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, I have a question on this issue of maintenance. In looking at your drafting of these amendments, I think there would be a lot of concern with the fact that, whichever carrier the resident or subscriber chooses, that automatically means that unless they decide otherwise that carrier is responsible for the maintenance through to that unit or to the house. So it means that, if something goes wrong with the phone and the consumer is a subscriber to Optus, they ring Optus and Optus has to take on the job of checking that the phone line through the system into the unit to what is still called the socket is actually being covered.

SPEECH.PARA: If the consumer can make an arrangement when they take on a carrier, whichever one it is—and they are changing carriers for commercial reasons and better price—that automatically means that, unless they agree to reach a separate arrangement with the particular consumer, that carrier takes on the obligation, in accepting the provision of the service, to fix it up if it breaks down. If they want to go and use a subcontractor or make arrangements with the landlord, that is their business.

What I am really after is that the consumers know that, if they make one phone call, they are not going to be switched backwards and forwards between the landlord, the electrical contractor and the carrier. So the subscriber needs to know who the carrier is for that line. If it is Telstra who has leased it out to Optus, if there is a change, Optus takes on the responsibility to get the line fixed through to the socket. If you can put that into the amendment, I think that will cover a lot of consumer concern. People will know where to ring to get that fixed. I just wondered whether the minister could respond to that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take that on board.
—I am going to suggest to the committee that either Senator Margetts's amendments be put or they be postponed, because at the moment the question before the chair is that the amendments be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —There are just three points I want to quickly make. Firstly, I draw the attention of the Senate to our amendments Nos 3 through to 6, which we were going to withdraw on the basis that we were happy with the Greens' amendments. However, one advantage with our amendments is that they, in fact, deal with this question of main distribution frame and/or telephone sockets, so that is spelt out there. So it could be that we would perhaps substitute these amendments for the Greens' amendments and that would solve the problem.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, I indicate that the Democrats would support an arrangement whereby consumers were protected. I think that this uncertainty has to do with understanding whether people who remain Telstra customers would be required to enter into some sort of maintenance agreement with them. I think that is the basis of the concerns.

Thirdly, I want to draw quickly on the submission made by the CEPU. The Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) talks about this opening up competition for new buildings. The CEPU said that communications installation industries have grown rapidly since liberalisations of 1989. A recent survey suggested there are now more than 10,000 businesses carrying out such installation work, and work in domestic premises is on the increase.

Similarly, there has been an increase in the number of Austel cabling licences over the period—most of which would appear to be from the non-carrier sector. In Telstra, employees now account for only about one-third of the 34,000 licence holders. So, Minister, I suggest to you that these figures do not suggest that this sector of the industry has been in any way constrained in terms of competition by the current regulations.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply say that I think Senator Allison is making the point that competition is actually working very well. That is why I think unions like the CEPU are much less unenthusiastic about these sorts of changes than they might have been a few years ago. They are recognising that cabling licensers and cablers are springing up all over the place, that the system is working effectively and it is providing choice.

BREAK.PARA: The problem with the Democrats' amendment is that under the current regime—I acknowledge the point that it does not go where the Greens would want to go in terms of taking the point from the MDF back to the wall socket—it does remove the regulation making power which contains a number of discretions to deal with particular situations and would impose a very rigid formula. At the end of the day I have no doubt that we would oppose both of those series of amendments. Therefore, we ask that the chamber agree on the voices, that we delay further consideration of both sets of amendments until a later hour this day.
Amendments 1 to 3 postponed.

TALK.START.PARA: —These are the result of the representations made by the ABC; is that correct? As I mentioned the other day—

The ABC sent me a note four days ago, I think it was, saying that they were still a little concerned—I do not know whether they were being a bit too precious or a bit too pedantic—that what we were proposing still did not quite cover everything that they were concerned about, that somehow or other there still might be a way in which the ABA and/or the communications authority might have some regulatory control over them. Have those latest representations been dealt with and is the minister satisfied that there is no accidental catching of the ABC in these changes?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, they still have some residual concerns, but from our point of view we have done our best to accommodate them. As I understand it, this is all designed to absolutely ensure that they are not caught up as carriers when they are broadcasters.

—Yes, I know. Minister, I am not going to ask for another amendment, because I want to keep the thing proceeding. TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously, everybody would like the opportunity to be able to read the amendment we have just received to see what the implications are. I do not actually see the word `infrastructure' in it so I guess I would need to look at that amendment more clearly.

If I may just take the time to explain our amendments. Amendment 4 refers to the public interest test that is used by the Australian Communications Authority when considering industry codes. It replaces the current narrow definition with a broader one. This amendment will broaden the definition of public interest which must be considered by the Australian Communications Authority when considering industry codes. Currently, the only explicit definition is `(d) the public interest in having competition in markets'. People have heard me express concern about that very narrow definition. It is inadequate.

The telecommunication service is an extremely important one for all Australians. For the elderly and infirm, it can also be a critical service for their safety and wellbeing. Public interest must be the overriding consideration in determining codes of practice for industry.

Our amendment 5 is to extend the definition of the universal service area to cover non‐geographically defined loss‐making services that constitute a public benefit. This was supported by the standard telephone service review. What this means is that a designated service area could include things such as individual pay phones. As an example, a pay phone in a disadvantaged area of Sydney may operate at a loss, but be heavily relied upon by local residents who might not otherwise be able to afford a telephone service in their homes. As such, it should be declared a universal service area.

As I have only just got this amendment, which has lobbed on the desk now, I would again ask if we might adjourn consideration of my two amendments so that we and the other members of the Senate can compare, contrast and see if the amendment I have just received meets our concern. I move:
That consideration of Greens (WA) amendments 4 and 5 be adjourned to a later hour of the day.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, does your amendment, which has just been circulated, deal only with the replacement of Greens amendment 4, and you oppose Greens amendment 5?

We can consider this amendment now. Amendment 5, as I suggested, indicates that, as stated in the standard telephone service review, there are potential designated service areas, which could—and we believe should—extend the definition of a universal service area, which is not just about geographic disadvantage but also about the public benefit in having access to a telephone service even if the service itself may not be a profit‐bearing one.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
