SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government takes the view that the USO was originally, and I think it is still, designed to enable net cost areas—in other words, areas where it would otherwise be commercially unaffordable to provide services—to receive services and products. They are effectively cross‐subsidised from other geographic areas where it is very commercially profitable to provide those services. So it has also always been done on a geographic basis.

SPEECH.PARA: The act does currently allow for a calculation in respect of services or products to be done within particular geographic areas. Part of our wider approach, particularly in terms of making the whole system more flexible and enabling more than one universal service provider to provide these services, is that you need to do it on a geographic basis. Otherwise, if you do it on a national basis—or as you would put it, without regard to geographic area—you will simply ensure that there is only one universal service provider.

We think that your concerns about calculations relating to services and products are already met. What you are really trying to achieve is to do away with the notion that you might have a range of different universal service providers between different geographic areas. If you remove that geographic nexus, you will simply not be able to have that sort of competition. If you want to cost losses on a service or product‐line basis, you still need to be able to do so within a geographic framework and that is really why the service area concept is provided for in the legislation. That allows product‐line costing for a particular service, but you might also want to have multiple providers serving different geographic service areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that amendment 5 be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support these government amendments because we believe they increase the scope for consumer and public consultation in the development of industry codes of practice. In our minority report to the telecommunications bills inquiry we detailed a range of concerns about the effectiveness or ineffectiveness, as it may be, of a self-regulatory approach to consumer protection based on codes of practice. Our concern, which we share with consumer organisations such as CTN and the ACA, is that adequate consumer and public input is essential if such codes are to fulfil their intended purpose. Self-regulation will gain public confidence only if inclusiveness of consumer perspectives is assured. We recommend that greater public consultation and consumer representation involvement be given in developing draft codes.

SPEECH.PARA: So we welcome these amendments. I note, however, that the Greens' amendments 6 to 8, which are yet to be moved, will improve upon those amendments of the government and we will be supporting them as well. Finally, we are also pleased that the government has at least acknowledged some of our concerns about the handling of privacy matters in codes of practice. The Democrats pointed out in the minority report that it was not appropriate in certain instances for privacy concerns to be dealt with in—

TALK.START.PARA: —I think you might be jumping ahead to the next set of amendments.
—I thought we were dealing with—
—Nos 44 to 49, 51 to 60, 152, 153 and 192 to 194. They are amendments moved by the government. You have been talking about Green amendments 6 to 8 to government amendments 50 and 61.
—Yes; I beg your pardon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (50) Clause 115, page 111 (after line 11), after paragraph (h), insert:

(2) Before revoking an industry standard under subsection 128(1), the ACA must consult at least one body or association that represents the interests of consumers.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 115 sets out the matters that the ACA needs to be satisfied with before it registers a code. Paragraph (g) requires the ACCC not to object to the code. This is inconsistent with the role of the ACCC in other areas, including industry standards, and with the roles of the TIO and the Privacy Commissioner. The ACCC has effective powers under the Trade Practices Act to address any anti-competitive concerns it may have.

The Australian Democrats' minority report recommended that there be a requirement for consumers to be involved in the development of codes. Amendment No. 50 achieves this by inserting a new subclause. Government amendment No. 61 amends clause 131A which provides that, before determining, varying or revoking an industry standard, the ACA must consult at least one body or association that represents the interests of consumers. This provision is intended to ensure that consumer representatives are involved in the earliest stages of standard development.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which recommendation in the committee's report did your amendments come from?
—Recommendation 1 on page 165 of the Democrats' report. Mr Tem porary Chairman, is it convenient for me to, at the same time, comment on the Greens' amendments?
—I think maybe the Greens should move their amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (6) Paragraph 115(1)(ha), omit "at least one body or association that represents the interests of consumers has", substitute "bodies and associations that represent the interests of consumers have".
(7) Subclause 131A(1), omit "at least one body or association that represents the interests of consumers", substitute "with bodies and associations that represent the interests of consumers".
(8) Subclause 131A(2), omit "at least one body or association that represents the interests of consumers", substitute "with bodies and associations that represent the interests of consumers".

These amendments relate to the government's amendments which seek to increase consumer consultation when the Australian Communication Authority considers industry codes and standards and when the Australian Communication Authority determines, varies or revokes an industry standard. On the surface, these new amendments by the government seem to be a reasonable attempt to address the concern that many consumer groups will not be properly consulted by the ACA on industry codes and standards.

But a fairly short time ago during this debate we saw that the minister himself can be very dismissive of groups that might not have his own viewpoints, or might not speak out on them at the right time, or whatever. He has been very dismissive of a number of concerns. So the wording is suspect. It states that the ACA must consult at least one body or association that represents the interests of consumers. Why only one? We are suspicious that `at least one' will in effect mean `only one'.

How can the ACA be sure that any one consumer organisation is truly representative of consumer concerns? Perhaps this might just mean that the government has a chance to pick and choose and might get a tame one. Surely it would want to consult all consumer organisations so as to get as much information and as many perspectives as possible. We are also concerned that the wording of these government amendments could be used to exclude consumer organisations that are seen as troublesome or radical. Our amendments remove the wording while retaining the intent of the government amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government, in its just over 12 months in office, has had a number of inquiries and has established a number of expert groups. On each of those we have been very keen to appoint consumer representatives. On the information policy advisory committee, for example, we have a representative of the ACA. On the experts group, which I established in relation to this whole package almost 12 months ago, again we had a representative from the ACA. On the standard telephone service review we had representatives of both the ACA and—
—Which ACA are you talking about?
—The Australian Consumers Association.
—Because the Australian Communications Authority has the same initials.
—Firstly, it does not exist; secondly, it is not a consumer body; and, thirdly, I am talking in the context of consumer associations. In that context, there is only one ACA.

SPEECH.PARA: For the standard telephone service report we appointed representatives from both the ACA and CTN. That, I think, establishes our bona fides and our determination to ensure that consumer views are taken fully into account. I certainly was not attempting to suggest that consumer groups had not been following the debate closely or have not put views forward. I am simply trying to indicate to you that, apart from you raising the issues here, very little concern has been expressed over a period of years about the whole notion of network boundary other than in general terms. That is the sort of stock‐in‐trade that you have thrived on for years. That is how Senator Allison earns a living: by basically getting up and raising concerns, doing a bit of hand wringing and sitting down again. You do not actually address a specific amendment or look at how the situation might be improved.
The problem with this particular amendment is that we would never know where to stop. If there is an obligation to consult bodies and associations that represent the interests of consumers—

TALK.START.PARA: —I'm sure you would.

—Well, you could set one up tomorrow. If they consulted a body and you did not get the right answer, you could set up another one, and that would have to be consulted. You would simply never know whether you had fully complied with that obligation. I suppose it would even be possible to get an injunction to restrain the ACA or the government from proceeding with legislation because it had not properly complied with the requirement to consult every conceivable body and association that might represent the interests of consumers.

SPEECH.PARA: The effect of this amendment will be to enable carriers and service providers to escape their obligations under industry codes in the standards regime. It would certainly make the codes and standards scheme unworkable. As I say, there is every intention to ensure that consumers' views are taken into account—for the obvious reason that, unless that is done, justifiable criticism is invited. At the end of the day, it is the consumers whose benefits ought to be paramount in all of these reforms.

I know there are those who would like to suggest that this is being done for some conspiratorial reason to benefit carriers or other parties. It all flows through to consumer benefits and, if you do not justify it on that basis, then you do not embark on changes. But consumer interests are what we have absolutely in mind as our paramount consideration. We very much want all of the regulatory bodies to ensure that they are fully aware of consumer views. An amendment as open‐ended and as wide ranging as that could simply never be satisfied if it were treated strictly on its wording.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quite extraordinary that there does not seem to be the same restrictions in decisions about industry involvement. In fact, in relation to a number of codes, industry in general has a power of veto—the ability to object. There are no restrictions that I know of about who can speak for industry. So it seems to me there is a line in the sand which says that we can pick consumer groups but for industry groups it is come one, come all. Why don't you have that concern about an industry group, which has specific interests, when you are worried about consumer groups having the ability to approach the government and maybe the right to be heard?

SPEECH.PARA: Consumer groups, I would contend, represent a far wider number of people than some industry groups and some industries. I am not sure why there is a fear about floodgates for people who represent consumers when there does not seem to be that fear in relation to powers of veto in industry codes for representatives of industry and which powers do not seem to be restricted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition supports the government amendments and, though we note the concerns of Senator Margetts about taking the worst case scenario that the ACA will pick a bodgie consumer group, I will give the benefit of the doubt to the government and the ACA, in particular the ACA. If in this consultation process they did pick bodgie groups, I would have thought that in a robust democracy such as Australia we would fairly rapidly have a blue about there being a process that is not transparent—
—We wouldn't be able to hold you, would we?

—Absolutely; I would be into it—and so would the Greens, the Australian Democrats and the community. Clearly the ACA would be mugs to fall into a situation where, say, the Oonagalabi Consumers Association, which consisted of three people, was the one being consistently consulted, because that would be apparent in a transparent process and it would destroy their own credibility. It would also be a matter of great controversy because there are a range of legitimate consumer groups with an interest in telecommunications besides the Australian Consumers Association, CTN and so on. They would certainly jump up and down about the fact that they were not being consulted in the process.

SPEECH.PARA: The public process will keep the government and particularly the ACA honest. If it turns out that Senator Margetts's cynicism and suspicion are correct, she would find all of us in here giving the government a good kick, which would be an embarrassment to the government of the day and a particular embarrassment to the ACA.

I hope the ACA would have the wit to send material to the half a dozen or dozen reasonable consumer organisations that they have on their list of organisations that have an interest in telecommunications and to ask them to respond to it. I also hope they would have the wit to, in their annual report to parliament, comment on the number of consumer organisations they have consulted as part of their reviews and drawing up industry codes et cetera. That would be another part of the debate and transparent process.

All in all, I think the process will keep the government and the ACA honest irrespective of how we define the number of associations. If we accept the Greens' amendment we could easily end up with a list that is as long as a piece of elastic—that is, it keeps stretching—because a group could start up at the last moment and say that they as a consumer association were not consulted. I think about half a dozen mainstream consumer groups with different views will consistently be involved in this area. I also hope that at a later stage in this debate the government can see the wisdom of making sure that proper funding is available to these consumer groups so that they can be healthy and vigorous parts of the telecommunications process.

TALK.START.PARA: —I put the question that the amendments moved by the Greens to Senator Alston's amendments Nos 50 and 51 be agreed to. Those of that opinion say aye, those against say no. I think the noes have it.
—The ayes have it.
—Is a division required?
—Yes.
—How many voices were there? I only heard one.
—Two.
—There were two.

—I simply make the point that I hope that, at a convenient opportunity, Senator Allison will indicate to the general public why the Democrats see the need to waste the time of the Senate when it is quite apparent what the outcome is going to be. What is achieved by that sort of stance? You have made your position perfectly clear. We accept that. No-one is going to be in any doubt about where you stood on the issue.
—Stop wasting time, Minister.
—I am talking about you wasting time, and I would like you to explain it in due course.
—Order! A division has been called. Ring the bells.

That the amendments (Senator Margetts's ) be agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question before the chair now is that government amendments 50 and 61 be agreed to.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Three of the government amendments to this bill have been circulated as requests. This appears to be on the basis that the amendments may result in increases of expenditure from the universal service reserve established by the bill. The amendments, however, do not directly affect expenditure from the reserve. The first amendment authorises a making of regulations to specify certain kinds of equipment and if regulations are made to specify that equipment this may result in increased expenditure from the reserve.

INTERJECT.PARA: The other amendments would authorise the Australian Communications Authority to exercise powers which, if exercised in a particular way, may result in increased expenditure from the reserve. The Senate has always treated amendments which merely empower the making of decisions which may affect expenditure as not requiring requests. A resolution of the Senate in 1981 declared that those types of amendments do not require requests. In any case, there is no money appropriated by the bill for the purposes of the reserve. The amendments will therefore be treated as amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 138, page 126 (after line 16), at the end of the clause, add:

PARA.TAB: (2) A reference in this Part to the supply of a standard telephone service includes a reference to the supply, to a person with a disability, of:

TAB.TAB: (a) customer equipment of a kind specified in the regulations; and
(b) other goods of a kind specified in the regulations; and
(c) services of a kind specified in the regulations;
where the equipment, goods or services, as the case may be, are for use in connection with the standard telephone service.

PARA.TAB: (3) In this section:

SPEECH.PARA: disability has the same meaning as in the Disability Discrimination Act 1992 .
I think this amendment is uncontentious. I indicate at this stage that we will be supporting Democrat amendment 15.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is in accordance, Minister, with discussions from the Senate committee on disability?
—Recommendation 2.13.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (15) Clause 144, volume 1, page 128 (line 30), after "paragraph", insert:
, including:
(a) criteria for determining the locations of payphones; and
(b) the process for public consultation on the location of payphones; and
(c) the process for resolution of any complaints about the location of payphones.

The purpose of this amendment is to introduce a clearly defined policy in the USO for payphone siting. Although such a policy is a crucial consumer safeguard for the new competitive environment, it is notably absent from the bill. While carriers may be willing to supply payphones in areas which are profit making or at least revenue neutral, they are not eager to supply, maintain or operate unprofitable ones. Currently, the issue of payphone siting density to comply with the universal service obligation to make payphones accessible to all Australians is a matter only for Telstra as the sole USO provider.

BREAK.PARA: It is notable, however, as revealed by the report of the standard telephone service review group, that Telstra's universal service obligation policy for payphone compliance happens to be a confidential document. Yet it is this document which addresses the arrangement for siting payphones in places such as remote Aboriginal communities. Clearly, such arrangements cannot be allowed to continue in the new environment. None of the carriers operating in a competitive environment will voluntarily want to operate and maintain loss making payphones, even if they are included in the USO.

The only way we can ensure they are provided as required and in accordance with the USO is to have a clearly defined policy. This was the finding and the view of the STS review group. A recommendation of their report says:

To ensure public payphone siting is responsive to community needs in a multi‐carrier environment, a publicly available payphone siting policy should be developed as a code of practice by the industry in consultation with consumers and users.

The Democrats support thoroughly this recommendation and have sought to give legislative effect to it by requiring that such a code be developed. Given support for the findings of the review group by all the major parties, I expect support will be forthcoming and I thank the minister for his indication that that is the case.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 144, page 129 (after line 2), at the end of the clause, add:

PARA.TAB: (8) An obligation does not arise under paragraph (2)(a) in relation to particular equipment, goods or services the supply of which is treated under section 138 as the supply of a standard telephone service if the customer concerned requests not to be supplied with the equipment, goods or services.

(9) An obligation does not arise under paragraph (2)(c) in relation to particular equipment, goods or services the supply of which is treated under section 139 as the supply of a prescribed carriage service if the customer concerned requests not to be supplied with the equipment, goods or services.
(10) To avoid doubt, an obligation arising under paragraph (2)(a) in relation to customer equipment requires the customer concerned to be given the option of hiring the equipment.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment makes it clear that an obligation does not arise under the universal service obligation to supply particular equipment, goods or services if the customer requests not to be supplied with the equipment. The obvious example would be where a consumer already owned a handset. The consumer would not have to be provided with a handset by the universal service provider. If subscribing to another carrier, then again the consumer would not have to take the service from the universal service provider. The amendment also responds specifically to the second recommendation of the Democrat minority report that the right to retain a rental handset should be explicitly a part of the standard telephone service.
Amendment agreed to.
Amendment (by Senator Alston) agreed to:
Clause 150, page 135 (line 6), omit "a Minister", substitute "the Minister".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (16) Clause 145, volume 1, page 130 (lines 8 to 12), omit subclause (2).
(17) Clause 145, volume 1, page 130 (line 13), omit "or (2)".
(18) Clause 145, volume 1, page 130 (lines 18 to 20), omit paragraph (4)(b).
(19) Clause 145, volume 1, page 130 (line 27), omit "subsections (7), (8) and (9)", substitute "subsection (7)".
(20) Clause 145, volume 1, page 131 (lines 14 to 26), omit subclause (8).
(21) Clause 145, volume 1, page 131 (lines 27 to 32), omit subclause (9).
(22) Clause 146, volume 1, page 132 (lines 7 to 11), omit subclause (1), substitute:

PARA.TAB: (1) The national universal service provider is the universal service provider for Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: (23) Clause 146, volume 1, page 132 (lines 12 to 20), omit subclause (2).
(24) Clause 146, volume 1, page 132 (line 22), omit "or (2)".
(26) Clause 149, volume 1, page 134 (line 27), omit "or 148(1)".
(27) Clause 149, volume 1, page 134 (line 29), omit "or 148(1)".

We also indicate that we will be opposing clauses 148, 150 and 151. The purpose of these amendments is to ensure that Telstra as the national carrier, which is still largely owned by the Australian public, remains the national universal service provider. It is our view that such arrangements should prevail whilst Telstra is in public ownership. If Telstra is one day fully privatised, then this policy should be reconsidered, but it is our view that that should not happen until then.

The proposal for tendering out of the USO stems from the assumption that other carriers may be able to provide the USO services, either nationally or regionally, more efficiently than Telstra. But the only way this is likely is through selecting a company which relies on cheaper labour rates. While the government may see this as appropriate, the Democrats do not believe it is wise policy to undermine the position of a substantially publicly owned company which operates nationally through promoting companies relying on cheap labour rates. This is a point I would like to emphasise to the Labor Party. If they vote against this Democrat proposal, then they should be clearly aware of the long-term implications.

Aside from the objective of encouraging reduced wage rates, which I do not put past the government or indeed the opposition, this proposal does not seem to have merit or indeed application in Australia. We already have a national network in place with a penetration rate of over 96 per cent. Duplication of communications infrastructure has been pursued in areas where it has been commercially feasible. It has been recognised as a major policy failure by numerous commentators. Sadly, the government and the opposition have chosen to keep their heads in the sand on this issue and persevere with more of the same.

Hoping to introduce competing infrastructure in areas where it is not commercially viable is simply a further invitation to extend the inefficiencies which the community and consumers have been burdened with to date. Indeed, as the CEPU has pointed out in its submission, the practical implications of the proposal do not seem to have been thought through. Telstra already supplies services to unprofitable areas. If an alternative universal service provider is selected for a particular region, then what is to occur to the Telstra existing facilities? Are they going to be sold off? What happens to them?

Is Telstra to continue operating a service at the same time? That is unlikely because if it is unprofitable for a single carrier to provide services, surely it is less profitable for two carriers to do so. By the same token, it is irrational to expect Telstra to act as some sort of reserve national universal service provider, ready to pick up the pieces if a regional or alternative national provider defaults.

As the CEPU points out, unless the industry is willing to fund the maintenance of its facilities while they lie idle, Telstra can be expected to withdraw selectively from those areas it is no longer required to service, making the necessary divestments with consequent risks and costs for consumers.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question before the chair will be dealt with in two parts: firstly, that amendments 16 to 24, 26 and 27 be agreed to and then, subsequently, that clause 150 as amended and clauses 148 and 151 be agreed to.
—I rise to indicate that the Greens (WA) will be supporting the Democrats on both of those proposals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government is very much opposed to this attempt to wind the clock back. The fact is that since 1991 the Telecommunications Act has allowed for multiple regional universal service providers. What the bill seeks to do is extend that to competition in the product market.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that the Democrats are violently opposed to competition, but they should at least reflect that this particular measure would take the national relay service away from the Australian Communications Exchange, which won the tender fair and square, and give it back to Telstra. Why would you want to do that? In other words, why would you want to remove the capacity for flexibility in the system, where Telstra at the moment might have no choice but to provide a service in a country area and, because they are the universal service provider, there is no incentive for them to carry out that service at a reasonable price and they therefore charge top dollar, you get all sorts of feather‐bedding, and there is no concern on their part because it is going to be recouped through the universal service levy?

If you allow tendering to occur, and that is what can happen under the 1991 act, then you provide the opportunity to get much lower tender contracts in place which have to meet the contractual standards. In other words, there is no question of reducing the quality of the universal service obligation, it is simply a matter of whether you can do it more cost‐effectively. In this day and age, when you are likely to have a plethora of new services emerging, the ability to have multiple national universal service providers provides real and valuable flexibility in selecting who should deliver particular components of the whole USO package.

If, for example, digital data capability was included in the USO, it may make sense for Panamsat to deliver that by satellite in some parts of Australia, particularly remote areas. You would have Telstra doing the lot, or you would have one universal service provider covering the field. That is completely inflexible. It is not a question of duplication. In a number of regional areas there may only be the ability to cope with one carrier. In other words, it might be the closest thing you get to a natural monopoly these days. It still does not follow that that should be the one company throughout Australia. It may well be that other companies are prepared to tender for that and recoup the subsidy through the universal service levy.

So what we are looking at in an open market is much greater differentiation. The whole concept of a USO is to provide a safety net to ensure that people, wherever they live, have the standard telephone service. In that way there is no risk as far as the consumer is concerned. What we are talking about here is whether it can be done more cheaply and just as effectively and done through a multiplicity of service providers. I think it can certainly be said that you may well find that one universal service provider specialising in cable based delivery services could provide service in densely populated areas and another specialising in radio or satellite based delivery would provide the same services in less densely populated areas. That is what the marketplace is all about. You have got your safety net in place. If you are violently opposed to competition then, of course, you support this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition supports the government's position on this. Yes, it is true we put it in the 1991 act, and I believe that there is a case to say that some competition in this area would be useful. I also want to say on behalf of the opposition that we would like to see the proof in the eating of the pudding in terms of this operation of providing competition in the provision of the universal service obligation over the next couple of years. So we reserve our position in accordance with what happens in practice.

SPEECH.PARA: What we are concerned about is that in one sense Telstra gets it in the neck both ways. It is expected to provide the basic infrastructure across Australia as the dominant carrier. It is expected by the community to do so. As I said before, whatever our theories of competition policy are here in this chamber or between political parties, most Australians, even with partial privatisation, still see Telstra as their carrier and as having to provide that service.

Particularly in rural areas, there is recognition that Telstra is the carrier and that so far the other competitors have not shown much interest, other than in a few specific examples, which may well grow, and in one sense I hope that they do. What the opposition is particularly concerned about in regional Australia is that, if there were a large number of non‐Telstra successes in winning the contract to provide the universal service obligation, that means that there would be a winding back of Telstra's infrastructure in regional and rural Australia. There would be further closing down, I suspect, of depots—

TALK.START.PARA: —People could go over to the alternative.

—Yes, they could go over. I suspect, though, that that could create some apprehension in the changeover, Minister, and that is one of the concerns in the regional areas. But once Telstra have withdrawn their infrastructure and their skill level and having employees in a regional area, when that contract for the universal service obligation comes up for renewal in two or three years time Telstra may not be interested in even bidding because they will have no infrastructure, or no so‐called critical mass, left to come back and compete. Therefore you might in effect replace the Telstra monopoly in this area with the successor who gets the contract, and in three or four years time they themselves become the monopoly and start shaving the edges in their favour on the contract.

SPEECH.PARA: You can say it is still a competitive process, but once you change the structure of Telstra in these areas, I am not sure all the consequences are automatically good. I want to put on notice that the opposition is willing, as we go into this deregulated area, to support this proposition. But I also have to say that we will watch over the next couple of years to see whether there are a large number of successes for it and we reserve our right to revisit the area in the future, as obviously any such areas of this legislation will be reviewed regularly, and there could be subsequent amendments, whoever is in government or opposition. I think the theory is correct—I do not have any doubt about the theory—but I think the practice may be a bit different from the theory, and in the end I think the people in regional Australia are more interested in the practice.

I do not know how many times as shadow minister I have had concerns expressed to me in country towns of a modest size in my own state when the Telstra depot is closed and three employees are transferred back to the city or to a larger centre. Three Telstra incomes in a small town the size of, say, Pinaroo or Lamaroo is an important economic factor for the rest of the town. Those things are flowing through. It is happening all over Australia. It is not just an initiative of Telstra—it is banks and everything else—but that is how the local regional communities see it. I think they are most interested in having the universal service obligation operating reasonably effectively. I do not think they are too much concerned whether it is costing $230 million or $280 million a year so long as they keep a Telstra, a Telecom or, as you would say, a telecommunications industry presence in the town.

I am not sure that the competition will mean that in the end the non‐Telstra people who may win the competitive contract for that universal service obligation for that particular area will permanently station people in the regional area. I think they will bring contractors in to do whatever they have to do and then take them out. If in their own cost structure they go to a very competitive price, I think they will look at ways of reducing the necessity to have permanent employees of their own in the area. I think that is where the practice is going to be different from the theory as far as regional Australia is concerned.

On balance, we are willing to support the government's position. We introduced it in 1991. But I put it here on behalf of the opposition clearly and squarely: if this does not work out in practice, we will want to revisit this issue. We do not think regional Australia should be left high and dry without proper telecommunications infrastructure consistently on the ground.

TALK.START.PARA: —That sounded very nice except that some honourable senators might be aware that, under competition policy, once you have opened a service by what was a government entity to tenders from other companies, I would think it would be almost impossible to go back; you would have to have a special exemption from competition policy. I do not think under the current competition policy regime you could actually go back. I think we all understand that this is a one‐way step. If we do not get if right now, there is no real going back. I think Senator Schacht should know that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —For a start, the Democrats are not violently opposed to competition. I do not know how the minister has got this false notion. What we are violently opposed to is this government writing legislation which has been ill‐thought through and which turns out to be, at the end of the day, a blank cheque. We are violently opposed to the way competition is used as an excuse for winding back services and jobs and support for the rural sector, as Senator Schacht has already mentioned. We are violently opposed to giving away our public infrastructure for private gain. We are violently opposed to the government not thinking these measures through.

SPEECH.PARA: I raised a couple of questions in my opening remarks. They related to the fact that we have no idea what this is about, essentially. The minister tells us it is to increase flexibility and to tender out the USO. What does that mean? Are we talking about the USO for the entire country? Are we talking about regions? Are we talking about municipalities? We still do not know what this means. I raised these questions at the time of the inquiry that we had and did not get any answers. I also raised a couple of questions a moment ago about what would happen to Telstra's existing facilities. Do they just get handed over to somebody else or are they sold? If they are sold, what happens to the revenue? Can Telstra continue to operate the service at the same time? If the government thinks it is unprofitable for a single carrier to provide the services, why does it think that two will somehow do it better?

The problem with this legislation, and the reason we have proposed these amendments, is that we just do not understand what it is you want to do with the universal service obligation and provider. I do not think we are satisfied that, by this legislation, competition is going to deliver benefits to anybody in particular. I would be grateful if the minister could give us a bit more flesh on this proposal so that we can understand what it is we are voting on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are only two reasons Senator Allison would not know what is proposed. One is she has not read the 1991 act, and the second is she has not been listening to what has been said in the chamber this morning.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said—and Senator Schacht immediately responded to it—the 1991 act allows for regional universal service providers. For Senator Allison to suggest that she still does not know whether this is a proposal to tender out the universal service provider on a national basis or on a regional basis reflects either a profound incapacity to look at legislation, explanatory memoranda or anything that has been written on the subject or simply an unwillingness to confront the facts. This bill does allow flexibility because it moves from competition in terms of regional to competition in terms of product and services.

As I keep saying, the universal service obligation provides the safety net that ensures that people in those areas still get those services. If you are genuinely interested in consumers, then you ought to be interested in seeing consumers get a better deal, a cheaper deal. I think it is also true to say you cannot have these sorts of debates in isolation. You have to take account of employment consequences and look at the impact, particularly on small regional towns. But be clear that is not a consumer issue. If it were, I think there would be a contradiction in terms. No‐one would suggest that reducing employment in country areas is somehow detrimental to consumers. It is likely that if there were substantial reductions then they would flow through in reduced prices.

I do not suppose anyone can tell precisely what the effect will be in terms of employment levels because it depends upon the level of productivity and the capacity of a new entrant to be able to provide substantially the same services at a much reduced price or by a very different form of technology. I think the challenge in many ways is to look at regional areas on a holistic employment basis and see how governments and others can provide those employment opportunities, but that is quite a different matter from providing services and products to consumers. If you are interest in consumers, competition is the vehicle for doing that. If you are interested in protecting jobs, and particularly Telstra jobs, you are talking about a very different animal and that is why I share Senator Schacht's concerns. Obviously, we have to keep a watchful eye on how these things play out. For Senator Allison to suggest that she has got no idea whether this is contemplating competition on a region by region basis or on a product by product basis simply shows that she is not following the debate.
Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that clause 150 as amended and clauses 148 and 151 be agreed to.

—Democrat amendments 16 to 24, 26 and 27 have been defeated. If they had been carried, they would have moved to have these opposed. Are they consequential in any way? Their amendments 25, 28 and 29, oppose clauses 148, 150 and 151. Isn't their opposition consequential on getting that first lot up, which they did not? Is that right?
—You have just defeated 16 to 29. The running sheet says that, if those amendments are not successful, the Democrats will move 30 to 32—and then I am back on track.
—I think I ought not to have moved amendments 25, 28 and 29; rather, I should have moved 16 to 29.
—We still have to put the question that clause 150 as amended be agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 150, as amended, agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now we call on Democrat amendments to 30 and 31, sheet 404.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (30) Clause 147, volume 1, page 133 (lines 13 to 17), omit subclause (3), substitute:

PARA.TAB: (3) A system so determined must require an applicant for selection to give the Minister a draft universal service plan for the area that is the subject of the application.

TAB.TAB: Note: For universal service plan , see section 153.

SPEECH.PARA: (31) Clause 148, volume 1, page 134 (lines 9 to 13), omit subclause (3), substitute:

PARA.TAB: (3) A system so determined must require an applicant for selection to give the Minister a draft universal service plan for the area that is the subject of the application.

TAB.TAB: Note: For universal service plan , see section 153.

SPEECH.PARA: Given that the Senate has not seen fit to proceed down the path of enabling the USO to be tendered out, the Democrats believe that it is essential that safeguards are put in place to ensure that consumers are properly protected. Consumer organisations such as the ACA and the Consumer Telecommunications Network have called for carriers to be required to lodge universal service plans prior to the grant of a tender or selection of a regional universal service provider. In our view, this is just commonsense. How can the government award a tender if it has not seen the carrier's proposed plans? The bill merely states that a selected universal service provider `may' be requested to lodge a plan within three months of being selected. If the draft is not acceptable, the government is required to notify the carrier within an unspecified time and request the carrier to submit another version.

It is quite conceivable that a whole year could roll by before an acceptable plan was lodged—that is, if one is requested at all. The purpose of these Democrat amendments is therefore to ensure that the universal service plans are lodged and approved prior to a carrier being selected as a regional or national universal service provider. We think this is essential in the interests of consumers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes these amendments as unnecessary and likely to create a regulatory gap. The bill already provides that the minister can require a draft USO plan, as Senator Allison just said, but to require the logic of a draft plan would create unnecessary inflexibility because a selection process need not involve a tender. If a tender process is utilised to select a universal service provider, the tender specification would be expected to set out in detail the USO requirements the successful applicant would be required to meet.

SPEECH.PARA: In other words, when you call for tenders, you spell out precisely what you want and you do not accept a proposal unless it meets your requirements, so to then turn around and say `you have got the tender' or `you are about to get the tender; we want you to again spell out what you have got in mind' ignores the fact that you have already made it clear what you have in mind. It is an unnecessary duplication. The minister need not employ a selection process to select a universal service provider. There may well need to be negotiations and, at the end of the day, what is important is that whoever tenders is able to comply with the government requirements which will very much address the needs of the universal service obligation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the minister whether the information that is provided in tender documents is available to consumers or to the general public and whether or not the suggestion by the Democrats would allow, importantly, those people in the community to have some idea of the bona fides and intent of those people providing universal service obligations.
—Yes.
—There were two questions there.
—The second follows from the first.
—Can I just clarify that. So the information in the tender document is protected by commercial‐in‐confidence. Is that what you are saying yes to?

—It is exactly the opposite to what I was asked. I was asked whether this would be a public document to enable consumer groups and others to comment on it. The answer was yes, so you immediately get up and say, `So it is commercial‐in‐confidence.'

—There has been a great deal in Senate estimates that has not been available through tendering documents. I am very pleased to see that these will now be available. Or is this not the case? Have tendering documents always been publicly available?

—The minister seems to be suggesting that these universal service plans have no purpose. Provided the contractor complies with the specifications, we should be reassured that that is all we need to worry about. Can the minister confirm, if the specifications are everything, why we need a universal service plan.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —To be clear, what will be made public are the tender specifications. The government or whoever is making these decisions would only accept a tender if it complied with those specifications. It does not follow that you would then release the document that complied with those. Everyone will understand the basis on which the decision will be made.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (65) Page 138 (after line 5), after clause 155, insert:

PARA.TAB: (1) Before giving the Minister a draft universal service plan under section 155, a universal service provider must:

TAB.TAB: (a) publish a preliminary version of the draft plan and invite members of the public to make submissions to the provider about the preliminary version within a specified period; and
(b) give consideration to any submissions received from members of the public within that period.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 215B Review of operation of this Division

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Before 1 July 2000, the Minister must cause to be conducted a review of the operation of this Division.
(2) In conducting the review, consideration must be given to the question whether any or all of the provisions of this Division should be repealed or amended.
