(4) The Minister must cause copies of the report to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after the completion of the preparation of the report.
We now get to an esoteric area called price discrimination, but it actually has a major and profound influence on the charging arrangements for Australian consumers in telecommunications.

In moving these amendments, the opposition wishes to achieve the following outcome. We simply want the advantages of competition that will occur, certainly in the competitive markets of the cities, to be available to rural and regional consumers for local calls. We do not want to see what has happened in the petroleum industry, which has been a major complaint for regional people.

Because of competition in the petroleum market in the cities, where discounting takes place on a regular basis, people are able to purchase petrol in the cities which is up to 10c or 15c a litre cheaper than in the regional and rural areas where there is a lot less competition—even allowing for the cost of transporting the petrol to those regional and rural markets. I think all of us in this place, as well as those at the state parliamentary level, have heard complaints about why country people cannot get cheaper petrol. Competition, a free market, does not work where you have a limited, small market. The petroleum companies are not willing to invest. They see it as a loss area and, therefore, are certainly not keen to reduce prices.

What we think will occur in Australia in the telecommunications local telephone market is that—and competition is already starting to occur but certainly will occur post-July 1—in the major metropolitan markets, particularly Sydney and Melbourne but also Brisbane, Adelaide and Perth, there will be significant competition between Optus and Telstra to start off with on what should be the local call rate. At the moment we all know that Telstra's local call rate across Australia is 25c. Telstra is the only effective carrier operating in what is called the local loop, the local call zone.

Optus announced last year that with the roll‐out of their cable past 20 per cent of Australian homes—of course, only in the major cities of this country—they will provide a telephony connection of 20c for a telephone untimed local call if you are in that market. So far, of course, they have had technical problems and cannot get the calls to operate. They may be successful in overcoming those technical problems, but that is their problem, not the parliament's or anybody else's. But, if they do get it to work, there will be a reduction in their charges. Telstra will obviously start responding to that.

What we want to do is make sure that the price reductions for local calls that people in the city get from competition, which will not automatically occur in regional and rural markets, are also available to people in rural and regional areas. Most of us know that a lot of phone calls in the regional areas are actually at a community call rate. That is a variation of an STD rate, but it is a timed call. Just the same, in many rural areas there is an untimed local call in large country towns which is at the 25c rate.

We believe that, if Telstra drops their price in Sydney to 20c to match Optus, in local call zones across Australia—where they are now charging 25c—they should also drop it to 20c. That is the intent of our amendment. I am sure the minister will get up in defence of his position, which is to have a price averaging arrangement which does provide—and I do not disagree—some reductions by price averaging into regional Australia. It does not offer the full unambiguous cut that we are offering by putting this proposal forward.

BREAK.PARA: The minister will raise an issue, which I think we will probably call the Ballarat experience, whereby the council of Ballarat has an agreement with a local niche telco which has come in. It is offering, if you subscribe to pay TV, free untimed local calls for the Ballarat area. That is obviously being offered as a package. On the telephony side, that is a pretty competitive position to be in vis-a-vis what Telstra would be offering. Telstra would have to make, one would imagine, some competitive response. Whether it is a free local call or some other package, I do not know, but that is up to them.

The minister may raise that, under my amendment on behalf of the opposition, if Telstra went down and matched the local free call in Ballarat in that local call zone, they will therefore have to offer a free call in all the local call zones in Australia, including Sydney, Melbourne, Adelaide, Perth and the big ones where there are major revenue issues.

To deal with this issue, I have put in my amendment that the carrier can get exemption. Where you have a bundled price—as it might well be called—or a bundled product, the carrier can go to the minister and say, `This is not apples with apples,' in comparing Ballarat's prices with Melbourne. They can say, `It is a bundled price and a local little market,' et cetera. `We have to compete there to protect our market, but it is not the same as going into Sydney or Melbourne.' So there is a discretion for the carrier to seek ministerial discretion to exempt them from the arrangement. I think this is the only fair way.

We do not want to cripple Telstra's prices or its income or its revenue, but we certainly want to make sure that all Australians in regional areas get the same advantages of competition. The minister may well disagree with this and say there will be robust niche competition in lots of regional areas of Australia vis-a-vis the Ballarat experience. I hope in one sense he is right. I am not arguing against that. But I doubt that it will occur in Pinnaroo; I doubt that it will occur in Ceduna in my own state. They will not even have a niche player as they do in Ballarat, which is a city of 60,000 or 70,000 people and is a compact area. For most of regional and rural Australia, which will still have local calls, there will be no competition. The prices will not change. They will stay at the standard 25c rate.

Therefore, we believe it is very important that regional Australia get the same advantages of competition. We do not believe that this is going to unnecessarily and adversely affect Telstra's revenue dramatically. We believe, in fact, there will probably be an increase in volume if you reduce the prices. There might be some argument about the elasticity of the market or some economic term, but there is no doubt that, if you reduce prices, you will end up increasing volume by and large. So the revenue will still go up.

There is also no doubt that a lot of people have commented that, with new technological development, the actual cost of making a local call—if you unbundle all the attachments, unbundle the cabling itself, unbundle the handset at the end—may be only 1c, 2c or 3c. Some people say that in America it may be down to under 1c. We do not believe that we are making a drastic impact on Telstra's revenues, but we do believe that this is a case, though there is a competitive market, to ensure that the theory of competition is not just for those fortunate enough to be in the city, but is available for local call numbers in all areas of Australia, where you are comparing apples with apples. Therefore, I commend the amendment to the Senate and look toward to the support of the Senate in supporting regional and rural Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats have amendments which are almost identical to the opposition's proposal, except for one significant difference. Where the opposition amendments refer to `eligible customers', the Democrats's amendments simply refer to `customers'. The Democrats believe all Australians should be entitled to untimed local calls, not only those who are eligible. We will be moving amendments to make this possible.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to deal with the issue of price discrimination. It is our view that prohibiting price discrimination between local call zones is essential if the benefits of competition are to be equitably shared by all Australians. Allowing for price discrimination will invariably mean, as Senator Schacht has indicated, that residents in high density urban areas, such as Melbourne and Sydney, will benefit at the expense of those who live in rural, regional and remote areas. I do not think anyone is in any doubt about that. Clearly, for residents in such places as Tasmania, where Telstra is the sole carrier, there will be no competitive push for price reductions. The Democrats believe that the way around this is to legislate to ensure that all Australians share the same rights. I expect that the National Party members will want to support these amendments and I will be interested to see if they actually do.

The majority report of the telecommunications bills inquiry, which reflects the views of government senators, was critical of maintaining price discrimination restrictions because it thought it would result in weakened competition, and thereby lessen consumer welfare. Two points need to be raised in response. Firstly, competition between carriers will still be possible. The only difference is that carriers will not be able to price discriminate across local call zones. Secondly, the alternative, as we all know, is that urban and business consumers will benefit substantially while many others will be left behind, potentially even cross-subsidising the former. To overcome the problem of making Telstra the sole carrier forced to avoid price discrimination, our amendments impose this measure on all carriers. This will ensure that Telstra is not unfairly constrained relative to its competitors.
Finally, I think it is important to point out that the amendments I am proposing do not lock this position in. We have provided for the minister to review the operation of this within four years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to underline what my colleague has said. We have a peculiar situation in Queensland, where the National Party spends a lot of time running around Queensland telling everybody that they do not believe in the competition reform bill, which of course they all voted for. The problem is, of course, they never admit that they actually voted for what they now say they do not believe in. This is another occasion, I think, where we will find that Senator Ron Boswell and Senator O'Chee will in fact run around Queensland when the effects of this particular measure become obvious in remote and rural Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: They will tell everybody, `Isn't it terrible?' and wring their hands and say, `Hilmer's dreadful, competition's not working, our rural constituents are not being served, we really don't like it and we think it's terrible.' But, of course, they will have voted for the exact measure which they tell everybody they do not like. I am underlining what my colleague said, and that is that the National Party must support these amendments. It must support them. If it is going to do what it has been doing—which in fact is telling lies to Queenslanders about how terrible these measures are—and does not tell Queenslanders that in fact it has voted for them, I think their hypocrisy will become obvious. I certainly will make sure it becomes obvious.

I am appealing to the National Party not to make hypocrites of themselves, to support what they are telling everybody in Queensland and, I suppose, in other states as well, and to vote for these amendments. If not, then we will certainly make sure that Queenslanders know that what they say and how the vote are quite different.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will realise that the Greens (WA) have been consistent in relation to access and equity issues in competition policy and this is one of those defining issues. I certainly do hope, as was mentioned today, that the National Party will actually stand up for their constituency. Of course access and equity issues, price discrimination, and so on are not just rural issues; they are issues of a fair go in Australia and what we have been led to believe Australia is all about and what we are led to believe the parliament is here to support. If it is not access and equity in provision of services, one can only wonder what it is.

SPEECH.PARA: I would really like to see that, in this particular instance, we do get support from all parties. But, as the government is clearly unlikely to do so, it would be very good to see the National Party standing up for their constituency in this regard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought it might be useful, as there are more amendments, to point out that in our amendment we make it not just Telstra; it is all carriage service providers. So when Optus is spreading its competition around, they also are bound by these amendments. It is not picking on Telstra; it is all carriage service providers.

SPEECH.PARA: I also wanted to point out that, like so many in telecommunications do, we do not claim to be oracles and know where it is going to end up in a couple of years. That is why, as part of the amendment, we have included a review of the operation of this so that, before 1 July 2000, the minister has to conduct a review of the operation of this division and table a report in parliament.

There is no doubt that this will work properly to the advantage of rural and regional Australia. However, I concede that, with developments in technology and the competition arrangements, other things may occur which need to be looked at. I accept that one should not be an absolutist in much of the telecommunications area. Those of us who have been absolutists in the past have usually had egg on our face some six months later. I admit to being one of those in the past. I am much more cautious now than I was as a backbencher in the early 1990s.

Even if the minister's amendment gets up—and I hope it does not—I think a review in this area would be a very beneficial process because issues will arise from the arguments, whether they are from carriers, the community or whoever. I emphasise that we want that review there to review the operation. I hope it will be the Senate's view that we support the opposition's amendment. I thank the senators who have supported it so far.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is, as Senator Margetts quite rightly said, a defining issue. Certainly, in the package to date, this is by far the most significant example of the enormous potential for competition to deliver real benefits. These opposition amendments have the capacity not just to chill competition, but to absolutely freeze it.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a matter of great concern that Senator Allison, in particular, spent all of 90 seconds on the merits of what is clearly a very important issue, and Senator Woodley tried to play what he thinks is a political card by suggesting that somehow the National Party ought to acknowledge that this is going to be contrary to the interests of consumers in rural areas. It is quite the opposite.
If you have a system which says—
Senator Woodley interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Absolutely. It you have a system that says that you have to charge the same price across‐the‐board, then if Telstra wanted to offer a 15c local call in Sydney, that requirement would have to be extended across Australia. The end result of that would be that Telstra would not contemplate offering a 15c local call. It would offer a marginal reduction which was affordable across Australia. All right?

SPEECH.PARA: What would the competitor do? The competitor is bound by the same rules so, if Telstra goes down to 23c, the competitor would go down to 22c, and that is where it would sit. There are no significant benefits from competition. Instead of having vigorous competition in some areas, which can then flow on in terms of a weighted average cost price, it would simply ensure that effectively there would be a cosy duopoly arrangement. There would be enormous constraints and it would be unaffordable for carriers to offer significant reductions because they would have to offer them across‐the‐board, and they simply would not do it.

The carriers do not like our approach because it does not allow unfettered competition. It does not allow price differentiation in one area not to flow on to another. That is why we have accepted the recommendation of the report of the majority of the Senate Environment, Recreation, Communication and the Arts References Committee which proposed a weighted average pricing mechanism.

That mechanism will ensure that those in country areas get the substantial benefits of the price reductions that are achieved else where. That allows very significant price reductions in some areas, that will then weight, very significantly, the price that is reflected in other non‐competitive areas.

It should not be assumed in this whole debate that there are going to be large parts of Australia that will not get the benefits of competition. The Ballarat example, as Senator Schacht calls it, will be reflected in many parts of Australia. Indeed, as a result of the changes to the telecommunications regime in the United States, towns with as few as 500 people are now getting the benefits of competitive telephony and cable television services because carriers are able to pick and choose.

A weighted average mechanism ensures that a significant part of those benefits flows on. However, if you are determined to chill competition in this way, it will effectively ensure that there will be no significant price competition in Australia. In other words, it will probably undermine in one fell swoop one of the biggest opportunities there is to achieve significant price reductions.

The carriers do not like our proposal, but I can assure you that the industry will be absolutely aghast, so will consumers and so will those in rural areas, if the opposition amendments get up, because there will no longer be the opportunity for significant price reductions, either in the cities or in the bush, because the carriers will not be able to afford to offer significant price reductions in the city, and therefore there will be nothing to pass on to the bush.

If significant price reductions are achieved in city areas, with bodies such as the World Exchange talking about 15c local calls and Optus talking about 20c local calls, that will ensure that they cannot afford to offer those sorts of discounts any more because it has to be replicated across Australia. The fact that both the Labor Party and the Democrats see the need to insert a review clause shows a high degree of nervousness—

TALK.START.PARA: —It doesn't.
—Let me be clear. You are right in saying that we need to be constantly reviewing processes.
—Absolutely, it is a theme I have pursued all the way through.
—Indeed, and we will do it. If we were dilatory, I am sure you would be calling on us—
—Drop the review, then, if you want to.

—You can drop your review. I am not asking you to have a review. I am saying that I think you are trying to take out some political insurance by saying to the industry and consumers, `Don't worry, if we've got it wrong, there'll be a review anyway.' You ought to be constantly prepared to review your position. You ought to constantly want to see how it plays out in practice. We would do that as a government, and I hope you would do it too.

BREAK.PARA: But to put in place a highly inflexible arrangement—the ultimate in inflexibility—is tantamount to ensuring that competition outside the city areas will be stillborn. Northgate are just one small example. Northgate would be hoping that they will be competing in a number of other regional areas. I think they have nominated 40 in the first instance. They will not be the only ones. You have people like Austar, Paynet and Rocom offering cable services. There is no reason why you would not expect a significant number of niche players to come in and provide telephony services.

But they will do it in accordance with the requirements of the local market, depending upon who is there. If it is a local player offering the service, then they will want to be able to compete against that local player. But, if they are a national company, they will not have the capacity to do that because they then automatically have to offer the same price all around Australia. So there will be no opportunity to go in and target a particular market; no opportunity to compete against the local entity. The great virtue of having a weighted cost average scheme is that where you do achieve significant price reductions they are then built in and flow on to those areas where you do not have competition in the first instance.

TALK.START.PARA: —But not to the full effect. It is an average; it is not the full reduction.
—Indeed, and it is the essence of competition that you would expect—
—Averaging is not competition.
—It is not competition, exactly.
—Averaging is a political decision by you to offer some reduction.

—It is a measure to ensure that the substantial benefits of competition flow on. But there is no point in contemplating it if you do not have competition in the first place. You are not proposing competition.
—Yes we are.

—You are not. You are absolutely guaranteeing that no-one can afford to offer any significant discounts in particular areas because they will have to offer it across the board. That is why this amendment is absolutely catastrophic in terms of achieving significant price reductions around Australia.
—You are not going to claim the end of Christianity and motherhood as well, are you, Minister!

—I do not think we need to go that far; but in terms of competition we do. You ought to understand that the consequences of this are very serious. I want to address my remarks also to an amendment which Senator Schacht has proposed that would allow a carrier to get a ministerial exemption from a bungled price arrangement. Once you propose that, you are effectively conceding that you want to allow local competitive arrangements to occur. You cannot have it both ways.
—Yes you can.

—You might try to, but you defeat the logic of your own argument. Either you are saying that everyone ought to have the same price across the board or you are saying that there ought to be an opportunity for flexibility which allows—
—There won't be many more Ballarats.
—Why do you say that?
—Because there are only half a dozen or a dozen towns of the size of Ballarat. They are not going to be a Pinnaroo or a Ceduna.

—I have just said to you that it is the US experience of towns down to a population of 500. There is vigorous competition in both telephony and cable. That is Pinnaroo for you. You are saying that it will not happen in Pinnaroo. Six months ago you probably said it would not happen in Ballarat. The fact is that you cannot predict where competition will and will not occur. But, to the extent it is occurring, you can ensure that the benefits are passed on to those areas where it has not yet extended.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Schacht interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest we let the minister conclude his remarks.

—Thank you, Mr Chairman. It is critically important to understand that you will actually benefit consumers in rural areas if you allow them to get the flow-on effect of a significant price reduction in the city areas. You will not achieve that if you simply have this uniform price proposal, because any carrier contemplating offering a significant discount will stop short and say, `But hang on; we're not just talking about whether we can beat Northgate in Ballarat or whether we can compete with Optus in Rockhampton, because the minute we offer a reduced local call price we have to offer it around Australia.'

BREAK.PARA: That is an entirely different ball game. It means that you suddenly have to be completely reassessing your business plan. You know instinctively what the consequences will be, because any form of price reduction has enormous flow-on effects. So the end result is that you will not be able to offer any significant price reductions. That is the vice of this whole scheme.

Far from the Senator Woodleys of this world trying to pretend superficially that it is not going to help the bush, it will very substantially benefit the bush. It will make sure that people in rural areas get the benefits of significant price reductions in city areas that would not otherwise be affordable, as far as the carriers are concerned. In an open market, a prohibition on price differentiation will severely inhibit the emergence of additional competition in local call markets. For example, Telstra will be unable or unwilling to respond to competition in a particular localised market because of the revenue effects of having to drop prices across the board. If you do not believe me, ring Frank Blount. Just ask him what he thinks.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well he would say that, wouldn't he. Every carrier would say that.

—The carriers do not like a weighted average scheme. But I tell you what: it probably suits the purposes of the incumbent because they are about the only ones who can afford to offer price reductions across the board; but they will be very modest price reductions. To suggest that a fledgling company, in relative terms, like Optus could come into the market and decide that there is an area where they can really compete and then to tell them that it has to be delivered across the board is once again ensuring that Optus cannot afford to do it—and they will not; nor will any other company coming into the marketplace.

BREAK.PARA: They do not come in and treat Australia as one big market. You know what is happening with competition. People are constantly revising their markets, wanting to target particular areas, assessing the competition, meeting it accordingly. You are ensuring none of that happens. You are ensuring that people can have only a national approach to a whole issue. That is the death of competition, the death of the prospect of significant price reductions in city areas and the death of any ability for those to flow on to rural areas.

You will be ensuring that there are very modest price reductions in capital cities and of course in country areas because you have the same modest price across the board. Under ours we will get very significant price reductions in the city areas because carriers will be able to offer in Brisbane a 15c local call and in Sydney an 18c local call. When we average that out we are well below the 23c call that we would have across the board. So all those rural areas will get the benefit of that average price. They will be looking at something like a 20c call.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will still be higher than what we would offer.

—No, they will not be higher because you will have achieved very substantial price reductions in those city areas. That will then be reflected in the weighted average cost. So the combination of the 15c call in Brisbane and the 18c call in Sydney means we will get something like 20c in the bush. Otherwise, all we will get is a 23c call across the board, so the bush would be 3c worse off for every local call. That is disastrous for the bush, it is disastrous for the capital cities, it is disastrous for competition and it is disastrous for Australia's competitive position. I can certainly assure those opposite that this is one amendment that we will simply not accept.
—I remind honourable senators that the debate will be suspended at a quarter to one. The committee is considering Senator Schacht's amendments, so I call him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you very much. I think the debate will go well into the afternoon when we return to it, so I do not think anyone will be accidentally gagged. Minister, everything you said was utterly predictable. You might well say, `Everything you said, Schacht, was utterly predictable too in defending your amendments.' But you were dead right about one thing. In my view, the pricing arrangements in this package we are providing to consumers is one of the most significant debates we could have. It is particularly significant for regional and rural Australia. No other part of this bill is as significant for regional and rural Australia.
—An area beyond Melbourne.

—Yes, beyond the metropolitan area. I am very pleased to see Senator Boswell, my good friend from the National Party, is in here. I hope he participates in this debate. First of all, Minister, I want to point out a couple of things. Yes, it is true my amendment is for all carriers. I do not want to discriminate against Telstra. If we are going to have a competitive model, all carriers, if they are providing lower prices in, for example, Sydney and they want to get into the local loop anywhere else in Australia outside a capital city, will provide calls at the same low price. That is absolutely clear in my amendment.
—But they won't.

—That means they will have to put their price back up in Sydney. I would love to hear them announce tomorrow that the price on their local loop of cable they have just rolled out in Sydney is going back up to 25c. Sell your shares now if they are going to do that, because that would be the end.
—They haven't got any shares. What are you talking about?

—Well, try to float Optus Communications, who are the 50 per cent or 48 per cent shareholder in Optus Vision, when they are going to say, `Oh, sorry; we're going to put the price back up to 25c because of this amendment.' They will not do that at all. They know they have a competitive advantage. We want them to make sure that, if they go into a local loop elsewhere in Australia—in regional Australia or in another capital city—they offer the same, say, 20c call they offer the Sydney market. We want other carriers. That is to be a competitive market. Stop picking on Telstra.

SPEECH.PARA: Minister, I thank your advisers very much for the quick response they gave to my question about your own price averaging arrangement. This will be done by a disallowable instrument under the Telstra act, as I understand it from the way you put your proposal forward. That again emphasises you are doing it for only Telstra. Every other competitor or carrier has an unlimited advantage against Telstra. I think that is very unfair.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why would Optus ever go to the bush if they are forced to offer a—
—The point is that, in fairness, why should Telstra have to bear the burden?
—But Telstra won't offer it.

—They will have to offer it under mine if they are going to compete with Optus one way or the other. You are dead right: the carriers have been crying crocodile tears in my office. They have been to see me and have phoned me. Suddenly I am a useful person to them. A shadow minister is usually a non-person, as you would know. But, now that this bill is up and we are dealing with price discrimination, I suddenly find I am reasonably popular with all the carriers. They ring me up to find out about this. You are dead right that they say that it will be the end of humanity, Christianity and telecommunications as we know it if our amendment is carried.

BREAK.PARA: I had to say to all the carriers when this came up in the hearings as well as in informal discussions that, sorry, I do not think it is fair that non-metropolitan Australia would suffer a price discrimination with competition. It is not possible to have in Lameroo or Ceduna in my own state the same levels of competition. I think that would also be the case for Charleville in Queensland, Zeehan in Tasmania and the Pilbara in Western Australia: you will not get the same level of competition as you will get in Sydney and Melbourne, then followed by Brisbane, Adelaide and Perth.

We are arguing that the competition that will come and will drive local loop prices down has to be made available in the local loop prices right across Australia by all carriers. In the end, if the carriers do not do it, if they try to squirm out of this, they will end up as unpopular as petrol companies in rural Australia. They may say that is their market decision—

TALK.START.PARA: —And banks.

—And banks. But we think this parliament has a responsibility for the national telecommunications system. We as an opposition are not afraid to say that we will intervene in the marketplace, even in the competitive model, to guarantee that the millions of people living outside metropolitan cities in Australia get the same advantage of competition.

BREAK.PARA: We are disappointed, Minister, that you have done it for only Telstra. I think a weakness in your position is that you have picked on Telstra. Another weakness is that it is a disallowable instrument, because it is very hard to negotiate. We are being up‐front and willing to put in legislation how this is going to be done so that it is unambiguous and for Australians to see how we all vote on this and what our view is about rural and regional Australia.

Minister, I also pointed out—I again emphasise this—that we have put in the opposition's amendment an exemption that, in all the examples you give which create difficulties for a carrier to compete against a niche operator who is in a bundled position like Ballarat, and I agree that others will occur, the carrier—

DEBATE.TITLE: LAW AND JUSTICE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 March, on motion by Senator Campbell:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to indicate the opposition's support for the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill 1996. In doing so, I would like to make a few points. I welcome the implementation of the promise of the Justice Statement of the previous government, which was to establish a Small Taxation Claims Tribunal under the Administrative Appeals Act 1975. We thought that would be a very worthy measure and would have obvious benefits. It is good to see that the government is pursuing this policy initiative of the previous government.

SPEECH.PARA: I also wish to comment about the amendments to the Judiciary Act 1903 to provide the Federal Court with jurisdiction under sections 75 and 76 of the constitution. Once again, I express concern that the Federal Court is one of those jurisdictions that is having to suffer more and more cuts from this government. In that respect, we need to note with concern that more functions are being referred to it whilst, like many other arms of the federal legal infrastructure, the court has been asked to do it with fewer resources.

I also advert to the amendments to the Privacy Act 1988 to insert a definition of guarantee. When the act was implemented to cover private sector credit operations, it was a matter which was of great debate and concern. It is an area where we will take an interest in the future to ensure that the privacy principles are adhered to with respect to this initiative in relation to the Privacy Act 1988. That said, I do not need to delay the Senate any longer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bolkus has expressed for us many of our own opinions. This is a housekeeping act which also includes some important improvements in matters of principle and advances the interests of law and justice administration generally. Therefore, the Australian Democrats will support the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —The Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill is an omnibus piece of legislation, amending quite a number of other pieces of legislation. I want to very briefly go to one amendment that is made in this bill to the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Act 1995.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been a great deal of concern expressed quite justifiably about child pornography. There has been a considerable upsurge in this concern, particularly in New South Wales where teachers have been accused of taking advantage of young female students. I might mention while I am on my feet that there is a draft criminal code, as would be known by the Senate, that deals with the question of the age of consent.

I know that in Western Australia there is legislation which makes it an offence for persons in authority to engage in sexual activities with persons who are minors, that is to say under the age of 18. But in fact the draft criminal code is actually suggesting that there be a uniform code which proposes to suggest to the state that that be overridden.

I have of course noted this and have asked whether the government of New South Wales, which is proposing draft guidelines to cover the sexual abuse of children by teachers, has been consulted in relation to the issue of consent as dealt with under the draft criminal code and whether state governments have agreed that it is appropriate for the law to allow teachers to presume on consent to sexual acts of any kind by children under their care once those children have reached the age of 16 years. That is precisely what the draft code is proposing.

I am speaking on a piece of legislation which deals with this question in respect of child pornography. I will have something further to say in the committee stage of this bill but I thought I would set the scene by indicating to the Senate that there are behind the scene moves which will affect and, I believe, put at risk female students particularly who are under some sort of authority, including authority of teachers. It seems to me quite unbelievable that this suggestion should be made.

I am waiting and I will be very interested to hear the response from the Attorney-General's Department to my questions that I asked some time ago in the additional estimates. I hope those responses are forthcoming pretty soon so we can have a look at them, not only in respect of that matter but of a number of other matters as well.

I now come to the question of what the bill is proposing to do in respect of the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Act 1995. I have agreed that this bill be treated as a non-controversial piece of legislation because at least the amendments that are being proposed are, might I say, a very belated improvement in this particular area. I think the fault largely lies with the advice that the government is given by the Office of Film and Literature Classification.

On the Senate Select Committee on Community Standards there has been considerable concern expressed over many years about the loopholes that are in the guidelines and have been in the guidelines for some considerable time in respect of these matters; that is to say in respect of how people, young people particularly, are portrayed in so-called consensual sex videos in the R or X category. I can remember raising this particular matter maybe 10 years ago.

It is not surprising, I might say, that the Office of Film and Literature Classification and its predecessor the Film Censorship Board have been laggard in a number of these areas. I am not pointing to this particular area at all but we only have to remember who was the deputy chief censor. None other than David Haines. He left the office of deputy chief censor and went as a hired gun to the X‐rated video industry. He jumped immediately from the office of deputy chief censor to being a hired gun for that organisation.

Is it any wonder that not only the government but the community have problems in this area and have had them for some time? It was interesting to hear this morning that he was interviewed by ABC Radio National which referred to him as the former deputy chief censor of the Film Censorship Board and did not advert to the fact that he is now the hired gun for the X‐rated video industry, for the Eros Foundation.

I want to refer to the amendment again by saying that it is an improvement. The amendment, as I said, is designed to tighten the child pornography criterion by making it easier for the board to deal with the material where it is difficult to determine the age of the person portrayed. Precisely, and I have been saying that for 10 years. This is in response to difficulties experienced in some cases in determining the precise age of children in the 15‐, 16‐ and 17‐year age bracket.

The current criterion says, `A minor who is or appears to be under 16.' The video would be refused classification if it involves a minor who is or who appears to be under 16. With this legislation that is to be changed to say, `A person who is or looks like a child under 16.' That provision provides for a refusal to approve advertisements on the grounds that the content depicts or describes, in a way that is likely to cause offence to a reasonable adult, a person who is or who looks like a child under 16, whether or not the person is engaged in sexual activity.

It is an improvement. It does away with the word `minor'. It makes what it says far more clear—that is, `a person who is or looks like a child under 16.' I have seen X‐rated videos, and some in the R classification, where you have a situation where the person is made up to look like a student of 16 or 17. This improvement puts into the child pornography bucket, if you like, persons who are 15 or younger.

But what about the exploitative videos that deal with persons who may not be minors? They might be 18. But in these particular films they are dolled up to look like 16‐year‐olds. What about them? We have had evidence to our committee that these particular videos are often hired by a person and looked at with the young person who will be the victim or who will be taken advantage of by that other person. That person puts on the video and it has a disinhibition effect.

It is about time we had a good look at this and a good look at what is happening. I know that the age of consent has been 16 for many years. It goes back to when girls married younger. It goes back to the last century, really. But we are in a different ball game here, are we not? We are in a ball game where people are in an uproar about teachers taking advantage of young students. Oh, yes, they may not be under 15; they may be 16- and 17-year‐olds. What are we doing in the classification of publications area? Are we allowing these publications to treat 16- and 17-year‐olds in a manner that would be demeaning and would cause offence to a reasonable adult person?
I apologise for speaking longer than I believed I would, but when I saw this yesterday I believed that it was necessary to raise it. Consequently I have raised it in this second reading stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I thank, for their contribution, the senators who have spoken. Through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, to Senator Harradine I say that the government is prepared to raise with the state and territory governments the question of increasing the age from 16 to 18 for child pornography purposes. I will convey to the Attorney‐ General (Mr Williams) the comments that Senator Harradine has made in the chamber today.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment in schedule 2, which has been mentioned by Senator Harradine, is a result of the state situation. The government will be speaking to various state and territory governments on this matter. In relation to the questions that Senator Harradine raised at the estimates, the answers are being prepared. They are currently in hand and he should have them soon.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 2, page 2 (after line 7), at the end of the clause, add:

PARA.TAB: (5) Schedule 17 commences immediately after the commencement of item 75 of Schedule 16 to the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Act 1996 .

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Schedule 13, item 8, page 30 (lines 18 to 27), omit subsection (2A), substitute:

PARA.TAB: (2A) For the purposes of subsection (1), the maximum permissible period for the keeping of personal information of the kind referred to in paragraph 18E(1)(ba) is the period of 5 years beginning on the day when the credit reporting agency is informed of the overdue payment concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Page 39 (after line 20), at the end of the bill, add:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Schedule 17—Amendment of the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Act 1996

SPEECH.PARA: Omit "Registrar of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal", substitute "Industrial Registrar of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission".
I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the government amendments which have been moved to this bill.
Amendments agreed to.
