PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Ellison) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 3 March, on motion by Senator Campbell:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition supports this legislation. It is a bill that implements a number of the recommendations of the 1993 report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs entitled, Checking the cash . In particular, it implements recommendations 12, 15, 16, 18 and the recommendation requiring bullion sellers to identify customers.

SPEECH.PARA: In essence, we are picking up the recommendations of a committee which was established under the previous government. They are recommendations which ensure access to financial transaction report information by state and territory authorities, recommendations clarifying the definition of `transaction', recommendations relating to inadmissibility of suspect transaction report information, as well as recommendation 18 increasing the reporting threshold for certain transactions.

The bill does a bit more than that. It also introduces significant cash transaction reporting by solicitors. It consolidates AUSTRAC's powers of inspection and access to records, updates the penalty provisions, updates specified provisions and corrects minor drafting errors. These are initiatives that were generated under the previous government so that, of course, in opposition we would not oppose them.

There are two issues that are worthy of further note. Firstly, the Senate committee did raise concern about the appropriateness of privacy protection if the financial transaction report information was provided to state and territory authorities. This bill requires authorities to comply with the privacy principles as set out in the Privacy Act 1988, section 14 thereof, and those principles have to be complied with in order to access information. That is provided for in this particular bill.

The bill also makes it an offence for an officer of a revenue authority to improperly disclose information. I think those two measures together go a long way, if not fully, towards satisfying the concerns of the Senate committee. They do satisfy our concerns from this side of the parliament.

Secondly, the bill extends the application of suspect transaction reporting to solicitors. This is a measure that was supported by the previous Minister for Justice, Mr Duncan Kerr, and he announced that a Labor government would introduce similar changes, changes flowing from recommendations of the Costigan royal commission, the National Crime Authority and the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, all of which uncovered considerable evidence that solicitors' trust accounts may be being used from time to time to launder the proceeds of crime.

In raising this particular measure we note that the measures proposed in the bill, whilst not as onerous as those imposed on financial institutions, are a useful means to bring transactions involving solicitors' trust accounts within the purview of AUSTRAC. As I say, we support that.

In doing so can I ask the parliamentary secretary to provide the Senate either now, if he is in a position to do so, or at an early date, with information as to whether the Attorney‐General has received representations from the Law Council of Australia relating to section 15A(1) of the bill before us as it relates to solicitors' accounts, particularly as the section relates to the definition of `transaction' and, as they say significantly, the relevant transaction is not confined to the physical transfer of currency of not less than $10,000 but includes a transaction involving such a physical transfer of currency.

The Law Council does raise other concerns as well in its representations. If the parliamentary secretary could provide us with infor mation as to the status of the Attorney‐General's response to these representations either today or an at an early date, we would be appreciative of that.
As I said at the start, the opposition does support this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I must advise the government that they have the strong support of the Australian Democrats for any improvements in the financial transactions area. I was impressed by the previous government's work in this area. I was impressed by the Checking the cash document. I have been at pains to pay some attention to the views of the National Crime Authority and the Australian Federal Police on these matters, and I have paid attention to some of the international scandals such as that which concerned the BCCI.

SPEECH.PARA: It is my opinion—and the opinion of many observers in this area—that the area of financial transactions, particularly given the nature of our computer and information exchange, is one to be assessed with great gravity and great care. The ways in which international criminals, both of the white‐collar and the black‐collar kind, use the international banks, the financial institutions and the mechanisms of modern information technology to move their funds around require governments to be extremely vigilant, not just from a point of view of morality, but also from a point of view of protecting their revenue, because it is used most of all as a process for avoiding taxation and for operating in a criminal manner.

I have doubts that this act yet goes far enough. I believe we should continue, and I would urge the government to continue, to adopt best practice in this area and to keep a watching brief with its international counterparts—which I know it does—to keep improving it. As smart as we might think we are, it seems that those with evil in their hearts are often a lot smarter.

I personally am particularly delighted that solicitors are at last caught in the net of reporting. I believe that the profession, if they can be called that, the way in which the legal authorities and bodies have adopted a self‐serving, mendacious and long successful campaign for exclusion from reporting, is a disgrace. I know a number of outstanding lawyers whom I regard as very moral. But I think that particular campaign was an absolute disgrace. We know within this chamber, as does the wider community, that big crooks use big lawyers; big crooks use big accountants, big valuers and big banks. That is what they need. To at last be caught within the net is an invaluable thing.

You might have smiled when I mentioned that solicitors might no longer be called a profession. One esteemed judge in Western Australia—not a young judge; one who has been around—said to me that solicitors have long given up their right to be called a profession. He says they are just a business. Well, they were in the business of cash transactions which ought to have been reported and I am glad to see the government clamping down on them. So my compliments to you, Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General (Senator Ellison), and to your government on this legislation which advances this cause one more inch forward. Thank you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, may I thank those senators who have spoken on this matter for their contribution. I thank Senator Murray for his remarks; however, in relation to my former life, I am not so sure that I would adopt all of those remarks, especially in relation to the profession.

SPEECH.PARA: If I might touch on the definition of transaction, the only kind of transaction required to be reported here is a significant cash transaction. That is intended to mean a transfer of currency of not less than $10,000 in value. The significant cash transaction reporting provision is intended to provide intelligence to revenue authorities and law enforcement about the movement of large sums of cash.

I was a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs which wrote the report, Checking the cash. In that report it was suggested that solicitors be exempt. Since then—and that was some three years ago—it has come to light that in 1994‐95 there were some 2,100 transactions handled by solicitors entailing $42.7 million worth in cash. I think that is a significant matter, such that solicitors should now be brought within the ambit of this legislation.

The reportable details which apply to solicitors are set out in schedule 3A of the bill. The reporting requirement is confined to such matters as names and addresses of the parties to the transaction, the nature of the transaction—whether it involves a transfer of currency to or from the solicitor—the date of the transaction and identification information about the party who is not the solicitor. It is really not a requirement that there be any reporting of the subject matter to hand—that is, the proceedings that are involved or any question of communication between the client and solicitor.

There has been some concern about how far the requirement goes for reporting. I would allay any concerns in relation to that. There is no requirement to divulge any information about agreements, contracts, business dealing or the content of professional advice and, in fact, no requirement for any other matter underlying or connected with the currency transfer. Accordingly, there is no legislative authority for AUSTRAC to seek any such information in performing its auditing or compliance function. That function is confined solely to the question of whether or not a relevant person or entity has complied with the specific requirements of the act.

The reportable details, as set out in schedule 3A of the bill, proposed to apply to solicitors are similar in scope to those now applying to cash dealers, though they are less onerous in their identification requirements. Similarly, they require no information about business dealings underlying the transfer of currency and, similarly, AUSTRAC could not access such information in the course of performing its audit functions.

If I might just touch on bankers drafts and cheques, details of the cheque or the bankers draft are required to be reported, and the circumstances, if a transfer of more than $10,000 in cash is accompanied by a cheque or bankers draft forming part of that same transfer—for example, a transfer of $12,000 in cash and a cheque of the sum of $5,000 payable to the solicitor's trust account and drawn by a third party. Because $10,000 or more in cash is involved, that is an amount of cash which is considered large enough to raise a suspicion that its source may involve a criminal enterprise. Its law enforcement value is enhanced by any further information which can be supplied from associated instruments. As in the case of cash dealers, any privacy concerns relating to third parties who may have signed the relevant cheques are considered to be outweighed by the law enforcement interest in providing the best possible intelligence for the fight against major crime.

In relation to foreign currency transfers, the reason for the difference in reporting transfers of currency which include foreign currency is the possibility that large sums of currency could be withdrawn from institutions for transfer overseas or deposited after being carried through the customs barrier. To date, no institutional body which has reporting obligations under section 7 of the act—and that is the section which requires cash dealers to report significant cash transactions—has advised of difficulties presented by having to comply with that provision. It seems that solicitors might be reporting such cash transfers which include foreign currency on a regular basis, and a review of that provision could be appropriate. The reporting period for reportable cash transfers which include foreign currency can be altered by regulation.

Given that the government intends the transactions that are the subject to the bill to have the narrow meaning explained, the meaning of the phrase `day on which the transaction takes place' in subsection 3(1) of the definition of reporting period in the Financial Transaction Reports Act will not be uncertain. Thus the concerns about the meaning of reporting period should be allayed.

I might say that the government is aware that there has been some criticism in the legal profession about these matters but really the enormity of the cash transaction that I have mentioned has pressed the government to take this action. As I say, the bill requires solici tors to report significant cash transactions. As explained in relation to the scope of transaction issue, AUSTRAC's monitoring powers are restricted to auditing compliance of the obligations under the legislation. In relation to solicitors, that means records reflecting reportable cash transfers.

It is the government's intention that the monitoring powers conferred on AUSTRAC by part IVA of the bill be limited to access to the relevant records of the relevant parties to the cash transfer. That is, AUSTRAC will not be at liberty to go through the solicitor's files, as such, and other extraneous material which could be privileged. In this case, the scope of AUSTRAC's access to records in the context of a solicitor's practice is limited by the solicitor‐client privilege. Its monitoring powers are exercised subject to the common law legal professional privilege. Having placed those comments on record, I commend the bill to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE:
RETIREMENT SAVINGS ACCOUNTS BILL 1997 RETIREMENT SAVINGS ACCOUNTS (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1997
RETIREMENT SAVINGS ACCOUNTS SUPERVISORY LEVY BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 March, on motion by Senator Campbell:
That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —In respect of the very important, fundamental and far reaching change introduced to the superannuation industry in this country by the retirement savings bills before the chamber, I would like to say at the outset that, generally, in respect of the Liberal government's handling of superannuation matters, we have a range of very grave concerns should this legislation—and, indeed, what certainly could be argued as being much more important legislation into the so‐called surcharge, which we will be dealing with next week—pass the Senate without major amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: It is Labor's contention that the legislation that I am speaking about today—the retirement savings account package—and the legislation in respect of the new superannuation tax, about which we will obviously have a great deal to say next week—potentially, if unamended, will cause a dramatic upheaval in the superannuation industry. Indeed, we contend that it will cause massive chaos generally in the superannuation industry in this country, if it goes without substantial amendment.

In respect of the legislation that we are considering today, I would like to outline a range of major concerns we have with the concept of retirement savings accounts, as reflected in the detail that we are considering in the bills. I would like to go, firstly, to the commitment that the Liberal and National parties gave, prior to the last election, to provide employees and consumers with broader choice in superannuation. We would contend that the RSA—retirement savings account—product fails to meet this commitment. Currently, the bills provide to employers—and I stress that it is to employers—the ability to open retirement savings accounts on behalf of employees.

As the bills are currently drafted, there is no requirement for an employee to consent to the opening of an RSA. This is contrary to the requirements of section 153 of the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993, which requires employers to have an employee's signature on the application form before being able to proceed with the opening of an employee's superannuation fund.

It is important to note that, in situations where it is deemed by the commissioner that a substantial period of time has passed, an employer is able to open a superannuation fund on behalf of an employee under section 153 of the SI(S) Act. This situation, however, is only able to occur when the commissioner believes that such a substantial period of time has passed and the employer has undertaken all relevant steps to attempt to get the employee's signature.

Due to the product's low rate of return—and RSAs are a low rate of return product; in fact, the government boasts they are a low rate of return product—we believe that a government has a critical role to play in ensuring that employees are not trapped in a product that is unsuitable for long‐term savings. As a consequence of this critical defect in the bills, and in respect of the government's own rhetoric of choice and the imperative to maximise choice, we will be moving amendments to ensure that it is the employee's decision to open an RSA—not the employer's.

The second area I would like to comment on today concerns, again, a commitment given by the Liberal‐National party prior to the last election. The coalition's promise states, `Banks, building societies, credit unions, life insurance companies, life offices and superannuation funds would be able to offer RSAs.' Some of you may recall the extensive leaked documentation from Treasury last year in respect to proposals to cabinet on this particular matter. Those leaked cabinet documents to the Treasurer (Mr Costello) made it very clear that superannuation funds should be able to provide RSAs. However, when the Treasurer announced, on 20 August, that RSAs would be offered from 1 July 1997, he omitted to mention—we believe, deliberately—that superannuation funds would be able to offer RSAs. Currently the bills as drafted do not allow superannuation funds to offer RSAs.

It has been suggested that the regulations may provide for superannuation funds to offer RSA look‐alikes. The major issue that needs to be considered is whether the regulations will allow superannuation funds to offer the RSA product or an RSA look‐alike. If the regulations only allow superannuation funds to provide a look‐alike product, existing funds may be at a competitive disadvantage as they may not be able to use the name RSA for marketing purposes.

The government's rhetoric in allowing banks—in particular, I highlight banks—building societies and credit unions to provide RSAs is supposedly to implement a level playing field in the superannuation product market. It has been a concern of banks—I emphasise banks again because we believe that this legislation is largely driven by banks—for a number of years that allegedly they have been denied access to the superannuation money pool. This is incorrect. They do have substantial access through their wholesale management funds arms and they are particularly successful, I would have to say, in this area. So it is not correct for banks to assert that they do not have access to the superannuation money pool in this country.

The Labor opposition will be moving amendments to ensure that superannuation funds are able to offer RSAs. This would mean that the superannuation funds would be able to provide a deposit style account which is capital guaranteed. By allowing the superannuation funds to compete in the RSA market, this will ensure competitive neutrality and ensure the government matches its own rhetoric with action.

We believe that, if superannuation funds are able to offer RSAs, then members' moneys will ultimately be better managed. This will occur due to the fact that the various industry funds and also existing employer in‐house funds, often forgotten in this debate, have to manage their funds on a trust basis under the sole purpose test which requires fund trustees to manage fund moneys to effect a retirement income for the member.

On the issue of fees and charges, I have already emphasised that we believe that this product is driven by the banks. Of course, in dealing with banks with respect to superannuation we should not neglect to mention the issue of fees and charges. The community is all too well aware of the existing level of fees and charges that banks charge. The rhetoric of RSAs is to provide a low cost, simple superannuation account to low income earners, or to provide a low risk product to individuals who are approaching retirement. The Liberal and National parties also believe that RSAs will provide increased competition in the product market, resulting in the driving down of fees and charges.

BREAK.PARA: If we look at current fees and charges in both industry funds and in‐house employer funds, the charges range between 80c and $1.20 a week in administrative costs. In fact, many employer in‐house funds make no charge at all—the employer picks up the cost. Concerns have been raised regarding the excessive fees and charges that banks already apply to low growth and small amount deposit accounts.

In the recent additional estimates proceedings, the Insurance and Superannuation Commission was asked whether any government body would be monitoring fees and charges. The ISC responded that, to the best of its knowledge, there would be no monitoring of fees and charges. And here we are opening up a totally new product range to the banks in this country. The Credit Unions Cooperative of Australia gave evidence that their members would not be charging any fees and charges with respect to RSAs. The Australian Bankers Association gave evidence to the Senate committee to the effect that their members would charge fees that would be competitive with current fees and charges levied by general superannuation funds.

Further concerns were raised regarding the capital guarantee nature of the product—that is, the capital guarantee provides that the account cannot be diminished by negative returns or losses. The contractual agreement between the provider and the holder is to return to the holder of the RSA all contributions made to the account. In the event of a bank achieving negative investment returns, these cannot be debited from the holder's account. Notwithstanding this, the product—as it is currently designed—does allow banks, building societies or life offices to debit fees, charges and taxes from the holder's account which could result in the account balance being less than the contributions. Labor will be moving amendments to ensure that, as RSAs are a capital guarantee product, the accounts cannot be reduced in any way by fees, charges and taxes, as is the general case with other superannuation products.

Some banks, particularly the National Australia Bank and ANZ, have announced—I suppose, from their perspective, quite proper ly—that they want to make a profit by making fees and charges. That is reasonable in that context. But we say it is not proper for banks in particular to make a profit through fees and charges through having the ability to reduce the member's account balance. We will certainly be arguing and moving amendments in that regard.

It is very important to remember that superannuation is a different form of saving from that of traditional bank products, due to its compulsory and long‐term nature. Therefore, it is entirely appropriate with a product of that type, being one of a low rate of return, that the balance is protected from what in the past, with respect to banks, have been excessive fees and charges in some areas.

The next issue I want to turn to is third line forcing. As the bills are currently drafted, an employer is entitled to open an RSA on behalf of an employee without an employee's consent. In some circumstances it may prove beneficial to the employer, not to the employee, to put all their employees into an RSA due to the relationship the employer may have with their bank.

The Australian Bankers Association has agreed that it is normal commercial practice for a bank to provide incentives for employers to engage in relationship banking. In other words, the bank goes to the employer and says, `Look, let's have a package deal. We'll offer you a lower interest rate on your general borrowings, commercial or personal, if you give us something in return, that is, your business.' It is not inconceivable for a bank to provide the incentive of a half to a full percentage point off a business's line of credit, should an employer make a choice and coerce employees, and open RSAs on behalf of the employees. It is certainly not inconceivable.

We believe that it is absolutely imperative that there should be no third line forcing, or coercion of employees, in respect of considerations relating to the employer's interests, which are absolutely opposed to the employees' interests in respect of their superannuation. We will be moving quite specific amendments to limit or outlaw third line forcing, as it is known.

The next issue is health warnings. RSAs are to be marketed as a simple, low cost, low risk product. The focus of the marketing strategy will be to highlight that RSAs are simple, low cost products which are simple to understand, due to the fact that they will be provided by the banks. It will be interesting to see the marketing strategy, because I do not think banks will be able to convince a lot of the populace about this. Anyway, we are sure they will attempt to do it.

There is no doubt that RSAs are a low return product. There is no doubt also that a consumer who is in a low return product, over a longer term—three, five, 10, 15 years—as they may well be in this case, will get a lower end benefit than if they are in a traditional superannuation product, because of the lower interest rate. Research undertaken by the Australian Consumers Association suggests that, if an individual were to remain in an RSA for the period of their working life, they could lose up to $200,000 in end retirement benefit because of the lower interest rate. Interest on interest provides a very substantial proportion of retirement income.

Concerns have been raised regarding the level of information an employee may or may not receive prior to a RSA being opened. It has been suggested that a health warning should be given prior to the account being opened and at critical points during the lifetime of the product, and then again when the account reaches $10,000. The Australian Consumers Association suggested that no RSA should be allowed to be above $10,000 except in situations where the RSA is being used as a safe investment vehicle, just prior to retirement.

It is a Labor suggestion that account balances in RSAs should be kept at a maximum. To do so is, in reality, going to be difficult, but we will be attempting it through the series of health warnings that should be required to be issued. Certainly the Australian consumer organisations believe in a predetermined level of $10,000 and that a health warning must be communicated to the member. The health warning should ensure the holder is informed of the dangers of a low risk, low return product, is informed that a RSA is not an appropriate superannuation product and is given comparable information about industry funds, traditional in‐house employer funds, public offer funds and master trusts.

The last area that I want to deal with is the cooling‐off period. Currently the bills provide for a 14-day cooling‐off period for employees to determine whether they do want an RSA or not. The period applies from the day on which the employee receives information regarding the account. It is important to note that, as the bills are currently drafted, the account will already have been opened on an employee's behalf by the employer. The bills as currently drafted do not make it clear when the 14-day cooling‐off period actually begins. In the event of the employee deciding not to continue with the RSA, the provider must transfer any contributions out of the account to the fund the employee directs them to, and not charge any administrative fees.

We will certainly be seeking to extend the cooling‐off period from 14 days to 28 days. We will be moving amendments disallowing an RSA provider from opening an account prior to the employee receiving the relevant disclosure and information documents regarding the RSA.

In the time available I have highlighted a number of the major concerns we have with this legislation, and my colleagues who are participating in this debate will be doing the same. In concluding, I want to reiterate that the Labor opposition has a number of major concerns about the way in which the Liberal National Party coalition is approaching superannuation policy in this country. Our prediction is that if products of this type are passed by the Senate without the types of safeguards that Labor is going to be highlighting and moving amendments to, and if legislation of the type in respect to this new superannuation tax is passed by this Senate next week, unamended, there will be chaos in the superannuation industry in this country.

I take this opportunity to give a general health warning to the government. They haven't seen anything yet if this sort of legislation goes through unamended. The degree of uncertainty in the general community, the general concern that is mounting about this government's approach to superannuation legislation, is very significant. It is growing every day and it is massive, to judge by the number of complaints that my colleagues and I, and I know government members, are receiving on various superannuation legislation. They proceed with this approach on superannuation in an unamended form at their peril.

From a political perspective, we believe that it is a great tragedy that superannuation in this country is being undermined to the degree that it is by this new government's approach. It will be at their peril and their cost, as they will find in the coming years, if this sort of legislation passes this place unamended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop, Sen Mark

TALK.START.PARA: —In this debate I wish to briefly address a number of topical concerns. They are, firstly, the history and development of occupational superannuation in Australia; secondly, the potential impact upon low income, casual and other part-time workers and those approaching retirement; and thirdly, the issue of fees.

SPEECH.PARA: Turning to the history and development of occupational superannuation in Australia, as pointed out in the opposition senators' report, the superannuation guarantee charge legislation was the first pillar in what has become a unique system of superannuation savings in the world. It was based upon three readily understood principles: firstly, compulsory employer contributions; secondly, the ability to voluntarily save for retirement; and thirdly, the continuance of a universal pension safety net.

The system of compulsory superannuation was designed around two aims. Firstly, there was the funding of a decent standard of retirement income and the achievement of that end to be consistent with intergenerational equity. In other words, the SGC had a policy objective of today's workers forgoing some of today's income to fund a decent standard of living in tomorrow's retirement. The key point to note in this context is that Australian workers were funding their own retirement out of their own wages. It was, and is, a remarkable example of user pays today for tomorrow's benefit.

That initial forgone wage rise of three per cent was to grow to nine per cent by 2002 and be matched later by a government contribution of three per cent and an employee contribution of another three per cent. The final mix was to be a nine per cent employer contribution, a three per cent employee contribution and a three per cent government contribution.

In another life I was heavily involved in the introduction, explanation and selling of occupational superannuation to a somewhat surprised work force in the period 1987 to 1992. It was indeed a surprise because in the retail, wholesale and warehousing industries, superannuation was a relatively rare benefit in those days. In retail it was confined almost exclusively to employees who fell within the following categories: they were permanent employees; they were full-time employees; they were almost exclusively management employees; and, they were almost exclusively male employees.

The work force, of course, was notable for different features, at least since the 1970s, with the changing nature of employment and trading hours. The work force is now, and has been since 1970, notable for these features: heavy numbers of casual and part‐time workers; an overwhelming dominance of non‐full‐time workers; a work force that is heavily award based—there are few over‐award payments—and a work force, as our eyes will tell us and the statistics confirm, that is 75 to 80 per cent female.

Logically and in practice, 90 per cent of the retail work force in the middle to late 1980s was denied access to superannuation. It was, essentially, a perk offered to a few on the management side, as an incentive to remain with a particular firm. Of course, often that incentive was illusory because most of the vesting did not commence until year 15 of service with a particular firm. Even in the years around 1970, there were few employees who chose to remain for more than 15 years and hence become entitled to some form of vested benefit in superannuation.

BREAK.PARA: Understanding the nature of the work force in a lot of service industries means that it is no understatement to say that the introduction of compulsory superannuation was a surprise, if not a shock. That award based occupational superannuation system, developed through industry funds, is now offering the following benefits. Firstly, contrary to popular wisdom, the system has very low administrative costs, often as low as 50c per week or $25 per year. Secondly, it has high levels of return, particularly in a time of low inflation. The real returns of many funds, particularly the larger industry funds, averaged over the past eight or nine years something between eight and 12 per cent, which is quite a commendable performance. Thirdly and most importantly, there are extensive provisions—through an adequate trustee structure supported under the regulations made under the relevant act—to prevent fraud, misappropriation or financial misuse.
In that historical context, one looks at the problems arising from superannuation arrangements and addressed by the Treasurer (Mr Costello). On 20 August, in his press release, he said:

RSAs will be a simple, low cost, low risk product especially suited to those with small amounts of superannuation, such as itinerant and casual workers, those wishing to amalgamate several small superannuation accounts and those nearing retirement (wishing to minimise risk).

Let us look at those three groups of individuals. With regard to those with small amounts of superannuation, the example given was of casual workers. In this debate, I discount itinerant workers because they have become a very minor, if not non‐existent, feature of agricultural society, with the heavy use of technology and capital in recent years.

Certainly, at the turn of the century and right up until the 1950s, there was a heavily itinerant work force engaged as railway fettlers, shearers, farm labourers, town labourers and the like. The itinerant work force on the agricultural side has almost disappeared. The itinerant work force on the development side has almost disappeared, because most of the development that is occurring involves work of the nature of two or three weeks at a location and then a week off—particularly in mining, bridge building, road maintenance and other such industries. So, I think it is fair to discount any significant numbers of itinerant workers needing access to a different superannuation system. But, in terms of casual workers, that is an issue—as it is for those wishing to amalgamate several small superannuation accounts and those approaching retirement.

As I analysed the bill and reflected upon its likely consequences, I came to the view that the government is most likely to fail in the objects it has set itself. Firstly, turning to casual workers, currently under the Superannuation Guarantee Charge Act large numbers of casual workers are exempt from employer sponsored superannuation contributions. Workers who earn less than $450 per month or workers who work less than 30 hours per week and are under the age of 18 are not a cost to the employer in terms of occupational superannuation because the act specifically excludes the employer from making contributions. When one analyses the ABS statistics on work force age composition, the overwhelming bulk of junior, casual and junior part‐time employees do not currently receive occupational superannuation.

It is further proposed, I understand, that the Superannuation Guarantee Charge Act will be amended to increase that exemption level from $450 per month to $900 per month. Nine hundred dollars per month is $225 per week. For most award employees, that is around $10 per hour. So with the foreshadowed amendments to the Superannuation Guarantee Charge Act to lift the exemption level, nearly all junior workers and most non full‐time employees working less than 20 hours per week will not qualify for occupational superannuation whilst so employed. Therefore, in terms of objective 1, the government proposes a solution to a problem that does not exist in any meaningful way or has the most minimal application. One asks the obvious question as to why the government invents a non‐existent solution for a non‐existent problem.

Secondly, turning to the issue of multiple accounts, there are two possible permutations: firstly, multiple accounts relating to multiple jobs by one employee at the one time; and, secondly, multiple accounts relating to successive jobs held by one employee over time. Looking at the first group, the bill does not solve that problem because it expressly authorises—indeed, encourages—individual employers to open individual RSAs in the financial institution of their choice. The Treasurer, in his press release, was probably talking of the second class of employees that I raised—that is, multiple accounts of one employee in successive jobs over time.

I acknowledge up front the potential problems: it is sometimes messy, there are some administrative fees problems and some accounts stand to be lost over time. But a simple solution does exist in the transference of funds from one account requirement—and I recommend it to the government. All you need to do now is to fill out a transfer form, post it to your new superannuation fund, they forward it to the administrators of the old superannuation fund and the account balance is transferred and consolidated in the new account. Thousands of those transactions occur every week in the superannuation industry. I used to sit on the board of a fairly large fund which received the reports from the administrators of thousands of transfers on that basis. So under current superannuation arrangements, a simple solution already exists for a real problem. This bill does not address that.

Turning to the issue of those nearing retirement, it is said that these older people wish to minimise their risk. It is a fairly legitimate proposition. As people become older, they become more cautious and pay more attention to financial security. Indeed, the financial industry would advise young people to take a particular form of investment and older people to invest in products that give security. To return to the current bill, the desire to minimise risk is easily achieved by superannuation funds offering different investment mixes. Those who are more interested in a higher return can invest in equity products. That is more suitable for younger people who intend to remain in the work force for a significant period of time. In terms of capital guaranteed products for lower risk applicants, the obvious option is to appeal to older people.

The problem that exists is that when super funds survey members on this point, there is little to zero interest in the type of product that is being offered. So, again, we have an inappropriate solution to a problem that hardly exists or, at best, a solution already exists by offering the option of a differing investment mix.
Debate interrupted.
