—My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, will you confirm that the government is undertaking the most substantial and fundamental changes to assistance for the unemployed since the establishment of the CES 50 years ago? Given that Labor's only response has been to accuse the government of trying to change the definition of unemployment, will you advise whether the government has any intention of changing the definition of unemployment or is this just merely another sign that the opposition is incapable of dealing with serious policy issues, particularly those affecting workers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator O'Chee for the question. It is true that this government seeks to introduce and implement the most radical changes in delivery of employment services to unemployed Australians since the introduction of the CES about 50 years ago. But today on Adelaide radio, Martin Ferguson accused the government of trying to redefine unemployment out of existence. He knows full well—he should know, as a former president of the ACTU—that unemployment is measured by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. The definitions used by the bureau have not changed under the Howard government, and there is no plan to change them.

ANSWER.PARA: He accused us of asserting that a 20 hour‐a‐week job is a full‐time job. He should know full well that that relates to when a final outcome fee will be paid to a case manager looking after, on a one‐to‐one basis, a long‐term unemployed person. The issue for this government—and it should have been the issue for the previous government—is placing the unemployed in a position that will make them independent of government assistance, to give them that independence.

The issue of whether or not a job is real does not relate to the number of hours worked. A 10 hour‐a‐week part‐time job is a real job. That person may still want more work and may still get some income support, but it is, nonetheless, a real job. We are saying that, if you get someone off benefit, we will consider that you have got them a real job; and that will be about 20 hours of work a week.

Look at the hypocrisy of this, Madam President. Under Labor's Working Nation case management guidelines, outcome fees were paid to case managers. Guess what for? For putting people into make work programs like the new work opportunities scheme. You did not even have to give them 10 hours of full unsubsidised work; you just had to plonk them in a new work opportunities scheme—into some six‐month rock painting program.

BREAK.PARA: These were the Labor make work programs that simply shuffled and churned the unemployed mercilessly through program after program without getting positive outcomes. We are getting rid of those. We are shifting to a system where case managers will get their final outcome payments when someone has had a real job—that is, an unsubsidised job—for about six months. Something that Labor cannot seem to come to grips with is that that is the purpose of putting someone into case management.

What was Labor's second outcome fee payment for? It was for putting a job seeker into a job for 20 hours plus a week or more. So Martin Ferguson either does not understand what Labor's Working Nation was trying to do or he was prepared to be quite deceptive on radio this morning by pretending that somehow what we are doing is a bad thing when he knows it is not.

If those definitions of outcomes were satisfactory for Labor, they certainly should be satisfactory for us. But our outcomes demand more—they demand better service for unemployed Australians. Let me repeat: we will pay for outcomes that get people off benefits, that give them independence, that give them a real job.

Nonetheless, it is very important to understand that, for every job an unemployed person got because they participated in new work opportunities that they would not otherwise have got, the net impact cost of a new work opportunities placement was $143,000. So the people opposite have no credibility and are in no position whatsoever to realistically discuss what should happen for unemployed Australians. All of this is coming from a government that after 13 years in office left Australia with deplorable unemployment. I can see that my time is running out. If I had more time, I would give Senator O'Chee a fuller answer. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Given Mr Ferguson's comments, perhaps Senator Vanstone could elaborate on how the track record of the Labor Party in failing to deal with things could be compared with the plans that the current government has to ensure that we get real outcomes for people who are genuinely affected.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —How intuitive of you, Senator O'Chee, to ask me such a question. I congratulate you. Madam President, if you had heard the radio this morning, you would not have believed it: Martin Ferguson saying, `The truth is we had a terrific record in government for job creation.' There he was on Adelaide radio. These are the people who destroyed something like 421,000 jobs with the recession we had to have. You people destroyed 421,000 jobs with the recession we had to have.

ANSWER.PARA: Trend unemployment was at or above 10 per cent for 33 consecutive months when you were in government. For 32 consecutive months, unemployment was at its highest since World War II. Martin Ferguson, with that appalling record, goes on radio and says, `The truth is we had a terrific record on job creation.' You had better start learning to stop lying, because you will never get re‐elected while you keep putting that trash over the radio.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Finance. I draw the minister's attention to section 21B of the Parliamentary Contributory Superannuation Act 1948, a provision of which states that parliamentary superannuation is reduced because of the holding of a government job. Can the minister confirm that former Senator Michael Baume, now Consul‐General in New York, Mr John Spender, now Australian Ambassador in Paris and Mr Andrew Peacock, now Australian Ambassador in Washington, are covered by this provision in the act? Can the minister further confirm that section 21B does not apply to Senator Short's $150,000 tax‐free job in London?

—Senator, you have raised an issue concerning the parliamentary pension scheme in relation to people who are currently employed by the government in government funded jobs. There is a rule, I understand, in relation to those schemes. As for the specific details, I will check with the Minister for Finance and see whether there is some addi tional information I can give the parliament. In relation to Senator Short's employment, it is not a government funded job, as I understand.
—It's jobs for the boys.

—My understanding, Senator Faulkner, was that that appointment was welcomed by Senator Sherry. I think you stood up and congratulated him. Is that right, Senator? I will see whether there is any additional information I can give to the parliament.

—Will the minister approach Senator Short and ask him to undertake the same sacrifice as his three Liberal colleagues, and have his superannuation reduced for the life of his government appointed job?
—Don't look to Senator Short for the answer.

—Why would I look to the person who is involved in the question? Why would I do such a thing, Senator Faulkner? I am advised that Senator Short has voluntarily agreed to abide by the existing provisions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism. Minister, you will be aware that the car industry is—

QUESTION.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Just a moment, Senator Lees. I cannot hear Senator Lees. There is far too much noise on both sides. Senators will cease conversing across the chamber.

—You will be aware, Minister, that the car industry is a very important industry for my home state of South Australia, but are you aware of the reported comments from the South Australian Premier? In the Financial Review , he said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . tariff reform had become Australia's de facto industry policy . . .

Do you agree with your former Senate colleague's blunt accusation that your government has no industry policy? Do you agree that, without an industry policy, you could realise Premier Olsen's fear that the 2007 Adelaide Car Show may showcase 350 models of fully imported vehicles?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Senator, for your question. I am pleased to see that apparently Senator Murray's interest in industry is spreading to other people in the Democrats. But do not hold your breath, because you will have to convince other people within the Democrats to change a whole lot of industry policy. The Democrats would have a carbon tax. They want to increase input costs on the car industry and they have the audacity to get up here and talk about this.

ANSWER.PARA: There can be absolutely no doubt about the government's position on the automotive industry and the review of future policy. The Prime Minister and the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism have both made it clear. The government is fully committed to the future viability of the automotive manufacturing industry in Australia. This is reflected in the terms of reference of the Productivity Commission inquiry itself, as stated in the House yesterday by the Prime Minister. Of course, we understand that the automotive industry is a major employer, a major producer of value added exports and a major source of investment and innovation. It should not surprise anyone that there will be a range of views on this significant issue from the industry itself and from the leaders of those states and regions where industry is located.

The South Australian and Victorian premiers understandably have strong views about the issue and have every right to put those views forward. But, as the Prime Minister said yesterday, this government will do precisely what the opposition did in government. The only difference is that we will listen to the views and, when we have the final Productivity Commission report, we will make a decision that takes into account the interests of all Australians. The only reason the opposition has chosen to enter the car debate now is sheer desperation. It has pinched the minority draft report of the commission and attempted to pass it off in its policy.

It is interesting to look at Labor's record when in government. In 1984, shortly after Labor came to office, annual car production in Australia stood at 370,000 units. When they left office in 1996, production was 314,000 units. In the interim, in the same period, Nissan closed down production and Australia had largely lost the capacity to produce small cars like the Ford Laser. In 1984, import penetration was around 20 per cent. In 1996, as a response to Labor's policies, import penetration was around 50 per cent. Under Labor, employment in the industry declined from around 70,000 to 45,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Madam President: I did not ask about the previous Labor government's policy. I asked a specific question regarding this government's policy and their response to Premier Olsen.
—Order! Senator Parer, I draw your attention to the question asked. I am sure you are building up to the answer.

—Thank you, Madam President. I think I have already answered the one in respect of Premier Olsen and, in fact, Premier Kennett. I draw to the Senate's attention that the Productivity Commission, in its recent draft report on the automotive industry, noted that progress had been especially slow in labour market reform, government regulations, and in the economic infrastructure supporting the industry, especially the waterfront, shipping and rail transport.

ANSWER.PARA: I find it interesting that the Labor opposition favours a pause in tariffs and a review prior to resuming their reduction, while at the same time insisting that Australia maintain its commitments to APEC. A question you should well ask the Labor Party, Senator, is that they specify how these contradictory objectives could be achieved. They might also indicate how certainty could be maintained for the purpose of planning investments. The government recognises that the car industry plays a very significant role in the Australian economy. We are not about to become its executioner.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will try again because, as I have already said, I did not want a re‐run of what you thought of the previous government's policy. I will try again to see whether we can find yours. Firstly, Minister, do you stand by your election commitment to actually increase the number of jobs in the manufacturing industry by some 200,000? If you do, will you please publish your policy so we can see whether or not these claims are accurate and, in particular, so that the 55,200 people who have already lost their jobs since you came to office may have some hope, may see some light at the end of the tunnel and have a chance of getting their job back?

—I think this is becoming very repetitive. It would seem to me that Senator Lees really has not listened to half of my answers to questions asked by Senator Murray. We are not deviating from our election commitment, as I have explained over and over again, to set proper economic policies in this country that are going to mean a very real increase in very real jobs.

—Madam President, my question is directed to you. Is it a fact that the Australian Federal Police have visited the Department of the Senate regarding its investigation into Senator Colston's travel allowance irregularities? Did the Australian Federal Police inquire as to the methodology being used in the Senate investigation? Did they make any comments as to the methodology? Did they request to see copies of the reports? Was the request granted? Have the Australian Federal Police expressed to you or your department any concern about the investigative process up until now and into the future?

—I have no information about the Australian Federal Police making such inquiries or talking to Senate officers. I shall make inquiries. If there are answers to those questions, I will bring them to you.
—I wish to ask a supplementary question, Madam President. Thank you for that response. If you find that that is the case, I would appreciate an indication of when those inquiries were made.
—Certainly.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer the minister to the Prime Minister's statement in the House of Representatives on 4 February 1997 in rela tion to the Constitutional Convention and, in particular, to his statement that the appointed delegates will include an appropriate proportion of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and young people between the ages of 18 and 24. On what basis will the 76 appointed members be selected? Can the minister provide an assurance that an adequate reflection of the diversity of community views on the republic and other constitutional issues will be represented in the convention? Does the minister agree that as well as the need for appropriate representation of young people and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, consideration should also be given to ensuring that 50 per cent of the delegates are women and that people from multicultural backgrounds are also adequately represented?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Some of the matters referred to by Senator Margetts are still being determined.
—Working out the result first before you get the method.

—No, the Prime Minister has said, as Senator Margetts said correctly, that it is his intention that the appointed delegates will include representatives of key groups, such as young people and indigenous Australians, who may not be well represented in election outcomes. It follows from that that it is the Prime Minister's desire that the appointed representatives will represent a diversity of groups.

ANSWER.PARA: I understand that before any announcement is made on that, there will be some consultations between the Prime Minister's parliamentary secretary, Senator Minchin, who is advising him on this matter, and other party leaders and Independents. Senator Margetts, you might like to take the opportunity to consult with Senator Minchin and ensure that your views are put to the Prime Minister on this particular matter.

We will soon be introducing the bill that will provide for the election. Our concentration to date has been on the election procedures. Some of these ancillary matters are now receiving the attention that will give the answers to your questions in due course.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Madam President. Will the list of appointed delegates be finalised and made public before nominations open for election to the convention? Considering that the minister mentioned a diversity of groups—he did not mention a diversity of views—will an answer be given to the question on whether a diversity of views on the republic and other constitutional issues will be included, or will we see a constitutional version of the Hillary Clinton luncheon list?

—That is most unkind and most ungenerous. It is somewhat curious that until today Senator Margetts was totally opposed to the convention and is now giving us advice on its construction. But, anyway, we take advice from all those who wish to offer it. I did say that I understand that the Prime Minister would wish to see a diversity of views represented. I do not think the timing of the appointments has been formalised. When it is, no doubt it will be brought to Senator Margetts's attention.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. Has Minister Jull received a report from his department relating to Senator Colston's use of parliamentary entitlements? Was the spokesman from the Department of Administrative Services correctly quoted yesterday when he said that this matter would not be tabled in the parliament? Thirdly, what does the minister intend to do with the report? Fourthly, has the minister communicated the contents of that report to any other government minister or the Prime Minister?
—Senator Ray has asked a number of questions in relation to issues regarding Senator Colston and travel allowances.
—Whatever you do, don't look down.
—I am going to look down because I have a brief here from the Minister for Finance. It would not be surprising if I actually read that brief to you.
—Don't be such a hypocrite.

—You are a very unpleasant person, Senator Faulkner. You are a genuinely very unpleasant person. I received a call from a constituent who asked me whether Senator Faulkner was as nasty in private life as he appears to be on TV. I had to say that the answer was yes.
—Answer the question.
—That is what I said: the answer is yes. The brief from the Minister for Finance reads as follows—
—Administrative Services is the minister we asked you about.
—Sorry, the Minister for Administrative Services. The brief reads as follows:

BREAK.PARA: There are a number of allegations concerning Senator Colston and his alleged misuse of entitlements. The department is currently, as a matter of priority, examining its records to determine whether there may be any substance to the allegations concerning the misuse of Commonwealth vehicles and other parliamentary entitlements. Both the Prime Minister and the Minister for Administrative Services have indicated the government takes these and any allegations concerning the misuse of entitlements very seriously. We will offer no comfort to anyone found to have abused their entitlements.

The department's examination will be a full and thorough examination and Senator Colston will be given an opportunity to respond to any matters which are raised. The report will be ready only when this process is completed, and I will not be directing my department to take—
again, this is the Minister for Administrative Services—
any short cuts or derail the process of natural justice merely to satisfy the opposition's thirst for revenge.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. First, you might like to check the date of that advice you have just read. You might like to also go back and check after question time, and give an answer today or tomorrow, whether in fact the report has been received, as I understand it has been. No-one here has yet asked for you to disclose any details of that report, so there is not much point you arguing that we are trying to interfere with the course of natural justice here. What we have asked is what you are going to do with the report and whether it has been communicated at this point to any other minister or the Prime Minister or, indeed, Senator Colston or any of his staff. I would ask, because these are factual questions that do not impinge on the content of the report, for you to promptly get an answer as soon as you can and put it down in this chamber.

—I note the further questions that have been raised by Senator Ray. Senator, I will refer those questions to Minister Jull, and I will come back to the chamber and deliver his response as soon as practicable.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, is about economic independence. Since the election last year, the coalition government has encouraged and promoted economic independence for indigenous Australians so that they may take control of their own destinies and move away from a dependence mentality fostered by the previous government. Minister, will you please give details of a recent joint venture, which you endorsed, between the Ernest Henry mine and the Koutha Aboriginal Development Corporation, that will provide employment opportunities and other economic benefits for Aboriginal people in the region?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Watson for the question, because there are very encouraging signs occurring in a number of areas along those lines that Senator Watson referred to. Last week I had great pleasure in being part of the official signing of a commercial contract between Mount Isa Mines, Ernest Henry copper‐gold mine and the Koutha Aboriginal Development Corporation of Cloncurry. The Koutha Aboriginal Development Corporation and joint venture partners Gulf Transport will carry concentrate 160 kilometres from Ernest Henry to Mount Isa for smelting. The joint venture is expected to produce annual revenue of $3 million and will create 12 to 14 full-time jobs for local Aboriginal people.

ANSWER.PARA: The ATSIC chairman, Gatjil Djerrkura, said the announcement of the first commercial joint venture for the Koutha Aboriginal Development Corporation was something for indigenous communities elsewhere to celebrate and emulate. He said:

Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people know that economic independence is the only way we will achieve financial independence and provide a meaningful future for our children. And this means finding opportunities for attracting investment and business partnerships from non-indigenous sources.

As I have said many times in this chamber, this government is committed to achieving economic independence for indigenous Australians. I have cited many examples where Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people are adopting this philosophy, and they can see the tangible differences in their communities. Indigenous Australians are starting to see that we are very different from the Labor Party and the Labor government. Unlike Labor, we will not let indigenous Australians live in squalid conditions without taking decisive action to implore the situation.

You will recall, Madam President, that I was criticised for the army-ATSIC joint venture. That is a very decisive action that we have taken. We are doing pilot projects, as you know. We all remember Graham Richardson's dramatic promises of fundamental changes, which were made for the cameras that accompanied him. Those promises, of course, never eventuated. The other day, Senator Collins, I was up at Wallaby camp—the place where former Senator Richardson was at and the great drama that occurred out of that. Do you know what has happened at that camp, Madam President? Nothing. Not a thing has been touched.

This government does not believe in the dependence mentality. We believe that self-empowerment and economic independence are the only way indigenous Australians are going to create a positive future for themselves and their children. They believe that too, because they can see that is the only way to go. That is the message that is coming from the communities. Senator Collins, you may be inter ested to know that I have been to 60 communities now throughout Australia, and I am still travelling.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wow!
—Yes, it is many more. I was at the ATSIC office the other day in Perth. I am the first minister ever to go to the ATSIC office in Perth.
—Wow!
—Where was your minister for six years, Senator Collins? He never went to the Perth ATSIC office. They have never been there. I was the first minister ever to go to the ATSIC office in Perth.

ANSWER.PARA: For the first time in a long time, indigenous Australians and the government are working towards a common goal. While it will take many years to repair the damage of our predecessors, I can already see progress with ventures such as the one embarked on by the Koutha Aboriginal Development Corporation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Hill, the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Minister, do you believe that Senator Colston is a man of integrity? I ask you, Senator Hill: do you continue to support him as Deputy President of the Senate?
—I believe that all senators are honourable.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Is the minister aware of comments by some universities that they are willing to flout the 25 per cent quota for fee paying undergraduate places and they are going to do this by offering the up-front fee paying places, paying the $9,000 per EFTSU fine and then pocketing the difference? Given that fees as much as $110,000 have been mooted, does the minister agree that a $9,000 per EFTSU fine on universities who breach the guidelines in legislation is unworkable and ineffective and a bad way of ensuring that HECS liable places are maintained?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Senator, for the question. I did see a report of those sorts of suggestions last week allegedly emanating from, as I understand it, Monash University, which allegedly had a plan to minimise their government funded enrolments, pay the appropriate fine on that and thereby encourage students into buying a place at Monash. I can assure you that I had my office immediately make enquiries about that. I have verbally been advised that Monash says that this story is not true. I have yet to have that in writing from either my department—or at least on by desk in writing—or, for that matter, from Monash.

ANSWER.PARA: I can assure you, Senator Stott Despoja, of two things—one of which I am sure you already know—and that is that where there is a bucket of money, the vice-chancellors are around the bucket. They will always be trying to maximise the financial outcomes for their universities. In a sense, that is not a bad thing, because we want them to act not like businesses but to be businesslike. We do not want them to be frivolous with money, and there is a difference.

I see you, Senator Stott Despoja, smiling at the distinction I am drawing. There is a distinction and it is a very important one to bear in mind for universities. We do not want them to be businesses and simply churn products out irrespective of quality. But, at the same time, we do want them to have some considerable concern for the Commonwealth dollars that they are using. We want them not to be businesses, but to be businesslike.

The second thing that you might not have known and need some reassurance on is that I have not the slightest intention of allowing universities in any way to subvert the government's plans to provide more undergraduate places to Australian students. You would have discovered last year, Senator Stott Despoja, as the vice-chancellors would have discovered, that I am not about to walk away from an argument if they want to have one. I am not about to let them subvert the government's plans and minimise government funded enrolments. It simply will not happen.

BREAK.PARA: If I have to make changes to the regulations, if I have to come back and get changes to the legislation in order to ensure that they cannot do that, I will do that. I look forward to your support, because this government has made it unequivocally clear that we want to protect the government funded undergraduate places and keep the limit for fee paying places at 25 per cent.

Not one university will successfully do this in any substantial way—there might be universities which are under-enrolled by one or two or a few students here and there. But there will not be a plan that escapes our notice and will not be dealt with promptly and harshly. Any university that tries that will be subject by this government—and I trust by you—to public ridicule.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for that answer and for that assurance, but I seek further clarification. In investigating ways that you will stop universities minimising government funded places or perhaps stopping them subverting the process, as you call it, will you investigate harsher penalties, for example, a higher amount in the penalties and the fines per EFTSU—higher, certainly, than $9,000—so that these are a real financial disincentive for institutions to subvert the process in any way?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, there will be a range of ways, presumably, that we could address any such plans. As I say, I have been verbally advised that Monash says that there is no truth in this and that they are not seeking to do that. I have not spoken to people at Monash directly myself but I take what I have been told to be true until I can ascertain otherwise. I can assure you that we will look at every option. I am absolutely determined to see that this will not happen.

ANSWER.PARA: Equally, I want to be sure that any university that has a small problem in under-enrolment is not overly penalised for that—because it is hard for them on a year to year basis to get it spot on—because of the evil plans of some others. We are not even satisfied yet that there are evil plans there. But I do know that when there is a bucket of money, the universities will be after it.

BREAK.PARA: You can have the greatest possible confidence that I am not about to walk away from this. I think the universities learnt last year that when we say we mean it we do mean it. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, is it true that on 17 March, your nemesis, Dr Kemp, attacked Australian teachers accusing them of not spending enough classroom time on basic literacy skills and having lost focus on what was important in schooling? Is it true that in Tuesday's Herald‐Sun , Dr Kemp, once again without consulting you, is quoted as encouraging schools to act as job placement agencies contracting with the government to provide employment for young people? How will expanding the role of schools into employment agencies enable them to concentrate on improving literacy skills? What exactly is the government's view of the primary function of schools?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Carr for his question. He just does not seem to understand that the truth is not always found in the newspapers. He should understand that. But, as time goes by, he will eventually come to understand it. Dr Kemp is not about attacking teachers. He recognises the value of teachers and has consistently made that point. Teachers are a very valuable resource. They look after our children—our best and brightest, and those who perhaps are not our brightest and who perhaps need teaching assistance even more.

ANSWER.PARA: What he has said, however, is that he is concerned, and rightly so, about literacy levels in Australian schools. You ought to know a lot about this, Senator Carr, because it is your party that was in government for the last 13 years and which did very little about this. Your party has let Australian students down. Your party has people leaving secondary school with inadequate literacy levels and inadequate numeracy skills. You know, as every other person over there knows, that when you let a kid leave secondary school with inadequate literacy and numeracy skills you are increasing their chances, heaven knows how many fold, of being unemployed and staying unemployed for a very long time. You are certainly predetermining the opportunities for the rest of their life. You are predetermining that they will be in a low skilled, low paid job for the rest of their life.

So, before you get on your high horse and ask us about what we are doing, you might like to contemplate, Senator Carr, what your government in the past 13 years, when it had an opportunity, simply failed to do. I would say that one thing we ought to expect from our schools is appropriate numeracy and literacy skills when you leave school. Surely you can agree that that is something we ought to be getting from our schools: students with adequate literacy and numeracy skills. You should agree with that.

Your second question related to employment placement enterprises. Dr Kemp has raised on a number of occasions over a significant period of time—perhaps when you were not listening—the opportunities or otherwise for schools to become employment placement enterprises. He has raised this matter with me on a number of occasions and I know he has raised it with a number of schools. Dr Kemp understands in a way that your party never did that schools are not there just for the 25 per cent of school leavers who go to university. You might like that, and all of you over there with degrees might think that is the function of a school, but it is not what we think over here. The other 75 per cent of students who go out of secondary school and who do not go to university are looking for better vocational training than your government ever provided, and they are looking for a job.

If the schools want to judge their level of success, they ought not do so simply by the number of students who go to university. They might like to look at the other 75 per cent of students and look at those who wanted a job and got one. To the extent that the schools turn their mind to that, I will be very pleased and Dr Kemp will be very pleased.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question. Minister, has your nemesis, Dr Kemp, informed you how schools' new employment functions will be funded? What provisions will be made to ensure that Commonwealth funded resources within a school's global budget are not siphoned away from literacy and numeracy programs to administer job placement programs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, it is just a gift for you to get up and demonstrate your lack of understanding about how the new employment services market will work. It will work quite simply like this: if an employment placement enterprise has a contract with DEETYA and successfully places someone in employment, they will get a placement outcome fee. If the employment placement enterprise happened to be a school or a group of schools, that school would get the placement fee. So that is an opportunity for income for schools. I am sorry you did not understand that and I will do my best to explain it to you at length when the committee stage of that bill comes forward.

—My question is to Senator Kemp. Earlier this week you told the Senate that you were confident that growth would strengthen over 1997, which of course is most welcome news for all Australians, including the people of Tasmania. Minister, will you now advise the Senate of how recent data on housing commencements released on Tuesday, the Westpac‐Melbourne Institute leading indicator released yesterday and today's DEETYA skilled vacancy index—which incidentally show Tasmania having the strongest rise—further support your confidence of a strengthening economy this year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Abetz for the question. As usual, he is on the main game. Senator Abetz's concern for jobs, for employment, is well known, so the question did not come as a surprise. The government is pleased, as I said earlier this week, that there are good signs that the economy is strengthening. Since then, as Senator Abetz said in his question, there are further positive signs. On Tuesday the ABS released dwelling investment figures for the December quarter. Senators will know that housing slumped dreadfully under the Labor Party.
—There were 26,000 more unemployed last month.

—Housing slumped dreadfully under the Labor Party, Senator Bolkus. Of course, you can remember the record levels that interest rates reached the last time you were in office. Every time you raised the interest rates, you referred to it as `de‐spivving the economy'. What a great phrase that was, as families and people in business were suffering.

ANSWER.PARA: Following the slump in housing caused by Labor's policies, there are signs of a recovery. Dwelling investment in the December quarter rose by a strong three per cent, prompting Mr Harnisch, a director at Master Builders Australia, to say:
This is an early but welcome sign that the housing recovery may be starting to broaden.

The housing outlook for 1997 is also positive, with total private building approvals rising in January 7.6 per cent and finance approvals rising 6.4 per cent. Vacancy rates remain low in the two major markets, Sydney and Melbourne, and vacancy rates have fallen in most other cities in recent months. Housing affordability, as measured by the Commonwealth Bank‐HIA index, is now at its highest level since the December quarter of 1984. Australians had less affordable housing for 11 years under Labor. That was the effect of Labor's policies: less affordable housing for families.

Yesterday, more good news was received in the form of the Westpac‐Melbourne Institute leading index. The index, which aims to indicate where the economy will be in six to nine months time, rose by one per cent in January, which reinforces the upward trend of the previous months.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unemployment.

—Senator Conroy mentioned unemployment. Senator Conroy, do you know what level unemployment reached under the Keating government, of which you were one of the strongest supporters? Do you know the record levels that unemployment reached under your government and how miserably you failed?

ANSWER.PARA: As mentioned by Senator Abetz, DEETYA released its skilled vacancy index. It showed the fifth consecutive monthly rise. The index rose two per cent for the month and is now more than 10 per cent higher than its low point last year. This comes on top of the 1.8 per cent rise in ANZ job vacancies and is consistent—Senator Conroy, why don't you listen—with continuing employment growth over the months ahead. More job vacancies, high housing affordability, stronger growth: this is very good news for families, very good news for business, very good news for the economy, but I regret to say that it is bad news for the Labor Party.

Nonetheless, whatever you do, Senator Kemp, never provide this chamber with any information and never answer a question directly! That is your style.

But today you usurped your own efforts by playing pass the parcel. You are the Assistant Treasurer. You have responsibility for taxation in this country. You had a question on taxation. Did you answer it? No. What did you do? You tried to pass the parcel to the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Warwick Parer, in order to avoid your own responsibility in this matter. —The government do not like it when they get pinned, and they are getting pinned on this. What was one of the most solemn promises made by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) before the election, made by the Treasurer (Mr Costello) before the election, supported by Andrew Robb in advertisements taken out by the Liberal Party before the election? EXPORT MARKET DEVELOPMENT GRANTS BILL 1997

Madam President, this bill delivers on the government's commitment to maintain the Export Market Development Grants scheme, and to provide full‐rate eligibility, for the first time, to the tourism industry.
It simplifies the scheme, better targets its support to sme's and retains a well funded program despite the budget black hole of the Labor government.

Madam President, the EMDG scheme has been assisting Australian exporters for over 22 years. During that time the Export Market Development Grants Act 1974 has been amended many times. As a result the act is now quite complex and difficult to use, and has been criticised as such by exporters.

The bill before you is a very much easier to read document than the act it will replace. As far as is possible it puts like matters with like, it flows logically from subject to subject, and it presents concepts and terminology in relatively simple language. It uses around only half the number of words of the existing act.

Two significant measures have been introduced to direct more funds to small and medium enterprise. The minimum expenditure threshold has been lowered to $20,000 per grant to benefit more SME's. In addition, applicants with income in the grant year in excess of $50 million will no longer be eligible to receive a grant for that year, thus freeing up available funds for those exporters most in need of assistance.

The government has also recognised the significant contribution made to our exports by the tourism industry. We have increased the grant rate for all tourism providers to the full rate of 50%, allowing free samples of services provided, and access to approved joint ventures.

As a result of the fiscal legacy of the previous Labor government, the cost of the EMDG scheme has also had to be addressed. The government has, therefore, decided to place a cap on annual funding. This is consistent with the government's wider goal of fiscal restraint.

Most importantly, the mechanism for effecting the cap will provide for full payment of smaller grants at the time of determination. Claimants eligible for larger grants will receive a partial advance at the time of determination and a pro‐rated balance at the end of the year.

If demand for grants exceeds the $150 million available, larger grants will be reduced. To minimise the potential reduction to individual grants, the government has introduced a number of policy changes which will simplify the scheme, address fraud and better target it at those SME's in the early years of exporting.

Eligibility to claim air fares continues for the first two grants, assisting businesses take that difficult first step of visiting export markets. Air fares incurred by an overseas representative will continue to be claimable for all grant years within an overall expenditure cap for overseas representatives of $200,000 per grant year.

Madam President, the fundamental principles of this scheme have not been altered. The scheme will continue to provide assistance to small and medium Australian exporters and potential exporters through the partial reimbursement of selected promotional costs. Under this bill the scheme retains its open access nature.

In the interests of broad consultation with industry and getting the bill right, an exposure draft of the bill was widely circulated late last year for public comment. Over 160 submissions were received. I thank those who provided submissions, and many of the issues raised in those submissions have been included in the bill that is before the house today.

Madam President, this bill demonstrates the commitment of the government to assisting Australian SME's enter and develop export markets. Not only have we retained a well‐funded EMDG scheme which encourages smaller firms into export, but we have also made substantial progress towards reducing the budget deficit and providing a better macroeconomic environment for all Australian exporters.
I commend this bill to honourable Senators.
EXPORT MARKET DEVELOPMENT GRANTS (REPEAL AND CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1997

Madam President, the government has introduced to this place a bill which will establish a revised and simplified Export Market Development Grants Scheme. I refer to the Export Market Development Grants Bill 1997. This bill repeals the Export Market Development Grants Act 1974, and deals with matters arising from the repeal of that act and the enactment of Export Market Development Grants Act 1997.
As a consequence of this change, it is necessary to protect the rights of certain applicants and the government, and the ongoing integrity of the scheme.
This bill:
. preserves the status of approved body, approved joint venture and approved trading house applications, and various related guidelines;
. preserves first time claimant registration, and guidelines with respect to the grants entry test;
. preserves "decision making principles" in respect of continuing business considerations under the scheme;
. prevents first time applicants from claiming expenses in respect of previously ineligible services;
. ensures the finalisation of pending claim assessments and grant payments;
. ensures that pending prosecutions may continue, and monies owing to Austrade may be pursued; and
. amends other acts to reflect the repeal of the export Market Development Grants Act 1974 and the enactment of the Export Market Development Grants Act 1997.
I commend this bill to honourable Senators.
EXPORT FINANCE AND INSURANCE CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL 1997

Last budget, the government announced that it would transfer Development Import Finance Facility (DIFF) loan liabilities from the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation (EFIC) to the government's account. As a consequence, EFIC would make a special payment to the Commonwealth, estimated to be $40 million. At that time, it was noted that amendments would be required to EFIC's legislation to allow the transfer of loan liabilities and associated payment. This bill implements that decision.

EFIC is a statutory corporation which exists to increase Australia's exports by providing international competitive insurance and export finance services. It has traditionally filled a gap left by the private sector, which has often been reluctant to finance or insure exports in certain markets because of the risks involved. EFIC operates on a commercial basis and meets all of its costs from revenue, including the need to build up reserves to enable it to meet future claims. EFIC operates essentially at no cost to the taxpayer and will, in fact, pay a dividend to government during the current financial year of $12.6 million.

In 1995‐96 EFIC supported $7.5 billion of Australian exports, supporting over 1,000 Australian businesses exporting to some 155 countries around the globe. Most of EFIC's clients are small to medium enterprises with an annual turnover of $50 million or less. The availability and cost of export risk mitigation is extremely important to these smaller companies. Some 87% of new clients to EFIC in 1995‐96 were SMEs, of which 60% were manufacturers—exactly the type of company needed to drive Australia's future prosperity and employment.

EFIC's role as a direct financier or guarantor has become increasingly important in line with the need to match overseas government supported involvement in the area of trade financing. EFIC's financing book stood at nearly $3 billion at the end of last year, all involving the export of capital goods and services from Australia.

An important part of EFIC's financing role has been to deliver the soft loan component of Australia's overseas aid program through the former DIFF scheme. DIFF loans were concentrated in Asia and were long-term—up to 25 years in the case of loans to Indonesia. A DIFF grant component of some $120 million per year translated to soft loans through EFIC of some $350 million. Delivering DIFF loans of this magnitude presented EFIC with two problems. The first was the need to build up reserves in case of defaults on these loans, noting that the loans covered a significant portion of EFIC's exposure at any one time.

The second problem, a result of Australia's overseas aid program focussing on Asia, was the concentration of exposure in a fairly narrow range of countries. Like all insurers and financiers, EFIC would normally seek to spread its exposure. However, the concentration of DIFF loans made EFIC's loan exposures undesirably lop‐sided. In addition, this concentration also had the potential to restrict EFIC's ability to provide non‐aid medium term credit for Australian exports in these countries, particularly Indonesia. This was a matter of concern to the government given the increasing interest of Australian business in Asia. The removal of DIFF loan liabilities from EFIC's account to the government's account, managed by EFIC on behalf of the government, removes these unintended consequences. This transfer will change EFIC's risk portfolio for the better, allowing room for EFIC to grow its medium‐term business, particularly in Asia.

In relation to the financial impact of the bill, EFIC will make a special payment to the Commonwealth of $40 million. This amount reflects the liability that the Commonwealth will be assuming for the loans. The calculation of this amount was made by the government in the knowledge that EFIC's viability, and capacity for growth, to a large extent depends upon its reserve structure and the income generated from those reserves. The government will be liable to reimburse EFIC for any losses occasioned by loan defaults or other interruptions to repayment. The Commonwealth will also pay EFIC a fee for managing the loans.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill and commend the bill to the Senate.

BREAK.PARA: AUSTRALIA NEW ZEALAND FOOD AUTHORITY AMENDMENT BILL 1996

This bill amends the Australia New Zealand Food Authority Act 1991 (the act) to implement provisions which will enable the Australia New Zealand Food Authority to focus its resources on issues which are of critical importance to its Australian and New Zealand stakeholders. Legislation which was before the Parliament last December created the Australia New Zealand Food Authority and a joint food standards setting system for Australia and New Zealand. This Authority and the unique system of Commonwealth, State, Territory and New Zealand cooperation it supports, will continue to protect the public health and safety of Australian and New Zealand consumers through:
. the development, establishment and management of the Australia New Zealand Food Standards Code;
. the development and implementation of the new hygiene standards for food processing, manufacturing and handling; and
. development of improved and consistent national arrangements for surveillance and compliance.
This bill will enhance the Authority's ability to undertake these important tasks.

The Final Report of the Policy Review published in May 1993 committed the Authority to undertake a Review of the Food Standards Code in recognition that, before the creation of the Authority, food standards had not been developed according to the objectives set out in section 10 of the Australia New Zealand Food Authority Act 1991. The need for this Review was supported by all stakeholders and a timetable indicated that the Review would be completed in March 1998.

However, this time frame cannot be met because of a provision in the Australia New Zealand Food Authority Act 1991 which requires the Authority to accept all applications (which meet certain basic criteria). The Authority is then obliged to commit resources to completing the assessments associated with each of these applications within 12 months, irrespective of the relative public or commercial importance of these applications.
There are three main deficiencies within the current legislation which prevent the Authority having the capacity to plan, manage or prioritise its work load:

. Firstly, the Authority has no control over the number of applications which it is legally bound to handle at any one time. As resources must be provided for the processing of each of those applications, the Authority is placed in the invidious situation of either compromising the quality of the assessment of each applica tion, or breaching its statutory obligation to finalise applications within 12 months.

. Secondly, the Authority is obliged to utilise available resources on a `first come—first served' basis so preventing it from taking into account the relative importance or value of each application (according to the objectives set out under section 10 of the act).

. Thirdly, the Authority's obligation to assess each application individually means that the Authority is required to make variations to the Code on a fragmented, one by one basis in response to individual applications which generally only benefit a particular sector of industry. This in turn prevents the Authority from undertaking more comprehensive and thorough reviews of groupings of standards. These reviews of groupings of standards are urgently needed to make the Code less prescriptive, easier to use and more consistent.

The Commonwealth wishes to give an undertaking to the States and Territories and to New Zealand that the Authority will develop a joint Australia New Zealand Food Standards Code by 1 January 2000. The development of this joint Code is a continuation of the Review of the Code begun in 1993 and it will result in a revised, simplified and much more effective set of food standards. This joint Code is absolutely essential to the efficiency and international competitiveness of Australia's food industry. A failure to provide the joint Code within the three-year timeframe will erode the food industry's international reputation and could jeopardise its market opportunities in the region.

To ensure that the joint Code is in place by the year 2000, the Authority is establishing a three-year Standards Review Work Program. This work program will set priorities for food standards review over the next three years and will be agreed to and supported by the food industry, the States, Territories and New Zealand. Development of this work program will involve agreement from stakeholders as to which health and safety, consumer protection, industry and international harmonisation issues require priority over the next three years.

A specific number of applications will be included in the work program, commensurate with the level of resources available to the Authority. It is anticipated that these resources will be drawn from Commonwealth, New Zealand and industry sources. The applications will be selected for inclusion in the work program in consultation with stakeholders. Criteria for selection will be based on the objectives set out in section 10 of the act. All applications accepted as part of this work program will be finalised within 12 months and there will be no charge to the applicant. Applications which cannot be accommodated within the work program because of resource limitations will still be accepted and processed within the 12 month timeframe, but will be assessed on a cost recovery basis ie: applicants will need to provide the Authority with the resources required to process the application. Alternatively, assessment of the application will be delayed until the charges have been paid.
Successful development of the joint Australia New Zealand Code hinges upon the amendments contained in this bill. In summary, this legislation will enable the Authority to:

. ensure that the Authority's resources are spent on assessing applications within the work program by allowing it to delay processing applications which are outside the work program until such time as any prescribed charges have been paid;
. assess applications which are within the work program at no charge to the applicant;
. enable the Authority to prioritise and direct resources to its agreed work program, and to the food standards matters which are of major public interest and commercial importance; and
. charge for its expertise by marketing its goods and services and to retain any fees and charges.
The bill—
. permits regulations to set the amount of these charges and to waive, remit and refund charges in whole or in part; and
. specifically limits the level of the charge to recovering the Authority's expenses in assessing an application.

This bill will protect the Authority's open and accountable processes which are admired around the world. The Authority will still be required to assess applications within the 12 month time limit provided that, for applications outside the work program, the prescribed charge is paid. Any person or body will still be able to apply to the Authority for a variation or addition to the Food Standards Code.

This bill will enable the Authority to develop, establish and manage a quality Food Standards Code for Australia and New Zealand which will protect public health and safety and strengthen our food industry.
AIDC SALE BILL 1997
The bill will put in place the necessary framework to give effect to the government's decision to sell AIDC Limited and wind up the Australian Industry Development Corporation.

AIDC's origins were in 1970 when the Australian Industry Development Corporation was established as a statutory corporation by the Commonwealth. It was formed to facilitate and encourage the estab lishment, development and advancement of Australian industries. Commercial operations commenced in 1971. The Corporation established a reputation as a prominent development finance company in Australia, lending to and investing in a wide spectrum of Australian industries.

Milestone transactions in its development in the 1980s included leading roles in the North West Shelf gas project financing for Woodside Petroleum Limited and the Eraring Power Station project financing. More recent significant transactions include establishing a consortium of institutional investors to take a 10% equity interest in Optus Communications Pty Limited.

The business activities of the Australian Industry Development Corporation were one of the first Commonwealth Government activities identified for privatisation. This led to the decision by the previous government to establish AIDC Limited to undertake the business activities of the Corporation and enable an initial offering of 18.5% of the shares to the public.

Although this approach provided for public participation in the ownership of the business, it did not provide a practical means through which the government was able to divest itself of the remainder of the company. As a consequence it was necessary for the Corporation to make a takeover offer for those shares in AIDC Limited not owned by the Corporation, (ie Commonwealth Government owned shares), to facilitate the full disposal of the activity.
The takeover offer was successfully completed in January 1996 and the shares in AIDC Limited delisted from the Australian Stock Exchange in February 1996.

Since its establishment as a company AIDC has been changing the direction of the business activity of the Company.While still focussing on the development or advancement of the infrastructure and resource sectors of the economy, it is pursuing to a far greater extent fee‐based merchant banking business. This government is firmly of the view that such business activities have no place continuing in the public sector.

In addition to moving the company from government ownership, the sale for which this bill provides the framework will further contribute to the government's competitive neutrality objectives. Through arrangements between the Corporation and AIDC Limited, AIDC was provided with access to funding at competitively attractive rates through the Commonwealth government guarantee. The termination of access to this facility will place the AIDC business on the same competitive footing as the rest of the industry.

The government's decision to sell AIDC Limited is consistent with the recommendations of the National Commission of Audit which considered that government business activities whose objectives are to provide goods and services on a commercial basis should only be retained in public ownership if there is a clear public interest case to do so. With the emergence and development of financial markets in Australia any public interest case to retain AIDC in public ownership has disappeared.

In reaching its decision the government consulted with the Board of the Australian Industry Development Corporation and AIDC Limited. The directors and management of AIDC are fully supportive of the government's policy of privatising AIDC.
Madam President, the AIDC Sale Bill provides the necessary framework to give effect to the decision to sell AIDC Limited.

The bill provides for a flexible disposal strategy in recognition of the complexity of the legal and commercial arrangements that exist in AIDC Limited and the need to take the appropriate measures in the sale process recognising the Commonwealth's position as guarantor of the Corporation's borrowings. It enables the transfer, under ministerial direction, of assets of the Corporation or any wholly owned entity of the Corporation to the Commonwealth or any other body.

Provision is made for the winding up of the Australian Industry Development Corporation by proclamation, the timing of which is subject to written certification by the minister that he is satisfied that the Corporation has no assets or liabilities. It is necessary to make this arrangement as the Corporation will continue in existence after the sale AIDC Limited to satisfy the Commonwealth's guarantee obligations arising from the Corporation's borrowing program. The Corporation's 1996 Annual Report indicates that $946 million of the borrowings are due in five or more years, long after the sale of AIDC Limited.

Schedule 1 to the Bill provides for a range of amendments to the Australian Industry Corporation Act 1970 to give effect to a restriction of the functions of the Corporation to the core functions. These include the facilitation and encouragement of the establishment, development and advancement of Australian industries through the provision of financial resources and securing participation by Australian residents in the ownership and control of businesses. While it is the government's view that such objectives should be carried on in future by private entities, it is important to maintain these core functions of the Corporation in relation to the existing obligations. Further changes are included to provide for the minister to give directions to the Board of the Corporation. Through this power the minister can require the Corporation to manage the wind down of its liabilities, consistent with the government's decision to sell the business activities of the Corporation and the ultimate objective of abolishing the Corporation when it no longer has any assets or liabilities.

A range of amendments to the act are proposed to provide for the variation to the composition of the Corporation's Board. It removes the requirement for the ex‐officio appointment of Secretaries of Departments as this is no longer appropriate given the ongoing functions of the Corporation.

With the sale of AIDC Limited, as provided for by this bill, the close linkage between AIDC Limited and the Australian Industry Development Corporation will no longer exist and as a consequence it is necessary to amend the existing legislation to ensure that the restrictions on the delegation of powers by the Corporation to an officer or employee who remains in the Corporation or to a fully‐owned subsidiary of the Corporation remain applicable in the context of the other changes proposed for the act.

Section 24A of the existing act is repealed and replaced by a provision that permits the minister to give the Corporation written direction to pay specified amounts to the Commonwealth at specified times. Under the existing provisions, payments to the Commonwealth were precluded from exceeding the Corporation's profit in that year. Within the sale environment and the wind down in the Corporation it is important for the Commonwealth as the beneficial owner to capture the proceeds at its determination.

A new Part VI is inserted into the Australian Industry Development Corporation Act 1970 to provide the flexible framework that will enable the sale to take place. The framework includes the regularisation of the ownership of AIDC Limited, the introduction of the government's ability to transfer assets and liabilities between different elements of AIDC or to the Commonwealth, the ability of the Commonwealth to direct to it the payment of the proceeds of the sale or sales and the abolition of any residual franking credits.

The bill includes provisions relating to transfer of minority interests in AIDC Limited. Although there was a successful takeover offer by the Corporation for those AIDC Limited shares not owned by the Corporation, two parcels of shares in the company remain outside the Corporations ownership. This gives rise to the situation where, despite the Corporation, and through it the Commonwealth, having beneficial ownership of 99.98% of the company, it can be frustrated in its intentions to pursue the sale of the company. Obligations are generated under the Corporations Law for directors of the company to protect the interests of those minority shareholders. While this bill makes specific arrangements for the compulsory acquisition of minority interests, the threshold at which it can operate reflects provisions in Corporations Law.

The bill provides for the minister for Finance to declare that at a specified date, which must be before 1 July 1998, that the legal and beneficial interests in those shares vest in the Corporation. The shareholders involved are protected in the bill by a requirement on the Corporation that reasonable compensation be paid for the shares, with recourse being provided to the Federal Court if agreement cannot be reached on the amount of compensation.

As part of its business activities AIDC Limited has built up a range of significant investment holdings. Important amongst these is the 48.5% holding in the Australian Submarine Corporation. This holding was able to be managed in a way that contributed not only to the development of Australian industry, but also to the development of Australian resources necessary for our defence. With the sale of AIDC Limited the government is concerned to ensure that this significant ownership stake in ASC continues to be held in a way that contributes to Australia's defence industry objectives. As a result this asset will be quarantined from sale, unless there is a compelling argument brought forward from the Department of Defence.

For this reason the bill makes provision for the minister for Finance to direct the transfer of the assets in a way that allows for the transfer of particular assets, such as the interest in ASC, and assists in achieving the government's objective of a sale of the business of AIDC Limited. Associated with the power to transfer assets, authority is also provided for the transfer of contractual rights and obligations and liabilities.

Many of the liabilities of AIDC and its subsidiaries involve liabilities taken on by the Australian Industry Development Corporation and therefore include a guarantee of the payment by the Commonwealth of Australia. Provision is made in the bill for the continuation of that guarantee of payment when the liability is transferred to another person. Following the declaration of a sale day, AIDC Limited and its subsidiaries will have no further recourse to raising new funds which are guaranteed by the Commonwealth. These changes will not permit the purchaser of AIDC assets, rights, obligations or liabilities to in any way change the nature of the existing obligations and retain the benefit of the Commonwealth guarantee. The guarantee will only continue to apply while the liability remains in exactly the same form as existed at the time of sale.

Provision is made for the Minister for Finance to direct that the proceeds from the sale or transfer of assets of AIDC bodies must be paid to the Commonwealth. This is to ensure that the Commonwealth obtains the full benefit of the sale of AIDC or any subsidiary bodies at the time of the sale rather than leaving it to the discretion of the Corporation or an AIDC company.

The bill sets out the stamp duty liabilities applying in the sale, specifying that it is not payable in relation to those transfers of assets or liabilities between AIDC bodies or between AIDC Limited and the Commonwealth, which arise as a result of ministerial direction; such directions being provided for in this legislation. It also provides that stamp duty will not be payable in relation to the sale itself.

The bill also provides in Division 7 for the cancellation of AIDC's franking credits as their inclusion in the sale process could result in the Commonwealth achieving only partial return for the credits.

New sections are introduced to provide that AIDC companies must provide information or other assistance as may be requested in writing by the minister to pursue the sale process. In providing this power protection is provided to those giving information or assistance to ensure that such actions do not result in a contravention of the Corporations Law.

Importantly the bill provides for the preservation or other recognition of entitlements of AIDC staff. It preserves accrued long service leave entitlements and ensures that the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act continues to apply in relation to injury or loss incurred before sale day. In these respects the bill reflects the past practice of government in protecting accrued rights of employees in asset sale situations.
The bill also makes consequential amendments to a number of other Commonwealth acts which will take effect on the winding up of the Australian Industry Development Corporation.

Madam President, this bill will provide a framework for the sale of AIDC Limited and the subsequent winding up of the Australian Industry Development Corporation, in the most flexible and expeditious way in response to commercial interest that is expressed in the sale process. It will also protect the interests of AIDC employees and enable the effective disposition of assets, liabilities, rights and obligations.
Ordered that the bills be listed on the Notice Paper as separate orders of the day.
Ordered that further consideration of the second reading of the bills be adjourned until the first day of the winter sittings 1997, in accordance with standing order 111.
