TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The committee is considering the Telecommunications Bill 1996 as a whole and opposition amendments 1 to 5 on sheet 422. The question is that the amendments be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the interruption of the debate at 12.45, I was speaking to a number of aspects of the opposition's amendments on price discrimination. I will not repeat the things I have already said. I was also responding to the remarks of the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) in defence of his proposition on price discrimination, that it be done on an averaging basis.

SPEECH.PARA: I now want to turn to the question of how the minister is going to prepare his proposal for price and I want to try to get from the minister more details of this price averaging arrangement which he says will deliver bigger cuts in telecommunication local call rates in non-metropolitan areas. First of all, this is not being done by legislation. It will be done by a disallowable instrument as part of the Telstra act and it will only relate to Telstra. We believe that is a deficiency in that we do not believe Telstra should be picked on. All carriers ought to be accepting the same obligations, in our model, to provide the same rates reductions into rural areas.

What I am particularly concerned about is that the minister has not yet given us the details with which to make the comparison between his proposal and my proposal, of which I have spoken to him, which is in an amendment form. Because we will not see that here in the chamber, because it is a disallowable instrument, I think there is an obligation on the minister to explain to the committee how it will work.

For example, we need to get a clear definitional understanding of which markets are going to be in the averaging arrangement. Will it be the major metropolitan markets? Will it be a market definition that the minister himself will determine and put into the disallowable instrument and be able to change from time to time if he chooses? Of course, it is up to the House of Representatives to disallow it, but the debate on disallowance will always be in this place rather than in the House of Representatives, where the government has a majority.

The next issue I want to try and work out from the minister is: how is it averaged? Is it a running average? Is it a fixed average for a set period of time? For example, is the average immediately readjusted every time a phone call rate changes in one of your defined markets by 1c or 2c? And then is there a change in all of those averages? Or will you, once you have set the figure in the disallowable instrument, specify that the average sit for three months? Six months? Twleve months? When will it be reviewed? Will it be until there is a change in the pricing structure?

These details are not available to the chamber at the moment, in the committee stage. I believe there is a real deficiency in the ability of the Senate to make up its mind about which is the superior structure: ours, which is actually in legislation and, as the minister would use it, represents black letter law arrangements; or his, a disallowable instrument yet to be determined and yet to be explained to us. We would certainly like to know how you work out your averages. Is it a running average? Is it a permanent average? What is the period of time for it? I think those are reasonable questions that we hope you could answer.

The second thing that I want to raise and have clarified is this: in the major metropolitan markets—and I presume that there are going to be only the metropolitan markets—which ones will you determine will be where there is potential for competition? Are we just looking at the Sydney, Melbourne, Adelaide, Perth, and Brisbane markets? Are we putting Hobart in that market as a metropolitan capital city? Which of those markets are in the average? Is there any chance for some of the regional areas, such as the Illawarra, or Wollongong, to be in the market? You can absolutely fix this average according to who you put in the calculation. If there is no competition in a major market like Wollongong or Newcastle—markets that have 500,000 people and, in some cases, are bigger than Tasmania—you will jack the average up.

This is a serious concern because we are not comparing apples with apples. You are asking us to take this on trust. You will tell us that it is a disallowable instrument—and though we can disallow it, if there is a Senate majority, we cannot amend it—and you will then come back with a variation. We all know that you will say to us, `If you disallow it and there is no instrument at all, there are no price cuts at all.' The advantage is always with the government on a disallowable instrument procedure in this case. We want some information about what you would expect to be the market in your averaging arrangement. What we are particularly concerned about is who would make the judgment from time to time on which markets are going to be used for the average.

There is another issue. We know, for example, that there is competition—or supposed competition—in, say, Sydney because Optus has offered the 20c call, once they get their telephony to work, and Telstra may match it. If Telstra goes down to 20c in Sydney but there is no competition, effectively, in Brisbane and they stay at 25c there, when you average it all out, the average price might be 23c or 22c across these markets. Even though Brisbane is defined for the purposes of averaging in the marketplace as a competitive market, will it automatically have its price reduced to the average for Telstra, irrespective of whether there is no competition?

This is something that is still very unclear in the government's model as explained on the record. I have to say, Minister, I have appreciated the consultation and discussion with your officers on this and I think, as a result, I may have a better grasp of what your model is than other senators, particularly those from the minor parties. It seems to me that whatever claim you may make that we will not deliver the bigger reductions that equate with your model for the regional area, at least our model is in the legislation. At least it is transparent.

Again I emphasise those examples of a regional specific nature that you raised and which I have called `the Ballarat example'. If the carrier—Telstra or Optus, or any other carrier—feels that that is not comparing apples with apples, that carrier can seek under regulation exemption to have that considered as a local call zone figure and that would have to be accepted as a local call zone figure for all other areas.

I also want to emphasise again, Minister—although in some of your remarks you criticised me and the opposition for this—that we were not certain because, in 21(5)(b) of our amendment, we had established a review process. On a number of occasions across the table over the last three days both of us have agreed that it is only reasonable to have reviews in a number of areas—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is ongoing.

—Yes. It is ongoing. We have accepted that. It would be crazy not to in a deregulated market where we are not sure how it is going to work out. I accept that price discrimination is a major—if not the major—issue in the economics of this whole package. Even if I accepted your model I would still insist and argue for a review to be conducted in the year 2000. Even with your model of averaging, I am not sure whether—even if that got up—that it would deliver and whether it would not have some unintended consequences.

SPEECH.PARA: This is about openness and transparency for both the industry and the Australian consumer. In this deregulated model where competition is encouraged, we want to know and want to keep it under review—and it will be a function of a deregulated regime that there will be ongoing reviews. That is why the ACA, the ACCC and all of these areas in your own department are being established. We will probably have more ongoing reviews in this industry than we have had bad dinners together—or bad dinners separately, I should say. I do not think that we have had too many dinners together—or bad dinners together. If I said `good dinners together' that would be a very small number.

You know as well as I do that a feature of this regime post‐July will be the endless reviews, and that is only appropriate. If there were not reviews—if there were not consideration after a period of time—we would be derelict as a parliament and you would be derelict as a minister in making sure that the system was working effectively, openly, and in a seamless and transparent way.

So, Minister, I again emphasise: I would like some information from you about how your model is going to work because we do not have that in detail before us. I would like to know how this process of averaging is going to work, and what the process will be for determining the markets that are going to be in the averaging arrangements, and wheth er the averaging will be a rolling average. Will it be for a set period that will be readjusted? All of these lead me to the view that you are less likely to deliver the substantial reductions that country people should get when there is proper competition in the city and therefore, again, I commend my amendment to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Schacht has pointed out our concerns on this issue in quite a specific sense. I would like to make a brief comment in a more general sense. I put to you, Minister, that in the shape of the USOs provided for in this legislation, we all know that a significant proportion of Australia is cross‐subsidised under that universal service obligation. By virtue of the fact of this question of averages and how they are calculated affecting the pricing in country regions, surely this issue takes us to the heart of the integrity of how the USO applies in a truly competitive market. This amendment creates a situation where those advantages are spent right across Australia. If this amendment is not put in place, how does that reconcile with the fact that the USO actually provides for a spreading of the cost burden of providing services to these remote and rural areas? Obviously the specific regions we are talking about have been identified.

SPEECH.PARA: To take that a step further, can you explain to the Senate precisely how you apply a competition policy that has its pricing and cost structures spread across the universal service obligation in a competitive environment to those areas where there is cross‐subsidisation under the USO? Surely by the nature of this legislation in applying a truly competitive environment you need to ensure that the carriers themselves cannot exploit the distinction between an area subject to a greater cross‐subsidisation and an area that is actually profit generating.

As I said, Senator Schacht has made some specific comments. I know mine are more general, but perhaps you can explain to the committee this overlaying of responsibility of the carriers and how the USO cross‐subsidisation, and hence those average costs, play back out into what we are trying to achieve, which is genuine competition in all areas of telecommunications pricing in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —There was one other point that was not covered by the debate earlier today, and it relates to price reductions being primarily from technological developments. I just want to make that point, which I in fact suggested during my speech at the second reading stage. We know that price reductions are primarily due to changes in technology, and that is clearly evidenced in the history of telecommunications in this country so far. STD prices fell very dramatically right through the 1980s when there was no competition.

SPEECH.PARA: These gains in technology development are at risk from the proposals the government has made. We know that, in an ongoing sense, the carriers will be more and more able to deliver those lower prices due to their cost reductions. But what is likely to happen in the name of competition is that those savings will be passed on to a select group of people who live where the densities are in cities—we have already identified those people—and country people will again miss out. I just wanted to make that point before we finished.

I think Senator Schacht and others have clearly demonstrated that we are not talking here about the death of competition—as the minister likes to suggest there will be as a result of these amendments. I think that it is probably time to wind up this debate, because it seems to me that most of the issues have now been adequately dealt with.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will elaborate on the way in which the model would work. An instrument would be made under the price cap arrangements in the Telstra Corporation Act to provide for equity in local call prices nationally by requiring price reductions in capital cities—I would envisage all capital cities being included, and possibly some other regional areas—where local competition is the most likely to occur, and for that to be reflected—
—Most likely to occur; not where it is occurring.

—No, where it is most likely to occur. You would include capital cities as a matter of course because they are the places where competition is most likely to occur. There is no competition anywhere, as yet, on local calls. That would be reflected in the maximum untimed local call prices that Telstra could charge nationally.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of actual price control arrangements, the following is proposed: in year one—that is, 1997‐98—Telstra's local call prices would be subject to an initial price ceiling—for example, 25c. Every 12 months, the revenue‐weighted average price of a Telstra untimed local call would be calculated where competition was occurring or likely to occur in the provision of local calls. This would reflect any reduction in local call prices across these areas. Every 12 months, the national local call price ceiling for Telstra would be replaced by the new revenue‐weighted average. Telstra would then have a short period, probably three months, to reduce local call prices in all areas where they would exceed the new cap to that level. Price control instruments are disallowable by parliament.

It is proposed that the competitive revenue‐weighted average would initially be calculated using data from all or specific mainland capital cities, including those areas where broadband cabling is being laid and where local call competition is most likely to develop in the short term. The geographic areas for the purposes of calculating the competitive revenue‐weighted average would need to be reviewed regularly, probably every two years, to ensure that competitive developments continued to be taken into account. The government would retain the power to reduce the national cap on the maximum price for an untimed local call below the revenue‐weighted average should this be considered appropriate.

Where there was a universal service provider other than Telstra, the government would tie the maximum price it could charge for an untimed local call to the adjustments to Telstra's national cap. These pricing arrangements only need to apply to Telstra—or the universal service provider, should Telstra not have that obligation for an area—not other local call service providers because Telstra's dominance in the market means that it is the price setter.

The effect of prohibiting price discrimination would be to severely chill competition by inhibiting Telstra's responding to vigorous competition in particular localised markets because of the revenue effects of having to drop prices across the board. As an example of how this would work, at the present time, as we know, 25c applies across the board. At the end of year one, if you had prices in Sydney of 22c, Melbourne 21c, Brisbane 23c and Adelaide 18c, the revenue‐weighted average calculated by dividing total revenue by the number of calls would fall to 21.4c. A new maximum applicable across the country for local calls of 21.4c would then be determined.

Telstra would have three months to reduce all higher untimed local call prices to this level. Prices below the new maximum cap could stay below. Under the approach, Telstra is able to respond to competitive imperatives on a market‐by‐market basis. It is not deterred from offering 18c in Adelaide, because it does not face the cost—that is, loss in revenue—of having to offer 18c nationally. All consumers benefit however from competition forcing prices below the maximum cap as price competition is reflected in each successive new revenue weighted average. The lower prices go in competitive markets, the greater will be the reduction for all consumers.

Let me just add a few more things. The fact is that, ever since 1991, section 185(a)(ii) of the Telecommunications Act has provided for cost justified price differential. So do not be under any illusion that we are suddenly proposing that prices can vary both within Australia and within markets. They can, and it is provided for under the current legislation, and that is a reflection of precisely what we say is important now. You are wanting to regress, in effect, back to—

TALK.START.PARA: —No; progress.

—No, you are not. You are actually wanting to go back beyond 1991, and the reason why that is highly antipathetic to the interests of consumers is that it will simply mean that you will only get marginal reductions in pricing, because people will not be able to afford to provide across‐the‐board—
—That's an assertion, Richard; you can't prove that.

—I think you know that, if you hope to get anything out of competition, even under your model, you would expect local call prices to fall. Senator Allison seems to think that the only reason that prices fall is because of improvements in technology. Quite clearly they fall for productivity reasons—because of better work practices—and the key, of course, that competition delivers is to ensure that you do not simply have monopoly rents that are creamed off and not distributed to consumers. The purpose of having a price cap is to ensure that those benefits are passed on and distributed across the country.

SPEECH.PARA: So you continue to have a maximum price cap there to protect consumers; you reserve the right to bring that down at any time. What you are trying to do here is, on the one hand, promote maximum competition, and then ensure that the benefits are distributed on a nationwide basis. But, if you do it on an across‐the‐board basis, that is absolutely the opposite of competition. That is not allowing any competition to occur, because the moment that you contemplate offering a reduced price to meet a local product, you have to offer it on a nationwide basis.

Senator Lundy is not here now, but she did ask how the USO could sit alongside the competitive model. The USO simply guarantees the standard telephone service, and that is not a function of competition. That is a function of a minimum standard being set by the parliament to ensure that everyone around Australia has access to a standard telephone—in other words, a handset that delivers the normal voice call. That has nothing to do with the level of prices. No‐one has ever pretended that this is a perfectly free market where players are able to do what they like. There is always a social overlay; that is why you have community service obligations and that is why we want a weighted average model to ensure that the real benefits of competition are distributed. There is a very big `if' there. You will not have those real benefits in the first instance, if you have this stultifying single standard across the board.

Although I agree with Senator Schacht that openness and transparency are important, it does not follow that because you have got a model that is readily understood, it is in any shape or form in the interests of consumers. It is just a logical inconsistency. It may be a great virtue to have a transparent model. It does not follow that it is in anyone's best interests. I am simply saying that you cannot claim that that therefore justifies you in taking an approach which is quite inimical to competitive price reductions.

There is nothing else I wanted to say except to stress once again that, in the government's view, this is the single most important initiative contained in this package of bills. It is a very important process that we are embarking on. We are setting the environment post‐1997 against which we hope there will be a lot of new players coming into the marketplace. We want to provide them with every opportunity to compete, drive down prices and maintain quality of service.

I think we can all be confident, on the basis of what has happened not only in this country but everywhere else, that you are very likely to see those sorts of benefits. But, once you start to put blockers into the system that fundamentally restrict the ability of players to offer deep discounts, because you want to regard them as national players by definition, you are tearing the heart out of the competitive model.

What we are proposing is not something the carriers want. It is very much something that they are opposed to, but it is a recognition of the social desirability of ensuring that benefits flow to non‐metropolitan areas. You can have the best of both worlds by going down this path, because you can ensure real benefits, ensure deep discounts and ensure that the bush gets the benefit. Under your model, you will get marginal incremental reductions across the board and that is not in anyone's best interests.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, can I have a bit more information. You used the phrase that, to get the average, it would be a `weighted revenue average'. This means that—
—A revenue weighted average calculated by dividing the total revenue by the number of calls.
—Does that mean that the revenue across all the markets is put together and then divided by the number of local calls in all those markets? I do not claim to be a mathematician.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Alston interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I know, absolutely. I am not bad at counting numbers, but I always know with a fair chance how I can survive in the numbers games of the ALP or whatever.
—The South Australian parliamentary Labor Party.
—There is not much competition over there.

—No, that is why I am asking the question. It may be very simple. Why is it not just an average? If the call rate is 21c in Sydney, 20c in Melbourne, 23c in Brisbane and costs such as that—just that simple number—why are they not just added together and divided by six rather than taking the total revenue of all of those markets and dividing them by the number of telephone calls? There may be a very simple reason for it; your adviser may be able to help. I just cannot see why, for the average person, you would not average out the simple rate and add them up.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer is that a weighted average gives you a much truer reflection of what is actually happening in the marketplace. In other words, if you included Cairns, which has 5,000 subscribers, and you have a 10c call, it is pretty painless to offer that, but it does not really tell you much about the overall cost benefit. If you then weighted according to traffic volume, you start to get a sense of what is reasonable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you for that explanation. My view about that is that if the bigger markets of Sydney and Melbourne do not offer the flat rate bigger reduction, they are going to affect the averaging out more than a Hobart market or a Perth market. When you put the total revenue in divided by the number of calls, it puts less pressure on coming down to a lower average unless the Sydney market turned out to be the lowest price of all. I can see why the carriers may be in favour of a weighted revenue average.

SPEECH.PARA: Now that it has been explained, it is still hard for someone to make a quick judgment about whether using that sort of weighted average will be more advantageous for lower prices or less.

TALK.START.PARA: —But it might be unaffordable. If you simply took the average of, say, five cities and two of those were very low cost areas, the idea of imposing that—
—It is not the cost going into the formula; it is the revenue. Irrespective of their cost, it is the revenue.
—That's right.
—If it is a flat rate with a cap on it, it is just a revenue.
—The level of price that you can charge is a function of the cost structure you've got, and in terms of revenue—
—But you already have the cap on. They cannot play around with their prices. I suspect that Senator Campbell thinks that this is all a bit esoteric.
—It's nice to have a round table chat. Why don't we have a cup of tea while we're at it?

—This is the only way you can handle telecommunications, Senator Campbell. If you try any other way, it is a disaster. I say to the minister that the impact of that may lead to jacking the price up. I cannot be sure; this is just a thing you dropped on the table with us. It further exemplifies why I think our amendment is simpler, easier to understand, easier to explain to people and will deliver a lower price.
—I indicate to the committee that after the minister speaks, I next intend to call Senator Harradine.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —The concept of weighted average is to give a true reflection of the total picture. In the big markets the rewards are potentially greater and, therefore, the prospect of competition is greater and, therefore, the price reductions are likely to be higher. You can see that from Optus's offer of 20c calls I think only in Melbourne or Sydney, because that is where the real markets lie. It would distort it quite unfairly if somehow you found that you had a much lower figure in a small country town, say, Ballarat, where it is zero, or it may be zero for other reasons if you have bundling.
—But they won't be in the average.

—If they were; I am just giving that as an example. If you included something like that in the average, you get a true sense of perspective because it is a low price but it is only a very small part of the basket. You could take that low price and equate it with a Sydney price and strike an average. Let us say that Melbourne, Sydney and Brisbane are all 20c and Ballarat, which happens to be in your group, is 5c. The average of that—64 by four—is 16. That is not a true reflection of the market at all, because Ballarat is only less than one per cent.
—Will they have another price under your model? It wouldn't jump back to 16c.

—You are not trying to artificially push it in one direction or another. You are trying to get a true reflection of the state of the market so you get a sense of what is affordable. In other words, if the carriers are in a position to offer significant discounts in the big end markets—Melbourne and Sydney—they have the capacity to deliver that weighted average across to the other areas. If you oblige them to pass on a very significant price reduction, which happens to be in a relatively small area because you have a straight line average, there is no reason to assume that they could afford to do that at all, because it might be much more expensive than a weighted average model would demonstrate.
—I have one simple question. Minister, in your model of the disallowable instrument of the competitive markets, will the Senate be able to disagree what markets are in the price formula?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it follows that if you are including your schema in the instrument and that is disallowed, you are back to square one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been listening to these discussions very carefully. I originally thought that I may be supporting the opposition's amendment. I have been listening to the responses and the questions. Firstly, the bed of competition has been made, and I suppose that both the opposition and the government have to lie in it. If you take that as a starting point, the government's amendment fits within that particular schema better than the opposition's amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to take up that last point that Senator Schacht raised in regard to what are the factors that are going to be placed in the weighted average scales. That is something that I would certainly like to hear more about. If I cannot hear more about it, then they should be in some sort of amendable instrument.

Secondly—I do not know who raised it: I think it was Senator Allison or Senator Margetts; it might even have been Senator Schacht—if this particular amendment by the government is carried, the least that should be done is a review to see how it is going. After a period of couple of years, you must see how it is going. If this whole concept is one of the major planks of your legislation, Minister, then surely we really do need to see how that is operating, particularly how it is going to affect those who are not going to be able to share in the benefits of competition in other ways. You know who I mean. Everybody knows that is the bush—regional Australia.

As I understand it, what the minister is saying is that in local calls there are not going to be benefits shared by regional Australian USOs unless, at the very least, his amendment is adopted. Under those circumstances, when is the proof going to be in the eating of the pudding—if a pudding is going to be cooked—and when are we going to know?

So I am inclined in the best of bad worlds to vote for the government's amendment, but I do feel that there are legitimate concerns in respect of what factors are going to be put into the scale for the weighted average and that these ought to be in legislation or in an amendable instrument.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the first thing to be said is that we are not trying to prejudge the extent to which there will be competition in the bush. It is very difficult to anticipate these things, and I suppose the reason we keep talking about Ballarat is that I happened to go there last week and launch this new product. In many ways it is a typical example of how, all of a sudden, Ballarat seems to be the testbed for regional Australia, when maybe six months ago you would have said, `Well, the bush is going to be left behind.' All of a sudden they are going to be the only people in Australia who will have free local calls to Northgate customers, and suddenly there is the prospect of untimed local calls between Ballarat and Melbourne, which is about 130 kilometres. So I would hope there will be a lot more pleasant surprises in terms of competition in the bush.

SPEECH.PARA: I think there are very encouraging signs in the US. Northgate, for example, together with Austar is talking about a billion dollar investment in Australia in the next couple of years. All of the signs in the US are that there is ferocious competition in regional areas. Indeed, Northgate's big claim is that they concentrate on regional areas. They are not interested in the capital cities. In the same way that there are companies out here now targeting rural areas for cable television, we are now starting to see companies that are targeting the rural areas for telephony.

What Northgate say, for example, is that they would anticipate at the present time that 50 per cent of their business would come from voice calls, 25 per cent of their business would come from cable television and 25 per cent of their business would come from data. Within five years they think it will be 50 per cent from data and only 25 per cent from voice calls. So you continue to see these sorts of revolutions. It is really only in those areas where you do not actually find competition emerging in the short term that they would then have to get the benefit of this weighted average model.

What we are particularly concerned to do is to ensure that it is passed on but that, in the first place, you get those significant reductions to pass on. I think what we are talking about here is a series of opposition amendments. Our model is already on the table, although it is in another act. The current legislative framework allows only for disallowable instruments. I think probably in the first instance we would take the view that this is such a major area of concern that you could not conceive of a situation where someone would disallow that and it would then be a vacuum. So in a practical sense I think there would have to be negotiations about it.

Quite clearly, as we said in the earlier exchange about reviews, I take the view that these things ought to be constantly under review. They should not be artificially under review in two years or four years—with people keeping their eyes closed until then and saying, `Who cares?' in the meantime.

We would be particularly sensitive about making sure that the benefits are passed on to the bush—and not just because of the National Party. We certainly have made quite a deal of noise about the importance of rural Australia because, after all, we have more seats in rural Australia than our National Party colleagues. I think everyone in this chamber is very determined to ensure that the bush does not get left behind. That is why we have already made a number of major announcements, such as the ISDN commitment.

So I will simply leave it on that basis but be conscious of what Senator Harradine said about the need to ensure that the parliament does have an opportunity to dissect the way in which this model is constructed and that we should all be prepared to revise our thinking on a regular basis. I am confident that will occur.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to put a parallel example here to the Senate. I worked in the airline industry for a number of years in a previous life. As the industry went through the 1970s and 1980s, there were excursion fares available, then there were advance purchase fares, stand-by fares and so on. As competition increased throughout the world airline industry, you found that, over time, the normal tariffs for airfares increased for various reasons, such as inflation and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: Those places which did not have a high volume of traffic, if they ended up with an air service at all—that is another thing—continued to have high airfares. Those places with the high volumes of traffic continued to have cheaper and yet cheaper airfares offered to them throughout the world. The excursion and cheap fares to the places where there was a high volume continued to decrease. The normal fares continued to be relatively high where you could have stopovers along the way. But those places throughout the world which do not have the high volume of air traffic continue to have high airfares. I put it to you that it is not—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is why you have redistribution mechanisms.

—If I may complete what I am saying, I put it to you that we do not have to have an experiment as to what happens when we allow carriers to discount to the areas where it is commercially more attractive to them to see whether or not there will suddenly be benefits to the areas where it is less commercially attractive, where there is less volume, and so on. I think we have many, many examples and we know what happens.

SPEECH.PARA: What happens is that the difference between the tight market areas, the heavily marketed areas and the less desirable market areas becomes greater and greater and the benefits for those businesses as well as individuals become greater in those areas where the volume is higher, so the disadvantage grows. I do not think there is anybody who can tell me that, over time, in that situation where there is not really a requirement to have equity in the pricing system, that does not happen where there is that ability for people to decrease or attract clientele in the areas of most volume. That is the way the market operates. It has always operated that way and, unless governments play a role in ensuring access and equity, it does not happen via the market.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a question for the minister, but I thought I would tell a little story before I put the question to him. It is a story that goes back to the 1960s, actually, when I was training for the Methodist ministry. The examinations were all written in Melbourne and many of us at the time were in places like Cloncurry, 1,500 kilometres from Brisbane, et cetera. The instruction came from Melbourne that we must all go to Brisbane to do the exam—that we could drive down and do the exam one day and come back the next.

SPEECH.PARA: It was not until we pointed it out that it was two days driving—that was the shortest you could do it in—from places like Cloncurry and two days back again, that finally they agreed that you could have a supervisor and stay in Cloncurry and do the exam. The problem was, of course, Melbourne's view of the world. The question, Minister, is: do you really regard Ballarat as the bush?

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the committee should be given a guarantee by the minister, in respect of this regime, that, before the disallowable instrument is actually made by the government, there should be an exposure draft circularised, particularly among members of parliament, so that we can have a look at it, give it consideration and make suggestions as to what might be included. I think that that should be fair. I would ask the minister to give that undertaking to the committee.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I can give that undertaking. I think that does make sense. It is an issue of very great importance to a lot of people and it does deserve to be publicly debated before it is finally proceeded with.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —These are my amendments that we are voting on. I have said three times in three different contributions that—and in the conversation I just had with Senator Harra dine, privately—I agree with that undertaking we got from the minister. Now, it looks like the—
—Thanks for the suggestion.

—That is certainly the way to go. It is certainly going to improve the method. I can accept that our amendment looks like it is going to be defeated—though I still will call a division. I agree with the minister. This is, I think, the most significant issue in this deregulatory package as far as the average Australian outside metropolitan Sydney and Melbourne is concerned. We will still call a division.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not going to be critical of the government, and the fact that they have not been able to have the detail that the minister read out a while ago available for consideration, because a lot of this stuff has only emerged as other amendments have been prepared by various parties, including the opposition. I think that, as Senator Harradine has said, first time round, if there is not an exposure draft put out about this disallowable instrument—although Senator Harradine has said that you can have an amendable instrument, I am sure that that is a pretty restricted arrangement—that is going to be necessary for a range of not only the carriers' interests but also the consumers' interests and those of regional Australia.

I would imagine, Minister, that, even after that exposure draft is put out, there may well be a debate about that instrument in itself in the parliament. I think it ought to be on the record that, though we might not necessarily formally disallow it, we want people to be able to express and comment about the process. We cannot do it here, because it is not in front of us. I still believe strongly that the amendment I have moved will provide lower prices for more rural and regional Australians than the proposal from the minister. I commend the opposition's amendment to the Senate.

PARA.EMPHASIS: A division having been called and the bells having been rung—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I wish to raise a point of order. Under standing order 99(1) or (2), I ask you to indicate whether you intend to vote and, if so, how.
—I have already indicated to the tellers that I am voting no.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Schacht' s ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

BREAK.PARA: (Senator Conroy did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the death of Senator Panizza)
(Senator O'Brien did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the resignation of Senator Woods)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government requests the Senate to defer consideration of the Australian Democrats' amendments 33 and 35 to 38, pending some further discussions.
—We will not proceed with those amendments. They are virtually identical to the opposition's and clearly there is no support.
—Could we have a postponement of consideration of the Australian Democrats' amendments 34, 39 to 41 and 42? I hope we will be able to come back to them later today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I proposed to move amendment No. 1 which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 216, page 172 (lines 21 to 23), omit paragraph (a).
This amendment deals with timed data calls. Is the thing you just deferred on the same issue?

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think it is.
—It is a new issue?
—Yes.
—This amendment is to do with the issue of guaranteeing untimed data calls for businesses et cetera, which is an issue that is around, as we all know. We will defer that to a later stage.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment postponed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (75) Clause 224, page 178 (line 19), omit "paragraph (d).", substitute "paragraph (d); and".
(76) Clause 224, page 178 (after line 19), at the end of subclause (1), add:

TAB.TAB: (f) any other matter concerning the supply, or proposed supply, of a carriage service to a customer.

SPEECH.PARA: (77) Clause 226, page 180 (line 25), omit "$3,000", substitute "$25,000".
(80) Clause 229, page 182 (after line 20), at the end of the clause, add:

PARA.TAB: (3) This Part does not limit, restrict or otherwise affect the operation of the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman scheme. In particular, this Part does not affect a customer's right to complain to the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman.
(4) Subsection (3) does not, by implication, limit subsection (2).

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments give effect to recommendation 2.17 of the Senate committee. They are unopposed. I presume they are uncontroversial.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support these amendments. They repeat the successful amendments the Democrats were able to put up to this customer service guarantee during the debate on the Telstra (Dilution of Public Ownership) Bill in December last year.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (43) Clause 224, volume 1, page 178 (lines 26 and 27), omit subclause (3).

The purpose of this amendment is to enable Austel to develop performance standards without having to await ministerial direction. We think this is important because it can prevent a situation arising whereby the regulator can be arbitrarily constrained. This may well be the case at present. The Australian Democrats moved the same amendment during the Telstra (Dilution of Public Ownership) Bill, where it was opposed and defeated by the government. The government has argued that Austel should be prevented from making a standard unless directed to do so by the minister. This is because it may not be appropriate for all telecommunications services, such as services used by only large corporate customers, to be subject to performance standards. The government has thus proposed that the minister have the power to direct Austel to impose standards in relation to services where regulatory attention is required.

We agree that the minister should have the power to direct Austel in this manner. We also agree that it may not be appropriate for all telecommunications services to be subject to performance standards. We also pointed out, however, that we do not believe that this is best achieved by preventing Austel from acting without ministerial direction. There are other ways of ensuring inappropriate services are not regulated without unnecessarily constraining the regulator.

The problem with the government's proposal is that it may unnecessarily constrain the regulator from being proactive and acting in the best interests of customers in cases where the minister, for whatever reason, fails or chooses not to do so. The regulator will often be better placed than the minister to determine which services require regulatory attention. For this reason we see no reason for preventing the regulator from being proactive and from developing appropriate performance standards.

Having to wait for ministerial direction could be problematic if the minister is, for whatever reason, disinterested or uninformed. It is my understanding that the minister has neither issued a direction to Austel to develop performance standards nor written to the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman to ask whether he will accept the power to issue evidentiary certificates.

It was way back on 19 December 1996, almost three months to the day, that the Telstra sale bill received royal assent, and the minister has still not acted to implement the CSG. This is the case even though the introduction of the CSG was one of the government's primary consumer protection measures and one which the minister praised so highly. If we cannot have the confidence in the minister to issue directions, then the regulator must be allowed to determine performance standards for the CSG without having to await ministerial direction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I am persuaded partly by the arguments of Senator Allison. I just want to find out from the minister why there is a hook, if there is one, in letting the ACA be proactive in the process of drawing up a standard. I cannot see what the hook would be to their making up a standard unless directed by the minister, which is what part (3) of clause 224 is. Maybe this could be drafted in a way whereby the ACA can be directed by the minister to make up a standard but it says `must not make up a standard'.

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot see the reason for precluding them beginning the work and being proactive about it. I wondered if there is a particular reason or hook somewhere that I have missed. It does seem to be a very blanket objection to performance standards, which will be an issue around the place. I was just wondering whether the minister has a view about that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the government's view is that there is no virtue in itself in being proactive. All parties need to be looking to improve the system but at the same time having regard to the cost implications. It is generally the responsibility of government to identify the priorities and the costs of a proposal. Certainly it can ultimately be disallowed by the parliament. I think in many respects you run the risk of the ACA embarking on an exercise which could be quite time consuming and, in terms of priorities, may not be the priority of government, or indeed the opposition for that matter, which then comes to nothing because it is disallowed.

SPEECH.PARA: So it seems to us that when there are significant cost implications, as there clearly are when you are imposing performance standards to help all consumers and therefore potentially imposing very significant cost burdens on the telecommunications carriers, that ought to be in accordance with policy rather than the regulator being off on a frolic of their own.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that Democrat amendment No. 43 moved by Senator Allison be agreed to. Those of that opinion say aye, to the contrary no. I think the noes have it. Is a division required?

—Once again, before we get to that point I ask Senator Allison to indicate what public purpose is served by her wasting another 10 minutes of the chamber's time when it is quite clear that there is no support for her amendment.
—I do not know that that support is clear. Perhaps I can get some indication from the ALP as to—
—Sorry; I did not make our position clear. The opposition will vote no to the amendment.
—A division is not required.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats oppose clause 228 in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: (44) Clause 228, volume 1, page 182 (lines 1 to 15), TO BE OPPOSED .

We oppose this clause, which allows Austel to make provision for customers of carriers to waive in part or in whole their protection and rights under the customer service guarantee. This is the same amendment we moved during the debate on the Telstra (Dilution of Public Ownership) Bill when the customer service guarantee was introduced.

It is ironic to be moving an amendment to remove the right of waiving the guarantee because the guarantee is not actually in operation. This is because the government is yet to undertake the necessary measures to implement it. This is the case even though the guarantee was legally approved some three months ago.

The government has argued that the waiver power is intended to provide customers with more choice. This supposedly enables carriers to offer cheaper prices for a service where a customer is prepared to waive some or all of their rights under this division. However, given the unequal bargaining power between carriers and customers, providing such a choice is questionable as we think it may lead to pressure being exerted on customers to forgo their rights. It is also uncertain whether the reference to a carrier offering cheaper prices for a service might not, in the case of Telstra, involve a breach of its obligation to provide services without discrimination.

Finally, the fact that the bill provides carriers with the flexibility to negotiate with customers the manner in which they discharge their liability when breaching performance standards should make the need for the right of waiver completely unnecessary. This in itself should go a long way to reducing unnecessary costs for carriers and providing customers with sufficient choice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the government is opposed to this amendment. I hear Senator Allison's empty rhetoric about unequal bargaining power and pressure to forgo rights. She does not give any examples of that. I would be absolutely amazed if she could point to examples of where consumers have effectively been forced under duress to forgo rights that were discretionary. What the Democrats are really saying is that they do not consider that Australian consumers are capable of making an informed judgment regarding customer service guarantees.

SPEECH.PARA: They will be there as a matter of course. Every customer will be automatically entitled to access those rights to have the benefits of the customer service guarantee unless they consciously choose to do otherwise. The only reason they will do otherwise is, presumably, if they are offered a deal that they think is in their best interests. It is not difficult to imagine those sorts of offers forthcoming. If you are in any doubt, you do not accept them. I never hear it said that carriers are somehow going around twisting people's arms. I have not heard anyone complain that they were forced to subscribe to one carrier rather than another.

What happens is that they are exposed to such ferocious competition that, the minute they say they do not want to stay with a particular carrier, they are inundated with phone calls trying to induce them back. But it is inducement on the basis of a more attractive proposal being put on the table or cash back deals and the like. It is not in any form intimidation or the exercise of pressure to forgo rights.

This is sloganeering from another age. If you are not prepared to allow people to make that choice, you are essentially back in the bad old days of saying, `We don't care what you want to do. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The Democrats oppose part 19 in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: Part 19, volume 2, page 263 (line 2) to page 265 (line 14), TO BE OPPOSED .

The Democrats want to indicate our opposition to the phase-out of the AMPS mobile phone network. We think there are very serious concerns being expressed. In our minority report to the inquiry for these bills we indicated in some detail what they were. We would hope that this decision could be reviewed. I do not expect there will be wide spread support in the chamber for this, but I will nonetheless indicate that we oppose the phase-out of the AMPS system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the amendment is unnecessary because the government already has flexibility under the existing licence condition to continue AMPS in rural areas with the carriers' agreement. The carriers have agreed to its continuation in areas of shortfall if there is no alternative service available by 1999.

SPEECH.PARA: It is also technologically deterministic because it assumes that terrestrial mobile networks will remain the only available technology, and it is meaningless because in rural and remote areas the only terrestrial digital technology available for foreseeable future will be GSM and it will fall short of current AMPS coverage in almost all areas. We know that it is about 35 kilometre radius compared with 70 for AMPS.

The government has already announced that it will retain some AMPS spectrum in each existing rural planned service area until there is alternative technology with a reasonably equivalent quality of service and breadth of coverage available in that planned service area. We do plan to have a review in 1999.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the minister is discussing my next amendment No. 51.

—As I understand, the Democrats are deleting the whole section from page 263 through to page 265, which starts `Advance mobile phone system—AMPS'. By deleting it means there is no phase-out at all. Is that correct?
—That's right.
—I want to get the Democrats on the record.
—That is correct.

—Minister, you were just speaking accidentally to the next amendment, but we may as well take the discussion together. In your announcement allowing some AMPS to operate in those rural areas where it does not look like GSM is going to operate, if that is somewhere in western New South Wales or mid-north South Australia, by having the AMPS continue that means that a person can use their present AMPS mobile phone, analog phone, in that area but if they go to Sydney on a holiday the phone is useless.
—Unless they have a dual mode handset.
—Unless they get a dual mode handset, which means they will have to buy a new handset.
—Yes.

—I know costs will always come down in these industries, thank goodness. It is one of our more pleasant features—equipment seems to get cheaper. Is there any idea of what the cost for a dual handset is at the moment?
—If it was more than $100, you would not bother. You would just keep the AMPS handset when you are in the bush and when you got to the city you would use your $100 digital.

—I wanted to get that clear. I am not surprised at your answer. That is what I thought it was, but I wanted to get it on the record. Do we have any idea how many estimated AMPS subscribers will be able to continue to have access to AMPS?
—We are all trying to remember what the number is, but it might be safer if I get you a precise figure. I am reminded that there are 155 sites already identified by Telstra.

—You said there are 155 identified sites. Who is identifying the sites? Can a community apply to keep their analog system or is a determination made technically by the carriers to say, `This falls within the description of a difficult area that GSM cannot operate in and therefore the analog will continue?' Do communities have a right to apply to say, `We think the analog should continue,' whether it is just for the fact that all the farmers have got one or they have made a guess themselves that the GSM will not be as good?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the answer is that they will not have a right to insist on AMPS coverage, irrespective of the quality of the alternative technology, assuming it is GSM at that time. What we will do is guarantee that you will not be allowed, as a carrier, to phase out the existing AMPS coverage unless you replace it with an alternative technology of reasonably equivalent quality of service and breadth of coverage. So they will be protected, but they will not have the right to effectively thumb their noses at the phase‐out and say, `Irrespective of the fact you are offering me a red hot digital service, we want to stay on AMPS.'

—Who has determined the 155 sites? Have the carriers determined that? Has Telstra determined that? I presume it is basically Telstra. Have they determined the areas? Is it the Spectrum Management Agency?
—The SMA in conjunction with the carriers. There has been a lot of work done on this over the last six or nine months.
—I am not trying to delay this, but I have to indicate to the Democrats that I oppose this particular amendment of just wiping it out completely, that there is a complete—
—Presumably offering to pay the bill when we are all sued by Vodafone and Optus.

—It is still a determination by the Spectrum Management Agency in consultation with a carrier about those areas. But is there actually any community consultation about what an area could be? Is the community informed as soon as possible that their analog is going to be available under those restrictions so that they know the equipment they have got can be maintained? They may want to just use it locally but if they want to go to the city they have to get a dual purpose phone. What I am after here is whether that information is provided to those areas as quickly as possible. Do we expect any more than the 155?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —No, we don't. There is only a relatively small number of people covered by those 155 sites—something of the order of 20,000, I think. It is a moving feast. It is too early at this point of time to be saying to anyone in those areas, `You will be able to stay on analog,' because you cannot be sure that they will not get commensurate digital coverage. That is why you have your review in 1999. You are then in a position to say, `It is now clear that they are not going to,' so you give them 12 months notice. The fact is that everyone who has got an analog phone knows that it is programmed to explode in the year 2000. There might be some who get a last‐minute reprieve, but they should all regard that as a bonus.

SPEECH.PARA: I think you will find that through the rural networks, the National Farmers Federation and the like, people are aware that we are prepared to maintain some areas where they would not get the equivalent quality of coverage. Rural users of analog sets are aware that if digital has not got to them by 1999 they might be allowed to continue on with the analog service. You cannot really tell them anything more until you see what the pace of the digital roll-out is at that time.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is information that you may supply later on because it is not directly related to this amendment as such. Is it possible to get from the Spectrum Management Agency a map of the 155 areas they have already designated?
—I have seen one. There is no reason why you shouldn't see one.

—I accept the fact that they have got till 1999 and some of these areas may no longer be covered by it and GSM will be available, but is there anything wrong in actually indicating to those communities now that they are one of the 155?
—I don't think so. I am not sure they do not already know, but in principle I do not see why, as long as they understand the rules.
—The question is that part 19 stand as printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 347, volume 2, page 264 (line 31), at the end of subclause (1), add:

PARA.TAB: or

TAB.TAB: (e) the coverage provided by a digital network in a particular area is not at least equal to the coverage provided by an AMPS network in that area at 1 July 1997;

SPEECH.PARA: or until problems caused by the interference of digital networks with medical equipment such as hearing aids and pacemakers have been resolved.

Amendment 51 deals with deferring the AMPS phase-out. The government has given some, albeit minimal, recognition to the impact the phase-out of AMPS would have on those rural and remote users of the system who presently do not have GSM coverage. Without some concession, these people will be left without access to mobile telephony services until such time as digital coverage is provided. However, without any genuine incentive to provide mobile digital telephony services, such customers could well be left behind for a considerable period of time.

Allowing for the possibility of AMPS to remain open for such persons provides a strong incentive to carriers to extend their digital coverage. However, the concessions provided by the government are, we think, unnecessarily weak. Firstly, they require excessive hoops before any of the AMPS spectrum is retained. The Democrats believe this should be a much stronger requirement, and for this reason we have proposed that the AMPS spectrum remain open until such time as coverage of GSM is at least equal to that of the present AMPS system. This will ensure that GSM coverage in the bush occurs far more rapidly than it otherwise would because carriers who want the AMPS network phased out would undertake the necessary investment required for this to occur. Secondly, it will mean that at no stage will rural and remote Australians be worse off.

The other concern we have is that, while the government has at least acknowledged the difficulties which the AMPS phase‐out will have for those rural dwellers who do not have access to digital, the same level of concern has not been afforded to disabled persons. For example, the Deafness Forum pointed out at the Senate committee which examined this legislation that at present most persons with hearing aid implants cannot use digital phones due to electromagnetic interference from them. Similar problems apply to persons with pacemakers.

It is for this reason we do not believe the AMPS phase‐out should be finalised until problems of interference, particularly with medical equipment such as hearing aids and pacemakers, have been resolved. In this way those customers will continue to have access to mobile telephone services. This can reasonably be achieved by retaining at least a portion of the AMPS spectrum open across the board, at least for the specific use of such customers. This approach would also ensure that rural persons who do not have digital access in their place of residence can continue to use their phone while they travel, whereas under the government's proposal they would only be able to use it at specific locations where stations are still retained.

The other advantage is that it would create an incentive to ensure carriers and component manufacturers continue to voluntarily invest in research and development to overcome these interference problems.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I was halfway through a speech on this subject, but I suppose I cannot let the opportunity pass without saying that I presume the Democrats were aware in moving amendment 50 that there were very substantial legal obligations entered into by the government with both Optus and Vodafone to the tune of hundreds of millions of dollars. No doubt they would have been aware of that. Once again, this seems to be yet another example of their being utterly oblivious to economic reality and pushing a line—not ideological these days, but simply a line that presumably they think will somehow appeal to a few disgruntled citizens at sone future point in time.

SPEECH.PARA: I have given all the reasons why we are opposed to the amendment. I did not hear Senator Allison respond to any of those, so presumably there is no need for me to go over them again. As far as any problems for the handicapped are concerned, I heard Senator Allison say, and I wrote it down, that the Deafness Forum told the Senate committee that those with hearing aid implants cannot use mobile phones and the same applies to those with pacemakers. If that is the case, what is the difference whether you have got analog or digital? It has got nothing to do with maintaining the analog service.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a difference with digital.

—Well, she did not say it, if that is what she meant. Assuming that she is talking about digital, retention of the AMPS network is not expected to provide any benefits to hearing aid or pacemaker wearers as solutions to interference problems experienced when the digital phone technology was introduced have been found and are being implemented. Hearing aids that comply with Australian standard 1088.9 enable the use of a digital mobile phone to within one metre of the aid. Aids that comply with AS1088.9 are already available on the Australian market. Any person requiring the greater immunity this aid offers from all electronic and electrical interference, not just digital mobile phones, could upgrade now.

BREAK.PARA: The Spectrum Management Agency is writing to the Therapeutic Goods Administration asking them to consider mandating the standard. Mandatory requirements would be phased in over a two‐ to three‐year period to ensure that aids that do not comply with the standard are not made obsolete overnight.

The future development of AS1088.9.C.2 will allow a hearing aid wearer to use a digital mobile phone, placing the phone against the ear, not using the hands‐free attachments that are currently available for some models of phones. Aids that meet these specifications are now being developed. Pacemakers used in Australia, if subjected to electromagnetic interference, will revert to backup, that is, the pacemaker's baseline program. The pacemaker will not stop working. Once the interference goes away, the pacemaker will revert to its normal program. Pacemakers that offer higher immunity from electromagnetic interference from digital mobile phones and other radiocommunication transmitters have been developed and show marked improvement in immunity levels.

For those reasons, we are opposed to this amendment. I stress, which I do not think Senator Allison did, that she is saying that, if you do not have coverage from 1 July, which is only a few months away, AMPS ought to be able to continue. It is simply a backdoor way of doing what the earlier amendment was designed to do but probably it would cause more chaos in the process.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to make some comments on the government's proposals that come some way to sorting out some of the problems with this phase‐out. The process we have is a very elaborate one. It allows potentially for some rural and remote customers to continue to have access to AMPS, but only at very limited sites. It also requires fairly elaborate consultation procedures, and I might say these are with the AMPS carriers but not with the non‐AMPS carriers. It would be interesting to know why it was that they were not to be consulted. I think our amendment provides for a much stronger guarantee for rural users and it covers the needs of those people with hearing disabilities.

BREAK.PARA: The minister also likes to say that the phase‐out of analog would cost hundreds of millions. Last year there was an article in the Australian which challenged this. It said:
The federal government is saying if it does not phase out analog mobile phones it will face huge compensation payouts to digital operators.
It also reports an Optus spokesperson as saying that the company regards the contract as binding. The journalist in this case said:

Optus did not pay $800 million for its digital cellular licence at the time it received the second wire‐line carrier licence. Digital was just on the drawing board. That $800 million licence fee was not for a mobile network, let alone a digital one. Optus bought the rights to duplicate Telstra's cable network, and to soften the blow the government added the existing domestic satellite service Aussat debt free as a sweetener. The satellites alone were worth $800 million. Optus also has the right to build the second analog cellular phone network in competition with Telstra. But for complex reasons which the writer has gone into in the past, Telstra and Optus then worked out a deal to share the analog MobileNet service with the proviso that Optus could later build its own digital network. Optus still earns hundreds of millions of dollars each year from the analog network.
And so on. I will not read that whole article. I am sure the minister has read it himself.

I think that the government needs to be reminded that it is not reasonable to go on saying that the phase‐out—or the deferral, which is what we are asking for here today—is going to cost hundreds of millions of dollars. That is a convenient excuse that the government uses and that the minister can no longer justify.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to seek clarification of the minister's earlier comments in regard to people with hearing aids. Minister, were you stating that there would not be interference with digital mobile phones for those hearing impaired people who were wearing hearing aids of a certain type? You indicated that that particular type of hearing aid was currently either under production and/or being distributed. Could you clarify? Is a certain type of aid required for those people to use digital phones?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I said that solutions to interference problems experienced when the digital phone technology was introduced have been found and are being implemented. Hearing aids that comply with the standard to enable the use of a digital mobile phone to within one metre of the aid are being developed. Anyone who requires a greater immunity can upgrade now. The Spectrum Management Agency is considering mandating a standard. There are further developments which will allow a hearing aid wearer to use a digital mobile phone. Aids that meet these specifications are now being developed.

—Thank you, Minister, for that response. Can I ask you for additional clarification? Is that as it sounded—that is, you talk about `within one metre'? I am just wondering about the distance between two parts being a metre. What are the two parts? I am assuming that is not the aid in one case and the digital telephone being a metre away. I just want to clarify what that distance of one metre referred to.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —It means that, if you are using a digital phone, you need to be more than one metre away from the person that you are talking to—I am sorry: away from the person with a hearing aid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition does not support the amendments moved by the Democrats. I do note the interest taken by Senator Stott Despoja. I think that probably has a personal consideration about it which I think is quite reasonable to raise. The evidence we received at the committee about this interference for people with hearing aids, which has already been covered, is something which cannot be walked away from and cannot be ignored. However, I do not think we can move to leave an analog system going across Australia. We should be directed at making sure the industry gets the standards right, the technical side right, in GSM. If you do not do that, in various areas—maybe not necessarily in this area, but I suspect it probably would be—people with disability will end up with a lower quality level of technology in various aspects in years ahead; that may be the case.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it always should be on the manufacturer and the carriers if they want to go to a new technology to produce equipment that does not affect people with disabilities rather than the other way round. I think that is a cheap way out for the carriers and the manufacturers. They say, `Oh, no, we don't have to spend on R&D for GSM and for digital because the hearing impaired still have analog available.' I think the pressure must be on the carrier when they introduce new technology to get it right for all people with a disability. On that basis, we oppose the amendment.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

All I am saying to you is that you are the prime culprits when people ask why—

—On a point of order: you asked for the vote to be taken; it was taken. My point of order is that we are now asking you to proceed with a division. I do not know what Senator Alston is raving on about, but there is no reason for us not to proceed to a division.

(7) Grants under this section are to be paid out of money appropriated by the Parliament for the purposes of this section.
(8) In this section:
consumer body means a body or association that represents the interests of consumers.
telecommunications means the carriage of communications by means of guided and/or unguided electromagnetic energy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek clarification. Does this mean that we now have three sets of almost identical amendments? Is that correct?
