SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, I accept the expansion of the wording. I trust that you are able to use that expansion to convince the Treasurer to increase the appropriation in the budget. We wish you well in the ERC on that. You have good support from your officers from the department about the several million dollars that will be needed in this area.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a view that was raised and discussed by some of the consumer organisations; that is, that this money should be raised as a condition of a licence or a levy on the licence, so that the carriers fund it. As I understand it, there are some constitutionality problems in doing it that way. I still believe carriers ought to make a contribution. I think it is in their own interest to be involved in this.

Minister, I would put it to you that, as far as the opposition is concerned, we do not see it as unreasonable to say that, if you may not be able to put a direct levy on it, you may be able to hypothecate an equivalent increase in the licence fee of carriers and make that money available for the purposes outlined in the actual amendment.

One of the issues is really important here. While Telstra was a monopoly and even the dominant carrier, they accepted the need—maybe reluctantly, but they did it accept it—and provided money to consumer organisations for research, for a consumer voice to be appropriately heard. Quite rightly, they say that now in a competitive environment with other carriers they should not be expected to carry the load to fund—even though they are still the dominant carrier—the social research and the consumer research of those organisations for other carriers. I think they have a perfectly valid point on it.

I also believe that it is not unreasonable, and certainly you have our support, Minister, if over a period of time you want to hypothecate an increase in the carriers' levy. It would not be a substantial amount compared with the revenues of the carriers. The carrier with a revenue of $15 billion, Telstra, has profits of nearly $3 billion. I think a small contribution of only a few million dollars from Telstra—maybe less than $5 million per annum—and from Optus, which is rapidly getting revenues of a couple of billion dollars, a proportionate hypothecation of their licence fees would be easier for you to argue in the ERC with the Treasurer than a straight appropriation from the government's revenue.

I accept the minister's expansion of the second dot point. I hope that it does not mean that there is such a call on these moneys that everyone ends up with so little that it makes it ineffective. This really was about consumer representation—consumer bodies being able to be in a position to vigorously protect consumer interests in a deregulated market. We accept the government's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I just wanted to raise a couple of points about the funding mechanism here. We have some concerns about this coming from normal budget measures, because of the fairly obvious reasons that they are so often the ones to be cut. We would have liked to have proposed that the fund be set at around $2 million a year and that it be obtained through the universal service levy.

SPEECH.PARA: We would argue that that way major industry participants could contribute on a more equitable basis and that that, as Senator Schacht has indicated, would ensure the ongoing availability of that money. We did not draft amendments which would reflect that, because of the difficulties in doing them. But I would be interested in the minister's comments about the ongoing security of such money and what sort of sums the minister would be asking for. I would like to get some feedback perhaps on those comments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, I wonder if you would care to comment about this variation of form of hypothecation by adjusting the carrier licence to raise the money—I am sure the Treasurer might be more interested in this—by increasing the carrier licence accordingly to all the carrier licences proportionately on their turnover to fund probably the few million dollars each year that will be needed. It would probably be no more than $2 million or $3 million. It may get bigger with the expansion now that you have added to the list. Is there any technical reason why a carrier licence cannot be increased to hypothecate an amount of money that then goes back, appropriated from parliament, to pay for the objectives outlined in the first two dot points?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot give you an answer to that, but certainly we will take it into account in looking at the way in which the system would work. If that is a sensible way to go, then we would be attracted to it.
—I am sorry, I may have missed that. Did the minister indicate a sum of money likely to be put forward in the budget?
—How about $10 million?

—I am sure even you would understand that you need to look at what the proposals are. You need to look at them in a budget context. You need to look at the effectiveness of what is contemplated before you allocate a sum of money. I cannot give you a figure that would be optimum. It depends entirely on what the merits of the proposals are, how many people are putting them forward and the extent of the overlap. The last thing I think you will want is a mindless formula that simply says, `You are entitled to X dollars irrespective of performance.' It ought to be on, I would think, probably a project by project basis. The capacity is there. If the programs put forward warrant financial support, then I am sure that they will be forthcoming.
—So there will be a sum of money put forward in the budget for this? I am sorry, I do not quite understand how the process will work.

—It is not hard to understand the process if you look at the form of the amendment that you were proposing to move. It says that the minister may, and that simply means that there is a discretion and the discretion will be exercised in accordance with the quality of the submission.

(207) Schedule 1, page 431 (after line 24), after clause 9, insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 9A Requirements relating to research and development activities

PARA.TAB: (1) The Industry Minister may, by written instrument, impose requirements that must be complied with by industry development plans in so far as those plans relate to the research and development activities of carriers.
(2) An industry development plan must not be made or varied in contravention of that instrument.
(3) If a purported plan or variation contravenes subclause (2), it is of no effect.
(4) If an industry development plan is in existence at the time (the imposition time ) when an instrument under subclause (1) imposes a requirement in relation to the plan:

TAB.TAB: (a) the requirement does not have any effect on the validity of the plan during the 180-day period beginning at the imposition time; and
(b) if, at the end of that 180‐day period, the plan is current but contravenes the requirement—the period to which the plan relates terminates immediately after the end of that period.

PARA.TAB: (5) An instrument under subclause (1) is a disallowable instrument for the purposes of section 46A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 .

SPEECH.PARA: (208) Schedule 1, page 432 (after line 6), after clause 10, insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 10A Compliance with provisions of plan relating to research and development activities

PARA.TAB: If an industry development plan of a carrier is current, the carrier must comply with the plan in so far as the plan relates to the carrier's research and development activities.

SPEECH.PARA: (209) Schedule 1, page 432 (after line 26), after clause 12, insert:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Industry Minister must, as soon as practicable after the end of each financial year (and, in any event, within 6 months after the end of the financial year), cause to be prepared a report relating to the progress made by carriers in implementing current industry development plans during the financial year.

(2) The Industry Minister must cause copies of a report prepared under subclause (1) to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after the completion of the preparation of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments to the carriers' industry development plan provisions will set out in more detail the information to be included in an industry development plan and for the industry minister to report to parliament each year. This implements the Senate committee's and the opposition's recommendations and one of the Democrat recommendations relating to industry development. The other Democrat recommendation, that approval of a proposed industry development plan being a precondition for being granted a carrier licence, would be WTO inconsistent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats strongly welcome these amendments by the government and will be supporting them. Although they are not as strong as they potentially could be, they are a very important step forward because they recognise that the industry development plans, as initially proposed, needlessly limited their effectiveness as a tool of industry policy and weakened the government's ability to extract desired outcomes for industrial development.

SPEECH.PARA: This was pointed out in the Democrats' minority report, which recommended that, where possible, enforcement of the plans was essential as, otherwise, preparation and monitoring of the plans would be futile. These amendments ensure that matters to be included in the carrier industry development plans are set out in more detail and, in particular, that they include matters in relation to meeting the needs of people with disabilities. Moreover, these amendments allow the industry minister to impose requirements in relation to research and development activities that must be complied within the carrier industry development plans.

I congratulate the government for having the courage to take this, albeit small, step in encouraging more and more foreign firms—which Telstra's competitors invariably are, and will continue to be—to come to Australia. However, this will do very little to boost our image as a regional centre for innovation and for research and development.

Indeed, a high level of foreign ownership actually contributes to low business expenditure on R&D because subsidiaries of multinational corporations are able to source their technology requirements from their parent companies. Given that they usually have large R&D facilities located at their home base, they have little incentive to undertake operations of much significance in their subsidiaries. If giant, foreign based firms dominate the market in an R&D intensive industry such as telecommunications, and are allowed to operate as they please, massive opportunities for the Australian community will be forfeited.

The government must continue to encourage and, wherever possible, exert pressure on such multinationals to undertake core business activities in Australia. This is something we should demand in return for giving them a carrier licence. The Democrats recommended that compliance with an industry development plan should be expected in all ways, other than any rendered ineligible under the WTO. Instead, the government amendments solely focus on R&D.

BREAK.PARA: The opposition amendment on sheet 420 goes this extra step. We will be supporting this amendment also. I appeal to the opposition to support the Democrats' amendments in this field as well, which we will move shortly. In the end, we may be able to impose stern conditions which will ensure that carriers, especially those foreign owned giants, in return for being given a carrier licence, are required to make investments which are truly to the long‐term benefit of the Australian economy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —My first question to the minister is to double‐check—
—I thought this was all uncontroversial.

—There is a query I want to put to you. I want to get something clear on my amendment 11A on compliance with industry development plans, which is on sheet 420. On page 26 of your sheet is amendment 10A on compliance with the provision of a plan relating to research and development activities. Your amendment says:

SPEECH.PARA: If an industry development plan of a carrier is current, the carrier must comply with the plan in so far as the plan relates to the carrier's research and development activities.
My amendment, which would be a bit further down, after line 15, says:
Compliance with industry development plans
I have called them industry development plans, which partly takes up Senator Allison's point—
(1) If an industry development plan of a carrier is current, the carrier must comply with the plan.
And, most importantly, it says:
(2) Subclause (1) has no effect to the extent (if any) to which it is inconsistent with Australia's obligations as a member of the World Trade Organisation.

Firstly, we appreciate that the government has overwhelmingly accepted the recommendations from the opposition in the report of the Senate Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts References Committee—which were also supported by the Democrats and even by some of the government mem bers—to strengthen the industry development plans.

The definition on page 25 overwhelmingly—and officers might confirm this—comes from a suggestion of the Australian Information Industry Association to give more detail about what ought to be in industry plans. That is an excellent step forward. I commend the government for taking that on on behalf of the industry. I think it will be good for Australian industry.

There are two issues on which we are only marginally different. I cannot see a difficulty. We have not confined it to just R&D, but we have said that it must not be inconsistent with our obligations to the WTO. We make it quite clear that the sanction that the carrier must comply with the plan is not going to put us in an argument with the WTO. Some people in Australia might say, `Well, the WTO can go jump,' in view of the fact that we have been very pure for many years on tariffs and on transparency in trade arrangements, while some of our competitors have not been so transparent. That is a wider debate.

Minister, is it possible for you to accept that amendment of mine on sheet 420? I do, however, acknowledge that the government has made a major step forward in trying to reach agreement with us and the Democrats on this industry development side for the telecommunications industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —The difficulty is that, apart from R&D where we are in agreement, there are a significant number of other matters which, taken together, would cause an enormous amount of uncertainty in terms of carriers knowing whether they were complying with the relevant requirements.

SPEECH.PARA: You have carriers' relationships in connection with the production and supply of facilities; investment in manufacturing and supply capabilities; strategic alliances with Australian companies and with multinational companies; the production and supply of equipment for use by people with disabilities; and on it goes. To make all of those things subject to potentially serious penalties—

TALK.START.PARA: —But they are not compulsory.
—As I understand it, a breach of any of those, under your regime, would result in severe penalties. Is that not right?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —My amendment says that if an industry development plan of a carrier is current, the carrier must comply with the plan. There is the plan—right? But then we say the sub‐clause has no effect to the extent that it is inconsistent with Australia's obligations as a member of the World Trade Organisation.
—Particularly for not complying with the plan.
—Yes, but you cannot put the compliance on if it is in any way inconsistent.
—Yes, I understand that, but what if it is consistent but, nonetheless, you do not comply? A penalty applies.

—Yes, then a penalty applies. I am not going to try and forejudge whether a particular part of the plan is inconsistent. First of all, there has to be agreement between the industry minister and carrier as to what the plan is. The carrier may say it is too onerous, even though these are guidelines laid down covering a whole range of things. The industry minister may well agree. The things which you have accepted in the description are not all mandatory. We are told:

SPEECH.PARA: The plan must include any relevant particulars of the carrier's strategic commercial relationship including (but not limited to) . . .
The plan must include any relevant particulars of the carrier's activities in relation to research and development, including (but not limited to) matters in connection with . . .

I do not find that giving absolute detail because no one would expect them to guarantee an arrangement. They could discuss it with the industry minister. The industry minister may say, `I see what you are doing in that area. You have put forward a plan about arrangements relating to a technology transfer to Australian industry. That is not relevant in this plan. Therefore, it is not binding.' But when they agree what the plan is and, in accordance with this list of criteria, there is agreement, then the carrier is bound to comply with them. The minister might say, quite rightly, `I think there should be some things in this area of your plan to give them a bit of stick as well as a bit of carrot, to get an industry development program going that is expansive, that delivers the jobs to Australians and economic wealth to Australia.'
I have tried to avoid criticism in respect of breaking WTO arrangements. Secondly, paragraph (1) my amendment 11A does not try to be specific, and says:
If an industry development plan of a carrier is current, the carrier must comply with . . .

But the plan has to be agreed to by the minister. If the minister for industry says, `This first draft of the plan you have put forward is not acceptable,' then both sides will have to negotiate an extension or improvement of an agreement. The real issue is that the plan has to be agreed to. Those of us who have been involved in the past in these areas know that some parts of plans have not been forthcoming and have not been carried through. Carriers—and one in particular—have been able to ignore what they previously promised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —The problem is that industry plans are meant to be a basis for carriers giving an indication of their general intentions in a whole range of areas that would affect industry development. Once you start to make those plans across the board—not just R&D but virtually everything that breathes in the running of a business in this country—subject to potentially very severe penalties, there will be a very significant inhibition placed on a carrier in volunteering things into an industry plan. They do not really know whether it is consistent or inconsistent with WTO until after the event. But assuming they are held to be consistent with, there is a very significant risk on their part that they will unintentionally infringe.

SPEECH.PARA: You could go through a very complicated process in determining the extent to which they have complied with each element of an industry plan that is as broad and varied as the one we have described. If all of those activities are to be potentially subject to serious financial penalty, it seems to us to mean that you will simply create an environment of uncertainty which will distort the content of the carrier's industry plans. Rather than having them come forward with their best endeavours, what you will get is simply a low level indication of their true plans because they will be afraid that they might otherwise be penalised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, I note the point you make. I do not want to take up much time. I have to acknowledge that the government has made a major shift from its original position, and that has been an important step for industry development. I am merely asking you to take what I think is one further minor step. It is clear that you do not wish to take that last step. On behalf of the opposition I will, in this case, proceed with our amendment and put it to the test of the chamber. I do not wish to waste time because of it. In doing so, I accept the fact that the government has come a long way. I acknowledge that, and I do not want to be in any way disparaging.

SPEECH.PARA: Although we are moving a further amendment, I think the amendment is actually quite reasonable and does not do anything to undermine the carriers' position. I think it is a reasonable position, but I will still move our amendment. As you may be aware, the opposition has been going through some considerable review of industry policy in recent times, and this is part of the outcome of it. I have to say, again, that I acknowledge that the government has come a long way through the committee process. I just believe that this last little bit is not unreasonable.
Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, I want to make sure that the amendments just carried mean that all of your amendments on industry policy have now been carried, and my amendment is a further amendment to that?
—Yes.
—Thank you. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule 1, page 432 (after line 15), after clause 11, insert:
(1) If an industry development plan of a carrier is current, the carrier must comply with the plan.
(2) Subclause (1) has no effect to the extent (if any) to which it is inconsistent with Australia's obligations as a member of the World Trade Organisation.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Schacht's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: (Senator Carr did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the death of Senator Panizza)
(Senator Cook did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the resignation of Senator Woods)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Democrats' amendment No. 55 for industry development plan exemptions is to remove the scope of the industry minister to dispense patronage in the form of being able to declare certain carriers to be exempt from industry development obligations.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats share the concern of the Australian Telecommunications Industry Association that there is a lack of criteria against which the industry minister may decide to give an exemption from the industry development obligation. The majority committee report expressed the view that legislative entrenchment of such criteria may not be appropriate. Under these circumstances, the Democrats are of the view that ad hoc arrangements under which certain carriers would be able to circumvent industry development requirements should not be permitted. This can only lead to inequitable treatment of carriers on an ad hoc basis and it opens up scope for political patronage, favouritism and corruption in our view. So I propose that the Senate delete clause 5 from the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek some further clarification, Senator Allison. Amendment 54 reads:

SPEECH.PARA: That the ACA must not grant a carrier licence unless the applicant has given a current industry development plan to the industry minister and the industry minister has approved the plan.
Is that the amendment that you are moving?

TALK.START.PARA: —I think what has happened is that I have commenced on amendment 55 instead of 54. The two sheets I have both have 55 on them, so I have picked the wrong one.
—Senator Allison, it is probably appropriate that you move your amendment 54.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (54) Schedule 1, clause 4, volume 3, page 430 (lines 1 to 10), omit the clause, substitute:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 4 Carriers must have a current industry development plan

TAB.TAB: The ACA must not grant a carrier licence unless the applicant has given a current industry development plan to the Industry Minister and the Industry Minister has approved the plan.

SPEECH.PARA: This has to do with pre‐approval of industry development plans Is that your understanding too?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —On page 7 of your document 404 with all your amendments it says that it will be four carriers. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule 1, clause 4, volume 3, page 430 (lines 1 to 10), omit the clause, substitute:
4 Carriers must have an industry development plan

I read the rest out a couple of minutes ago. As I understand it, this means that you are asking that existing carriers must have an industry plan. That is, the ACA must not grant a carrier licence unless the applicant has given a current industry plan to the minister. Does that mean that every new carrier coming in from 1 July and existing carriers from 1 July must have an industry plan? Is that what it means?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, that is the thrust of our amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, unless it is covered somewhere else, this cannot be a controversial amendment, because what it is requiring is that the ACA must not grant a licence unless the applicant has given a current industry development plan to the industry minister and the industry minister has approved the plan. This is making sure that when they put the licence in—whether it is existing post 1 July—we are almost charging them a nominal fee, a peppercorn fee, to be a licensed carrier. I think it is a very small fee indeed. But the one thing the licence application does do is that before it is granted the industry minister must approve it. Because once he grants the licence your ability to get an industry plan is going to be compromised, because they will then be operating and it is going to be impossible to say, `We are going to take the licence from you after you start operating and providing services to consumers.'

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore, it seems to me, Minister, that this is not an unreasonable proposition to make sure that all carriers do provide a plan and get approval for it from the industry minister. If you can tell me that it is covered somewhere else, then fine. But if it is not, I cannot see how you can object, and we certainly would support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —The problem with amendment 54 is that it would essentially require an industry plan to be provided as a condition precedent to the granting of a licence, irrespective of whether or not the carrier was in the business of being engaged in industry and therefore requiring an industry development plan. If it simply owned a small amount of technology, then it would be a carrier but it would not necessarily be in the building business or the expansion business. To be a carrier, all you need to do is own a bit of piping more than five kilometres long. You do not have to be in the business of building, expanding an industry, or employing people, for that matter. You can simply be the owner and therefore a passive investor.

SPEECH.PARA: There would be no need for you in those circumstances to provide an industry plan. This would become a significant barrier to entry. It might also undermine Australia's position with its trading partners. Our amendment No. 207 allows the industry minister to impose requirements that relate to the R&D activities of carriers and we have just dealt with that. The industry minister is the one who is best placed to make judgments about whether there is a need for a plan and whether to grant exemptions. What the Democrats want to do is to remove any discretion to grant exemptions and they want everyone to put in an industry plan, irrespective of whether they are in the business. It just seems to us to be mindlessly bureaucratic.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —The present bill says that 90 days after a carrier is granted a carrier licence he must at all times have a current industry development plan. So, even if he is a pretty mickey mouse carrier, he is going to have to have a plan.
—Unless he is exempted. But they want everyone to have an industry plan, with no exemptions. What is wrong with the current flexibility? They want to remove it.
—The exemption from industry development plan declares that part 5 does not apply. Part 5 is where the exemptions are. It then says:

SPEECH.PARA: This part does not apply to a specified kind of carrier.
That is a disallowable instrument so, in one sense, there is a bit of protection there for the parliament if we think that some carrier is trying to dud Australian industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you just want a few line links, why should you have to provide an industry plan?

—I would have thought that a carrier has an important role. You are giving a carrier a licence and carriers get certain advantages once they get a licence in Australia, even under the deregulated regime. They are not service providers. They get certain advantages as a carrier. Even if they are a small carrier, it is not unreasonable that they submit something with their licence at the time.

SPEECH.PARA: If the minister implies that the so‐called small carriers are going to be exempt from a policy, then I suspect that we, as opposition, will be in here making a lot of disallowances because we believe that the quid pro quo for having a deregulated competitive market—which has a lot of advantages to a carrier—is the development of an Australian telecommunications industry so that jobs are created in Australia. Then we create critical mass, so that some of these carriers, whether they are Australian or not, actually start exporting, as well. I do not think that it is unreasonable to say that no matter how big or small you are, at the time you lodge your application to be a carrier, you have to give some indication of what your industry plan is and have that approved by the minister for industry.

I am not opposed to the industry minister having a power of exemption—which is section 5—but I am very concerned that, firstly, carriers might not have to lodge any plan at all until 90 days afterwards. Once they get a licence, it is much harder to say what the plan is. It really is shutting the stable door after the horse is more than well out. We all know that.

It is not an amendment I brought forward, but I have to say that the Democrats amendment replacing 4 with theirs is not unreasonable. You still have the exemption in 5—a disallowable instrument—and the Senate can determine whether it is a fair exemption being given and it can debate that. But we let every carrier know, no matter how big or small, that the Australian telecommunications industry is one that we want to create jobs in. We have a commitment to develop Australia in this area for jobs, and to get into exports, so that the growth in this industry will not continue to be an extraordinary drain or a deficit on the current account figures that come out every month. Over a year for telecommunications that runs into billions of dollars.

TALK.START.PARA: —We're not here to have a bloody debate about policy, surely?
—Well, I have to say—
—Just address yourself to this.

—I am saying that that is why we believe it is not unreasonable to have a look at the Democrats' amendment and that we are sympathetic to it. We accept the fact that the minister has got an exemption saying, `They don't need to have one,' but when they—
—Does that mean you are not supporting them on 55?
—On 55, which is—
—That will remove the power to grant exemptions.
—No, I would not support them on that. I think a minister should have the power, because it is a disallowable instrument and we will have the debate at the time. So, Minister, I support—

BREAK.PARA: Senator Alston interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —If that is a compromise you can live with, I am certainly going to live with it as well.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I repeat that I think it is inflexible. You are requiring it irrespective of what their plans are, whether they are in the roll‐out business or whether they are simply passive owners of links. We are prepared to not oppose 54 on the basis that the opposition opposes 55.
—Done. It's a deal.
—I would be interested to hear what Senator Allison says about all of this. I understand the point that has been made, but I would certainly like to see what Senator Allison says about the matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —We put forward this amendment to ensure that approval of proposed industry development plans by the minister should be a precondition for being granted a carrier licence. It is our view that the industry development plans, as they are currently outlined, needlessly limit their effectiveness as a tool of industry policy and weaken the government's ability to extract desired outcomes for industrial development.

SPEECH.PARA: Carriers are only required to have an industry development plan in force within 90 days of being granted their licence. We think it is far more appropriate that approval of industry development plans by the industry minister be made a prerequisite for obtaining a licence. This would ensure that the government has more leverage and that industry development plans are not simply bureaucratic procedures which do not have any relevance in themselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chair, unfortunately on the last division I was a victim of misadventure. I was in Speaker Halverson's office at a function and, because of the attendant noise there, did not hear the bells until they had almost completed ringing. I therefore would ask the committee's indulgence that that matter be resubmitted so that I can make my vote.
—We cannot do it at the moment. We will have to get rid of the amendment before us.

—There is an amendment before us at the moment. Could I suggest, as Senator Brown has requested this, that the matter be recommitted at the end of the committee stage. Could we do that? I would appreciate it if that were done.
—The full committee stage?
—Yes, why should he queue jump?

—I have been trying to follow this matter through in a logical sequence. I am quite happy for the matter to be recommitted, but the question is when? Can we continue to deal with these matters as we have been doing and have the recommittal at the end of the committee stage?
—I agree with Senator Harradine.

—All I want to suggest to you, Senator Harradine, is that I think we should complete the debate we are now on. We are about to conclude dealing with the present clause. I cannot see why we cannot then recommit. I think it is now a standard convention in this place—

—I am suggesting that you do it at the end of the committee stage. I would not agree to anything else. I think the appropriate time is at the end of the committee stage. I am quite happy for it to be recommitted.
—We will not finish the committee stage tonight. At the end of the committee stage this afternoon, can we clear the matter up?
—No.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I indicate that I accept the logic of Senator Harradine's argument and I think it ought to be understood that, if there is a good reason for someone not being here for a vote on a division and they wish to have the matter recommitted, it should not be recommitted at their convenience; it ought to be at the convenience of the committee. If the committee's wish is that it be done at the end of the current debate, then that is when it ought to be done.
—It seems to me to be the will of the committee that we have any recommittal at the end of the debate, and that is when it will occur.
—Mr Chairman, all I want to say is that when the incidents occurred last year—I think one involved Senator Alston—the opposition always agreed to recommit for misadventure.
—No-one is disagreeing with that.

—Okay. I have to say that my memory is not fresh on whether we waited until the end of the committee stage to recommit or whether we did it as soon as the opportunity arose, when those incidents occurred. All I am saying is that if it was done as soon as possible within that committee stage when those previous episodes occurred, I think it is only reasonable that the same procedure should apply. I have to say to Senator Harradine that I cannot recollect whether, in the episode that Senator Alston or others were involved in, they waited until the end or did it at the first opportunity within the committee stage.
—On the last occasion I remember it was submitted then and there.

—These are not ironclad conventions. It is a matter of convenience in this particular debate. If you are at a point in the debate then there is nothing unreasonable about suggesting that you wait until the end of the committee stage.

—I think that the problem may be that we will be setting a convention if there is insistence on the matter being kept until the end of the committee stage. I would ask the government and the Independent member to reflect upon that. It may be, for example, that there are consequences of a motion being altered which have to be dealt with in committee. It may not be the case on this occasion, but I am sure that is going to happen further down the line. I think the commonsense decision would be that we resubmit the matter straight off. However, I am at the mercy of the committee on this. I am grateful that it will be resubmitted and I leave the question of when to other members to determine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I am going to say this. It is all right, you can jump up if you like. How long have you been sitting here listening to the debate? I have sat here hour after hour. How long have you been sitting here, Senator Brown, listening to this debate? Do you know what this amendment is all about? What is this amendment all about? What I am asking you to do is to have a recognition that I, for example, and other people have been sitting here hour after hour after hour on this particular measure. You missed a division. Okay, it was misadventure. I am quite happy to have it recommitted—quite happy indeed. All I say is: let us deal with the matter as we are dealing with it at this point. At least have some respect for those of us who have been sitting here hour after hour.

SPEECH.PARA: We are prepared, as is the convention if an honourable senator, through misadventure, has not been able to be here for a division—on a matter, presumably, which you know nothing about—to have the matter recommitted. If we are setting a precedent, well good‐o. I think that is a good thing. It will probably reflect on me as much as anybody else. But let us have the recommittal at the end of the committee stage. As far as I am concerned, I agree to your request that it ought to be recommitted, but that ought to take place at the end of the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman—
—All right, Jim, how long have you been here?

—I am not only exercising my right as a member of this chamber to speak on this debate but, at the moment, speaking as the acting opposition whip. The opposition whip, at any time, has a right to intervene in the debate.
—You can speak as long as you like.
—The only remarks I want to make—and they are not so much personal remarks—will be made in the context of the position that I am occupying at the moment.
—How long have you been here?
—I understand there has been an opposition whip in the chamber all the way through this debate, and that is what I am acting as at the moment.
—You wouldn't have a clue.
—Mr Chairman, I want to make this comment: we could be setting an unfortunate precedent for the future.
—How could we?

—The precedent being that we can interrupt the flow of how amendments are dealt with during complex debates in the committee stage if, through misadventure or any inadvertent action of the committee, a vote goes the wrong way—which can happen. There was some difficulty between the whips in counting the last vote. We all witnessed there was a difficulty in counting it, in arranging the pairs. It could have been that through the actions of the acting whips things went amiss, and might do in the future. This might set a precedent for how in the future we handle situations like the one we are in at the moment. It could be dangerous.

SPEECH.PARA: From a personal point of view—although I am not necessarily speaking from a personal point of view—I think we have to be aware of what precedents we set in addressing this. I can recall on the last occasion when such a misadventure occurred—and I dare say I will remind you, Senator Alston, about that matter—that it was important, from your point of view and from the government's point of view, that the vote be recommitted very quickly. After a period of argument that certainly was done.

That is not to say that we should not disregard what Senator Harradine has said, but we do have to be cognisant of the precedents we might be setting for the future. I would urge the committee to recommit now and get the matter out of the way so that we will know, if the matter happens again in this shape and form, the way it will go.

TALK.START.PARA: —Suit yourself; put it to the vote.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak as one who has been in this situation in the not too distant past. It could not possibly set a precedent to have this recommittal taken at the end of the committee stage, for the simple reason that that was not what happened in my situation. So you will have two conflicting precedents, if you think precedent has anything to do with it.
—It was pretty quick though.

—It was pretty quick in that instance. Was that the precedent then? Is this the precedent now? Neither of them are precedents. They are both examples of doing it in different ways at different times. That ought to be what guides you. You ought to do it in the context of what is going on in the chamber, the importance of the issue and the convenience of the senators involved in the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: I think why Senator Harradine has exploded—and he is probably a bit less restrained than I am on this occasion for once, but I felt similarly—is to think that this bloke can just wander into the chamber with a smirk on his face, and get up and expect to be given instant royal treatment and have the vote recommitted after he said about two words. As I recall, I had to grovel for at least five minutes.

BREAK.PARA: There is no doubt he would not have the slightest idea what this is about. We have been in here for hour upon hour. Senator Brown, to think that you can just come in here to suit your own convenience and then presumably go back to the party you have been attending, I think, ignores completely the courtesies of the chamber.

What has been suggested in this instance by Senator Harradine very much meets the circumstances. You are entitled to have your hearing later on. You ought to do that and be grateful. You ought to accept that there are other matters that have been dealt with here over a protracted period. Perhaps tempers get short in the process, but that is simply a reflection of the fact that we think there are conveniences that ought to be acknowledged. The way in which you have come in here has been particularly insensitive. To think that you can simply get to your feet and effectively demand to be heard on the spot flies completely in the face of the discretions that the chamber ought to exercise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, Senator Alston, I think that Senator Brown did the right thing. As soon as he found out, he came into the chamber—
—He did, and we have agreed to recommit.
—Okay, but you said he came in in a particularly insensitive way. I do not think it was insensitive.
—He was expecting to be immediately given the call.

—He came in. The first thing he did, which was the correct thing, was to bring to the attention of the Senate that, due to misadventure, he missed the division. Nobody can argue with that. He did the correct thing.
—While we were considering a particular motion he got up and said it. It had nothing at all to do with that particular motion.

—Yes, but he brought it to our attention. The next argument is: when is the correct time? As I understand it, you can move a motion to recommit or you can seek leave to do so. If you seek leave, one senator can object and therefore you cannot do it that way. If you have a motion to recommit, although we are in the committee stage, that will be a debate and a vote in itself.
—Move it and see how it goes.

—All I can say, Senator Harradine, is that if I move a motion to recommit and you vote no, even if the Greens and the Australian Democrats vote yes with the opposition, that is a tied vote. I am not that good at mathematics but I can count that. That is a tied vote, without even knowing how Senator Colston would vote. That would be a tied vote and it would be lost. I am not interested in wasting time. The minister and I have been here longer than anybody else on this bill in the committee stage. We win that argument together, Alston and Schacht, without any trouble.

SPEECH.PARA: A motion is going to be defeated and will just waste time. I have to say that I am interested in what the precedents are of people coming in here and giving notice. Did we get straight on to it or did we wait till the end of a debate, end of a committee stage, end of a second reading or whatever?

TALK.START.PARA: —Australian Senate Practice does not give any real assistance on it.

—Senator Harradine, this time I am on your side. We on this side of the chamber have had some time to tick‐tack and we now accept that there is some logic in Senator Harradine's recommendation, if I can put it that way, that the recommittal occur at the end of the committee stage. It did take time to sort it out. As there is a recognition on this side of the chamber that we should do that, I do not think we should delay the matter any further at this time. But, clearly, approval has been given to recommit that particular opposition amendment.
—The question is that the Australian Democrats' amendment be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats oppose schedule 1, clause 5 in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: (55) Schedule 1, clause 5, volume 3, page 430 (lines 11 to 16), TO BE OPPOSED .

This is in relation to industry development plan exemptions. The purpose of this amendment is to remove the scope of the industry minister to dispense patronage in the form of being able to declare certain carriers exempt from industry development obligations. The Australian Democrats share the concern of the Australian Telecommunications Industry Association that there is a lack of criteria against which the industry minister may decide to give an exemption from the industry development obligation.

The majority committee report expressed the view that legislative entrenchment of such criteria may not be appropriate. Under these circumstances, the Democrats are of the view that ad hoc arrangements under which certain carriers would be able to circumvent industry development requirements should not be permitted. In our view, this can only lead to inequitable treatment of carriers on an ad hoc basis and opens up scope for political patronage, favouritism and corruption. I propose that the Senate delete clause 5 from the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition opposes this, for reasons already expressed.
—The question is that clause 5 of schedule 1 stand as printed.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (210) Schedule 1, page 444 (after line 6), after clause 28, insert:

PARA.TAB: (1) For the purposes of this Part, giving access to a tower includes replacing the tower with another tower located on the same site and giving access to the replacement tower.
(2) For the purposes of this Part, giving access to a site on which is situated a tower includes replacing the tower with another tower located on the site.

SPEECH.PARA: (211) Schedule 1, page 444 (after line 24), after subclause (3), insert:

PARA.TAB: (3A) In determining whether compliance with subclause (1) in relation to a tower is technically feasible, the ACA must have regard to:

TAB.TAB: (a) whether compliance is likely to result in significant difficulties of a technical or engineering nature; and
(b) whether compliance is likely to result in a significant threat to the health or safety of persons who operate, or work on, the tower; and
(c) if compliance is likely to have a result referred to in paragraph (a) or (b)—whether there are practicable means of avoiding such a result, including (but not limited to):
(i) changing the configuration or operating parameters of a facility situated on the tower; and
(ii) making alterations to the tower; and
(d) such other matters (if any) as the ACA considers relevant.

SPEECH.PARA: (212) Schedule 1, page 445 (after line 23), after subclause (3), insert:

PARA.TAB: (3A) In determining whether compliance with subclause (1) in relation to a site is technically feasible, the ACA must have regard to:

TAB.TAB: (a) whether compliance is likely to result in significant difficulties of a technical or engineering nature; and
(b) whether compliance is likely to result in a significant threat to the health or safety of persons who operate, or work on, a facility situated on the site; and
(c) if compliance is likely to have a result referred to in paragraph (a) or (b)—whether there are practicable means of avoiding such a result, including (but not limited to):
(i) changing the configuration or operating parameters of a facility situated on the site; and
(ii) making alterations to a facility situated on the site; and
(d) such other matters (if any) as the ACA considers relevant.

SPEECH.PARA: (213) Schedule 1, page 446 (after line 12), after subclause (3), insert:

PARA.TAB: (3A) In determining whether compliance with subclause (1) in relation to an eligible underground facility is techni cally feasible, the ACA must have regard to:

TAB.TAB: (a) whether compliance is likely to result in significant difficulties of a technical or engineering nature; and
(b) whether compliance is likely to result in a significant threat to the health or safety of persons who operate, or work on, the eligible underground facility; and
(c) if compliance is likely to have a result referred to in paragraph (a) or (b)—whether there are practicable means of avoiding such a result, including (but not limited to):
(i) changing the configuration or operating parameters of the eligible underground facility; and
(ii) making alterations to the eligible underground facility; and
(d) such other matters (if any) as the ACA considers relevant.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment 210 is designed to clarify the requirement to provide access to another carrier and to ensure that it includes a requirement to build another tower if necessary. It makes it clear that the obligations placed on carriers in providing access to a tower include the obligations to construct a new tower and that providing access to a site on which a tower is situated includes replacing the tower with another tower. It ensures that carriers cannot refuse requests to collocate if it is possible to accommodate the request by building a new tower. These do not arise out of the Senate committee hearings.

Amendments 211 to 213 require carriers to provide access to telecommunications transmission towers and sites and underground facilities, unless the ACA certifies that it is not technically feasible. The amendment provides guidance as to what the ACA should have regard to in certifying what is technically feasible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, I appreciate that you said that this did not come out of the work of the Senate committee, but, in view of the fact that the issue of towers is extremely sensitive in the community, I think you should give us a bit more information about the purpose of these amendments about access to towers and whether they came from carriers, DOCA or anywhere else?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —These provisions generally come from the licence conditions, and they are being put in legislation to ensure that there is no ambiguity. There has been a lot of consultation with the carriers. There has been concern that Telstra in particular has been reluctant to collocate—as we know—and this is designed to ensure that, as far as practicable and possible, facilities are co‐located.

—We had the round table discussion at the Senate hearing where Vodafone and Optus made a bit of a point and Telstra admitted that only seven of their towers had had some sort of collocation. So you are saying that this is how that is being addressed?
—Yes, it arises out of that discussion.
—If that is the case, the opposition supports the amendments, which have nothing to do with the other issues relating to towers which will come up later under `immunities'.

—Minister, I wonder if you can give us some clarification about part (1) of clause 28A. Is it intended that `access' gives an opportunity for another tower to be built alongside an existing tower? Is that what the purpose of this is? I do not understand why that is necessary. Isn't collocation about putting antennae on the same tower?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —The concept of access to a tower is twofold: to enable access to existing facilities and to effectively bring about the replacement of existing facilities, if necessary, in different places so that you have them collocated on a new tower.
—I am sorry, Minister, I thought you indicated that it would mean building another tower if necessary. Are you suggesting that that is not what `giving access' means?
—If necessary, you would construct a new tower.

—This raises questions about powers and immunities. Would this mean that a tower might be replaced with one which is taller than that which might be given an exemption under the new arrangements? I realise that we do not know what those arrangements are. Would this require that the second tower, after one was demolished and removed and another built in its place, be the same size? Can it be a different shape or taller? Does replacing a tower with a bigger tower remove it from the need to demonstrate low impact or medium impact, for instance? What status does a replacement tower have compared with a new one?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is really designed to ensure that the problem that Senator Schacht identified—where Telstra plays hard ball and refuses access—is overcome. But if you are to construct a new tower, you would have to go through all the normal planning processes that will apply after 1 July. There will be no particular exemptions for new towers that are designed to bring together existing facilities any more than there will be for a brand new tower in a new area.

—I still do not understand why, if it is to encourage collocation and Telstra to accept another carrier on its site, there would be the need for replacing the tower. Surely we are not talking about Optus coming along and demolishing a Telstra tower in order to put another one up. I am still not clear about the necessity for part 1 of that clause.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think that we can anticipate all the situations in which it might not be technically feasible. There may be a limitation in terms of the area of land—it might be just big enough to accommodate the resources of one carrier. If you are going to have two or three carriers using the same tower, then you may need a greater area of land than you already have. The tower itself may not be designed in such a way as to simply accommodate addi tions to it. I suppose there is a whole range of other reasons.

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the day, the purpose is clear: you are trying to avoid an unnecessary multiplicity of towers and to collocate wherever possible. If that involves, for whatever reason, the demolition of existing towers and the construction of a new tower to accommodate several carriers, then, having gone through the normal planning processes that will be in place, it will be possible to do that. That will be a collocation on a new tower.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, the purpose of this clause is to define access, and the purpose of that is to encourage collocation. It is to insist that Telstra provide access for other carriers to collocate. I still am not clear about what this clause intends. It is the rebuilding which is unclear. Does this mean that Optus can come along and say, `I want to collocate on this tower, but it is not big enough for my equipment, therefore, I will pull it down and build another' or `I want you to build another'? It still does not gel. I can understand giving access to an existing tower, but why is this provision enabling construction of a replacement tower?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is simply designed to promote collocation wherever possible. In a situation where another carrier is very keen to collocate with an unwilling carrier, such as Telstra, and if it is necessary, for technical or other reasons, to construct a new tower, then that can be approved by the planning authorities. Presumably the cost will be shared on an equitable basis.
—But it won't be a low impact facility, so it has to go through—
—It has to go through the normal planning processes.

—I find this extraordinary. On the one hand you are saying that perhaps the carriers can share the cost, but I do not see in this clause the procedure for doing that. It seems to me that this leaves a whole lot of questions. It might mean that a carrier can come along and remove a tower which belongs to somebody else and put another up. You just said that it would simply be a planning matter. But it seems to me to be much more than that. It is about giving access to a tower in order to remove it, which seems to me to be quite an extraordinary provision.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —For about the fifth time: the current rules allow for applications to be made by carriers to collocate where possible. The reality has been that Optus and Vodafone have managed to come to agreements on a regular basis; Telstra has not. This is simply designed to make it easier for physical collocation to occur. I cannot keep saying it endlessly without assuming that you are deliberately attempting to be obtuse to avoid getting on with the main game.

—I am not being obtuse for any reason other than to seek clarification of this. You still have not explained why it is necessary, and what the process is by which a tower can be required to be removed and another erected in its place in order for collocation. That is not clear. I understand point 2 and I am quite happy to support that. But it is the building of another tower in the same place which does not seem to me to make any sense, unless you already have that cooperation and unless you have that agreement between the towers—otherwise what is the purpose of this.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have said about 10 times that Telstra does not often cooperate in these circumstances. You have several hundred sharing and collocation agreements between Optus and Vodafone. You have about half a dozen in the case of Telstra. Clearly they are not cooperating in the same way; they are not wanting to share the same tower. This amendment simply enables carriers to apply to have a forced collocation, if you like. If that requires the construction of a new tower for technical reasons, so be it. But it has to go through all the planning processes, so I cannot see what your objection is to that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —If you are forcing Telstra to have their tower demolished in order to have another one built, what are the arrangements for funding that? Who does pay? If it is to be shared equally, what sort of process do you need to go through to decide, firstly, whether or not the tower is to be removed?
—They are either agreed between carriers or arbitrated by the ACCC.

—The minister probably wants to shout over me, but I think I still have the floor. We are talking here about forced cooperation—forcing Telstra to accommodate another carrier. This clause allows for a whole tower to be presumably demolished and another built in its place. You might argue that that may be necessary under certain circumstances, but what are the provisions for the arrangement of who pays for what, and is this reasonable?

SPEECH.PARA: Can Optus come along and say, `I need to collocate here. That tower is not big enough. I propose that we pull it down and build another one'? As I said earlier, you did not answer this question. Is Telstra able to object to that? Is there some route by which it can go to the ACA and complain? What exactly is the mechanism? It seems to me to be an extraordinary provision which does not allow for the sorts of disputes that might arise, whether they are about cost or whether they are about having one's tower removed and another one put up in its place. What happens in the meantime to this tower? Do you just pull one down and have no service in that area until the next one is built? What does this in fact do?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —It sounds to me as though you are the one who is not in favour of collocation wherever possible. You seem to be wanting to find every reason to ensure that it does not occur. The facts are that, if other carriers want to co‐locate and Telstra does not, those carriers will have the ability to apply through the normal planning processes to get, if necessary, a new tower built. The terms and conditions on which that construction will occur will be a matter of negotiation in the first instance and, in the default of agreement, will be arbitrated upon by the ACCC.

—This seems an extraordinary circumstance. The circumstance today indicated that Vodafone were telling us, `You let us do something not nice or we'll do something worse.' I think it is an appalling situation that we have got to this stage in relation to telecommunications and we are finding already that we have a situation that seems to be out of the control of government. The indication is here that it should be out of the control of the Senate as well, in terms of providing a situation where people should behave reasonably within the community in relation to the collocation of towers or their actions in relation to whether or not they abide by reasonable community standards. How have we got to the situation in the Senate where we almost have a gun to our head and are being told, `You allow us to do something you do not like or we'll do something worse'? I would like the minister to explain how we have allowed ourselves to get to this situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —On a philosophical basis, I feel that there would be a need to approach this matter in a different way ab initio. In other words, my policy approach would have been to suggest that there be a telecommunications authority which the carriers then would access for the infrastructure. In other words, the telecommunications authority would have had the infrastructure and the carriers then would have been eligible to—
—It is called structural separation amongst the aficionados.

—Structural separation; you are right. That argument has been advanced and it has been lost. Now we have a situation where, as I understand it, this amendment is at least requiring Telstra to allow other carriers to access their already existing towers. That is how I see it. It would be better for business and particularly the environment for that to take place.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the point that Senator Margetts raised, I would like to hear the minister's response to the question about reasonableness. Is it a fact that, if Telstra is not reasonable in the circumstances, the ACCC has the power to direct Telstra to provide access to its tower facilities?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to that is that the ACA will determine the feasibility—in other words, whether or not it is necessary to construct a new tower or it is simply a matter of adding additional antennae to cater for the second carrier. But beyond that point, in determining the terms and conditions of access it is like the interconnect regime that applies between carriers: the ACCC is the competition body charged with making decisions about price. So the ACA does the technical feasibility; the ACCC does the financial arrangements in default of agreement.
—Am I correct in assuming that the ACA can require Telstra to make its towers available to a second carrier and that the price, if there is a dispute, will be settled by the ACCC?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, that is the case. The ACCC's responsibility is essentially confined to competition issues, which include the price of access. The ACA's responsibilities are essentially technical. Therefore, they are the ones most competent to make the judgment about whether or not it is feasible to have access and whether in fact it makes more sense to share a new facility. Beyond that point you move to the next economic regulator.

—It is interesting that the minister told me during a previous argument that the ACA did not exist. If I recall correctly, when I asked him which ACA he was talking about, he said there is only one ACA and that the other one does not exist. It is interesting he is talking about—
—It doesn't exist until after 1 July.

—Fine. So I cannot talk about it in future tense but you can. That is terrific. If bigger towers are to be built because of these sharing arrangements, would they still be low impact facilities? Is it the case that, if there was a necessity to build a larger tower, the tower would no longer be a low impact facility and would in fact need an environmental impact assessment if it is to become a bigger facility? If there is a necessity for a larger tower, is there not then the ability for the ACCC to work out an arrangement with Telstra in terms of the cost sharing of that facility? Obviously, if they have built a tower for their needs and do not feel they need to build a taller tower for their own needs, you can understand their reluctance to do so. Is there not some means by which these kinds of things can be worked out?
—Minister, do you wish to respond?
—No.

—I asked two specific questions, and I am not sure why the minister has chosen not to answer them. Firstly, if there was a necessity to build larger towers, is it not the case that in many instances they might no longer be low impact facilities?
—In many cases it will not be a low‐impact facility and you will need to go through the normal planning processes.

—Fine. I can understand why Telstra would not be keen to pay for a new tower if they felt that the tower they had already was all they needed for their requirements, but is there not some mechanism by which all of this can be worked out in a better way than we are seeing now?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very difficult to force people to be reasonable. If they choose not to be, then you need to take action to impose decisions, if necessary. I suppose you should not necessarily attribute bad faith to Telstra. I think the circumstantial evidence is pretty persuasive that Optus and Vodafone clearly see it as being in their economic interests to share because they have limited resources and it therefore reduces the cost. Telstra, on the other hand, has very deep pockets. Playing hard ball does not particularly worry it. In fact, it just ups the ante for its competitors. That is, I would have thought, the reason why it has been much less willing to enter into co-location agreements.

SPEECH.PARA: If government policy is to encourage co-location wherever possible and you have a carrier not wanting to co‐locate for its own commercial reasons, then government policy prevails. To the extent they go on being unable to reach agreement, then you have the matter arbitrated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Do we not in the end get down to a lack of will by government—and this is the question I asked before which did not get answered at all—if what we are left with is a mess where, despite all the best of assurances beforehand, we are left with a situation in which really the market decides and the community ends up paying the cost?

SPEECH.PARA: These are only the beginning stages of the post-1997 environment, we are just at the stage of formulating them, and we are finding that the market players are being left by government to make decisions already which obviously will be to the community's detriment. What I asked before—and the last time I was asking it you were also in conversation with somebody else—was: how did we get to this situation where already, before the post-1997 environment has even started, we have no real control over the impact these networks are having on the community?

TALK.START.PARA: —After this number of hours, I am not about to embark on a quasi-philosophical debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (214) Schedule 1, page 449 (line 6), after "their", insert "designated overhead lines, telecommunications transmission towers and".
(215) Schedule 1, page 449 (before line 15), before subclause (1), insert:

PARA.TAB: (1A) If a carrier owns or operates designated overhead lines, the carrier must keep and maintain records of the kind and location of those lines.
(1B) If a carrier owns or operates telecommunications transmission towers, the carrier must keep and maintain records of the kind and location of those towers.

SPEECH.PARA: (216) Schedule 1, page 449 (line 20), omit "subclause (1),", substitute "subclause (1A), (1B) or (1),".
(217) Schedule 1, page 450 (before line 1), before the definition of eligible underground facility , insert:
designated overhead line has the same meaning as in Schedule 3.
(218) Schedule 1, page 450 (after line 3), after the definition of eligible underground facility , insert:
telecommunications transmission tower means:

TAB.TAB: (a) a tower; or
(b) a pole; or
(c) a mast; or
(d) a similar structure;

SPEECH.PARA: used to supply a carriage service by means of radiocommunications.
(247) Schedule 3, page 498 (lines 12 and 13), omit subclause (1), substitute:

PARA.TAB: (1) The ACA may inform members of the public about the kinds and location of:

TAB.TAB: (a) designated overhead lines; and
(b) telecommunications transmission towers; and
(c) underground facilities.

SPEECH.PARA: Note: The heading to clause 46 of Schedule 3 (page 498, line 11) is altered by inserting "designated overhead lines, telecommunications transmission towers and " after "about ".
(248) Schedule 3, page 498 (line 26), after "means of the", insert "lines, towers or".
(249) Schedule 3, page 499 (after line 2), at the end of clause 46, add:

PARA.TAB: (5) In this clause:

SPEECH.PARA: telecommunications transmission tower means:

TAB.TAB: (a) a tower; or
(b) a pole; or
(c) a mast; or
(d) a similar structure;

SPEECH.PARA: used to supply a carriage service by means of radiocommunications.

Amendments 214 to 218 amend the access provisions and require carriers to keep records about towers and overhead cables as well as underground facilities. The amendments implement committee majority recommendation 4.5. They require the carriers to keep records for overhead lines and telecommunications transmission towers as well as for underground facilities, as originally provided for in the bill. The committee report recommended that there be an amendment to require carriers to keep such records and to provide that the ACA has discretion to inform members of the public about the kind and location of telecommunications transmission towers and designated overhead lines, respectively.

The government has accepted the committee's recommendation, as it considers it reasonable that carriers must keep records. Related amendments 247 to 249 will provide the ACA with the discretion to inform members of the public about the kinds and locations of designated overhead lines, telecommunications transmission towers and underground facilities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a very quick query. You said that amendment No. 247 has a discretion to inform. It says `may inform members of the public about the kinds and location'. Is there any need for `shall inform members of the public' through the normal arrangements of informing local governments about these locations?

SPEECH.PARA: I just want to know what difference is meant by using the word `may'? Does it mean that they may inform local government, the local planning authority, where they think it is reasonable? Is it in that way the word `may' is being used in conjunction with the word `public'? If that is the case and it is only to local government level, can they then inform the public, their local constituents, if they so choose? Is it possible to consider making it `shall inform members of the public about the kinds and location' of the designated (a), (b) and (c)? Do you have a view about that?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose it is only from first principles, but the normal reason why you would shy away from the mandatory is that there may be circumstances in which the public has no interest in the issue. There may be commercial‐in‐confidence reasons. There may be a variety of other reasons why the ACA, acting properly, would judge that it was not reasonable in the circumstances. Admin law would require them to do that so they cannot operate capriciously.

—I wonder if the minister can explain what this means in terms of retrospectivity. Are we talking now about carriers keeping records of the overhead lines and transmission towers, et cetera, that they are erecting now or will be in the future; or does it go back and are they required to build records based on current and existing installations? Also, what sort of records would you expect these to be? Would they be drawings, how would they be kept and how are they made public?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —To the extent that they already have records in place, they would be required to maintain them. To that extent, it is retrospective. Beyond that, I am sure the ACA would have a reasonable view of the world; it would simply say that you need records that are sufficient to provide information about the kinds and location of telecommunications transmission towers. Whether they do that by going out and taking films, whether by cartoons and sketches or by descriptive essays is all a matter for the ACA. I would have thought that, to any ordinary member of the public, keeping records is not a terribly difficult thing to define.

—Can the minister explain the purpose for these? What was it that generated the need for keeping them? I can imagine what it was. But I just wonder, in terms of the ACA's need for these records, what purpose would you expect them to be put to? I am just wondering why it is that the need for this documentation keeping is arising at this point of time, and why it did not happen back in 1991. Could that just be explained to us?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —You were on the committee, I was not. This arises out of majority recommendation 4.5. I presume it was canvassed during the committee stages and hearings and, as a result, it has had sufficient to commend itself to the government to find its way into legislation.

—The reason for my asking is that I think this recommendation was made because there seemed to be some doubt about where lines in particular were undergrounded and whether there was capacity. There seems to be some doubt about the ability of carriers to underground and because it is so expedient to erect aerial cabling the preference was always to do that. This seems to have arisen in the absence of real information about what that underground capacity might be. Perhaps the minister can tell us whether these provisions address that question or whether they are about something else.
—Minister, do you wish to respond?
—No.
—I did actually put a specific question. I think it is important. I will say it again because I noticed the minister talking.
—The minister does not wish to respond, Senator.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (56) Schedule 3, clause 3, volume 3, page 467 (lines 9 to 13), omit paragraph (b).

Amendment 56 deals with the definition of overhead line. The purpose of our amendment is to ensure that immunity from state and territory environment and planning laws is not extended to telecommunication lines under 13 millimetres in diameter and that local government approval is required for such installations. The government has argued that a size based definition is preferable to a service based definition if the source of concern is visual impact. This may or may not be true. But it is no reason why cables of less than 13 millimetres in diameter should not be the cause of concern, I would suggest. Nor is it clear if there is anything which would prevent multiple carriers from rolling out multiple cables of less than 13 millimetres in diameter. I do not think there is. I think this is a very legitimate source of community concern.
