BREAK.PARA: The Australian Local Government Association has warned that it is unclear how a court may, for instance, interpret the definition—that is, whether the 13 millimetres applies to just a single cable or to a bundle of cables plus any supporting wires or to the cables within a bundle. The ALGA has also raised concern that, contrary to the conventional view, the aerial broadband cable that is currently rolled out may be smaller than 17 millimetres in diameter.

The ALGA has discussed this issue with all of the major cable manufacturers in Australia, as I understand, and it has found that there is in fact a great variety of cables with different diameters which are currently being used. It is the ALGA's understanding that a variety of cables all under 13 millimetres are currently being rolled out. This being the case, we do not believe that a size based definition should be utilised. Perhaps the minister can indicate the purpose behind stipulating 13 millimetres and also address some of the matters I have raised. Is there an arbitrary figure or does this relate to some other cables?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Optus broadband cable is generally 17 millimetres in dimension. The Telstra broadband cable is generally 14 millimetres in cross-section. The standard telephone service line is generally significantly less than 13 millimetres, normally around 10 millimetres. It is therefore a point designed to differentiate between ordinary telephone lines, which are in themselves I would have thought very difficult to identify or single out as having any significant impact on the environment, and the ordinary hybrid fibre coaxial overhead cabling embracing both broadband cable and telephony wiring.

SPEECH.PARA: Consistent with the approach that the Democrats have taken to all of this, they simply do not want to see, in any shape or form, anything overhead when it comes to telecommunications. But of course you continue to have electric power lines up there. So, quite clearly, you will continue to have visual detriment even if your view of the world prevailed overnight. What this is designed to do is to try to strike a balance between normal telephony cabling and new technology cabling which is being rolled out at the present time.

To accede to your approach, which of course does not even pretend to draw a line—it simply produces the dimension to zero and it does it immediately because it inserts it in the designated overhead line definition, so in one fell swoop you also remove the transitional provisions—you are essentially just going down the same old path saying, `By hook or by crook we are not going to allow anything to go overhead.' I think there are some much greater implications for that proposal than you are prepared to concede.

It has significant economic implications not just for the carriers and those who might invest in them but for all those citizens who do make a conscious choice that they would prefer to have overhead cabling and all that goes with it in terms of access to competitive technologies, new local call services, cable television, the Internet and the like. There are a number of people around Australia, a number of councils around Australia, who have made that decision. But what you would do is simply say, again, `Irrespective of what your preference or your choice is, we are going to tell you what we want to do. We are not concerned that the carriers might have committed themselves to multibillion dollar roll-outs. We are not prepared to allow any transitional arrangements.'

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not transitional though.
—But for transitional provisions the construction of ordinary telephone services would be made subject to the same provision as for broadband cabling.
—This is about the size of cable.

—That is right. But once you change the definition you are effectively ensuring that you cannot have anything, not just in excess of 13 millimetres. You would not be allowed to have anything from day one, which is 1 July.
—Okay.
—So it eliminates the transitional arrangements.
—How long are the transitional arrangements to last anyway?
—Three months for overhead cable and six months for the rest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition supports this amendment from the Democrats. In the next part of the debate we are going to get into the bedevilling issue of immunities powers because of the issue of overhead cables. In the Senate committee hearings it was quite clear that the definition—that is, the reason for the 13 millimetres—was quite arbitrary: this is the thickness, as we know technology at the moment, of broadband cable for on-line services. For a mixture of on-line services Telstra's is 14 millimetres—the minister has said that—and Optus's is 17 millimetres. The minister has also said that for the standard telephony cable the copper wire is under 10 millimetres.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been made quite clear that any existing cable less than 13 millimetres hanging anywhere in Australia continues to hang there because that is exempt under the provisions of the various parts of this bill. That is existing infrastructure, like existing overhead broadband cables. They stay. That is what the bill says. So we are not talking about ripping down any cable that has already been laid.

We should not have a scare campaign that carriers will have to go out and pull down existing even thin telephony cable or copper wire which is less than 10 millimetres. It has to be quite clearly stated that we are not ripping anything down and that no carrier will be forced to. What we are saying is that from now on—from 1 July or, if the minister wins his amendment, 30 September—you will not be able to put up new thin cable less than 13 millimetres for any purpose unless you get agreement through the planning processes that this bill also is yet to consider.

Telstra, the major carrier, over many years now has progressively, particularly in rural areas and in most cities, undergrounded its telephony thin cable. I grew up in the bush in Gippsland in the 1950s when down every road opposite the electricity wires was a telephone system with dozens of copper pairs running on them for the local telephone system. Over the years Telstra of its own volition, because it is economically more feasible to do it and for the purposes of maintenance, has put all those cables underground in rural Australia. In most city areas they have done the same.

In my street, which was built in the 1960s, the copper wire for my telephone comes underground to the front of my house, goes up an electricity pole and then hangs as a thin wire coming into the house. If this amendment by the Democrats is carried, Telstra does not have to come round and pull that cable down, because it is already there. But if in future they want to go into a suburb and say, `We're going to hang thin telephony cable around,' for any reason, less than 13 millimetres, they have got to get planning approval. So it should be. There should be no exemption on this. Whatever the level of angst—some people say it is very strong to modest to very mild—the community is overwhelmingly fed up with the argument about cables.

TALK.START.PARA: —Metropolitan communities.

—As I have said, you drive through a lot of rural areas in Australia and there are no telephone lines above ground. I mentioned the other day in a speech that, for example, when the Ash Wednesday bushfires went through South Australia in a catastrophic way in March 1983—
—February.
—February 1983.
—16 February.

—It was Bob Hawke's policy speech day. You might say that was also Ash Wednesday for the Liberal Party. Nevertheless, what was interesting was that, throughout the extraordinary devastation that took place in rural South Australia, the telephone system still worked. Why? All the wire was underground. It was electricity that fell over. Electricity actually started the bushfires in many cases when live wires in the wind crossed each other, created sparks and started the bushfire. Telephony still existed. You could ring almost anywhere around South Australia because the wires were already underground in rural areas, in the main trunk lines between towns and so on. Telstra have done that of their own volition for the past 40 years because it is economic for them to do so and the best way for them to achieve a service.

SPEECH.PARA: What we are saying is that, even in the few areas where they have thin telephony wires less than 13 millimetres hanging, this bill does not make them put them underground. Later on, from 1 July or 30 September—we will debate that later—if they want to put an overhead wire up for whatever reason, whether it be telephony or broadband services, it has to go through the normal planning services, whether it is the minister's plan or the opposition's plan.

I cannot see any reason why we cannot make the change the Democrats have proposed. The 13 millimetres is arbitrary as between broadband and telephony. Of course, with technology development, digital compression and whatever else, it may be at some stage within the next two or three years quite possible to run a broadband service on a cable of less than 13 millimetres. It might be a new style cable. It might actually be a pure fibre cable, optic fibre cable, which is very thin, even with its insulation. Under this provision, that could be strung out across Australia without any planning because it is exempt. I do not think the community would put up with it. They would say, `What have you done again?'

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you let them choose?
—Under your provision, Minister, they will choose that if you want to—
—They can't with this.

—Yes, they can. Under the definition of a cable above 13 millimetres, they can choose to put it above ground if the carrier reaches agreement. It does not matter whether it is a broadband cable, a thin cable—whichever style and size of cable it is, it has to get the approval of the local council. Minister, you have banned it in your own legislation. For broadband cables, it says that unless the councils agree, you are dead.

BREAK.PARA: I have to say that it ought to be the same for thin cable because within three or four years thin cable may well be a broadband service. Therefore the same conditions ought to apply. The problem we have now is that, basically, no council trusts the carriers because of what has gone on in the last three years with this overhead cable. That has been a terrible happening in that the community is taking out its antagonism against telecommunications generally because of the way in which the overhead cables have been used.

It seems to me that this is quite a reasonable amendment. It does not mean any existing cable has to be pulled down. It just means that any new cable that goes up after, I hope, 1 July under our amendment, has to get council approval. If they can convince the council, whether rural or city, that a thin cable is okay—less than 13 millimetres or any size—that is their decision. But by having this in here, it means that 13 millimetres is exempt and that a carrier can put it up without any consideration for local community feeling or local council planning arrangements. That is unacceptable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —We have had various talks throughout this debate about leafy suburbs, but a lot more suburbs right throughout Australia are getting smaller and smaller backyards. In Western Australia, we have got larger blocks being subdivided and, as a result, people not having much of a backyard. The front of a house is one of the few places where they can actually put up a tree and have one grow to perhaps provide a corridor for birdlife.

SPEECH.PARA: A couple of days ago, while I was sitting here hearing the debate, I did a little picture of a tree with a Dagwood Bumstead haircut. We have all seen them. I have got them around a side street at home: trees with lines going through them because, if it has escaped the minister's attention, communication lines do not sit there and float in thin air. They have got poles. They have to be free from the trees. All this means that those leafy suburbs that exist now make other suburbs look as if they are going to be condemned never to be able to have a streetscape in the front of their yards.

It is not a small thing. It is an important thing. Amenity—the way people feel about their suburbs and the way people feel about their community—is actually affected by the way the streetscape develops. People are putting a lot of effort into changing streetscapes so they work better for communities. I think it is a dreadful thing to condemn all communities, from now until it is changed, if ever, to not being able to enjoy that amenity.

We all know the situation where, even if it was just a matter of the width of the band, you can create several ply by putting several 10 millimetre cables together, making one big rope and saying, `Look, that's all right. We have got 10 millimetre cables but they are just twisted.' So there are issues here about the misuse of regulations and also ones about the community choosing. In case it has escaped the minister's attention, local government associations actually do end up covering the whole of Australia.

People in the community are choosing at the moment. They are saying, `We would choose to have regulations so that we do get to be asked.' If the communities want it, they will still say yes. You are trusting them to make that decision with regard to thicker cables. If the thinner cables go to communities for decision, some communities will say, `That's okay.' But why should they be exempt?

Why don't you also trust the communities to be able to decide, as they do with the thicker cables? Why don't you say, yes, there is a reasonable case for allowing communities to make their own decisions about their streetscapes in the future, and for them to be able to say, `Okay, from now on we will act responsibly and will allow community amenity to be developed and trees to be developed in the future.'? I think this amendment is quite reasonable and I will be supporting it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The government, and the minister in particular, have been hypocritical in the extreme over this issue of 13 millimetres. What has been said today shows that we are all pretty sceptical of the notion that overhead TV cabling will never be less than 13 millimetres. Minister, you yourself have said that Telstra's cabling is 14 millimetres. I cannot imagine that it is beyond the wit and the will of those interested in technology to reduce that by one or two millimetres; in fact, I am sure it would be quite easy.

SPEECH.PARA: I wonder, Minister, what you would do if all TV cabling was 12 millimetres. Would you stand by and allow those cables to be exempt when you have travelled around the country on so many occasions and put out so many press releases saying, `Oh, no, overhead cabling will be undergrounded from now on unless local council authorities agree otherwise.' That is what makes this such a joke.

We all realised the minute we saw this legislation that there would probably be no problem for the carriers at all to continue to roll out their aerial cables as they have in the past. Once again, you have removed the ability of councils and communities to do or say anything about that. I again say to you, Minister, that you have made much of the grand plan in this legislation which would put overhead cables underground. In your opening remarks you launched into your normal tirade of abuse by suggesting that the Democrats were going to cause havoc with this amendment by requiring all overhead cabling to be put underground. You knew very well that was not the case. This is part of your normal tactics to try to discredit anyone who might not agree with your view.

I find this, as I say, quite hypocritical and quite cynical on your part. I think it will not be too long at all before we see the carriers coming out with their 13 or 12 millimetres. As Senator Margetts points out, it is not a matter of whether they are 17 millimetres or 13 millimetres; the point is that they go through trees and they are at a lower level than the electricity wiring—they cause enormous damage. I am sure that, if you pointed a resident to two lines of cables and said, `Now, that one's 13 millimetres, but that one's 15,' they would not be able to pick it, and neither would they care. The point is that those cables are still being erected above ground.

BREAK.PARA: I think, Minister, you have taken every possible step—whether it is transitional arrangements, whether it is feasibility or whether it is this 13 millimetres—to make sure that the rest of Australia is rolled out with aerial cabling. Your protestations and your promises have really come to nothing over this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am just wondering whether the minister could enlighten me, at least about the reference on page 467 of schedule 2. It says `if another distance is specified in the regulations, that other distance'. Could the minister explain precisely what that means? Also, in respect of the maximum external cross‐section, `any part of which exceeds 13 millimetres', are we to assume that it is okay if it is 13 millimetres and under? Are you suggesting that this will always be slung on the poles of, say, another utility—for example, the electricity utility—or, in the event of there being no current facility such as the electricity poles, that this would enable a free rein for the carriers to put up their own poles in the particular areas of their choice? Is there no limitation on that or are they required to use existing infrastructure?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —The provision in clause 3 to allow for another distance to be specified in regulations is, I think, designed to address the concern that, if new technology enables a broadband cable to be less than 13 millimetres in diameter and if that were regarded as the appropriate cut‐off point to distinguish between broadband and ordinary telephony, then you would simply adjust the measurement accordingly. As I understand it, the concern that—
—Can you just explain that again?

—The regulation provides that the maximum external cross‐section of any part which exceeds 13 millimetres or, if any other distance is specified, that other distance. The purpose of that is to provide flexibility so that you can keep up with changes in technology. So, if you choose 13 in order to distinguish between broadband and ordinary telephony and it becomes possible to produce, as Senator Allison suggested it might, a broadband cable that was only 11 millimetres in diameter, then you could bring your limit down to catch it in the same way.
—Or put it up.
—You could, but the purpose is not to do that.
—It just didn't dawn on me about the regulation aspect of this.
—Its purpose is not to do that. The whole purpose of having 13 millimetres is designed to achieve that line of demarcation. I think it is a bit late in the night for me, Mr Chairman.

SPEECH.PARA: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard
Leave granted.

The purpose of this bill is to amend the Excise Tariff Act 1921 (the Tariff Act) to ensure the continuing excisability of all beverages which contain distilled alcohol, including spirits, regardless of their alcohol content.

Under item 2 of the Schedule to the Tariff Act, "spirituous beverages" are subject to duties of excise, which are calculated at a dollar amount per litre of alcohol in each beverage. The term was introduced into the Tariff Act in 1985 with the intention of making excisable any beverage that contained a spirit. Since that time, all such beverages have been treated as excisable regardless of their alcohol content, including beverages whose alcohol content ranges from 5% to 9% (for example the rum and cola mixer drinks).

In November 1994, Carlton and United Breweries (CUB) commenced the manufacture of the product known as "Subzero Alcoholic Soda" which had an alcohol content of approximately 5.5%. The Australian Customs Service (the ACS) considered "Subzero" excisable under sub‐item 2(H) of the Schedule to the Tariff Act as a spirituous beverage. CUB appealed the decision of the ACS to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT).

On 7 June 1996, the AAT determined that the production of "Subzero", with such a low alcohol content by volume, could not be described as spirituous and was therefore not excisable under sub‐item 2(H). The decision was based on what the AAT considered is commonly regarded as the definition of "spirit" in the community, which is a strong alcoholic liquor usually containing not less than 37% alcohol by volume. The ACS is appealing this decision to the Federal Court

Since the AAT decision, CUB has ceased manufacturing "Subzero" using alcohol derived by distillation. However, there are several other companies (UDA, Remy Australia, Swift & Moore and Angove) who manufacture beverages of low alcohol content which are based on, for example, brandy or whisky. The ACS has continued to impose excise duty under sub‐item 2(H) on these beverages as they are considered by the ACS to be spirituous beverages. The payments of excise duty by these other manufacturers are being made under deposit in accordance with section 154 of the Excise Act 1901 on the basis that, since the AAT "Subzero" decision, these manufacturers allege that these beverages are no longer excisable. Prior to this decision, all producers of beverages containing distilled alcohol had been paying duty on the alcohol content of the beverage. There was no dispute with manufacturers of the low alcohol beverages using distilled alcohol as to their excisability or their proper classification to sub‐item 2(H) of the Schedule to the Tariff Act.
In order to ensure the continuing excisability of all beverages containing distilled alcohol, it is proposed to amend the Tariff Act to:
(i) delete all references to "spirituous beverages" in the Schedule and item 2 (item 1 of Schedule 1 refers); and
(ii) clarify that excise liability is imposed upon all beverages which contain distilled alcohol (new sub‐item 2(H), item 2 of Schedule 1 refers).

The combination of these amendments will remove any connotation that there is a minimum strength that an alcoholic beverage must be before it will be excisable. All such beverages will continue to be excisable regardless of their alcohol content and the excise duty will be calculated according to the alcohol content of the beverages.

It is also proposed that the amendments will take effect on and from 3 February 1996. The effect of the retrospective commencement date of the amendments will be to extinguish all rights of appeal to the AAT in relation to the excisability of low alcohol beverages and all rights to refunds of excise duty in respect of such beverages.
The commencement of the amendments on this date is considered justifiable on the following grounds:

(a) The intention of the term "spirituous beverages" was to make excisable any beverage that contained a spirit and there had never been any dispute as to this intention prior to the "Subzero" case. It is considered that the amendments are not altering the law with respect to alcoholic beverages as it stood at the time of the "Subzero" decision. They are merely clarifying what was the status quo. It is, therefore, considered appropriate that the amendments commence on 3 February 1996 to remove the technical loophole which was uncovered in the Tariff Act by that decision and which this amending legislation is now removing.

(b) The commencement of the amendments on 3 February 1996 will not require the retrospective recovery of any excise duty from the manufacturers of the alcoholic beverages. The excise duty has continued to be paid by the manufacturers, under deposit, and the 3 February 1996 commencement will protect the government against all claims for recovery of this duty. If the amendments do not commence on 3 February 1996, however, the government might be liable to pay $12.6 million in refunds of excise duty if the Federal Court confirms the AAT decision in favour of CUB. Given that the products manufactured by these companies have been sold duty paid, such a favourable decision to the companies would represent a windfall gain to them, with little chance that it would be returned to the consumers of the product.
The proposed amendments, including their financial impact, are outlined in greater detail in the Explanatory Memorandum.
Ordered that further consideration of the second reading of this bill be adjourned until the first day of sitting in the winter sittings 1997, in accordance with standing order 111.

I have pleasure in presenting to the Senate the report of the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Legislation Committee's inquiry into the Export Market Development Grants Bill 1997 and the Export Market Development Grants (Repeal and Consequential Provisions) Bill 1997.

On 6 March 1997, the Senate referred the two Bills to the Committee for inquiry and report by the last sitting day of this week. Following approaches to businesses and other organisations with a known interest in the EMDG
Scheme, the Committee received 48 written submissions commenting on a number of provisions of the EMDG Bill. Further evidence was received at public hearings conducted in Canberra on 17 March.

The EMDG Bills repeal the Export Market Development Grants Act 1974 and replace the Act with new simplified legislation for a revised EMDG Scheme. In media releases on 20 August and 16 December 1996 and in his Second Reading Speech in the House of Representatives, the Minister for Trade, the

Hon Tim Fischer MP, said that the Bill increases the focus on assistance to small and medium-sized enterprises. Funding for the revised scheme will also be capped at $ 150 million whereas the current scheme is open access.
Witnesses generally welcomed the simplification of the EMDG Scheme as laid out in the EMDG Bill compared to the current legislation which has been much amended.
However, a number of areas of concern in the EMDG Bill were expressed in submissions and in evidence at the public hearings.

The Committee received considerable criticism of clause 54 of the EMDG Bill, which provides that trusts are no longer eligible to apply for grants under the EMDG Scheme. This provision was criticised on two grounds:
(a) discrimination against businesses which used a trust as their legal business structure; and
(b) the retrospectivity of the provision as it applies to business expenses incurred from 1 July 1996.

It was pointed out that trusts are a legitimate business structure and that many small businesses adopt the trust structure on professional accounting and legal advice. A number of witnesses told the Committee that, because of the exclusion of trusts in the EMDG Bill, they had already cut expenditure or were proposing to do so, which would have the effect of reducing export marketing and hence the level of future exports.

The Committee understands that the inclusion of trusts in the EMDG Bill would add some further complexity to the Bill but believes that any consequential loss in simplicity is overridden by the benefits accruing to SMEs, the main target group identified by the Government for this revised scheme. Trusts are used by small and medium-sized businesses and so the exclusion of trusts would hurt the Government's main target group.

The retrospective nature of the exclusion of trusts from the revised EMDG Scheme drew strong criticism in written submissions and from witnesses at the public hearings. When the Government first announced in August 1996 its proposed revision of the EMDG legislation, it foreshadowed many of the proposed changes to the scheme. However, no mention was made of the proposed exclusion of trusts. It was not until 16 December 1996, when the Government released the draft bill for public comment that businesses became aware that trusts would be excluded. By that time, it was almost half way through the financial year and trusts which would reasonably have expected to receive an EMDG grant for expenses already incurred then faced the prospect of having to find additional funds to cover those expenses.

The Government encouraged trusts to incorporate so that they might become eligible for an EMDG grant. The Committee received evidence that some trusts have established a corporate structure but this is not necessarily an easy or cheap option for trusts. Austrade has also confirmed that trusts which incorporate during this financial year are precluded by the legislation to claim expenses for the part of the year prior to their incorporation. The Committee recommended that the Bill be amended to enable trusts which incorporate this year to be able to claim eligible expenses in respect of the whole year.

In view of the Government's emphasis on the refocusing of the EMDG Scheme to help small and medium-sized enterprises, the Committee believes that the government should reconsider reinstating trusts to the revised scheme.

Under clause 34 of the EMDG Bill, expenses of air fares associated with international marketing visits are now ineligible after a second grant. This two year limit on air fare expenses was strongly criticised in the evidence because international travel was regarded as essential for developing and expanding export markets.

The industry associations which made submissions and gave evidence to the Committee sought special dispensation for approved organisations, should air fares remain excluded when the bill is enacted, to remove the two-year limit for their promotional activities on behalf of small businesses which cannot attend major trade fairs and other promotional meetings overseas. These associations said that they did not have the financial resources to maintain such promotional activities if they were ineligible to claim air fare expenses.

It is clear to the Committee that two-grant limitations on air fare expenses may have an adverse effect on the ability of SMEs to develop export markets. It can take a long time for Australian exporters to break into some overseas markets, including some in our region. Personal contact is essential in all markets but particularly in Asian countries. Evidence given the Committee indicates that inclusion of the two-year limitation would retard efforts to expand our export drive and even put at risk existing export arrangements. As with many of the restrictions placed on the scheme in the EMDG Bill, the Government's main target group, SMEs, would be affected by the exclusion of air fare expenses after two EMDG grants. Given that the EMDG Scheme will be capped, there is no financial penalty for the Government in removing this limitation. The Committee recommends that clause 34 of the EMDG Bill be amended to permit the claiming of air fares after a second grant.

A number of other submissions and witnesses, both small and medium enterprises as well as national organisations, supported the continued eligibility of expenditure on patent registration and trade marks. This is another area of the EMDG Bill which affects SMEs in their efforts to break into new markets and develop existing markets overseas, which is contrary to the spirit of the legislation as articulated by the Minister for Trade on a number of occasions. The fact that the scheme is capped means that allowing patent costs as an eligible expense in the Bill would not increase Government expenditure and enhance opportunities for export of unique Australian products rather than restrict exports of those products or force their producers to move offshore.
Many submissions expressed concern about areas of the Bill which gave Austrade discretionary powers which are not contained in current legislation.

Having listened to the explanations provided by Austrade, the Committee is satisfied that Austrade's discretionary powers in the Bill should not act as a disincentive to potential exporters, particularly as Austrade provides an advisory service to assist exporters with eligibility questions.

Whilst the Committee appreciated the concerns of some witnesses about the administrative cost of the scheme, the Committee considers that a five per cent ceiling on administrative costs is appropriate.

The Committee considers that while the Government has met its objective of simplifying the Bill compared to the existing EMDG legislation, the exclusion of a number of eligible items will have an impact on the ability of SMEs to export. In fact, a number of exclusions, especially trusts, air fare expenses after the second grant, and, to a lesser extent, the cost of patents for intellectual property affect SMEs. As the revised EMDG Scheme will be capped, the reinstatement of these items would not impose an extra financial burden on the Government. Any reintroduction of categories of expenditure would clearly reduce certainty for those who claim amounts over $50 000 as to the grant amount they would receive. Recognising this constraint, the Committee believes that it would be far preferable to assist and encourage small businesses to export by reducing the size of claims of larger enterprises, which are in a better position to absorb reductions in grants.

As a result, the Committee recommends that the Government consider the Committee's comments about the reinstatement of some exclusions to assist small and medium size businesses in developing export markets in line with the stated objective of this Bill.
The Committee also recommends that the Bills be enacted, subject to the Committee's recommendations in this Report.
I commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
Debate adjourned.

That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to Senator Bob Collins for allowing me to precede him in this debate. I think this is one of the most significant issues to come before the chamber, certainly in my 10 or 11 years in this place. There are very few opportunities to address issues that have such significant moral connotations as this bill does. I do not regard it as a state rights issue. Indeed, a territory is not a state, so by definition that is an irrelevant consideration. I think what is much more significant is that this is a bill which essentially seeks to interfere in the natural processes of life, which I regard as sacred and which I think should be seen by all those who have a similar perspective as being well beyond the right of ordinary citizens—and indeed parliaments—to prematurely interfere with.

SPEECH.PARA: I certainly understand the concerns that people express about putting people out of their misery, so‐called, or allowing themselves to be put out of their misery. During the some 5½ years during which my father was in a nursing home—and for most of that time was non compos mentis—it never for a moment occurred to me that it was in his best interests or indeed in anyone's best interests to have him put down. I think in many ways, to the extent that he was able to be aware, he would have realised that the suffering that he was going through did have a higher purpose.

It is very difficult for many of us to acknowledge that when we are in that particular situation, but I do not personally regard the purpose of human existence as being to simply satisfy ordinary wants and desires or to achieve happiness irrespective of the moral consequences. It might be a natural—and indeed laudable—human aspiration in many circumstances to wish to be out of pain and to wish to avoid suffering, but this is a world in which these things are uncertain and where I think we all take our chances. I do not think we have the right to say that, because we would feel better or those around us would feel better, they have the right to simply interfere with the process for those purposes.

I think it is impossible to divorce the longer term consequences from that situation. Unless you believe in a life after death, it is perhaps difficult to comprehend why you need to go through that period of suffering. But if you do believe in a life after death and you do believe that your purpose on earth is not simply to enjoy yourself, I think you start to have an understanding of the enormity of what is being sought by those who argue that people ought to be allowed in certain circumstances to determine the extent of their life span.

It can obviously be very difficult when you have serious and protracted illnesses which involve a great deal of pain and suffering. I think we have all been exposed to those illnesses either directly or indirectly. That does not persuade me for a moment that we are therefore justified in suiting the convenience of those who might like to be put out of their misery. Inasmuch as it might seem harsh in a superficial sense, if you are fully cognisant of the meaning of life, you appreciate that there is a much greater dimension than the human.

Those are the reasons that will motivate me to support the Andrews bill. I do not wish to speak at any greater length but simply to say that it is an issue on which I do feel strongly, almost viscerally in a sense, because the bill goes against all that I have ever believed in and been brought up to believe in. Nothing that I have experienced in my lifetime persuades me that I should diverge from those beliefs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I foreshadow an amendment which reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—
(a) is of the opinion that because of the discriminatory nature of the provisions of the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996, it should not proceed to consider the measure further; and

(b) calls on the Attorney-General and Minister for Justice (Mr Williams) to have an alternative bill prepared and presented to the Senate in a form which does not discriminate against the people of any part of Australia and which would enable senators to vote according to their views on the issue of euthanasia on the basis of a possible uniform, national approach to the issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under what constitutional provision?

—I am sure that Senator Harradine will give me the same respect that I accorded to him on issues in this House and not attempt to interrupt my speech on this issue, as I did not seek to interrupt his.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I address the terms of this motion and the reasons why I will move it, I want to say a few words about the context of this debate. One of the reasons I want to talk about the context of the debate is that simple misunderstanding that Senator Harradine had, for example, in here just the other day when he accepted as a matter of course that federal parliamentary broadcasts were being broadcast in the Northern Territory. Of course they never have been.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha.

—Senator Harradine has just indicated that this is much to his amusement. It is an interesting attitude from someone who comes from a small state the size of Tasmania, with a population just twice the size of the Northern Territory, and yet with their full complement of 12 senators here in this place.
—Let's hear the constitutional issue.

—Perhaps if I could appeal again, Mr Acting Deputy President, considering the gravity of issue, against the continued interjections of Senator Harradine in what I am trying to say to the Senate tonight.
—I want to hear the constitutional question.

—I rise tonight conscious that many of my constituents are listening to this broadcast and, indeed, to the interjections of Senator Harradine, on the parliamentary news network. It is a service that the vast majority of Australians have had available to them, and many, of course, would take it for granted. It is a service that the territorians are hearing for the first time this week and only because of the extraordinary measures that were taken to connect the service to broadcast this debate. I can assure all senators that many in the territory are following this debate with intense interest.

SPEECH.PARA: When you have lived in remote Australia for as long as I have and many of those listening in the territory have, you take nothing for granted in the way of new or improved services. Unfortunately and ironically, this new experience of being able to sit at home in the territory and listen to debate in the national parliament is being tainted for many territorians by the feeling that they are doing so as third‐class citizens. The reason is simple. These broadcasts are carrying debate on a bill which strikes at the very heart of self-government in our territory. It seeks to remove the right of our parliament to make its own laws for better or worse.

We know that this is not, in essence, an anti‐euthanasia bill. It is not a bill which seeks to outlaw euthanasia throughout Australia. It is an anti-territories bill. It seeks to give us as territorians fewer rights than our friends and relatives in every other state of this country.

I am opposed to euthanasia but, as I said, being completely honest about it, if I were suffering from a terminal illness—I might add, an extreme terminal illness; I am not talking about the grey areas—that imposes real and enduring distress and pain, I would like to think that I would be true to my beliefs that society is diminished by this legislation and not resort to euthanasia if it was available myself. But I would not absolutely bet on that, and that is the honest truth. I envy people who are so certain on these issues of life and death. I confess that I am not.

I am opposed to euthanasia, but I am also opposed to this legislation. The reason is simple. It seeks to strike down a legitimate law of the Northern Territory parliament—a law which I oppose but, nonetheless, a legitimate law. The legislation which this bill seeks to strike down was passed into law under the constitution conferred on the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly by the federal parliament's Northern Territory (Self-Government) Act 1978. The self-government act gave to the Northern Territory legal, judicial, administrative and executive responsibility.

The Northern Territory administration has exercised those rights for 18 years—free of any threat of federal intervention. I have no doubt that it has passed bad laws during that time, as have all parliaments in Australia. The Rights of the Terminally Ill Act is, in the view of many, one of the worst, but I vehemently defend the right of the democratically elected Northern Territory parliament to pass that law. That law is properly within the heads of power conferred on the Northern Territory parliament by this parliament.

I freely acknowledge that the Commonwealth has the capacity under section 9 of the Northern Territory (Self-Government) Act, through the Governor-General, to disallow the proposed law or part of the proposed law of the Northern Territory. But this must be done within six months after the Territory administrators assent to such a proposed law. The time for that type of action in relation to the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act has well and truly expired. In any case, section 9 was a transitional provision on the grant of self-government to the Northern Territory 18 years ago. It has never been used; it is anachronistic; it should be repealed.

There has been a steady progression of constitutional development in the Territory. There are a number of further important constitutional advancements that can be made ahead of the grant of full statehood. The repeal of this transitional power under section 9 is one of them.

It is important to remember the former federal Labor government made no attempt to invoke these reserve powers between the passage of the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act in the Territory parliament and the last federal election. Indeed, the former Prime Minister, Paul Keating, was asked to intervene and overturn the Territory law. He refused. He said that it was a matter properly left with the states and territories. Unfortunately, the current Prime Minister, Mr Howard, has not adopted a similar view. Had he done so, we would not be debating this bill tonight.

Senators may recall that Mr Howard was asked in this parliament on 29 June last year by the member for Menzies, Kevin Andrews, if the Commonwealth would be arguing for or against the validity of the Territory legislation proceedings, which were due to commence within days in the Northern Territory Supreme Court. The government, Mr Howard said, had decided that steps should be taken to have the Commonwealth removed as a defendant in the challenge to the Territory legislation by a number of parties, including the Australian Medical Association. Mr Howard said the government was seeking to be removed as a named defendant in the legal challenge—and I quote from the Hansard of the parliament—`as it is clearly legislation at the instance of the Northern Territory parliament'.

BREAK.PARA: It is a great pity that the Prime Minister did not leave it there. The Prime Minister went on to suggest that it was open to any member of this parliament to introduce a private member's bill if he or she felt strongly about the issue. It would not be the desire of the government, he added, to hamper the consideration of the issue. In fact, the Prime Minister has given a priority to this private member's bill that has not been accorded to a great deal of his own government's business.

As senators would recall, Mr Andrews gave notice of this private member's bill on 20 August last year. He introduced his bill on 9 September last year. I would remind honourable senators the Territory legislation was introduced in February 1995. It was assented to in June of that year, and no-one can deny that it was both a controversial and highly public debate.

As Senator Vanstone, to her credit, pointed out earlier in this debate, it could easily have been made an issue at the March election last year. It was not. Why, I ask, did Mr Andrews or Mr Howard not seek to make it an issue then? The public record clearly shows that neither of them did so. Why has the Prime Minister left it to a backbencher to raise it in this parliament and then given that backbencher priority over a great deal of government business? I ask that question on behalf of my constituents because Mr Howard, of course, voted in the other place to overturn the rights of the Territory parliament to make its own laws.

The Prime Minister has also led the charge in attempting to stifle the threshold constitutional issues raised by this bill. I have here an article which appeared in the Melbourne Age on 24 January this year. It is headed `PM keen for Senate veto on euthanasia'. Mr Howard is quoted as saying:
I don't think it's got anything to do with state or territory rights. I think that's one of the weakest arguments I have ever heard.

This shows a profound ignorance about the terms of the Andrews bill. It is not about states' rights. If it were, I would have no hesitation in supporting it because it would then be a true anti-euthanasia bill. It does not—I repeat, it does not—seek to outlaw euthanasia in any part of this country, except the Northern Territory, the Australian Capital Territory and Norfolk Island. Of course, in real terms it discriminates only against the Northern Territory.

In fact, Mr Andrews has said publicly that he would probably not have sought to introduce this legislation had it concerned a law of a state and not of a territory. It is not about states' rights because it does not affect a state. That is the central problem with this bill. If we are fair about making this a true debate on whether all Australians have a right to exercise a choice on this matter, we should be debating a bill which seeks to outlaw euthanasia in all states and territories.

I have moved my amendment to achieve that end. It seeks to have this bill withdrawn. It then calls on the Attorney-General and Minister for Justice, Daryl Williams, to have an alternative bill prepared and presented to the Senate. It should be drafted in a form which does not discriminate against the people of any part of Australia and which would enable senators to vote according to their views on euthanasia on the basis of a possible uniform national approach to the issue.

The motion is in the same terms as that moved by the member for New England, Ian Sinclair, during debate in the other place. I am happy to say that Mr Sinclair has precisely the same position as I have on this matter: he is also opposed to euthanasia and he is opposed to this bill. I commend his contribution in this debate to all members and to all territorians. It makes an interesting comparison with that of the Prime Minister.

This bill can be withdrawn and redrafted in the manner I suggest. We know from evidence given to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee that this is, at least, an arguable case. The senior lecturer in constitutional law at the Australian National University, George Williams, told the committee that this bill removes the powers of the territories to pass laws permitting euthanasia but leaves the state powers intact. However, other similar laws that have impacted upon the legislative ability of the state or territory parliaments have been expressed to operate Australia wide. The most significant recent example, of course, is the Human Rights (Sexual Conduct) Act 1994, which was introduced to override Tasmania's anti‐homosexual laws. Section 4(1) of that act states:

Sexual conduct involving only consenting adults acting in private is not to be subject, by or under any law of the Commonwealth, a state or a territory, to any arbitrary interference with privacy within the meaning of article 17 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

This section clearly operates to affect the rights of all Australians. Nowhere is Tasmania specifically named or singled out. The legislation we are debating here tonight only operates to limit the ability of territories to choose to legislate with respect to euthanasia, specifically, of course, the Northern Territory. This unacceptably erodes territorians' control over their political future compared to other Australians.

If a Commonwealth response to euthanasia is needed, the Commonwealth should at least attempt to pass a national law—a law that equally affects all Australians. As Mr Williams points out in an article published in the Australian on 27 October last year headed ` A clumsy attack on territories', the Commonwealth may well have the power to do so. He says:
The Commonwealth might argue that it lacks the power to extend the Andrews bill to the states. This is not a convincing argument.
In 1994, the federal parliament passed the Human Rights (Sexual Conduct) Act, which overrides Tasmania's anti-homosexual laws.
The act relied upon the Commonwealth's external affairs powers to implement the right to privacy in Article 17 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.
It seems the Commonwealth could similarly rely on articles of the covenant and use the external affairs power to enact a national euthanasia law.

I want to make this abundantly clear. If this legislation was drafted in precisely the same way as the Human Rights (Sexual Conduct) Act, which relied for its authority on international conventions to provide a consistent national law from this federal parliament on euthanasia, I would be supporting it.

My consideration of this bill boils down to one central question: is the Northern Territory self-governing or not? If the Andrews bill is endorsed by this Senate, then clearly it is not and the constitutional clock is turned back to 1978. There are those who have claimed in this debate that the issue of territory rights is a cloak of convenience being used to avoid debate on the central question of euthanasia. This does not stand up to one minute's scrutiny. As I said earlier, the territory legislation was introduced in February 1995. Need I remind senators that it has been the subject ever since of the most vigorous debate. It has virtually consumed public debate in the Northern Territory.

It should never be forgotten that the legislation was immediately referred to a select committee of the territory parliament, which received more than 1,000 submissions. Fifty amendments were introduced during the committee stages of the bill before the Legislative Assembly passed it by a vote of 15 to 10. The act has survived a number of attempts at repeal—supported, I might add, by many MPs sitting on the Treasury benches in the Northern Territory and by people such as me. It has been the subject, as I mentioned earlier, of a challenge before the full court of the territory's supreme court.

The full court was asked in essence to determine just how self-governing the territory is. It found the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act were within the powers of the territory parliament, as confirmed by the Commonwealth more than a decade and a half ago. An application for special leave to appeal to the High Court against the decision has been lodged. These events must be granted recognition in this debate. It is in fact vigorous democracy at work—territorians freely exercising our democratic rights under the powers conferred by the self-government act of this parliament.

Over the last 170 years or so, when the sovereign in England was granting increasing powers to the colonies such as New South Wales and Victoria, once power was transferred it was never taken back, except in exceptional circumstances such as war and rebellion. The Andrews bill seeks to wind those territory rights back. Forget the so-called cloak of convenience arguments. If you are still in any doubt about this, I would commend a reading of the Senate Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest No. 7 of 1996.

The all-party committee expressed profound doubts about the constitutional validity of the Andrews bill. It found the Commonwealth parliament, having given the legislative assemblies of both territories and Norfolk Island the power to `make laws for the peace, order and good government' would, by this bill, negate the valid exercise of that legislative power by one of them. It goes on to say:

The Commonwealth parliament, by this bill, proposes to intrude on the law making function of the territories not in accordance with a general principle but on an ad hoc basis. This threatens the certainty which ought to exist for its citizens when any one or more of the territories passes a valid law.
Precisely. In essence, the Senate committee found that this bill would trespass unduly on the personal rights and liberties of territorians.

There are only two courses of action which I believe can be reasonably followed in this matter. The first is the repeal of the legislation in the territory's own parliament, which I will continue to work for, as far as I am able, as a territorian. The other is a matter for this parliament. It is the course that I propose in this foreshadowed amendment. It would ensure a national uniform approach to what I think everyone would agree is one of the toughest issues the Australian community has been asked to come to terms with.

It is unthinkable for me that, once the powers of self-government have been conferred on our territory, they should be then taken away. I remind honourable senators of what the then Minister for the Northern Territory, Mr Adermann—of course a conservative colleague of the current government—told this parliament in his second reading speech on the introduction of the Northern Territory (Self-Government) Act 1978—our constitution. When he introduced the bill into the House he said this:
I am sure that honourable members will support the philosophy behind the legislation.

The people of the Northern Territory, in common with other citizens of our federal Commonwealth, have the right—indeed the duty—to control their own affairs through a democratically elected legislature.

All I can say is hear, hear! It is a pity that his conservative colleagues now do not take a trip back through the Hansard and read what was said then. Mr Adermann went on to point out that at Federation the citizens of the Northern Territory, as residents of the state of South Australia, enjoyed the same political rights as other Commonwealth citizens.

Because of the requirements of the constitution, those political rights were removed in 1910 when the territory was transferred from South Australia and accorded the status of a Commonwealth territory. In a very real sense, the constitutional history of the Northern Territory since that date reflects the endeavours of the people of the territory to regain the rights they lost in 1910. That objective will not be achieved until the territory is accorded statehood—a goal which has been supported in principle by all heads of government in Australia, including the Prime Minister.

There is a reasonable expectation in the Northern Territory that we will have full statehood at or around the turn of the century. Need I remind anyone in this Senate that that is only a few years from now, at which time the effect of this bill, if passed, would lapse in any case. I would ask all senators not to turn the clock back in this vote and to support the continuing progress of constitutional development for the Northern Territory. I commend the amendment to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to begin by saying that I have, since I can remember, firmly supported the notion that an individual should have the right to die at a time and by a means of their own choosing. I hope that that choice will be available to me and to others should we want to make it.

SPEECH.PARA: Some people are fortunate enough to die a natural, quick, quiet and peaceful death. My own grandmother used to say, `What a blessing it would be to die in one's sleep.' Twenty years ago, I watched my grandmother die in agony over a prolonged period. My memory of her almost always brings back that last night of horror when I so vividly recall it in all its detail.

Perhaps these days she would have died a little sooner and died from an overdose of morphine. In that case she may or may not have been party to the decision which would determine the end of her life. My family would have been greatly relieved to think her suffering had been minimised but, on the whole, the intervention in her death would be a matter which may have been understood but not discussed. It would have been a decision made by her physician.

No doubt we have made significant progress in palliative care in the last few decades, at least in some parts of Australia and for some, but not enough, people. As I understand the philosophy of palliative care, it is not just a method by which pain can be controlled but it is an approach which allows the dying and their families to make informed decisions about their treatment. In this debate I want to argue that we should concern ourselves with the much broader end of life issues and that we should see voluntary euthanasia not as some freakish and shocking event which threatens our whole society.

I want to say that voluntary euthanasia is and should be regarded as one small part of the whole of the treatment of those who are terminally ill. Whether or not Kevin Andrews's bill changes the legality of euthanasia in the Northern Territory, except for some rare cases, end of life decisions will continue as before. The decision not to proceed with surgery or resuscitation, the withdrawal of life support systems, the denial of certain drugs on the basis of cost, the administration of drugs which relieve pain but which will certainly and eventually cause death are, in my view, just parts of a continuum. It seems to me that the only difference between these medical decisions and voluntary euthanasia is that the former may or may not have been requested by those most affected by the decision.

A member of my family is a nursing sister who has had extensive experience in palliative care, and I acknowledge her contribution to this debate and to my views. I might add that she believes that legalised euthanasia will have very little impact on ensuring peaceful deaths and reduced suffering and she is not one of the health professionals who would assist patients to die. She says:

I have no ethical problems with the morality of euthanasia provided the person choosing this is a competent, terminally ill person who rationally makes a well-informed decision, in consultation with a humane doctor regarding ending their life. However, as a health professional, I would find assisting in the administration of a lethal injection to a patient I was caring for a very difficult procedure.

It has been easy for me to speak as an individual in support of euthanasia and I do not step aside from that position. I do want to make a plea, however, for those physicians and nurses who deal with these decisions on a daily basis. The reason we are so polarised in this debate on euthanasia is that we as a society are still uncomfortable with dealing with death. I do not necessarily mean that as individuals we are afraid to die. Rather, I think we are reluctant participants in the process of dying.

That is why so much of our effort is in trying to prevent death. Doctors are trained to cure and very often they try every last‐ditch effort to prevent death, often to the detriment of their patients. My 87‐year‐old neighbour, after resuscitation from his third massive heart attack, said, `I just hope the next one takes me off. I cannot bear to go through it all again.'

The Medical Treatment Act in Victoria is meant to prevent treatment beyond what people feel they can tolerate. My sister-in-law says this act is rarely used. Does intravenous antibiotics for a ninety‐year‐old with pneumonia constitute too aggressive a treatment? For some the answer is yes, for others no, depending on their physical and mental condition and the possible complications which can ensue. But decisions are not always made using this rationale and people are often overtreated with sophisticated drugs and the most expensive intensive care. They have numerous tests and CAT scans to prove they have in fact an age related illness. Dying patients are often tossed from one specialist to another. They can be given four different opinions and end up with a very confused idea of their condition, their prognosis, the most appropriate treatment and, especially, how on earth they will cope.

Their GP is rarely involved in the acute treatment but will have to pick up the pieces following this phase. It is often not until physical care is required or pain control is needed that referral to a palliative care service is made. By then there is often a feeling of despair and loss of control. All of this has the effect of increasing the suffering of the patient.

We spend most of our health dollars on people in their last few months of life. Very often we stop them from dying from natural causes and send them for the last months and sometimes years of their lives to a nursing home or a special accommodation house. I think that Kevin Andrews's bill has given us an opportunity to begin the discussion about where our health efforts should be directed. How much more beneficial would it be for all of us to concentrate on disease prevention? What are we doing to address the problems of high mortality rates in Aboriginal babies?

The quality of life for many in this country is limited by curable and preventable diseases. We have scrapped, for example, an important dental health program which costs the government annually a fraction of what its loss will cause further down the health road. Mental health services for adolescents meet a small proportion of the needs. In Victoria, maternal and child health services are being wound back.

We need informed public debate and we need leadership in determining which end of the life cycle should attract our greatest effort and how far we should go to save a life close to the end of that cycle. We must speak about this issue freely and openly. Doctors are not the font of all wisdom and it should not be up to them alone to decide. We need education and perhaps guidelines under which our doctors and nurses can operate. We do need better palliative care services and we do need more hospice beds.

I realise that these will be highly contentious matters to raise in the middle of this debate and there will be some who will interpret my remarks as endorsing involuntary euthanasia—which of course I do not—but I will take that risk. I do favour euthanasia as a choice which should be freely made by those who wish to die and those who are willing to assist them. I do not seek to impose this on anyone who does not make this choice for themselves.

Many correspondents to my office, including organisations such as the Motor Neurone Disease Group and the woman in the Northern Territory who has a rare cancer of the gut, point out that deaths from such diseases are not simply painful and are only partly helped by palliative care. I cannot imagine what it must mean to know that you will face a certain death by gradual asphyxiation—the loss of control of bodily functions, the indignity and the discomfort. In March 1995, seven Melbourne doctors published in the Age an open letter to the Victorian Premier. They said:

For the sake of all of those who may be unfortunate enough to be trapped in suffering and anguish, we ask you to put an end to the uneasy hypocrisy of our law and to allow us to work without fear of prosecution.

Each of us who has signed this letter has personal experience of treating terminally ill people whose condition has moved them to ask for assistance in suicide and each of us has, on occasion, after deep thought and lengthy discussion, helped such a patient to die.

We declare this now in public, knowing that this declaration may be construed in the State of Victoria as an admission of a criminal offence. We do this because we believe passionately that this state's law on the assistance of suicide is wrong, and because those who continue to support the law have failed to recognise the reality of our work.

We have assisted patients to end their lives and we know others who have. We believe that we have acted in the best tradition of medical ethics, offering our patients relief from pain and suffering in circumstances where it would have been an act of cruelty to deny them. We respect life. All of our professional training and work deepens that respect. However, the reality is that there are some patients who are beset by physical and mental suffering which is beyond the reach of even our most sophisticated efforts at control. When such patients clearly and repeatedly express a rational plea for help, it is out of respect for them that we have felt compelled to act.

There are many who cry out for help and who are denied it by doctors who may sympathise with their plight but who are unwilling to break the law. There are some who attempt to end their lives unaided and who botch the attempt and survive with their misery redoubled. There are others who may be helped by a doctor but who, for fear of incriminating their friends and family, must choose to die alone without the chance to say farewell.

These doctors were of course not prosecuted. I sincerely hope that this debate can move beyond the questions of sanctity of life, with which we all agree, beyond the slippery slope arguments and the individual religious and high moral ground and get down to some of the real issues about dying.

Passing this bill would be an indication that this parliament is prepared to intervene in the laws made by another government in order to deny a human right. I hope, too, that those who hold on to the sanctity of life arguments in euthanasia are also the first to be counted in relation to human rights abuses in this country and elsewhere. In Indonesia more than a million people were killed when Suharto came to power. This regime is responsible for killing more than 300,000 East Timorese. My colleague Senator Meg Lees said last night much of what I would have said on this broader understanding of the sanctity of life. In this parliament there was much we could have done and there is much that we can do to prevent involuntary death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I should firstly say that I will be supporting the Euthanasia Laws Bill. My attitude in opposing euthanasia was a view that I arrived at many years ago. Whilst I have considered much of the recent discussion on this matter, I have been little influenced by it because of the conclusions I reached in respect of the sanctity of life and having a passionate opposition to euthanasia, as I said, having reached that conclusion a long time in the past. I, in being elected to parliament 6½ years ago, never dreamt that we would be considering in this country a piece of legislation that allowed the state or gave the state the right or imprimatur to end human life.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I go into my further contributions on this, I would just like to talk very briefly about some of the basic principles that I adhere to. I am a passionate student of his tory. To me, much of the central tenets of Christianity, which have played a very important role in the set of ethics that we as a Western society observe, are particularly important.

I have to say and emphasise that I am not a practising Christian in the sense that I attend church. But I do believe very strongly that many of the tenets laid out by Christ which have been so important in issues such as not taking human life and in a range of other areas—respect for the individual and some community understanding and support for individuals in a range of circumstances—are very important and I hold them particularly strongly. The sanctity of life—that you will not take life, that the state does not sanction the taking of life—is particularly important and is the overriding principle that I have followed in respect of my decision to oppose very passionately euthanasia.

As I said, I am not a practising Christian in the sense that I attend church regularly. I am not approaching this from the perspective of an argument relating to church and state and I do not see it as an issue of separating church and state, as some have advanced. I do not approach it from the religious point of view in the sense that I adhere to a particular Christian denomination. But I still think that in our Western society these Judeo-Christian principles are very important and should be preserved. A range of issues are emerging in our society today. Euthanasia is one of them. Clearly abortion is another. The death penalty is an issue that has been around for a long time.

The other issue is genetic engineering. Genetic engineering, similar to euthanasia, causes me very great concerns about what type of society will develop and emerge in the next 10, 50, 100 years. I believe that the issue of genetic engineering, or manipulation in many cases, will become one of the major political issues in the decades ahead.

I have already made reference to the fact that I am a keen student of history. One of the approaches I have taken to this legislation is that I do sincerely believe we have to look at the consequences of the decisions we as legislators take today and what the effect will be in 10, 20, 50, 100 years time. From my modest study of history, it is apparent to me that what were relatively minor changes in the past could have a dramatic effect on the future of our societies on this planet.

As I said earlier, I never believed that we as legislators would be considering legislation to overturn the legalisation of euthanasia. I never dreamed that it would be us in Australia having to consider this issue. This is the first national parliament in the world to have to consider this issue and make very important decisions about it—decisions, as I have said, that will impact on the type of society that we in Australia and the rest of the world have.

It is a very difficult issue. I understand the deeply held commitment, passion and concern people have for the terminally ill and the difficulties we have in dealing with a person who has great suffering and pain and the medical prognosis predicts that that person will die. That is a major and deep consideration.

The issue of states rights, or in this case territory rights, has been raised. My preference, frankly, would be to have a piece of legislation before us that outlaws euthanasia Australia wide, but that is not the reality of the situation we are confronted with. I have some sympathy for Senator Bob Collins's argument about this legislation overriding the Northern Territory legislation and not, in his argument, imposing a view across the nation.

If we had legislation before us that sought to outlaw euthanasia around this country, I would support it. But we are confronted with a situation where the Northern Territory parliament has passed a piece of legislation that clashes fundamentally with the principles that I adhere to. Being faced with that situation, the principles that I hold passionately have to be the overriding consideration. It is not a matter of territory rights or states rights. If the Tasmanian parliament had passed legislation with respect to the legalisation of euthanasia, I would be here supporting legislation to override the Tasmanian parliament.

This is not a dissimilar situation from that with respect to the Human Rights (Sexual Conduct) Bill—that is, whether to override a state law, in that case a Tasmanian law, because the critical principle at stake was more important than what is another important issue: the role of state legislatures and territory legislatures. They certainly do have a major role in our federation. But, as I say, it clashes with the central principle that I hold very importantly: you shall not take life and the states should not sanction the taking of life.

Abortion causes me a particular problem with this issue. It is not the issue of debate tonight, so I do not intend to make comment in that area. But, as I have said, over the coming years we in this federal parliament will inevitably be faced with decisions in other areas, for example with respect to the death penalty and genetic engineering.

Politicians are often accused of not taking a longer term view. On this issue I plead with my colleagues to think about the type of society that could emerge through the state sanctioning of the taking of life—that is, what could occur in the next 10, 20, 30 years. It has been referred to as the slippery slope argument. It is not a term that I like. After the initial sanctioning of the taking of life, what next steps will occur? I believe that that law will inevitably be broadened. It is not inconceivable to conclude that perhaps in 100 years' time we will, because of various economic pressures, because of the demographic changes that are occurring, increasingly marginalise people in our society, particularly the elderly and those with extreme ill health, for whom the easiest solution would be to end their life.

Some may consider this to be an absurd analogy but there is a particularly good science fiction book, made into a film, called Logan's Run, where in 200 or 300 years into the future everybody's life is terminated at the age of 30. I believe that, if we have sufficient vision and give sufficient consideration and thought to this issue, we can see that that is not an impossible scenario for 100 or 200 years hence. Albeit we can all be horrified by that concept today, I would hate to think that the first place on this planet that that process may begin is the Northern Territory in this country called Australia.

BREAK.PARA: It is argued that there are extensive safeguards to this legislation, and I have looked at those safeguards. But, regrettably, any sort of safeguards on the taking of a human life can be abused. Albeit that that abuse may be small—very, very small—I just cannot accept there being any possibility that in some way those safeguards, no matter how firmly in place, may be manipulated or bent. And I think that will occur.

As I have said, I fear very greatly for the marginalisation of people who have significant ill health, and particularly the elderly in our society. Our approach as a society must be to ensure that as a community we are always committed to the support of people in those circumstances, to ensure that sufficient resources are devoted to assist and protect to the maximum extent possible those people in our society with extreme ill-health and who are elderly.

Unfortunately, the sanctioning of euthanasia, I believe, will lessen the pressure in our society to devote the maximum resources to seek the solutions, to minimise the pain and the suffering and to ensure that as a society we devote more of our resources to palliative care and hospice beds. There is no doubt that in coming years it will become more and more of an issue and will require greater and greater effort in terms of our budget commitment.

I do have a few words about the attitude of the wider community as reflected by opinion polls. I am well aware that opinion polls do indicate that 70 to 80 per cent of the community supports euthanasia. But I do not regard my role as an elected politician simply to reflect what the latest opinion poll tells me that I should do in this case when I have the opportunity to exercise a conscience vote; it is a very rare occasion. I have no doubt that, certainly at the moment, those polls are accurate in terms of the community discussions, feedback and comments I have had on this issue.

But as elected representatives we are not simply here to do as the polls would indicate on all issues. At times it is a difficult judgment to make. We are elected representatives of the community—and in my case, the community of Tasmania. I am well aware that an overwhelming majority of people at the moment support euthanasia, although if there were a referendum—and I do not support that process—I think the arguments would be much more publicly debated than has occurred already and I think that that sentiment would change significantly.

But I do ask people in the broader community who are looking at the way I vote on this issue—and, as I said, I am supporting the legislation—to respect my conscience and my decision as an individual, because my party have allowed me the opportunity on this occasion to make an individual judgment and to cast my individual vote. It is not easy at times where my view does not match the opinion of the community to say, `I am not going to accept what you say'; it is not easy to do that. But we as legislators are not here simply to reflect on every occasion what the community would demand of us.
