The ultimate judgment of my views on this issue will be made through my party preselection process and, to some extent at least, in Tasmania where personal votes are certainly cast to a more significant degree than with other states. The ultimate judgment will be made and cast on my vote tonight in reflecting on my broader performance as a politician at the ballot box in five years' time. I do ask the people in Tasmania who on this issue have continued to push very strongly the argument of community sentiment to understand and respect my decision in supporting this legislation.

I do have some sympathy for the position Senator Collins is in. I do have some sympathy for the amendment that he has moved. But that is not the reality of the issue that we are faced with here and now. By all means, if Senator Collins wants to write and sponsor legislation that applies to the whole of the country, I would be more than pleased to support it. But at the moment we have a situation where the taking of life is occurring in the Northern Territory, and that situation must end—and it must end as soon as possible.

I suppose one of the strongest arguments in favour of euthanasia is that it happens any way. It does happen. I acknowledge that it is occurring to some extent, albeit illegally, and that is a difficult issue to have to answer. But I do not see full legalisation as being the solution to dealing with a problem that obviously does exist in our society today. I believe that in weighing up the arguments, where euthanasia is occurring illegally, the solution is not to legalise the problem.

I certainly do have very great sympathy with people who have been involved in that decision making process and who have been involved in the termination of a life illegally. I concede that, if a prosecution were occurring and I were on a jury in those circumstances, I would certainly be weighing up and considering the circumstances of each individual case. I think human nature and our legal system is sufficiently flexible to deal with those very difficult cases that come to trial.

In concluding my contribution, as I have said earlier, I regard Judeo‐Christian values very important to western society and to Australian society. They have contributed and do contribute a series of very basic principles that I support very strongly. One of those is the sanctity of life, the respect for human life. With my respect for life, the sanctity of life, and having considered the issues deeply, I came to the conclusion with a clear conscience that I will be supporting this legislation to ensure that the taking of life in the Northern Territory and euthanasia is ended as soon as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996. In 1978 this Commonwealth parliament gave self-government to the Northern Territory. In 1979 the same was extended to Norfolk Island. In 1988 it gave self-government to the Australian Capital Territory. The people of those territories had a right to expect that when they voted for their governments the people they subsequently elected would serve their interests to the very best of their abilities. When self-government decisions were made, the residents of those territories had no real cause to believe that there was an overrider, that they have self-government only as long as the Commonwealth agrees with them.

BREAK.PARA: However, in strict constitutional terms, one must recognise that there is a question mark about the constitutional provision to overturn the legislation of the territories. I recognise that the Commonwealth has the power to remove a legislative power granted to a territory. Clearly, this bill seeks to overturn legislation of the Northern Territory parliament but is not doing so within the legislated six months stipulated in the Northern Territory (Self-Government Act) 1978. Additionally, I recognise that such a power has never been used. It is correct therefore to say that this issue is not equivalent to that of states rights. It does certainly, however, raise the issue of the right of self-government.

Sadly, this debate has been derailed somewhat and presented as a bill either for or against euthanasia. It is actually a bill about overturning the decision of the Northern Territory parliament and I believe one must remember that fact. If the question was restricted to a debate purely about euthanasia then that would and should be an entirely different debate from that which we are having at present.

Most of us have our opinions formed by events in our lives. Those events can be ones experienced personally or by association with those who primarily we love and care for. My life has been typical of that course and I do not need to go into the specific events that have formed those lasting judgments. That would and should be a debate about the provision and extent of palliative care, it would and should be about various medical practices and also about those people whose needs do not fit into any given category.

I do believe, however, that there have been superb improvements in palliative care over the last decade or two and that those improvements will continue. The dedication of the health professionals who care for those in palliative care is something I admire greatly. Unlike some even in the medical profession who have sought to undermine the ethics, the motive and the simple question of morality of their colleagues, I have to say that I have trust in health professionals and the judgments they make in the best interests of their patients and acting as caring human beings with all the foibles that are attached to that mere fact.

The reality for me is that, as I have already said, this debate and vote should be about the merit or otherwise of the federal parliament striking down legislation in another jurisdiction. I have been an avid supporter of a federal system of government because I do believe in the role of the states and the general ability of state parliaments to make sound decisions based on local input and activity. That was one of the main reasons that I joined the Liberal Party of Australia, because of its commitment to federalism.

Not long after the introduction of this legislation last year a state colleague said that he sincerely hoped that I would be supporting it. My response to him was, `How would you feel if, after giving all due scrutiny and consideration to a piece of legislation, I then marched into your office and said, "Hey, listen pal, I am smarter than you. I know better than you. I am going to vote your legislation down."' His response was to purse his lips, suck in the air and say no more.

The six states can legislate for such a thing as euthanasia but this bill will prevent the three territories from doing so. I remind honourable senators again that those territories have been granted self-government by this very parliament. One can only presume from such action that none of the territories will be safe from future federal intervention if any one senator or member disagrees with a course of action taken by that territory parliament. The question really does need to be asked as to why territorians were given self-government in the first place if a democratically elected parliament can be usurped as easily as this bill proposes.

I can fully understand why all the premiers and chief ministers of both political persuasions were unanimous in their opposition to this bill last September. I believe it is a dangerous path to tread, especially on an emotive issue as euthanasia, because the next time it will be an issue that is felt equally passionately about by the same or other groups of people even though they could still be a minority.

My agonising over this bill has in the end revolved around its intent. That intent is somehow to make territorians different to all other Australians. The intent is to say that those democratically elected governments do not have the maturity to make difficult decisions. The intent is to say that for some reason the legislators of the federal parliament have better and clearer judgments and greater wisdom than those of a territory.

I have to say that I find it difficult to accept that I or, with respect, any one of us have a right to suggest or believe that we are superior legislators to those of the territories and that, as a consequence, our views should be pre-eminent. I, like all of my colleagues, have had considerable numbers of representations seeking to influence my vote. Most have been exceedingly reasonable and polite. Some have not.

I find it sad to note that, in the main, senators' speeches have simply been reported as either for or against euthanasia without due consideration that some are not voting on that basis at all. Some senators are voting on a basis, such as mine, that is linked to a long‐held conviction associated with federalism. I do not believe the argument that has been put that this does not apply. To me, it is the thin edge of the wedge.

I only hope that my view on this bill will be tolerated in the same way in which I have accepted and tolerated all the views that have been presented to me. I cannot and will not jettison my long‐held views on federalism, nor cloud them with an emotive issue and vote for federal intervention. It is for those reasons that I will not be supporting the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —I enter the debate on the Euthanasia Laws Bill with a commitment to the principle of an individual's right to choose to die in a way that is dignified and humane. However, I do recognise, as most honourable senators have done during this debate, that it is a particularly complex one. I have actually listened with interest to contributions from all senators—those with a genuine concern about euthanasia, those who have told heartfelt personal stories and even those who have questioned the right of a parliament to overturn a territory's law.

SPEECH.PARA: As a younger Australian, I am also keen to play a role in this debate. I hope that many people in our community do not make the mistake of thinking that younger Australians do not necessarily have a role to play in this debate or of thinking that, in my case, my life experiences are perhaps not great enough in number or in depth to speak with gravitas on this issue. Senators, of course, will not think this because they know that the decisions made in this chamber and in the other place impact upon all people in our society—young and old.

This has been anything but a clear-cut decision for me. I have found myself having to reconcile my belief in the principle of the right to choose to die with dignity with questions that surround the territory bill and the concept of active euthanasia. I do not want to see a devaluing of life in our community as a consequence of any bill passed in this or in any other place. But nor do I wish to see people's lives devalued as a result of the suffering they endure from disease and pain.

My overall commitment remains to improving our health system and the provision of appropriate palliative care in this country. In fact, I wish that our federal parliament would spend as much time and resources debating the concept of health provision and the well-being of people in this country as we have devoted to this particular extraordinary debate.

I acknowledge that palliative care is not the answer necessarily for all patients, but we should never stop seeking the solutions to health problems in our community, especially terminal diseases. I know that some do argue that the legalising of euthanasia may remove incentives for such an ardent search for solutions. Any move in such a direction, of course, should be strongly opposed by us all.

I do not see palliative care and euthanasia as mutually exclusive. I believe that the key for patients is choice—to be informed and to have access to all kinds of treatments, as well as the option of ending their lives in a legally controlled and humane fashion.

BREAK.PARA: I also know that we as legislators must have regard for the democratic aspects of this debate. The effect of the federal parliament passing a law that impacts only on the territories does concern me. In general, I have no hesitation about the federal parliament passing a law that affects all Australians and strikes down a state or territory law. However, when the federal parliament has restricted legislative power to strike down only territory legislation, I am disposed to challenge that law on the basis that it distinguishes between states and territories and the peoples in those states and territories. In these circumstances, I accept that denying the rights of territorians when a person in a state will have that right, is difficult to rationalise.

Admittedly, not all aspects of this debate are so precise for me. A particular difficulty I have had with this issue of euthanasia is in relation to younger Australians. I do not want to see decisions made in this place or by any other decision making body that tacitly or otherwise lead to an acceptance of the unprecedented levels of youth suicide in our community, already among the worst in the western world. I am glad to hear that other senators have spoken of their concern for the effect on young people.

We need young people to focus on life, not death. But this is not such an easy thing to do when you are jobless, without sufficient support, unable to access education, living in remote areas or when the feelings of alienation which have come to categorise many young people today are overwhelming.

There is one argument—I acknowledge that argument—that if the example from our elders is to hasten the final exit for whatever reason, young people in dire situations will see little reason for not emulating it. I realise that we do have to weigh that up, if we are being responsible in the messages we send young Australians. By legalising euthanasia, are we giving them an example of death as a choice?

We who are sheltered and privileged from the worst storms of life by education and support may find the distinctions easy to make. But a young person whose dreams are shattered, whose lot is loneliness and isolation or joblessness and repeated disappointment may not make that distinction so easily. They may easily see their situation as no less hopeless and painful than that of a person with a terminal disease.

Life is about the perceptions and we must grant that such a young person may have such a perception. But death is no stranger to people of my age. I have had friends who have died by choice and most of my contemporaries, alas, would say the same. I am haunted by the knowledge that, given another day, a week or a change in circumstance, the choice of those who left us prematurely may have been to live. I cannot bear the thought that any decision that this or any other chamber could make should make it easier for young people to make that choice by being able to infer that it is okay to end life when it seems unbearable as a result of psychic or physical pain.

So you can see I have grappled with this issue in this debate. I also realise that there are many aspects to the debate about youth suicide and there is a need for additional funding for youth suicide education, research and prevention programs and for real education, training and employment options for young Australians so that they do have the promise of a real and meaningful future. I do acknowledge the opinion polls that show that young people are among the strongest supporters of legal euthanasia.

It is not only older members of our community who get terminal diseases; young people do too. I know that there are many young people in the AIDS lobby—for example, the New South Wales AIDS Council—who do support legalised euthanasia. I do appreciate the arguments that have been put forward by them and other HIV-AIDS sufferers and their representative organisations.

I acknowledge the statistics of suicide among older Australians. As I understand it, more than 640 Australians aged 75 or over committed suicide between 1990 and 1994. In the case of suicides among older Australians, we must ask how many of them were as a result of voluntary euthanasia being denied them. Some do argue that decriminalising voluntary euthanasia could lead to a reduction in levels of trauma or anxiety in our society and it could lead to a reduction in the number of violent suicides.

Death and the politics of death impact on everyone, young and old. The complexity of this issue has been recognised by the Australian Council on Ageing, who chose not to adopt a position in this debate but to distribute a discussion paper covering all the arguments and urging people to discuss this issue with their families. Perhaps the most valuable aspect of this debate has been that it has caused the topic of death and dying to be discussed not only in the houses of parliament but in houses all around this nation.

The president of that council, June Healy, has noted that women live longer than men on average, are more likely to be caring for a husband with a debilitating disease than vice versa, are more likely to be carers and have to endure the painful prolonged process of death than men, and are more likely to die without their partners being present.

Women have been another concern for me in this debate. Women are traditionally the carers, the ones to ease the way in family life. I do not discount the fact that they may be vulnerable to feelings that, when terminally ill, they should show care for their families before their own wishes to live as long as possible and ease family life by making an exit before their time. This argument has caused me great deliberation.

I am also aware now of the arguments of women such as Dr Margaret Otlowski from the Department of Law at the University of Tasmania. Hers is a convincing argument. She claims that laws such as the Northern Territory's are necessary in order to regulate and bring out into the open what is currently a hidden and unregulated practice.

I do accept the reality that euthanasia does take place already, even with the legal prohibition in place. It takes place and laws like the Northern Territory Rights of the Terminally Ill Act 1995 are designed to regulate this practice, ensure that it is transparent, ensure that doctors are accountable and actually empower those patients, including those vulnerable groups that I have mentioned. Dr Otlowski argues:

The current legal situation is totally unsatisfactory in that it creates very real dangers for both doctors and patients: doctors are at risk of criminal liability for murder (or assisted suicide) if their conduct is exposed; the rights and interests of the patients are vulnerable, particularly in light of recent evidence indicating a relatively high incidence in Australia of killing of patients occurring other than at the patients request.

It is estimated that 30 per cent of Australian deaths are preceded by medical decision explicitly intended to hasten a patient's death. Of these deaths, 3.5 per cent or around 4,400 involve a decision to end the patient's life without the patient's concurrent explicit request and 1.8 per cent of the deaths are the result of doctors administering or prescribing drugs with the intention of ending the patient's life at the patient's request.

So there currently exists no appropriate structure and no regulatory framework. Already there exists a balance of power of the well over the sick and of the professional over the patient. I do not seek to entrench such a power imbalance or to increase the power of doctors over patients but to empower those terminally ill patients so that they can determine how their lives end and when that takes place and so that they can do so in a safe fashion, humanely and with dignity. It is a right I would wish for myself. It is a decision that I would wish to exercise safely and legally.

I commend those Australians on all sides of this debate who have contacted my office or who have written often quite well researched or heartbreaking letters. I also thank those people who appeared before the committee. My thanks to Shirley for agreeing to disagree.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs, Sen Bruce

TALK.START.PARA: —I think there has been an impressive quality of debate on this Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996. The sincerity of senators who have described their own personal experiences of loved ones dying is touching. I do not doubt the goodwill of all senators on either side of the argument genuinely searching for the best outcomes based on their beliefs.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe a person has the right to demand release from hopeless and helpless pain. I believe that forcing a person to die slowly and painfully rather than allowing them to die quickly and painlessly if they so choose is cruel and beyond the proper role of government. I feel bound to point out some of the contradictions in the arguments put by the supporters of the Andrews's bill.

The first contradiction is between our role as representatives and this move to overturn the clear will of the people. As parliamentary representatives, we seek sometimes to reflect the will of the people and sometimes to lead public opinion. We are professional decision makers and at each election we ask the populace to trust us and allow us to make decisions on their behalf. In most cases, the decisions we make are removed from the average person's everyday experience.

Complex legislation changes are delegated by the people to their parliamentary representatives, yet we have a situation in the case of voluntary euthanasia where almost every person in the community has an opinion based on intimate knowledge of someone close to them dying. They have had the experience, they are informed. We here in the chamber are no different. Many senators have spoken very movingly about their intimate experiences of loved ones dying, but they are only reflecting a community experience.

The consistent message from the community is that there is overall support for voluntary euthanasia, although a vocal, well organised minority has bombarded parliamentarians with anti‐euthanasia messages. Community polling usually shows support for voluntary euthanasia in excess of 70 per cent. The contradiction in this instance is that despite clear support for the Northern Territory's voluntary euthanasia legislation, the same parliamentarians who pore over opinion polls and take notice of them refuse to listen to a clear message from the people. Do those parliamentarians who support the private member's bill believe that the will of the people on this matter is irrelevant or do they believe the majority who support a right to voluntary euthanasia just do not know what is good for them? To imply that community support for euthanasia is uninformed is elitist. Unfortunately, some senators have conveyed that impression.

The second contradiction in this debate has been covered extensively in the media and by others, including by Senator Collins tonight: that is the contradiction between those people who consistently argue for states' rights and yet in this instance are willing to overturn a measure that has bipartisan support in the Northern Territory. The majority of people in the Northern Territory have been quite clear in expressing their support for voluntary euthanasia.

I see another reason for leaving the Northern Territory legislation as it stands. Isn't it possible to look at the legislation for voluntary euthanasia in one territory as an opportunity to gauge the success and effectiveness of this option? Legislation of voluntary euthanasia in the Northern Territory would give the Australian community a chance to gauge what voluntary euthanasia would mean in an Australian context; it would give us a case study in an Australian context. If the legislation proved in any way problematic it could be overturned later, instead of the indecent haste of this bill. Why shouldn't we give this a fair go? Some would argue that any delays mean lives lost, yet the people to make use of the Northern Territory legislation to date have all unequivocally wanted release from suffering; they had been in the final stages of terminal illness.

A third contradiction appears in the selective application of the sixth commandant—`Thou shalt not do murder'. Some opponents arguing for the sanctity of life say that, no matter what the quality of life, a person has no right to end it. The underlying assumption is that God gave life and only God can take it away. Yet in my lifetime I have seen that as soon as the flag is raised and patriotic fervour is whipped up, respect for the sanctity of life goes out the window. Many of the same people who raise their voices against voluntary euthanasia are prepared to stand by while governments send young men off to be killed in war. Granville Williams, an eminent jurist from the United Kingdom, made the point almost 30 years ago in his book The Sanctity of Human Life and the Criminal Law. He said that the sixth commandant is not `Thou shalt not kill', but `Thou shalt not do murder'. He said:

BREAK.PARA: . . . and it is only by a stretch of words that a killing with the patient's consent, to relieve him of inexpressible suffering, can be morally described as murder.

If wholesale killing in war and the punitive killing of criminals are not "murder" surely a killing done with the patient's consent, and for his benefit as an act of mercy can claim to be excluded from this ugly word.
If euthanasia is condemned only for religious reasons, then the fact that we live in a secular state should be enough reason to exclude voluntary euthanasia from the criminal code.

The fourth contradiction lies in the concern that some groups, especially some of the church groups, have expressed for Aboriginal people and how they will be affected by voluntary euthanasia. This is in stark contrast to the poor record of churches and the state in protecting Aboriginal families. They have ignored the disastrous effects of stealing children from their families, they have ignored the suicides and high rates of incarceration, deaths in custody and substance abuse, and they have denied the role of paternalistic white institutions, especially churches, in this destruction. In my state of New South Wales one in three Aboriginal people now living were stolen from their family as children. It has taken some people until now to discover concern for the plight of Aboriginal people.

I would like to hear a debate like the one we are having, in which two‐thirds of senators speak, about our consistent failure to improve conditions in Aboriginal communities: about 200 years of neglect at best and, more often than not, state‐sanctioned brutality. I would like to see the amount of time and energy that we have spent on overturning the Northern Territory's legislation directed to improving the living conditions of Aboriginal people.

Many speakers have referred to the need to prevent voluntary euthanasia being legalised in the Northern Territory because it is the `thin end of the wedge' or the `beginning of the slippery slide'. The thin edge of the wedge argument also supposes that, while euthanasia may be morally defensible in an individual case, the wellbeing of the community as a whole is diminished by its acceptance. Joseph Sullivan defined the wedge principle in the 1940s when he wrote:
The wedge principle means that an act which, if raised to a general line of conduct would injure humanity, is wrong even in an individual case.

Sullivan supposes, for the sake of argument, that the merciful extinction of human life in a suffering patient is not in itself immoral. Still it is immoral because, if it were permitted, this would admit `a most dangerous wedge that might put all life in a precarious condition'. This argument could be applied to almost any act whatsoever.

I should also remind other senators that not so long ago the use of anaesthetic during surgery or childbirth was considered the `thin end of the wedge'. Many Christians considered that the pain of childbirth was woman's punishment for Eve's sin and was given by God as a reminder of this. Although many women still choose not to accept anaesthetic during childbirth, the concept of denying a woman pain relief because it is God's will that she should suffer seems barbaric to us now. I believe that it is inevitable that, as a society, we will eventually come to feel similarly about voluntary euthanasia—that it is barbaric to expect a person to live on in pain when they are wholeheartedly wishing for release.

A fifth contradiction arises when palliative care is considered. I wholeheartedly support the provision of the best quality of palliative care. My feeling is that the vast majority of terminally ill people, as long as their pain is manageable, will choose to wait for a natural death. In a majority of cases, pain can be managed. However, we have a coalition government that is cutting spending on health care and palliative care, with many government members arguing that palliative care should be the only option available to terminally ill people irrespective of the pain they may be suffering. Senator Crowley yesterday pointed out the contradiction of drugging people until they are insensate, as often happens in the final stages of palliative care, yet not allowing those same people to make a choice to end their own lives while they are still able to.

I have received, like everybody else, many pieces of correspondence from all sorts of people. One organisation that has been very impressive in the material that it sent to me is the Motor Neurone Disease Association of Australia. I will read only one letter that refers to this condition because it highlights one of the groups that I think has a very powerful case. So many people already have referred to people who are dying with cancer. The letter says:

Motor neurone disease is a terminal disease that brings about death through a progressive disabling process. MND does not affect the intellect or the senses. As the disease progresses, the sufferer is increasingly unable to impact on their surroundings. They are aware of what is happening to them, but they are unable to do anything about it.

What cannot be treated is the mental pain and anguish of MND—the torture of knowing what is happening around you, what is happening to your body and not being able to do anything about it. Providing support for people with MND is about providing options. Currently, with the exception of the Northern Territory, these options are about living with the disease. However, the Northern Territory legislation provides an additional option—the right to voluntarily terminate life.

Suicide is legal in all states of Australia. With MND, however, the progressive nature of the disease results in an inability for a person suffering from the disease to take their life. This is particularly true at the end stages of the disease where a person has little or no mobility, and cannot effect an end to their own life.

They do not have the option of suicide to consider. Palliative care can meet many of the needs of people living with MND. But not all needs. Palliative care is an option this association recommends, wholeheartedly supports, and has invested significant resources to establish cooperative relationships and strategic alliances to ensure that people living with MND are able to access services that meet their needs. The association is of the view that patients should have a range of choices regarding living with their disease, including the right to make a choice not to continue living with MND.

That particular association, I think, sums up the sort of illness that would be considered under the Northern Territory legislation. As I said at the commencement, if you are frightened—I know some senators genuinely believe some of the horrendous stories of slippery slopes and thin ends of the wedges—then surely the fair way is to give it a fair go in the Northern Territory, wait a year or two, and come back with all the horrific cases, if you think they are there, and present the case again. Not to do that at this moment is to allow your own predetermined views to override the declared view, the declared attitude, of 80 per cent of the Australian people and particularly the people in the Northern Territory.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I remember a story once about a 70‐year‐old woman who went to a doctor because her knee was giving her pain. The doctor said `Well, the trouble is you are getting old.' She said, `Doctor, my other knee is just as old and it doesn't hurt. Fix it.' I say that because of the way our system is at the moment. We have heard a number of people talk about how euthanasia occurs within the system that exists now. We have heard of cases where people suffering from cancer have died—and that example is used a lot in this argument. We have heard that, in this system—and it is usually important to ask not only nurses but also doctors what happens in this system—there are many cases where people are helped along their way.

SPEECH.PARA: However, we generally do not hear about the thousands of people who die in our hospital systems annually as a result of neglect. It is not because people are not nice people, but when you cut and cut out of a system which is labour intensive, you concentrate on illness rather than community health, you cut from the unpointy end and you leave to crisis care, bit by bit the conscience and the efforts of the people in the system have to be blunted. There are whole wards of people, especially in the public hospital systems, who for mental reasons can be called various names. I remember there was a ward in Royal Perth Hospital which somebody referred to as a self-inflicted ward. It was a ward full of older people who had suffered strokes and so on. Somehow you could justify the lack of attention that some of the people in those wards got on the basis that `they probably drank too much or they probably smoked too much or they probably brought it on in some way through their lifestyle'.

I think they are some of the ways in which nurses had to cope with the reality of what the hospital system was becoming. If the patient was younger, if the patient was co operative and so on, they would get the assistance that the hospital system could give them. If they were older, especially if they were a bit cranky and difficult, and if some patients were not keen on eating if they were ill, it was a different story. In the case of my father, I know that if he did not want to eat and felt revolting every time he had to be sat up to eat, he would say, `Go away.' Somebody actually had to sit there and talk him into eating. They virtually forced him to eat. The system would have just put a pump in his stomach and he probably would have pulled it out. I know that my grandfather probably died from some form of malnutrition in the end because he had a throat cancer whilst he was suffering from other problems.

There is a line that is drawn within our hospital system that says, `Above this age, we have so many resources. Let's put them into the areas where we are most likely to get a result—the younger people, the relatively healthy people and so on, the people who we can get better.' I can understand the people in that system having to make those decisions. I do not envy their position. I cannot understand those people who sit back and continue to close their eyes to the effect of what we are doing to our system and then say, `It has nothing to do with me.' Do you not think that they would say that people ought to be able to make the choice to live through this system?

I am the last person who thinks that the system of economic fundamentalism or rationalism ought to be pushing this debate in any way in relation to euthanasia. I find it extraordinary that people can close their eyes to what we are doing to people who manage to find themselves at the hands of the health system if they do not have families who are watching their welfare closely. What happens to those people? It is not because of anyone's wickedness but because of neglect, because of the resources we do not give to the system and because of the triage system where we have to work out which people are likely to benefit from the scarce and diminishing health resources compared to the people who seem to require those resources.

BREAK.PARA: To me one of the great hypocrisies of many people who stand on the right to life in itself and the sanctity of life is that, whilst for economic gain they promote Australia's arms sales and what they might do to other countries, they would think, `There's nothing wrong with that; that's the market.' They would condone Australia's contribution to weapons of mass destruction. They would say, `That's the market; let's sell uranium.' So we can do things which might in the end poison or kill many thousands of people but sanctity of life does not come into that!

Having said that, I do not think that this situation that we are faced with tonight is simply a matter of choice. It is not as simple as saying, `It is a matter of what I do with my life or what I do not do with my life.' I think it is broader than that. Most of the people who have been asked to make a decision realise that. There is a concern. I know that my parents felt that concern in relation to the potential brave new world. I know that there is deep concern within the Aboriginal community based on what they see from the hospital system and the health care system already and that institutionalised neglect and disadvantage—what they see already and what they may see as their relative power position within the system.

I do not think we should use economic rationalism as an excuse for allowing their fears to come to fruition. We all have an obligation after tonight's debate to make sure that we do not continue to neglect categories of people within our health system, we do not continue to allow the suffering of those people who we know are dying within a short time, we do not care just for those people who we know are dying of cancer and we do not continue to let people suffer in very long, drawn out ways from all sorts of diseases. They include the people within our hospital system for whom we do not supply enough orderlies—for instance, the people who need to be sat up once or twice a day for their condition, the people who get left out for two hours because there are not enough orderlies to put them back into bed and who suffer from being left out and the people who cannot bathe themselves and whose relatives might not even come into the hospital. They are being left uncomfortable because they cannot speak out for themselves.

There are many people suffering within our hospital system. I refuse to let economic rationalism overrule those people's wishes as well. That is a large reason why I foreshadow a second reading amendment to add to the motion, which reads:
But the Senate calls on the government to provide adequate funding for—
(a) the development and implementation of national guidelines and standards in relation to palliative care;
(b) increased levels of training for health care professionals in all aspects of palliative care;
(c) an integrated approach to palliative care, including—
(i) coordination of care delivery with support of volunteers, whether in home or in institutions for maximum effectiveness; and
(ii) provision of respite care as an essential component; and
(d) improved and expanded research into palliative care, especially pain control and symptom relief.
I believe I cannot move this amendment, as a second reading amendment has already been moved.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is correct, Senator Margetts.
—I foreshadow my amendment at this stage.

BREAK.PARA: We cannot, as a society, refuse to accept responsibility for what we are doing to people who find themselves in our hospital system. We cannot cease to be a caring society. At the same time, if we do have a situation as has occurred in the Northern Territory—where the legislature has chosen to take the step, which they have, of allowing voluntary euthanasia—then we cannot not provide the support that is necessary to make sure people have the maximum choice.

I agree with those people who say that palliative care is not the answer to euthanasia. My challenge is to both sides of this argument. If you are very much against voluntary euthanasia and say that people must value their last moments, even if they are in great agony, then you must be prepared to allow appropriation to make sure that quality palliative care is a right of those people who are dying, whether they are dying quickly or dying slowly. That includes those people who are under the dotted line who are currently being neglected in our system.

If you believe in the right to choose, then there must in fact be a choice. For many people in Australia we know the choices are not as good as they should be. We know that there are many places in Australia, there are many parts within Australia, there are many parts within cities, and there are many people whose funds do not allow them to find the care they need to be able to make the best choices and to be able to choose the time which is best for them, if they so choose to end their lives.

Whilst federal governments might say states make the decision on health care, I think that is a cop‐out. There are many ways in which the federal government is currently telling the states what to do on many issues, and that includes education. We are going to have compulsory tests on literacy for young children in our schools, and we are going to get the states to pay for it. If we are going to do that—if we are going to make prescriptive comments about vaccinations, if we are going to make prescriptive comments about literacy tests—then we can say that the federal government will provide them with funding, and that appropriation will be made to make sure that there is a choice. For all of the people who feel strongly about this issue in this Senate, there is a choice, and we all have an obligation to make sure that that choice is a real one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson, Sen Kay

TALK.START.PARA: —As there is a number of senators still to follow me, I will be reasonably brief in my comments. I have read all of the contributions to the debate in the House of Representatives, and I have listened to almost all of the contributions here in the Senate. If I have not listened to them, I have read them. I have followed those closely and I know that most of the arguments, if not all of them, have been canvassed over and over. So I will not go over them all. I hope that the brevity of my contribution will not be taken as an indication of the thought I have put into it.

SPEECH.PARA: Like many of my colleagues in both this place and the House of Representatives, I have not found the task of considering the Euthanasia Laws Bill an easy one. I have tried to approach it with an open mind. I have invited people to come and see me and have sought people out who I thought would have different opinions from mine and also different opinions from each other. I did that in order to examine the issue as widely as possible.

I have to admit that I have wavered in my decision. One reason for this is that the question before us is not a straightforward one. It is not a straightforward one which has to be made by any of us. It is not only about being pro-voluntary euthanasia or anti-voluntary euthanasia. It also involves a decision about overturning legislation made under another jurisdiction. I am not a constitutional lawyer, but the weight of evidence has convinced me that the Commonwealth does have the constitutional power, under section 122 of the constitution, to overturn the Northern Territory Rights of the Terminally Ill Act.

The overturning by the Commonwealth of legislation enacted by the Territory should, however, only be undertaken in exceptional circumstances. The question then is: does this constitute an exceptional circumstance which would warrant the activation of the constitutional provision?

The Northern Territory legislation, as it stands, is not restricted to Northern Territory residents alone. It potentially affects all Australians. Already two of the four people who have chosen assisted suicide have not been residents of the territory. The issue has been brought before the federal parliament by means of this bill. It is incumbent on me to do my best to evaluate the arguments, to form an opinion and to vote on the bill. Barry Jones said in his contribution in the lower house:
I have a moral obligation to vote . . . indeed, not to choose is to choose.
I agree with him on that.

BREAK.PARA: Many in the debate who have been opposed to the Andrews bill have argued that it should be a matter of choice on the part of the individual, that no-one else should be able to deny another the opportunity to make a decision to end their life. It is a compelling argument and, many would argue, a compassionate one. But what may be seen as the most compassionate option may not be in the interests of the common good in the long run, nor is the view that to allow people to choose euthanasia the province of the compassionate alone. In 1939, Hitler said, `Incurably sick persons should be granted mercy death.' I think no-one here could defend him as a compassionate person.
I must admit that during my contemplation on my response to this bill, I identified with Keats when he said in his Ode to a Nightingale:
Darkling I listen; and, for many a time
I have been half in love with an easeful Death . . .

In fact most of us, if not all of us, despite our beliefs or religious convictions, if we were absolutely truthful, could say with Keats that, if we were suffering an incurable illness, we might be tempted to be `half in love with an easeful death'. Even the most resolute in their abhorrence of euthanasia may be tempted, as Bob Collins admitted tonight, to choose euthanasia as an option. I believe I am no less mortal.

If one were merely to respond on the basis of the plethora of the polls and surveys, one would be tempted to oppose the Andrews bill. Poll and survey after survey indicates general community support for euthanasia. But the closer one looks at these polls, the less certain one must surely be of basing a decision on them. An opinion piece in the New York Times by Daniel Yankelovich, chairman of a US public opinion and social trends research organisation, cautions us. He says:

There is an important lesson here about the strengths and limits of opinion polls. Most of them do accurately measure what people say. But only the most sophisticated measure what people really mean. Market researchers learned the lesson years ago; politicians and most of the media have not.
Why the disparity between what people say and what they mean? On complex issues like health care,—
I put in here euthanasia—
they haven't thought through all of the consequences of their opinions.

In the early stages of public debate on an issue, people typically hold conflicting opinions, with no real awareness that they are in conflict. (I call this "raw opinion.") As public debate progresses and people have the opportunity to consider alternatives and trade-offs, the compartments break down and people's views become more integrated and thoughtful.

With the right kind of public debate, raw opinion evolves into responsible public judgment. The disparity between what people say and what they mean disappears. Only then can the answers to opinion poll questions be taken literally.

I have made it my business since this bill was first introduced to ask people about their views on euthanasia. I have terrorised Comcar drivers, who look a little stunned first thing in the morning when they pick me up and I ask, `What do you think about it?' Taxi drivers, shopkeepers, doctors, nurses and other health professionals—even some in the press gallery—have been haunted by my questions and I have challenged them to answer.

It is very easy in the community to say on the one hand, `I think this' and, on the other hand, `I think that.' But on Monday night we actually have to make the decision to sit on one side or the other. I have challenged almost everyone I have come in contact with and I am sure most of those who are associated with me will be glad when this debate is over. The overwhelming majority, other than the health professionals, have said emphatically that they believe in voluntary euthanasia. However, their resolve has dissolved the more we have discussed the pros and cons. Maybe it is a case of their being half in love with an easeful death or the concept of an easeful death. Maybe, as the pollster has explained, they had not thought through all the consequences of their opinions.

Some of us in this debate have not been in a situation of having been closely involved with someone who is terminally ill. Others have and have chosen not to talk about it and others, as I have said, have not experienced it. I have had the privilege—I count it a privilege—of having been very closely associated, in fact sharing the last days of life, with two young friends, both of whom died: one from melanoma and the other from a chondro sarcoma.

I was therefore no stranger to death when I was confronted with my mother's diagnosis of terminal cancer two years ago. I will admit that I was devastated and, like Senator Newman, was fearful of what lay ahead for someone for whom I cared so much. Had voluntary euthanasia been an option, and had my mother chosen voluntary euthanasia, I am sure she would have discussed it with me. What I am not so sure of is what my response would have been. I will admit the anticipatory fear of what lay ahead was almost more than I could bear. Being my mother, she no doubt knew my fear as intimately as she knew her own.

Who is to say that, motivated by a perverse sort of altruism, she would not have chosen euthanasia? Or that I, in agreeing with her decision, would have been motivated as much by my own fears as by supporting her decision to end her pain. Terminal illness leaves both the sufferer and their families uniquely vulnerable. Relationships of trust and dependence are magnified so powerfully by uncertainty and fear of what lies ahead. In such a situation, stressed by the certainty of impending grief, loved ones, however well intended, may agree with a dying person's half-meant request for euthanasia as a means of assuaging their own fear. The dying, hearing their loved one's agreement, may form a real intent not present before.

My mother's death was not an easy one. In fact, it most probably would have been described by Senator Eggleston as a hard one—at home in a country town and with me, a fairly inadequate nurse, which she identified at one point and said, `I'm glad you didn't do nursing.' I asked her why and she said, `You're rather bad at it. But I wouldn't change you for the world.' As I said, it was a bumpy ride, mixed with sorrow and joy. The community nurses and her doctor, himself terminally ill, relieved her suffering to the best of their ability.

In the grief of my loss, I did not have to ponder the particular concern or guilt of my mother having made a decision based more on my needs than her own. The complex and tangled nature of love can lead just as surely to someone choosing voluntary euthanasia as a decision influenced by the motives of greed and personal benefit of those associated with a dying person.

Another concern I have is the pressure of a doctor suggesting euthanasia to a patient as an option. How many fearful patients may read into the doctor's suggestion that he or she anticipates that their dying will be insufferable or that the doctor has given up hope on them? Nor am I convinced that the interaction between the dying patient would not be influenced by the doctor's own difficulty with supporting and caring for a patient who is terminally ill. Doubts are also cast upon the ability of doctors—even three of them in the Northern Territory case—to decide if someone, especially a patient with whom they have had very little, if any, contact, is depressed. Nor are medical practitioners infallible.

All of us most probably have examples of people in the last stages of their life—in fact even some with whom I have spoken—who have been in palliative care, people whom we would assume, and the doctors have assumed, are dying. They then, for sometimes inexplicable reasons, apparently defy their prognosis and, through spontaneous remission or through intervention of a new and untried therapy, live.

I have other concerns with the Northern Territory legislation but time does not permit me to address them all. In a perfect world, one may be able to devise a law that is free of the possibility of abuse. If that were the case, even if one were personally opposed to the law on moral or religious grounds, I believe it would be difficult to argue that others should not be free to choose to die when they believed that the pain and suffering of their terminal illness was unbearable. But we do not live in a perfect world, given the emotions of the dying person and the emotions and motives of those closely associated with them. Some, and maybe many, may not be in a position to make a free and competent decision that is not the subject of overt or covert pressures.

Individual rights do not exist in a vacuum. The integrity of individual rights is wholly dependent upon the nature of the society that begets them. The nation which would allow the vulnerable to be placed at risk for the pursuit of self‐determination by others is not a society, I believe, which can call itself a `free society'. A free society curtails individual rights for the common good. It pursues the greatest possible freedom for the greatest possible number of people.

The right to self‐determination, presupposed by the concept of voluntary euthanasia or assisted suicide, must be balanced against the right of the sick and vulnerable to receive the protection of a just society. If we sacrifice the former, people will continue to suffer, and I acknowledge that with great sorrow. But if we sacrifice the latter, some—more likely the weak and vulnerable—may die against their will. Therefore I will be voting to support the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —In determining how I will vote on this most important issue, I have endeavoured to read and contemplate all of the arguments advanced for and against euthanasia. I have tried to read widely and as much literature that I could get hold of on the subject. I have thought long and hard about the issue. I have tried to understand the depth of feeling of the people who support or oppose euthanasia. Like all senators, I have received hundreds of letters and many phone calls. I thank the people who have taken the time and trouble to put their point of view to me. I have considered my personal feelings and my conscience, but I have also tried to step back to make an objective analysis of all the arguments.

SPEECH.PARA: I have come to the conclusion that I cannot, in conscience, support a law which legalises and promotes the deliberate and intentional taking of human life. Accordingly, I cannot support the Northern Territory Rights of the Terminally Ill Act. I will therefore support the Euthanasia Laws Bill. In explaining my reasons, I take as the starting point the question that I have posed to myself and sought the answer to throughout this entire debate. I asked the question: what is our primary responsibility as law makers? In answering the question that I pose, I believe that our primary responsibility as law makers is to protect and advance the rights, freedom and welfare of our citizens. That is ultimately why we are here. The greatest of those rights, recognised in our system of law and also in any system of human or social values, is the right to life.

Without life, there is no humanity. The greatest individual right to be protected under the law is life itself. Correspondingly, the greatest crime that can be committed against humanity—against the law—is the deliberate and intentional taking of human life without just cause. This right to life is recognised in international covenants and in jurisprudence. This is not just a religious principle or belief. What is often called the `sanctity of life' extends beyond religious faith and belief in a god. It is fundamental, I believe, to human existence, whether one follows a religious faith or not.
The right to life is explicitly recognised in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. Article 6(1) states:
Every human being has the inherent right to life. This right shall be protected by law. No‐one shall be arbitrarily deprived of his life.

I speak of rights—the recognition and the protection of rights—because that is central to the views of many who have participated in this debate. Indeed, the title of the Northern Territory legislation is the Rights of the Terminally Ill Act.

Many of those who have spoken in this debate and have supported euthanasia, and people who have supported euthanasia in the debate in the wider community, have based their arguments on the principle of the right of the individual, on the freedom of the individual. It is passionately argued that individuals have the right to choose whether they wish to die or not at the time of their choosing and that other individuals and the legislature—the state—should not deny them that right. However, I believe that this argument, as passionately held as it is, is both illogical and contrary to the entire basis of our legal system.

BREAK.PARA: As I have said, the right to life is recognised in that international covenant, but it extends much further and permeates our entire legal and social system. We have many laws which reflect the principle that human life is to be protected and advanced. For instance, we have a social welfare system and a health system underpinned by legislation that is intended to protect peoples lives and livelihood. We grant humanitarian aid so that people will not starve to death. We spend millions of dollars on rescuing people from otherwise certain death in far‐flung oceans. In more recent years, we have come to give specific and greater recognition to the rights of the disabled and the mentally ill under the law. We regard their lives as having worth and having meaning and we have enacted legislation specifically to promote that recognition. It was not always so.

In the light of this fundamental principle of the sanctity and worth of human life—of all individuals—which underpins our legislative and democratic system, I cannot accept the argument advanced by the supporters of euthanasia that there is a corresponding individual right to die and that it should be enshrined in law, contrary to the rest of the criminal justice system. The two concepts, to my mind, are mutually exclusive.

However, if, as the supporters of the Northern Territory law argue, such a right to die exists and if, as they argue, it is an inalienable right of all individuals and none should seek to interfere, then the Northern Territory law itself, which is based upon this principle, is both discriminatory and inconsistent. The Northern Territory law recognises a right only for the terminally ill who are of sound mind, are suffering pain or distress and can obtain the necessary authorisation. What is claimed to be an inalienable right of all individuals is confined by that very legislation to a very select group of people, namely the terminally ill. Further, the law provides that the only exemption from criminal prosecution under the law is restricted to a select group of people, namely doctors.

If this so-called right or freedom of choice, this individual right, exists, then why is it not available for all other individuals in society? It is a rhetorical question, I know, but it goes to what I believe is a fundamental issue in the matter. I do not seek to argue that the right should be extended, because I do not accept the principle that is argued for in the first place. But it is illogical to support individual rights and freedom of choice on the one hand as the basis for the Northern Territory legislation and yet support that same legislation which grants that right to only a very select few in strictly defined circumstances on the other hand.

Euthanasia is often referred to as assisted suicide. While suicide is no longer a criminal offence in most jurisdictions, the law nevertheless enables the state to intervene—forcefully, if necessary—to prevent a person from taking his or her own life. We believe that suicide is contrary to the interests of individuals and of society. We are rightly concerned and disturbed at the high incidence of youth suicide and the deaths in custody particularly of our indigenous people. These are recognised as major problems that society and governments must endeavour to prevent.

I am sure that many of us know someone who has suicided or attempted to do so. I have known such a person. A close friend of mine from school and university suicided many years ago. I have often thought and wished, `If only I'd seen the signs at the time. If only I or other friends had had a chance to talk him out of it. If only we'd been with him and stopped him from jumping.' That is what society would have us do—take steps to prevent that suicide. That is what the law and our social and health systems would expect us to do. And we would have been right to do it, given the chance.

But that was obviously not what he wanted. His pain and his anguish was just as real and just as severe as that of the person with a terminal physical illness. His desire for release was just as real. But society does not condone and never has condoned that such suicide should be a right—to be assisted by other people and recognised at law.

There are many instances of where people who are not necessarily terminally ill nevertheless suffer extreme pain and suffering and distress and may wish to end their life and would like someone to assist them to do so. This very issue was raised during the Senate committee hearings and it was commented upon by the architect of the Northern Territory legislation, Marshall Perron, when he gave evidence to the committee on Friday, 24 January this year. I quote from the Hansard. Marshall Perron was asked by Senator McGauran:

Would you think that once this legislation, if kept in place, reached a maturity—whenever that would be, but several years down the track—you could look at changing it to accommodate others, as many of its advocates are already pushing, one being Professor Baume? For example, he already believes that people with disabilities should also have access to euthanasia. It is a similar point to the one Senator Abetz was making with you. Do you think that in time, with the maturity of this legislation, it should be amended so that other than the terminally ill can access it?
Mr Perron replied:
I think it is too early to make that judgment. Quite clearly, no-one can predict what a democratically elected group of people might do in years to come.
Senator McGauran further asked:
You personally.
Mr Perron replied:

I believe there is a case to expand the legislation to other categories. But, quite clearly, the proposals as put forward in the Northern Territory were limited to a specific group. That leaves unanswered the misery and suffering which we see and that I object to in groups other than the competent terminally ill adult. The first group that comes to mind perhaps is the non‐terminally ill competent adult, the quadriplegic, who might live for 20 or 30 years but be begging their carers—I believe many of them do—daily for release.

It is clear that Marshall Perron, the architect of this legislation in the Northern Territory, does not see the concept of euthanasia and the right to die or the operation of choice as necessarily being limited to only the terminally ill, however that may be defined. Marshall Perron's view was also supported before the committee by a representative of the Northern Territory Voluntary Euthanasia Society.

I can understand and appreciate that a person with an incurable illness and only hours or days to live may wish that their life was ended. They may wish that someone would help them end the pain and the dis tress. But I can also understand that a quadriplegic confined to a wheelchair sees years and years of frustration, anguish and mental torture ahead and has that same desire for release. Unless Marshall Perron's wish to expand the legislation comes true—and, if it does, then we really are down the slippery slope—society and the law currently says and will continue to say that such a person has to accept the pain and suffering, notwithstanding his or her individual wishes or supposed rights.

If the Northern Territory law is, as it says in the preamble, about confirming the rights of the terminally ill, then why is it not also acceptable to those who argue for it that a person who is suffering from a terminal illness but is also diagnosed as suffering from depression to have access to euthanasia or assisted suicide? Why are they excluded if they also have rights? Under the Northern Territory law these persons are excluded. Under the Northern Territory law their inalienable right is not recognised. They have no equivalent freedom of choice to exercise.

It has also been noted that, whilst the Northern Territory Rights of the Terminally Ill Act protects doctors, it does not extend the same privilege to members of the family who may be involved in mercy killing or assisting a person to die. Equally, it does not extend to other health or medical personnel who may assist a person to die.

In my view, the situation that applied prior to the Northern Territory legislation and which continues to apply in every other state and territory in this country, and indeed in just about every other country, is preferable to the position that applies under the Northern Territory Rights of the Terminally Ill Act. The Northern Territory act is, in my view, contrary to the principle of the protection of the right to life under the law. Further, it is inconsistent, ambiguous and discriminatory.

During the debates both in this parliament and in the community a number of other issues have been raised. I cannot, in the time available, deal with them all but I would like to make some comments about some of the more important aspects of this debate. Firstly, it has been argued that the Commonwealth should not override a law of the Northern Territory. I cannot accept this argument. I reject it because this parliament has, particularly in recent years, taken the opportunity on a number of occasions to override the laws of the states. We have protected trees and forests; we have protected lakes and national parks; we have protected the rights of individuals to sexual privacy. I cannot see how we cannot take steps to protect the right to life under the law.

I also point out that this Northern Territory law does impact on the citizens of other parts of Australia as people have travelled to the Northern Territory to have their lives terminated. Further, some proponents of euthanasia clearly wish to see the Northern Territory legislation as the springboard to extend legalised euthanasia to the rest of the country.

Secondly, many have argued that the public supports euthanasia and therefore we should also support it and respect their wishes. The evidence for this is based upon opinion polling. However, on fundamental issues we do not necessarily accept opinion polls as indicative or as a basis for the making of sound law. If that were the case, then we would legislate to reintroduce capital punishment—something that I equally totally oppose. Yet I note that some who strenuously support euthanasia also vehemently oppose capital punishment on the grounds of adherence to the principle of the right to life under the law. I well recall the farcical and degrading debate in the United States in 1977 when Gary Gilmore, a convicted murderer, demanded his so‐called right to be executed.

I also note that, prior to the introduction of Marshall Perron's legislation, there was no public clamouring for euthanasia legislation around Australia or even in the territory. This is a situation where the Northern Territory Chief Minister used his position to propose a law that he personally wished to have implemented. The initial legislation which fundamentally altered the application of the criminal law in the Northern Territory was carried by a narrow margin. Also, there was no public campaign by the medical profession to implement the Northern Territory law. Rather, its operation has been opposed by the bulk of the medical profession.

Thirdly, I believe there is significant confusion and uncertainty on the question of what is meant by a terminal illness. I have personally spoken to doctors who support the Northern Territory act, and I get different definitions. Some define it as when death is imminent—only a matter of days away. Others are prepared to accept a more lengthy period running to months or even years. The Northern Territory act does not define terminal illness with any degree of certainty. It does not specify a period of time within which death would be likely to occur for an illness to be terminal.

These questions are ultimately a matter of the doctor's opinion; of their diagnosis. This is something which is clearly subject to error and wide differences of opinion, both between doctors and potentially between doctors and their patients. What, for instance, happens in a situation where the patient wants to die but the doctor says no, he does not believe the illness is terminal? We should not allow any law, let alone a law as important and as fundamental as the Northern Territory act, to be left in such a state of uncertainty.

Finally, I believe that there is a substantial difference between a situation where death may be hastened by an ongoing process of treatment such as increasing doses of drugs for pain relief, called the double effect, and a situation where a patient is deliberately injected with a lethal drug with the specific and sole intention of causing death. Pain, suffering, illness, distress, anguish will always be with us. They are an inherent part of life. Some will suffer more than others. Many will suffer great pain and distress, physical or mental, during their lives. Some will suffer it greatly in their final days.

We must devote our efforts to alleviating that pain and suffering and distress as much as possible. That is where the focus of our policies and laws should be directed. It should be directed at improving the quality of life for all, including the terminally ill, through palliative care rather than directed towards finding ways of intentionally depriving people of their life. Our duty is to protect life under the law, not end it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon, Sen David

TALK.START.PARA: —Legislation normally appears in this chamber as government legislation. While provision exists for private senators and members to introduce legislation, a practice which is common in the Unites States Senate, it is a very rare event in Australia. The practice here is for the private bill to be introduced, first reading made and second reading incorporated, and then it never surfaces and it never comes into law. That is one of the characteristics of the system of government that we have when so much power resides with the executive government. So we as legislators become habituated to dealing with government legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: As a legislator, when a bill appears in this chamber, I have two concerns in examining it. The first is: what is the aim of the bill; it is a worthy and necessary aim? The second is the drafting of the bill; does the bill provide the definition of the means to achieve the aim simply, accurately and unambiguously?

When we are dealing with the rare event of private legislation there is a second, and really a prior, consideration. That is: are we properly exercising our powers in debating that legislation? In a legal sense, the answer in relation to this particular bill is: yes, the Commonwealth is empowered to override the legislation of the Northern Territory in this instance. But the real question is: can we responsibly and honestly exercise that power? That must be the first question resolved before we debate the content of the bill.

Australia is a federation. This house, the Senate, is the very embodiment of the federal system. When the founders came together to draw up the constitution of Australia, they had three dominant factors. First of all, this is a vast country. The second factor they had to deal with in a democratic system was the fact that the majority of the population lived in Melbourne and Sydney, just as they do today. The third factor was that there that there were six colonies, all independent, all proud of their achievement.

The negotiations that led to the setting up of the federation of the Commonwealth of Australia were protracted. They were not carried out by academic people. They were not carried out by well‐wishers. They were carried out by hard‐headed, practical politicians. And they gave us the constitution that we have today.

There were two key essentials they had to deal with. The first was that four states—the four smaller states—were not going to join with the two populous states and be overrun numerically. The second point they had to deal with was that, in recognition of the vast size of this country, Australia could not be run from either a national capital or from a series of state capitals.

That determined the system that we have today, which is a federal system. It is a system which I have to say is almost totally misunderstood in Australia. And, sadly, a large number of people in this parliament simply do not understand the basis of the federal system under which we are governed.

We hear a lot of comment about the difficulties of the present system of government in Australia—and, undeniably, it is difficult. A federal system is the most complex of all systems of government to operate. We are going to see that tonight at the Premiers' meeting at the Lodge and we will see it tomorrow at the Premiers conference, and that is only one example of the difficulties of running a federation. But it is the best system for Australia.

One of the concepts behind it was that the states wanted to join as free and equal partners. They wanted to put the colonies behind them and become part of the nation of Australia. So we got this federal system, a bicameral system, which consists of two chambers—two chambers with equal powers: the House of Representatives, with equivalent electorate populations; and a Senate, with equivalent representation numerically for each state. That balanced out the fact that we have 50 members in the House of Representatives from New South Wales versus five from Tasmania.

The concept behind the federation was that, on matters of legislation, there would be a majority of voters supporting that legislation coming from a majority of the states. That, of course, is tied up in the provisions of the constitution which relate to constitutional change. Implicit in the spirit of federation and the constitution of Australia is the equality of the individual before the law, and the equality of states. I would like to read clause 99 of the constitution because it says:
The Commonwealth shall not, by any law or regulation of trade, commerce, or revenue, give preference to one State or any part thereof over another State or any part thereof.

What the Andrews bill sets out to do is to take a sectional view with respect to a legislative provision. It applies a certain set of conditions to the territory known as the Northern Territory. To me, that is totally unacceptable.

The previous speaker in this debate said that the Commonwealth often overrode state legislation and, therefore, it was immaterial to have these concerns in relation to this legislation. Section 109 of the constitution provides:
When a law of a State is inconsistent with a law of the Commonwealth, the latter shall prevail, and the former shall, to the extent of the inconsistency, be invalid.

The interpretation of that is that the Commonwealth legislation certainly overrides state legislation if it is in conflict. But the implication is that the Commonwealth legislation applies equally to all the states; it does not apply sectionally.

The correct procedure is for Mr Andrews to withdraw his bill and draft a bill which legislates for the whole of the Commonwealth of Australia. Only then can we properly and responsibly discuss the contents of the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill, Sen David

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Trade and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that no bill has been so agonised over as this bill. I think it has made everyone really sit up or stand up and take a lot of notice of what is going on. The bill has been argued, and the debate has been on many levels. In assessing my views on the matter, I felt it was important to take into account the constitutional, as well as the ethical, dimensions of the bill—and I think Senator MacGibbon covered some of those things a moment ago.

SPEECH.PARA: But in deliberating, I read with great interest the Senate Legal and Constitutional Committee report on the bill, and I congratulate all those committee members and the secretariat involved in the process and the actual report. It is a most comprehensive document. Many things have been said about this bill. But I will not canvass all of the issues that have been canvassed, and I will try to keep my remarks reasonably brief. But I think the most important thing will be the way in which people vote on Monday.

If we look at the constitution, under section 52 the Commonwealth does have the power to intervene. So the question becomes: does it have the right? This becomes a political and constitutional argument. In considering this I looked at arguments put to the committee and elsewhere. I was mindful of comments by people such as Professor Tom Campbell from the Australian National University, who is quoted on page 14. He said:

If the intrusion of the Commonwealth Parliament into this matter is justified by the argument made by the Bill's proposer, namely that this is a matter of fundamental rights, then this introduces a novel constitutional basis for the exercise of Commonwealth power. There is nothing in our Constitution to require that fundamental rights are not equally a responsibility of States and by extension of Territories. The Northern Territory has a responsibility and right to determine for itself the implications of human rights in relation to such specific issues as euthanasia.

Then you ask: is this simply a question of states rights? Clearly, senators from the ACT and the Northern Territory believe so. Clearly, the governments in the ACT and the Northern Territory are adamant. They have all voted unanimously against this bill, even though on the issue of euthanasia they are not unified.
