SPEECH.PARA: The abolition of the Commonwealth dental program has meant that four million concession card holders no longer have access to free dental treatment. Older people with concession cards now have to pay 50c more per prescription but the government has not increased the pharmaceutical allowance to offset this additional cost. Some of these older people may even lose their concession cards altogether as the coalition `rationalises' concession cards, leaving 350,000 people without cards over the next four years.

Another 30,000 senior health card holders will not be able to access free hearing services in another one of the cost-cutting measures of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). Despite its promises, this government will cut its contribution to the home and community care program by $88 million. This will be offset by user fees averaging approximately $6 an hour. Rent assistance is also in the line of fire for single aged pensioners in share accommodation. Older Australians claiming this entitlement could see up to one-third of their rent assistance being lost.

Due to cuts in funding of public hospitals to the tune of $800 million, older people will spend longer trying to access public hospitals. The move towards a user-pays society is becoming more and more entrenched in Australia under this coalition government. What this government chooses to ignore is the inherent lack of social justice in their approach and what the long-term effects of such ignorance will be on Australia. I have to assume that this means that they do not care about older Australians or that they cannot see themselves in power after the next election. These explanations are the only things that can account for bills such as the aged care bill.

The advice to the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) is ill-conceived and dangerous. The long-term implications on the frail and aged is sickening. Basic human rights will covertly be eroded by the introduction of legislation like the aged care bill. If this was not so serious it would seem quite ludicrous.

The government has spent a large proportion of its time to date blaming Labor. They have painted what they know to be an incorrect picture of the situation. They have in the past compared the amount of money spent on older people with the amount of money spent on criminals and theorised endlessly about the injustice of it all but, when forced to come up with decisions about the direction of aged care services, they have pulled off a political charade.

How can the coalition claim to respect or understand the needs of older Australians when they are introducing these cuts that so obviously disadvantage so many older people? The Minister for Family Services has said that the aged care industry is merely looking for leadership, action and, importantly, decisions. The current government, it is true, is making lots of decisions, but these decisions and leadership are not based on respect for the needs of lower and middle income earners.

Mrs Moylan has conceded that Labor's policies were good but, instead of supporting the implementation of such policies and pursuing the path that Labor embarked upon, she has consistently condemned Labor for focusing policy on ideological grounds. Well, I contend that such a focus bases policies on a well-founded belief system that has indeed provided for all Australians. Instead, we have a Liberal government that is obviously served by some long-lost relative of Machiavelli. We only need to quote Machiavelli to see how true his words are with respect to Mr Howard:
Nothing does so much honour to a newly risen leader than the new laws and measures that he introduces.

Increasingly, older people are taking on even more and more responsibilities. With further cuts to child care and the continuing problem of unemployment, many older people are being asked to help cope with offsetting the costs of child care and care for family members who are unemployed. Inherent in the Labor approach is the principle that older people should be able to choose whether they want to take this role on. They should not be forced into a role of adhesive for a community that is falling apart under coalition policies.

The older community of this country also has a strong and very respected commitment to volunteer work. It is work that some older people choose to do to contribute to a community after a lifetime of contribution. But it is not something to be exploited. Again, this is something that they may choose to do. What I am seeing and hearing in my community is that volunteer organisations are being called upon to fill the coalition's funding crisis gaps. Older Australians, like all volunteers, do not and should not be exposed to patching up the social fragmentation of what is occurring in the youth, disabilities, legal, women's, health, housing and aged care sectors because of the economic rationalism of the coalition government.

Constituents are saying to me that they are not confused or ill-informed, that they have tried to access information on the coalition's policies but they are too unclear. There are too many questions unanswered. The time frame for examining the aged care bill was ludicrously short. The limited information that has surfaced gives the community even more cause for concern.

I have heard of a case where someone booked their partner into a nursing home but, as a result of the speculation surrounding the coalition policies, they withdrew their partner's name from the list and decided to care for them at home because they were too frightened they might lose the house they had worked so hard to own. The focus on short‐ term solutions that the coalition is promising leadership and action in is quite antagonistic. Older Australians are attempting to fight these policies. But, like many other constituents I have spoken to, it is pretty difficult to fight what is not tangible or what is shrouded in mystery.

A hostel for the frail aged in Canberra that I visited does an amazing job caring for socially and financially disadvantaged older people. This hostel has reported that the aged care bill will see a pensioner being $10.70 worse off a fortnight. A 17 per cent reduction may not sound like much to someone who is receiving $353.50 a fortnight. But, if the zealots in Treasury would like to subtract 17 per cent from their salary, the dimensions of this injustice may perhaps become more real. If these same bureaucrats were told that this 17 per cent was to be taken out for no reason, I feel sure I know what the response would be—they would not be happy. This type of legislation shows yet again that the coalition government has no commitment to the principles of social justice. This hostel report exemplifies how rural and remote areas will also be affected by the aged care bill alone.

Workers and managers in the aged care industry are consistently reiterating the fact that no additional money is being put into aged care residential services; instead, more people are being told to pay more money. Operators of hostels and nursing homes are being forced into a position of adjudicating on the relative merits of taking individuals into residential care based on how much and how soon they can pay. This is not fair and proves that this government's policies will marginalise older people.

This is just another example that demonstrates, I believe, the ineptitude of the research and advice the minister has received and taken. The minister has developed a penchant for attacking Labor's approach to consultation with the sector and postulating about the need for leadership, action and decisions.

Successive Labor ministers have, however, addressed the issue of aged care, remaining committed to the concept of a fair and equitable system of quality residential care for older Australians. This is the ideological underpinning that the current minister has swept aside in the government's bid to economically rationalise aged care in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson, Sen Kay

TALK.START.PARA: —I have taken the unusual step of seeking to remove myself from the chair in this debate in order to respond to Senator Lundy's contribution. While in the chair, I had to restrain myself from not indicating my displeasure with what she was saying. I would not normally have done what I am doing tonight. But it is late at night, these proceedings of the parliament are being broadcast and it is most likely that the majority of people who have tuned in to the national network—if anybody is—to listen to the debate on the euthanasia bill will be older people. Therefore, I felt it necessary to get up and counter the argument that Senator Lundy put.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Lundy in her speech said that she knew a couple where one person was eligible to go into a nursing home but the choice was made that they would not because of the speculation regarding the changes that were to occur in the aged care bill. She said that they were afraid to go in into a nursing home because they were frightened that they would lose their house.

There is no truth in that—that is, the fact that they would lose their house. They might have been frightened—and why would they be frightened? Because Jenny Macklin, the shadow minister for aged care, has been going around this country spreading what are nothing short of scandalous and outrageous claims about what is going to happen as a result of that aged care bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not so.
—Senator Lundy, I had to listen to you in silence because I was in the chair. I had to restrain myself. I now ask you to be so restrained—and I ask through you, Mr Acting Deputy President.

SPEECH.PARA: But there is nothing in that. It is so far from the truth. I would ask Senator Lundy to come to my office where I will go through it with her. I have to say that I can stand here and say there is no-one else in this parliament—and I cannot say this about many things— who has taken greater interest in issues affecting older people than I have. I think I can say that without any fear of argument from anyone else. I have persistently pursued issues affecting older people since I came in here.

When Labor was in government, they neglected the issue of what was happening to nursing homes for years and years. They neglected a report by Professor Gregory, a report that they had commissioned, where he said that $520 million was needed to bring nursing homes up to current, acceptable standards. He identified the fact that a significant proportion of nursing homes had residents in four- and six-bed wards, sharing bathrooms with even more people.

The best nursing homes in Australia are better than anywhere else in the world. I can say that because I have visited nursing homes in England; I have visited nursing homes in France as a guest of the French government, where they took me to what they identified as their best; and I have visited nursing homes in America. We have nursing homes that would stand up to any of those, nursing homes that are better or as good as they are.

We have, however, many that do not reach those standards. We have to put money into them. We have a limited pool of resources. Tonight we have heard in the debate on euthanasia of the need for more money to be spent on palliative care. There is only so much money in the bucket. There is only so much the taxpayer of Australia can tolerate. There is only so much that those who invest capital in Australia will tolerate before taking their capital offshore. So we have to do with the limited pool we have.

Labor realised that when they introduced the need to pay an `ingoing' or, what we now call, an accommodation bond to hostels. The world did not fall in when that happened, the world did not come apart. People were not discriminated against. Appropriate measures were put in place to ensure that people who had limited means or no means were able to access hostels. And we did not find the situation where those who had paid an ingoing were getting cream on their two‐fruit for dessert, and the ones who had not paid an ingoing were not getting cream on their dessert. That did not happen.

The most bizarre thing of all was that, when you had a nursing home and a hostel in the same complex run by the same organisation, and sometimes the hostel was across the corridor from the nursing home, and a resident became so frail that they had to move across the corridor, the institution—the Anglicans or the Catholics, whoever they were—had to pay the ingoing back to the resident. I cannot understand the logic of that, nor could anybody else—why, if they had paid an ingoing to a hostel, it was not appropriate for them to pay an ingoing to a nursing home.

We have an ageing baby boom population. Senator Lundy and Senator Stott Despoja—Senator Stott Despoja gets up here and talks about young people all the time as if none of us have ever been young: I keep saying that I represent the old without having been old and I can also represent the young, but Senator Stott Despoja thinks she has a monopoly on the young—being young people, ought to be looking for every possible opportunity to provide facilities for older people.

In the next 25 years we will need about 2½ times the number of aged care facilities in Australia that we currently have. That is given the current demand on nursing homes. I believe there will be an increase in demand for nursing homes because people who are currently in nursing homes and hostels usually have been in a monogamous married relationship for their whole life, where their children have a sense of joint responsibility for their parents.

But as the baby boom comes through, with the bizarre life that many of the baby boomers have lived, their children will have divided loyalties. Why on earth would many of them want to care in their own home for a parent and a step‐parent with whom they have never lived? There will be increasing demands on residential care because there will not be the same commitment to both parents by children or there will be divided loyalties. I will not go into all the permutations and combinations of families.

Given our current needs, we would need about 2½ times the facilities. But my expecta tion is that we will need more because we will have more women working and therefore we will not have as many carers. We will also have divided loyalties within families. We have to find a way of ensuring that not only do we upgrade nursing homes currently but we actually provide capital for the future. There was no way of providing capital under Labor.

Why is there a difference between hostels and nursing homes? One of the reasons there is a difference between hostels and nursing homes is that there is an ingoing required in hostels so they have the money to actually make the capital improvements. What we have tried to do is come up with a solution based on what Labor had done. If Senator Lundy really cared about older people, she would be saying, `Here is the proposition. That is what we did in government with hostels. How can we extend it to nursing homes? Let's make sure it is right.' I am not saying that there may not be some small changes that need to be made. We do not have the truth. There may be some small changes that need to be made but we have to find a way of upgrading nursing homes now and increasing the capital stock.

Let me reiterate and remind anybody who may have been listening to Senator Lundy that nobody will be required to sell their home. They may have to rent it to find the money. What happens is that people who have adequate means, and that will be assessed on the basis of their income and assets, will not pay—I have to do this from memory—anything for the first $49 they have over and above the pension per week. Over and above that they will pay 25c up to $60 a day. What that will do will mean that we will have assets. But people could choose to do that by renting their home.

If they have a spouse or a long-term carer or a dependent child or a dependent carer or dependent child who is disabled they will not have to sell their home or rent their home. If they are in the nursing home for less than six months they will not have to pay an ingoing or an accommodation bond, as it is now called. If they are there for longer than six months they will be required to pay an ac commodation bond or interest on an accommodation bond. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy, Sen Shayne

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel I have to make some contribution on the adjournment with regard to some of the matters that Senator Patterson raised in response to Senator Lundy. I appreciate the fact that you have gone back to the chair, as I came to the chair to allow you to make your contribution.
—It is like a two-man band, Senator Murphy.

—It seems like we are the only acting deputy presidents left in the house. With regard to the draft aged care legislation that the government has brought forward and some of the points that Senator Lundy made—and I did not hear all the points—there is a degree of concern amongst the aged people of Australia about what is proposed in the legislation. I was interested to hear the comments—and I will be interested to hear further comments—you made in particular about people not having to sell their home.

SPEECH.PARA: It is my understanding of the proposed legislation that, if you are a full pensioner, you are seeking to enter a nursing home, you wish to retain the full pension and you have a home that you own—and I think somewhere in the order of 65 or 70 cent of Australians aged over 65 actually own their own home—you would have to sell your home to enter the nursing home, that is if you wish to retain the full pension. I think that is very clear in the draft legislation.

What concerns me and I think a lot of aged Australians is: how do you actually determine the best time to sell your home? There is another issue relating to the home. Say you have a relative or a carer who has lived in the home with you for an extended period of time—I think five years is the minimum. The home is not then considered an asset for the purposes of assessment. I think that is also a problem. Why should five years be the minimum?

BREAK.PARA: How do you deal with people who may have suddenly, in the last two years, required assistance and may have a relative or carer who, according to the draft legislation, essentially has to be a recipient of some form of benefit. Who determines that they have minimal income? What is minimal income? I have been able to find out from the minister's office that someone considered to be on minimal income is someone who is on a benefit. I do not accept that. There would be many aged people in Australia who would prefer to live in their own homes and who may have a family member with a full-time job who assists them of a morning and evening. They may be the only times those aged people require care.

I think there is a whole host of problems associated with your draft legislation. I think there will be some significant changes required. I have a view that the legislation as it stands will force nursing homes and hostels—as far as I know, some nursing homes already do have an entry fee, but I stand to be corrected about that point; nevertheless, they will under this legislation if it is carried—to seek out people who have the financial wherewithal or have a home of a certain value.

The intent of this legislation is to provide the capital funding, as you said, to enable nursing homes and/or hostels to redevelop or continue to develop and meet the requirements. I think it was Macgregor who said in the report that nursing homes needed an injection of somewhere around $520 million or $550 million of capital funding to bring a lot of them up to scratch. I found that a little bit interesting, given the government decision to provide funding to a nursing home in Launceston that did not even meet the standards in a report of the department. Your government took a decision to provide funding to that nursing home while other nursing homes in the area had to make the standards to get their funding. I think that is another issue you will have to deal with.

A lot of organisations, including Aged Care Australia, have a different view. Aged Care Australia seek out the granny bond, which would be government underwritten. Their view of the world is that you give the money to the government and somehow the government provides funds from a pool. I am not quite sure how it works on a state by state basis or who sits in judgment. I think that could have some political difficulties in relation to how you actually dish the money out.

What about areas in regional Australia in which home prices are low? As Senator Calvert would know, in his area of Tasmania, down around Geeveston and Huonville there are a huge number of homes on the market. How would nursing homes in those areas seek out the necessary funding they might need, if you are talking about people having to sell their homes?

I am a bit curious at the end of the day as to how you are going to raise all this capital if people do not have to sell their homes. If they keep them, they will have that assessed in terms of income for the purposes of determining how much pension they get.

Then there is the issue of daily and/or weekly fees. I was interested to note the maximum daily fee. From memory, from what I have read of it so far, if you do not do certain things in terms of providing information for the assessment of your income and your worth, you will pay the maximum fee, which is $60 a day. That is $420 a week. I imagine there would be very few people who would have the capacity to pay that sort of money.

In addition to that, I was very interested to look at how the government was going to change the application of paying rent assistance to pensioners. They were going to pay it directly to the nursing home. I think there was a $49 threshold. You could earn $49 as a single pensioner before you started to be assessed. They plan to somehow take $37 a week off people and give it directly to the provider. I find that an interesting situation.

Even when people have paid an entry bond, an accommodation bond, a six‐month period must elapse before the provider can commence drawing down the money. They can draw up to a maximum of $13,000 over a five-year period and also the interest on the money, whatever the money is. If it is $100,000, they can draw down $13,000 over five years after six months plus interest. I assume that is the interest from day one. After five years they can take no more money, but what about the ongoing interest for people who remain in the nursing home for longer than five years? I would be curious to hear what happens to that.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are not too many there after five years.

—Senator Calvert, you are probably right because I think the average is about 15 months. That is true, but there would be a number. There are a lot of issues that the government has yet to clear up in regard to this legislation. Madam Acting Deputy President Patterson—and I thank you for your indulgence—I hope that you will continue to pursue, as you say, the interests of aged Australians and ensure that some of these very important questions are answered.

BREAK.PARA: Friday, 21 March 1997

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Trade and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, upon notice, on 7 February 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Why is it that federal funding for the Commonwealth's vocational education and training (VET) programme in 1997 in Victoria results in students in private schools being funded, on average at around $1 700 per student whereas students in Catholic schools are funded at $433 and in State schools $300, as shown in the table below.
(2) How were the allocations calculated and on what basis.
(3) What are the comparative figures for each of the other Australian States and Territories.
(4) On what basis were VET programs funded in previous years and what was the per capita allocation, by sector.
(5) Do State governments supplement this program; if so, please supply details.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

BREAK.PARA: (1) & (2) The Australian National Training Authority Ministerial Council agreed that, over four calendar years, $80 million of VET funds be provided to support the expansion of VET in schools. The proposal was endorsed by the Ministerial Council on Education, Employment, Training and Youth Affairs (MCEETYA) in July 1996.
The allocation by State and Territory was calculated on the cohort of 15—19 year olds and endorsed by the MCEETYA Task Force on VET in Schools.

Funds were then allocated to each school sector within each State and Territory on the basis of the total student population in Years 11 and 12 (1994 National Report on Schooling in Australia— Statistical Annex). These allocations were included in the Principles and Guidelines For Improving Outcomes for Vocational Education and Training (VET) in Schools that were agreed by representatives of the Commonwealth, the Australian National Training Authority, the State and Territory school and VET sectors, and the non‐government school sectors at a tele‐conference on 29 November 1996.

The purpose of the $80 million is to complement VET in school funds already spent by education authorities and to support a demonstrated expansion of activity in all school sectors. Senator Allison's calculation appears to be derived from a simple division of the funds allocated for expansion by the number of students currently undertaking VET in schools in the three sectors.

Comparative figures for the States/Territories and sectors within the States/Territories are set out in the Table below. Allocations between sectors within each State/Territory may be varied by agreement between the sectors. Future allocations are subject to review.

ROW.ENTRY: Distribution by sector based on % of Year 11 and 12 students 1994 data
Allocation based on 15‐19 year old cohort $

BREAK.PARA: (4) The Commonwealth has not previously allocated specific funding to the States and Territories for VET in schools.

(5) The Commonwealth does not have data in relation to the level of support providedby the States and Territories. However, I am aware that Victoria released a Policy Statement in 1996 in which it is stated that Victoria will be allocating $10 million over the next four years as a Budget initiative to support vocational education and training schools.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 12 February 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the $7.4 million allocated in the 1996‐97 Federal Budget over the next 3 years for the establishment of clinics to run trials of alternative management of acute lower back pain:
(1) How many applications have been received for funds under the program.
(2) How many applications were successful and what are the details of those successful applications.
(3) What selection criteria were used to assess the applications.
(4) Who was responsible for the final approval of successful applications.
(5) Are successful applicants required to follow any particular research protocols or guidelines and will they be subject to ongoing clinical or other supervision.
(6) What reporting requirements are successful applicants expected to observe.
(7) Were any applications received from chiropractors; if so, were any of these applications successful.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health and Family Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1)‐(4) Applications were not called for.

The initiative announced in the Budget was based on a proposal which had already been comprehensively developed by the Faculty of Musculoskeletal Medicine. Moreover, the initiative is very specifically aimed at trialing an evidence based approach to medical treatment for acute and sub‐acute regional pain syndromes such as those affecting the neck, back, shoulder and arm. A Steering Committee has been set up to oversee the initiative and is currently examining the methodology and scope of the proposal and the treatment protocols that will be trialed. It will also agree on a process for selecting any additional trial sites that may be required to complement the hospital clinics that have been proposed by the Faculty.

Nine unsolicited expressions of interest were received following the Budget announcement of the $7.2 million funding for the establishment of musculoskeletal medicine clinics. These were referred to the Steering Committee which considered that they were all outside the scope of the project.
(5) Yes. Protocols are to be developed and the project will be overseen by the Steering Committee.
(6) Reporting requirements are also under consideration by the Steering Committee.

(7) One expression of interest was received from an existing chiropractic clinic but was not accepted by the Steering Committee. The initiative will involve General Practice control groups. These may include chiropractic services to the extent that they are part of their "usual practice", but the project clinics will not be trialing chiropractic treatment.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy—

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can details be provided of the date and nature of any contact the Minister, his office or the department have had with Mr Chris Graham of Nimmitable or his family in relation to illegal logging and woodchipping on his land early in 1994.

(2)(a) What information has been provided to the department by Mr Graham about this illegal woodchipping; and (b) what action has been taken in response (please list the nature of the action, when the action was taken and the outcome).

(3) (a) What has the Woodchip Export Monitoring Unit (WEMU) done to investigate the illegal woodchipping of Mr Graham's land; and (b) what action has WEM taken against the companies involved for breach of woodchip export licence conditions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Indus following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Graham wrote to the former Labor Minister for Resources, the Hon David Beddall MP (apparently copied to the former Labor Minister for the Environment, Sen the Hon John Faulkner) in January 1995, claiming Harris-Daishowa (Australia) Pty Ltd (HDA) contractors logged his property without consent. The matter was not referred to the Woodchip Export Monitoring Unit (which did not begin operations until 1996). The former Minister did not seek to progress a prosecution against HDA, or take any action to suspend or revoke the export licence under the Export Control (Unprocessed Wood) Regulations.

Mr Chris Graham contacted the Department of Primary Industries and Energy (DPIE) in early May 1996. He stated HDA contractors logged his property without his permission in 1994. On 13 May 1996, an officer of DPIE informed Mr Graham that no action was undertaken to prosecute HDA, or suspend or revoke the licence in relation to the claims of harvesting on his property. Mr Graham sought copies of any correspondence between HDA and the former Minister. In response to this request, Mr Graham was informed that access to such documents was more appropriately sought under Freedom of Information procedures.
